Definition: In this task, you will be given an Amazon review and you have tell whether it is a positive review or negative review.

Positive Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Positive Examples.explanation: This rating is based on this review provided by the user as he liked the product very much and he was surprised that product is so good

Positive Examples.input: Bought cables in 3ft, 6ft and 9ft.  NONE of them worked.  NO FUNCTIONALITY WHATSOEVER.  Tested many times, its as if the copper wires are just not connected to the terminations.  Do these even go through Quality Control before they leave the factory?  Waste of money and time.
Positive Examples.explanation: User did not like cables at all and found all of them useless so it is a negative review.

Negative Examples.input: I was very surprised at the high quality of the stitching, the sturdiness of the handles and the padding for my laptop. The price is amazingly low and the look is very good. I am quite happy with this purchase. It fit my MacBook Pro perfectly, with a little bit of room to spare.
Negative Examples.explanation: User likes the product very much still rating provided is not according to his review. There is incorrect relation between review and rating given.

Negative Examples.input: Bought cables in 3ft, 6ft and 9ft.  NONE of them worked.  NO FUNCTIONALITY WHATSOEVER.  Tested many times, its as if the copper wires are just not connected to the terminations.  Do these even go through Quality Control before they leave the factory?  Waste of money and time.
Negative Examples.explanation: User feels the product is useless  and he tested it many times but it does not work so it should not be positive review here.

Instances.input: The letters aren't see through so it can't be used at night efficiently. I do like the color it has.

I picked up the Sharkoon Skiller keyboard at a price point at or under $30, and at the same time I made my purchase, Logitech's G-series keyboards (with and without the LCD screen) don't have a single offering available under $100.

While I can understand the desire and benefit one might have if they were using both Logitech G-series mice and a G-series keyboard together (thanks to that allowing for a singular app to control and modify settings, macros, etc.), I can now say that such perks do not come anywhere close to justifying the $70+ price difference. Not in my book. Plus, the Skiller offers more customization profiles and keys, period.

My only complaint about the Skiller is a token one, as mine arrived with several of the special optional rubberized keys (for A/S/D/W and the arrow keys) crushed and unusable due to shipping conditions. However, after e-mailing Sharkoon directly about the issue, a full set of replacements arrived almost immediately thereafter in the mail, free of charge.

Honestly, I've take more than a few spins with $100+ keyboards in my time, including the Logitech K800 (more of a high-quality/luxury keyboard than gaming-specific) and mechanical G-series offerings. And while those keyboards are indeed quite nice, that price tag they carry is more than a little bloated......Sharkoon Skiller on the other hand ihas been very modestly priced, so much so that I hope that Logitech and other manufacturers take note of how much functionality has been packed in at this price point (the only thing it is missing is wireless operation).

Definitely recommended for anyone seeking a programmable keyboard, one with extensive pre-set media/computer controls (i.e., volume up/down, Play/Pause/Previous/Next, and even internet controls like Forward/Back/Refresh), and/or anyone looking for a premium keyboard priced like a discount one.

Griffin is really swinging for the fences asking $99 for this thing... It's not that it doesn't do what they claim, it does. It's just that once you get the thing it's obvious that you've overpaid. It's more or less one of those little things you have on your desk to hold the mail with a few USB ports and an ac adaptor. There is nothing stunning about the technology or design and the plastic is light weight to the point were I am worried about breaking it. The worst part is realizing that now that I've coughed up darn near a Benjamin on this thing I now need to go buy the 5 lighting cables required to transfer the juice... Anyone that has goofed around with those things knows that you can't buy one for less the $20 if you want it to last longer then about a week. Another problem is that for this thing to really serve it's purpose (for me this was to reduce cable clutter and save space on my desk) it really needs lightning cables that are around maybe 6 inches or less, which as far as I can tell don't exist. As it is now, once you get all five 1 meter cables plugged in you are really just back where you started, a rats nest of wires. Giffin needs to either cut the price by at least half or include the right sized cables as part of the package, maybe even both.

I'm usually pretty forgiving on my reviews but this product left me feeling beat like a garage sale sofa. This one is a no go.

Update - Griffin did stand behind their product and allowed me a return with full refund minus return shipping.
It works, however it was not the source of my problem.  My computer still died.n  I am not dis-satisfied.  Thanks.

It has the standard blue looking plug, but 9-11 MB/s is not USB 3.0. I bought 4 of these on a great deal, and apparently will be using them as IMAGE drives for installing OS's and such. Nothing where I use daily and like fast writes. What a shame.

** Updated **
To make matters worse, apparently these awful flash drives are working exactly as designed. Patriot has designed these to be at the exact bottom of USB 3.0 specs. Here's their take on my complaints:

Dear William,
Those write speeds are within with our testing in-house. The Blitz is a competitively priced drive that offers increased capacities and is primarily for storage.
Patriot Memory Technical Support

Got from Costco, ZT systems, 8GB DDR3 at ~799 + CA tax and recycle fee; at the time DDR3 RAM modules for 4X2 GB were $800; thus the system was equiv. getting the system hardware for free, or RAM modules for free if purchased the system case and AMD Quad. Not to get into the weeds, be sure and get the 8GB of DDR3 RAM if you buy this system; seen them with 8GB but they were DDR2, and that is not as fast as DDR3 which is usually the RAM on video boards rather than system RAM. Price out the DDR3 RAM modules and see the Price you get if you buy the DDR3 as part of the Desktop system. Don't add the DDR3 into the machine post purchase,

DDR3 RAM is very expensive in 2010; DDR2 is relatively cheap. 64-bit OS allows one to exceed the 4GB barrier to your Operating system and thus your machine. Get Win 7 pro and it will allow an overlay of 32-bit Operating system if you need the 32-bit applications like Outlook 2003 that may have an entire lifetime of addresses and contacts. Personally purchased the Office 2010 to get tHe outlook 2010 and it utilizes the PST file of previous outlook versions directly.

This stylus works superbly with the Kindle Fire HD!

The fibermesh tip takes the BoxWeave stylus to a whole different level! Far superior responsiveness than a rubber tip stylus. Also more durable, without the rapid decay in firmness of the rubber tips. I was getting tendonitis from having to press the stylus so hard! Luckily, my cat stole the first two types of stylus I purchased, both rubber tipped.

This stylus also comes with multiple attachment choices. I use the coiled spring that plugs into the headphone jack on one end. Using a standard jewelry \\"lobster claw\\" fastener on the end of the stylus to quickly detach and re-attach was pure genius. Having the stylus attached to the tablet on one end also solves my worry of accidentally scratching the tablet with the wrong end.

The clip on the stylus is a bit tight when trying to clip to the folding leather Kindle Fire case [[ASIN:B00825BZUY Amazon Kindle Fire HD 8.9\\" Standing Leather Case, Onyx Black (will only fit Kindle Fire HD 8.9\\")]], but since the jack is pretty secure, I'm not worried about losing the stylus.

Reviews here said you couldn't dock it, but I saw others that said you could, so figured I'd try anyway, since for under $10 it's nearly free... And of course you can't dock it, and as another reviewer pointed out, there's a large hole in the center of the back over the apple. Not sure if it's their attempt to at least leave something open to help prevent overheating or what...
Granted, it is less slippery than the iPad with no case, but hardly what i'd expect when I hear \\"silicone\\". Fit is outstanding though, things line up way better than the overpriced Apple case that I have (and really dislike). Since this was so cheap, I'm going to use a scissors and give myself enough room in the back to dock this, since with the curved back, that will still leave the parts that touch something when set down protected...
Power button does not have a cutout, it's covered but still responsive, and the silicone case has a raised rectangular feel there so you can still sense it in the dark. Cutout for speakers, dock, earphone jack, and rotation lock. Volume is like the power button, not cut out, but has a raised feel there. Up works fine, but the down can be a bit tricky sometimes. Raised edge protects it if you set it face down on a flat surface too, keeps the screen from coming in contact.
The slightly grippier feel doesn't impact it from sliding in and out of my macbook pro bag either.

For the price, great product, fits extremely well, does not move around or feel loose at all. But if it could've been docked without cutting, it would've earned 5 stars...

This Kindle was purchased for a person in her 90s with disabilities. The reader has the use of the right side of her body only. She is a avid reader.
The PagePress page forward & page back control works extremely well for her. The haptic feedback also works well. We set PagePress at minimum (most sensitive) and feedback at maximum (most feedback). She is able to tell immediately when she has advanced multiple pages and can quickly page back.
The light level, text contrast and automatic adaptive light level work extremely well for her. The adaptive font size works extremely well for her. There is some inconsistency in font size and publisher selected font style between books. This requires assistance from her care giver when a new book is selected. There is also an info page that appears when opening a new book. This is annoying. I like the feature, but would prefer that it could be controlled and turned off in settings.
I have an iPad with the Kindle app. This reader is unable to control the Kindle app features. The iPad is usable but requires much more care giver assistance than the Kindle Voyage. I tried the Nook app on an iPad with no better success. The iPad apps were barely usable. We tried using a laptop with eReader apps. The laptop required too much keystroke & mouse action. We were continuously trying to re-open the app and recover the book. The laptop apps were vetoed by the caregivers. We tried a Nook tablet. The Nook requires additional keystrokes plus knowledge of where the appropriate key is, where to press and where to swipe. The Kindle Voyage is by far easier to use and easier on the caregiver.
We purchased the Kindle Unlimited service. This service includes many authors that I have never read and never heard of. On the other hand, it is a surprise what a 90 year old finds interesting. It is easy for a caregiver to download a selection of ebooks and use the Goodreads to keep track of completed books.We have access to two large metro area library system that includes a large ebook catalog (Phoenix & Detroit). This is useless. There are a limited number of copies of each ebook. The reader has favorite authors. The library indeed has ebooks by these authors. They are typically checked out. An avid reader might queue and wait. A caregiver has less patience for this nonsense.

The senior living facility warned us that electronic items disappear, if unattended. We purchased a CTA anti-theft stand (PAD-UATGS). This device has a key lock and bike cable. We attached the Kindle to her work table. The stand is very nice, the cable has adequate length. You could purchase a bike anti-theft cable as an extension. HOWEVER, the Kindle Voyager does not fit this stand - contrary to the CTA product claim and the video that some fellow included on the Amazon page for this product. I created a wooden frame using a hobby oak wood strip (0.25"x1.5"x48") from Home Depot. The frame is essentially a picture frame that captures the Kindle and in turn is captured by the CTA stand. Cost $7.50 and 2 hours labor, including design time and sanding. Home Depot offers oak, alder & linden strips The frame looks very nice in oak. Note: Oak wood dust is a skin, eye and lung irritant. Alder wood dust is also. Sand in a well ventilated area.
Amazon Kindle or CTA could easily create a product to secure the Voyage and smaller tablets to a stand. HINT.

Spent most of the summer toying with the idea to buy a netbook, and finally pulled the trigger a month ago. I wanted something that I could use for my personal studies and research and that was less bulky than my 15\\" Dell Laptop that I use for work. I purchased the ASUS 1005HA with the 10.5 hour battery life. I have been extremely pleased. It worked right out of the box and I was using it within minutes. I tug it around for all my personal stuff and it is light, easy to carry (CaseLogic Bag) and I really do get 10 hours plus use of the battery. My biggest concern was how I would handle a smaller keyboard. For regular typing, the keyboard has worked well. Navigating with the arrow keys and the Fn function key took some time to get used to. I'm 50+ years old, so the screen size was also a concern, but it is adequate for the type of things I use it for. I have had a freeze up twice where the mouse and keyboard stop responding.  Just keeping things real, but I love my ASUS!!!

My router does not support WPS (or I can't figure out how to reconfigure the settings for it), so this device is useful for connecting WPS push button devices like my D-Link camera on a WPA2 network.
The device needs to be connected to your local network via a D-Link log in page. This was not the most difficult things to do, but I could see it being confusing for those unaccustomed to working with basic network settings.
Ideally I should have just purchased a better camera. I have no need for the usb settings, and I never got my head around the hotel Wi-Fi selling point.
I can't give a thumbs up or thumbs down, as one's desired use for this device may be different than mine.

At first I loved the case. The finish was matte and the color was just as seen in the picture (purple case). After a few days I did notice it got kind of dirty, but I didn't mind because I figured it would come off with glass cleaner or even a little bit of alcohol. The dust was of course easy to clean off, but there were some marks that seemed more permanent and some didn't come off at all. I don't know what it was, it almost looked like grease because the surface looked smoother in that area than the matte finish....but I'm not sure because I tried to keep it off any sort of food and usually just left the computer on my bed.

Anyway, that didn't bother me TOO much because I figured it didn't look terrible as long as I kept it clean from dust. What really bothered me though was that my MacBook, which is what the case is supposedly designed to protect, still was getting dust from underneath the case!!! I took it off and my MacBook had more dirt piled up than if I hadn't put on the case at all.

Also, the case cracked around the hinges and on some corners where it's supposed to click around the edges. It didn't even last a month before that happened...I would have rated it better if it had broken but still kept my laptop clean. But it did neither so I wouldn't buy it again or recommend it!

I work as a news reporter, which means I typee counttles words every day, and I've never had a keyboard that gave me this much off a problem. I constanttly have to go back and fix \\"ttypos\\" (which I purposely am NOT doing here). Iff yure going to be using this keyboard for simpple web surfing, it will probably not botther yyou too much. Butt iff you pplan on tying documents, I recommend going with a different keyboard.

Another problem: the pop-uup bracket that holds your tablett uppright, tends to stick, forcing the user to shake the keyboard upside down whilee pressing the relese button just to get it to extend.

On the bright side, the keeyboard is nice to look at and extremely lightweight.

But it fails pretty badly att it's main responsibility --as you cn probably tell by the misppellings in this review.

******UPDATE 12/21/13*********
Anker customer service sent me a replacement keyboard shortly after I posted the original review.

Sadly, the second keyboard works just as poorly. And while customer service agent \\"Sunnie\\" promised to send me a postage paid return envelope for both keyboards AND refund my $39,99, NEITHER has happened. Very disappointing experience. The two keyboards are now collecting dust waiting to be returned. I've downgraded my review from 2-stars to 1-star.

I'll post another update if Anker ever gets around to refunding my money.

FYI: I bought a refurbished Logitech keyboard for $20 and it works like a dream! I used it to type this updated review.

*********UPDATE 12/25/13******
After another email to customer service and the poor review here, Anker finally got around to sending me the prepaid mailer and refunding my account. I have now adjusted my review back up to 2-stars. But again, be forewarned: the two keyboard I received are NOT meant for any kind of extended typing, If you're using it to type in email addresses or really short emails, you can get by. But anything over a couple sentences and you WILL be frustrated. Happy Holidays!

I've considered myself a bit of a webcam snob. Glass lenses only, stuck with name brands, upgrade them every year or two. But I do buy on sale so I often have one below the \\"best\\". This time I ended up with a Webcam C510.

At first I thought that since the lense wasn't glass that the picture probably wouldn't be as good as the Logitech c905 that I currently have. But, the C510 has a much better picture. I guess the sensor and processing improvements mean more than the lense, at least in webcams.

This webcam is better in low light, has a sharper picture in normal light, and it folds up nice an neat without needing a case.

I also like the way it attaches to my desktop better than the C905. It's not perfect, but I didn't like that I needed a dumb stand to use the C905 with my desktop. Unfortunately, the C510 likes a thicker screen, so it doesn't attach as well to laptops. It will often stay, but if the laptop is bumped it may fall. You can fold the camera so that it is its own stand and that works well even if it won't stick on the screen. I guess the clip is the one thing I would change.

So I like the webcam a lot and it works well. I'd definately suggest it.

I plan on picking up the backplate for my card, which is supposed to help by 3C or so when air cooling.

The only drawback to the card itself was the red LED that comes on when using LN2, the overclockable bios. This will probably be remedied by the backplate.

After I wrote the review below, MoKo shipped me a replacement unit. The replacement top looked the same, but there were minor changes in the molding of the bottom cover. The rubber feet I was complaining about falling off look identical.  But you know what? They fixed it! I don't know what they did, but I've have the replacement for a few months now, and the feet are exactly where they should be. I've had no problems whatsoever with the case.   It's a minor fingerprint magnet, but not really, and I'm a lot less worried about carrying my MacBook about.   Old review: -------   I bought this because I was happy with my last MoKo purchase, and because it was the cheapest case on offer.  Shipped in a padded envelope, the two halves were shrinkwrapped together with a second layer on shrinkwrap on the top half, and a chunk of plastic in the middle to separate the two halves. There was a little thin plastic fluff on the feet that wiped off easily.  There are no instructions, but it's easy to figure out. Installation is trivial.  The case is well made, and should do the job. The smoke finish looks good on the space grey finish. It doesn't look like it will fall off. The plastics have a sort of "soft touch" matte finish.  Edit: removed two stars. The rubber feet are not well attached. So far, I've been lucky enough to find them and stick them back on, but eventually, I'll be missing feet. I find this very annoying. I don't know if the other cases are better at retaining their feet, but I'll probably find out once this one starts losing feet for real.

I love the high quality, vintage look of this backpack, in a world full of cheap nylon backpacks with plastic zippers that don't last even a year. I appreciate the extra attention to details like stitching and hardware, and the high quality of the leather. I had planned to give this backpack to my college-age daughter, but after seeing it I decided it's more my style and I look forward to using it for trips to the library.

Some of the high quality features on this backpack:

- real leather on the front straps, handle and top flap (that leather smells great, too!)
- heavy canvas/denim on the body
- padded, adjustable shoulder straps
- heavy-duty metal hardware on back straps and front closure
- strong metal zipper to close the main compartment
- well sewn, thick nylon lining inside
- padded inner pocket for laptop (with elastic strap closure to keep it safely in place)
- two small inner pockets for cell phone, calculator, keys, etc
- big outside pocket (under the leather flap)
- top handle for hand carrying
- magnetic snaps on front straps (straps are decorative only)
- large enough for all your daily items (roughly 17"H x 14" W x 4" depth, varies with expansion and contents)
- comes in gray, rose and dark blue (I got a gray one)

I received a complimentary Vochic backpack for testing and review purposes. I wasn't asked to leave a positive review, nor was I otherwise compensated. My honest opinion is that this Vochic unisex backpack is a five star item.

The Case Logic IFOL-202 is the third iPad case/cover that I've had a chance to review. It also earns third place in my list. I've also had a chance to try Apple's Smart Cover and the [[ASIN:B004N62I0C Targus VuScape Protective Cover/Stand for Apple iPad 2 - 16GB, 32GB, 64GB, WiFi and WiFi + 3G  THZ044US (Black/Blue Interior)]].    The iPad is a slim, elegant tablet and I expect a case or cover that will complement it. The IFOL-202 is none of those things. For starters it's big and bulky. There's no clasp or elastic to keep the cover closed so it's usually flapping around unless you keep your fingers on it.    The outside of the case if made of a rough nylon material. Tough most certainly, but out of place on an iPad. There are really two parts to this case. A small inner sleeve that the iPad fits into that then attaches with velcro to the exterior shell. This makes it possible to use the case as a stand in both portrait and landscape mode. But lifting and reposition the iPad is a pain and and not nearly as elegant as the [[ASIN:B004N62HZI Targus Versavu 360 Degrees Rotating Stand Case for Apple iPad 2 2nd Generation Wifi / 3G Model 16GB, 32GB, 64GB THZ045US NEWEST MODEL (Black/Blue Interior)]]. To close the case you need to make sure the iPad is attached in landscape mode    The sleeve and case are not designed to fit \\"like a glove\\" and the fit overall is okbut not spectacular. The inner iPad sleeve isn't quite snug and the part that overlaps the iPad by about 1/2\\" doesn't always sit snugly against the surface. There's a large cutout on the back for the camera but the speaker on the back is partially covered and no accomodations were made for it.

I purchased wi-fi antenna for a friend after researching many products and reading a lot of reviews. I was sure it would increase the laptop's wifi reception for nearby signals, but I was truly amazed at the amount of additional and distant signals it pick up and moreover at the quality of strength in reception. A 99% pick-up from a medium distanced signal was able to transmit at 150Mbs and streamed a full length Netflix movie without effort or issue!   As the costs continue to decrease and the quality continues to increase, this is even a viable alternative for adding older, addition traditional PCs in the house to the network versus running cat5 line.  A definite, versatile recommendation.  It should be noted, I think, though I purchased through Amazon, the seller and shipper was dbrorth and while I was not able to track the order and package as thoroughly as my normal Amazon purchases it didn't matter - it arrived a mere 3 days after the online purchase. Kudos!

After reading the earlier reviews at this website, we decided to experiment with this mouse. Our installation was with an IBM ThinkPad T40P, a laptop that has an integral Bluetooth radio. We were interested in using this mouse *without* the Microsoft-provided USB-attached transceiver.
Initial experimentation with the T40P and the Windows XP Bluetooth attachment wizard produced a good result. We had to trial several speed settings before being satisfied. The optical sensor performance is not as good as Microsoft's tethered Intellimouse products. It is fussier about the surface quality.
We were interested in trying the Intellipoint (4.9) software. It offers a variety of additional customizations that will be helpful to some users. But sadly, this is where it all goes wrong with the ThinkPad T40P. The software installs fine but is incompatible with IBM's UltraNav drivers and removes them upon installation.
The IntelliMouse software is wonderful, but the IBM ThinkPad UltraNav drivers that control the builtin pointing-stick and touch-pad devices are replaced by Microsoft's own generic--far less robust--versions.
While the hardware still functions, forget about using the keyboard without having the cursor jump randomly to another part of the screen during routine typing. You'll think (and eventually scream at the PC in horror), "what the heck is going on here?" UltraNav obviously includes critical and specifically tuned debounce performance that was overlooked in Microsoft's replacement drivers.
The ideal solution would be to have the peaceful coexistance UltraNav for the IBM hardware and Intellipoint 4.9 for the Bluetooth mouse, but alas that combination is not easily achieved.
As for the question of whether the Bluetooth Intellimouse works without Microsoft's transceiver on the ThinkPad T40P, the answer is "yes." If the Intellipoint software is going to back out your PC's hardware-specific device drivers, you probably shouldn't install it, and you'll just have to do without it.

I was happy with this drive until 2 months ago when it stopped backing up my photos and videos. It says the files are not supported. I called Tech Support and spent over 35 minutes with a technician who first thought it was my files that were "read only".
He was given access to my computer but was not able to fix the problem. He spoke with his "lead" person and got back on line to tell me to call Microsoft because it was not a Seagate drive problem !

Here is what the Seagate "support" page on their website indicates. If someone can explain it to me, I'd be very grateful. Note the solution which says "Backup of system files and folders is not supported " IS THAT A SOLUTION ? :-)

Error/Message: Not Supported/File skipped (backup of system files and folders is not supported)
Cause: File or folder has system attribute set
Solution: Backup of system files and folders is not supported
Note: This is a common error on the file thumbs.db which is a file created by windows to display thumbnail versions of the files in a folder. This file is recreated by the operating system if a folder is restored, so it is not necessary to backup this file.
This error is also common on the file desktop.ini which tells windows explorer how to arrange the files in a folder (list, details, thumbnails, special view), this file would be automatically recreated after a restore and it is not necessary to backup this file.

Speeds between drives varied less than .1 MBps so I will not be posting each drives tests but the averages for back and front ports.

Write Read from sata3 Samsung 128GB ssd 4BG file
Front 20.3MBps
Back 23.8MBps

Read Writing to sata3 Samsung 128GB ssd 4GB file
Front 61.3MBps
Back 65.4MBps

I hope this helps you decide on your purchase.

Good:  Lightweight, fast, thin, hard drive, memory, battery life.  Bad:  Trackpad, screen, and bezel around the keyboard.    I bought this laptop to replace my old dying one as a junior at UC Berkeley studying econ. This laptop is small and fast (using STATA and other econometrics and statistical analysis programs are really fast). The battery lasts 4-8 hours depending on use. If you're listening to music, writing a paper and reading .pdfs the battery will last around 6.5 hours. If I'm just reading a .pdf it will last 8 hours. The trackpad on this is pretty bad, it was almost unusable when I opened the box. The program allowed me to tweak the settings and it's much better but not perfect. The screen on this isn't very good. It's hard to use outdoors in bright sun (it's doable but not as easy as more expensive laptops). Also the bezel around the keyboard scratches really easily. Overall, this is a perfect laptop because I paid $600 and I expected it to come with flaws, and these flaws are very minimal for the specs and overall quality.

my house has insulation in the walls to reduce noise. (4 kids in my family)

At best I could only get a fair, 3-5MPs signal on whichever devices I was using.
My wife's Kindle HDX kept losing the router connection.

I bought the TP Wi-Fi repeater and followed the easy instructions, (pressed the sync/pair) button on my router
installed it close to the bedroom and now have a strong to very strong signal (3-4 bars on the TP repeater)
with 19-35Mps on all of the devices. I using it 20 feet and 2 walls away from the TP repeater.

In fact most areas in my house away from the router now have a better Wi-Fi signal.
I couldn't be happier with this product.

Hard to believe that this might actually be my first Amazon review, because the amount of things I have purchased from Amazon must be in the hundreds now. That being said, I love this computer so much that I decided this to be my first review.  This is the fourth or fifth mac I have owned, and I am very satisfied with it. I didn't know whether to pull the trigger and go for the  13 inch, but I am glad I ended up getting this size, which is perhaps some people's biggest reservation, an 11.6 inch screen. I can tell you that Lion makes having a smaller screen seem completely fine. Just spend a few minutes learning how to use the gestures, understand the value of full-screening certain applications (Mail, iTunes, Safari, etc.), and you can switch back and forth between items seamlessly.  I think that having at least 128gb is a must. I can't imagine having anything smaller, but the cloud and external media make 128gb a fine choice. The SSD drive is fast, very fast. This is the first computer I have owned with one, and I don't think I will ever be able to go back. I have the latest generation 21.5 inch iMac at work, and this seems to blow that out of the water. I know there is speculation out there about the Samsung and Toshiba drives, but I got a Samsung drive (the \\"faster\\" one), so this has not been an issue for me.  Overall, I could not be happier with the device. Only time will tell in terms of battery life, but as long as I continue to get 4 - 5 hours, I will be happy.

I took pictures of a bathroom remodel I was undertaking and by the time I returned to my computer the pictures were there. I thought this was great. Then I discovered that in order to reliably ensure pictures are transferred you effectively need to disable the auto-shut off feature of your camera. Doing this has resulted in several occasions when I pulled out my camera to take a picture and the battery was dead. This alone made me pull the card and put it back in the box. I will keep an eye on future versions to see if this issue is solved and give them a try again if they do.

My first unit arrived with a pinhole light leak (you'll know it if you see it, it's a bright dot on your screen, like a reverse stuck pixel on an LCD screen). This might not bother some folks, but I know me, and I could see my eyes wandering to it all the time. I might as well have retitled all my books to THERE'S THAT SPOT AGAIN, VOLUMES ONE THROUGH INFINITY. So I contacted CS, and the lady I chatted with was on it like a champ, issuing me a new Paperwhite straight away. She was awesome. She should get a raise. And a free Paperwhite. You can totally give her the one I just mailed back! Maybe the spot won't bother her.

Anyway, I just got the replacement, and as soon as I turned it on another spot was all \\"Hey, bud, can I crash? Cool! Hope ya don't mind, I brought a couple of friends!\\" Yeah. Three pinhole leaks. Also, the replacement seems a bit cloudier at the bottom edge. I had to flip it over and check to see if I got the new one with the Amazon logo and not the old one with the Kindle logo. Also-also, there's a teeny-tiny black dot permanently showing on the bottom left corner, like a stuck piece of e-ink. My stellar luck with electronics continues!

I suppose I could send this one back, too, but I haven't even put the first one in the mail yet. Besides, what would be the point? So I can get a new one with a constellation of light leaks and a dinosaur shadow puppet on the bottom edge? I mean, this is where it's obviously heading. I'm just gonna keep it, and each time I see one of those spots (which will be every single time I look at the screen), they will serve as a twinkling reminder not to order electronics online. Sort of like shooting stars, only instead of making a wish I will sharply hiss a curse word under my breath.

I just don't think their QA is very Q. I imagine they basically just turn it on, mark off the \\"I saw a bunch of words\\" box on the checklist, and pack it up. Clearly they don't give a flip about it once it leaves the warehouse, otherwise they'd use an actual shipping box instead of just slapping mailing labels all over the retail box. My first one looked as if someone had goal-kicked it onto the UPS truck. Nice job, Pelé. You're a legend.

Features? Yeah, they're okay, I guess. Page flip is nice. Footnotes are finally something useful instead of something dreadful. The front light has...kinda-sorta been \\"fixed.\\" By that I mean the \\"shadowing\\" at the bottom is still there, just very faint. It no longer looks like a flashlight being held under someone's chin in a dark room, is what I am saying. It will absolutely not look like that hilariously optimistic dazzling white mockup on the store page. When you jack the light all the way up, the e-ink washes out a little. After about three or four page turns, you might find that Page Flip is somewhat unnecessary, as you'll still be able to read the previous pages via all the ghosted text. Page turns are fast, I'll give them that. So that's a thing. You can do all kinds of turning pages in a fast way.

I mean, it's all right, all things considered. I don't know how enthusiastic I should be about it. I mean, let's not get crazy, it's an ereader with a light. So you can read in the dark without using a lamp or a torch or your zippo or whatever. I got a couple of bad ones. You might get a good one.

Anyway, I hope this was helpful. Actually, I don't really care, I'm just blowing off some steam. I know some hysterical types will consider this review a deeply personal attack instead of a product critique, and the laughs that will bring make me feel a little better about my bad gadget luck, so thanks for that. Now I'm gonna go see if I can make out the Little Dipper on my Paperwhite screen.

Pros:

It has the ports I wanted, and no others that would just be dust inlets.

Cons:

- The SD card port and all the USB ports are rather tight. This means that significantly more force than usual is required to connect or disconnect a device, and the card slot has a habit of nudging an SD card's slider switch to the \\"lock\\" position.

- Ships with old firmware that causes trouble for some people.
- Syba support staff know nothing about the firmware upgrade. It is a generic upgrade for the VIA Labs VL810 chipset.
- The firmware updater requires Windows.

Outstanding video, the display is better than any other tablet on the market. Wireless network speed works very well, I have not had any problems with lag time or disconnects. The battery life lasts for about 16 hrs on a single charge. The time to charge the battery is only a couple of hours for a complete 0-100%. It is very easy to operate.

The VX2770SMH - LED 27\\" IPS Viewsonic monitors are an excellent product. Assembly was no problem and the set-up was not complicated. There were zero dead pixels on either monitors. After a single adjustment on both screens there was no necessity to make further adjustments and I do not find it necessary to switch \\"off\\" the monitors when the computer shuts down. Access to the controls was not an issue and the pedestals are more than sufficient for proper support. The color, clarity and performance is excellent.    I purchased two of the 27\\" - ViewSonic monitors which is a wonderful experience after using a single monitor set-up. With dual monitors your ability to perform multiple functions on your computer is greatly enhanced. I performed an extensive amount of research prior to my purchase. The experts who reviewed and graded this monitor, and in comparisons with many other top name manufacturers of monitors, found the ViewSonic to be an excellent choice. In fact the ViewSonic was much less expensive and graded equivalent and sometimes better than other comparison monitors.    Much of the testing and evaluations performed by the experts was related to the following: Maximum Black Luminance; maximum contract ratio; gray scale error; gamma value range; average gamma; color gamut error and screen uniformity. All of this testing is way above my understanding but it was helpful to know the experts who tested this monitor gave it a high rating. In fact - after grading the ViewSonic on 17 specific tests it scored higher than other well known brands in 9 of the 17 tests. I use an external Altec Lansing speaker system and consequently do not use the integrated monitor speakers. So, I cannot comment on the speaker system which is incorporated in the monitor.  For general purpose use and gaming this is a very good choice for a monitor in this price range especially in consideration of the three (3) year parts and labor warranty provided by ViewSonic. I highly recommend this monitor.

I bought this adapter to allow me to run DJ hardware and software on my laptop PC. This adapter allows me to feed the main amplifier from the 'front channel' while monitoring my cueing-up of the next song in a discrete channel (not fed through the amplifiers) through headphones driven from the 'rear' channel. A nice bonus is the fact that the external sound card removes some of the processing load from the microprocessor in the laptop. All connections, so far, have been made using the analog connections - in the future, I'll also be testing the digital input/output connections. As a suggestion to others trying this for portable DJ-ing, I recommend adding a powered USB hub (about 5 bucks here on Amazon) so that the sound card, DJ mixing hardware, and other USB components are not pulling their electrical power from the PC's USB connection.

When I'm not DJ-ing, I also use this same sound card to play surround-sound movies on my laptop.

Thanks to my profession I have been able to use a Mac AIR over a year and have been recently upgraded to latest version of one.  Overall its a great lap top but its also $1000.  You could get a more powerful Wintel laptop for half the money.  I realize that is sacrilege to MAC OS guru's.  But the fact is as easy and solid as apple tries to make OS X and MAC hardware they both still have some issues.  - Both versions of the mac air I use and a MAC pro I also use constantly drop WIFI.  While non-mac laptops attached to the same WAP do not drop.  The frustrating thing is the apple goes out of their way to hide all of the real advanced settings that may actually fix the issue.  I understand they want to make these things like a toaster and thats fine, but some time you need to open the \\"hood\\" and fiddle with the \\"engine\\".  OS X is based on a UNIX variant and I have been working on various UNIX flavors for 16 years, I am no stranger to UNIX OS's.  But even at the CLI level they hide many of the advanced tools that one could use if one should run into an issue.  Of course you can pack the thing up and take it to the genius bar, which may cost you money.  BTW in windows or linux you are able to get to the advanced settings easily enough if needed.  -  As much as I don't love windows because of its instability, make no mistake OS X is not immune.  While it is overall more stable than windows 7 it does have its moments of instability.  Run it too hard or open too many windows it can freeze or hang.  Matter of fact I notice when I run the airs and the pro hard I see bluetooth devices loose connectivity, especially the mouse, and the only way to get it back is to reboot.  Wait I thought windows only did that, well OS X does too unfortunately, albeit not as much.  - OSX still is safer than windows as far as viruses go, but that is because there are more virus written for windows.  IT is not because OS X is immune.  Purchasing virus software is a good idea.  -  Software is stillkind of limited for the Mac, and the ones that are available are usually pricy.  Sometimes I just want to play a game, but most of the good ones run on windows.  If you are not  a gamer or power user and just want something to surf the net why pay the big bucks when you can get a Acer for under $400.  I can ramble all day with the comparisons but end of the day the Mac air is a cool device and sleek but I wouldn't dole out my money for it.

I would be happy and have called it a day....had I stopped there.    Then I experimented and installed the Soundblaster Z, since I had been extremely happy for years with an \\"underpowered\\" $200 Asus Xonar card (which is based on Creative).  The Z also works great with my Senns, but the value is that the software customizes the sound to a further degree!  My headphones are legendary neutral so they're the perfect cans to mess around with an equalizer.  I flavor to taste and music genre.  The amp also drives them better than the mobo chip.  The headphone is more dynamic.    I also tried the Fiio E09k/E17.  Good sound as well, but I still preferred the EXTENDED flavorization/customizability of the SB software.  The Z's a cheaper product to begin with and also less desktop clutter as it's an internal sound card.  That said, you can't go wrong with the Fiio if that's the route you want to take, as it has a great DAC/amp.    Btw, the DACs on all these hardwares are great and as a pseudo-scientific \\"audiophile\\" blind testing at a respected tech website concluded, \\"audiophile experts\\" couldn't tell the difference from a good computer mobo DAC and $2k+ standalone audiophile DACs.  LOL.    All in all, software customizability won the day for me over other products and why I kept the Z.  Couldn't be more happy.    My machine runs on Windows 8.1, btw, and had no issues with the drivers.

While a little pricey, it's really not bad compared to some of the high-end cases. As for the layout, it fit my needs perfectly. I especially like the PSU at the bottom of the case so it can draw fresh air in, instead of the pre-heated air inside the case. Heat causes you PSU to be less efficient, and shortens it's lifespan. As far as heat inside the case, there should be very little due to the presence of three large fans (front, top, and rear). The option to install a couple more on the side is nice, but I don't think that will be necessary... even with my crossfired HD3850's. There's 11\\" of space where my PCI-E slots are located (my vid cards are 9 1/8\\"), so long video cards have plenty of room to breathe. I could easily fit my pair of HD3870 X2's (10 1/2\\" x 1 5/8\\" each) in this case. Cable management is pretty nice when it comes to keeping things neat and tidy, too. The front fan cools the HDD(s), while the top and rear fans exhaust the heat that my video cards dump into the case. RAM sits directly below the outer edge of the top fan, so air will be drawn the length of the modules, instead of across them. I wasn't sure I'd like the tool-less design for the HDD(s), but these things are very tight and secure. Someone complained about plastic screws holding the side panels on... this isn't the case. The screws are metal Phillips screws with large plastic, knurled heads. There's even a slot across the top of the heads so in case you overtighten them and can't unscrew them by hand, and you don't have a Phillips screwdriver, but you DO have a dime in your pocket... you're good. All in all, I am extremely happy with this case. If you're looking for a well-built case that's got plenty of space for your components and good airflow to keep things cool, this is the case for you.

PS: I ordered it on 9/19/11, and it was delivered by noon on 9/20/11! That's AWESOME!!!

I had run out of back-panel USB ports and decided to buy this card to move my WD My Passport Essential SE drive over to USB-3.0. I was hoping to see some performance improvement going from USB-2.0 to USB-3.0 with this external drive, but no joy!     This WD drive supports both USB-2.0 and USB-3.0. Using it on USB-2.0 was fine and performance was average for an external USB-2.0 drive.    In moving it over to USB-3.0, I was curious to see what my real world performance boost would be. I don't find much practical value in those speedtest bench marks that move small chunks of data and test all sections of the drive. They don't give meaningful indication of what happens with large video files. (After all isn't that the reason you buy a Terabyte drive?)    I measured transfer rates for both USB-2.0 and USB-3.0 speeds using two sample video files. One sample was 1.0 GB and one was 2.0 GB. Here are my results using the USB-3.0 cable supplied with the WD drive:  USB-2.0: 1.0 GB file = 184 Mbps (42 seconds)  USB-2.0: 2.0 GB file = 176 Mbps (90 seconds)  USB-3.0: 1.0 GB file = 176 Mbps (44 seconds)  USB-3.0: 2.0 GB file = 160 Mbps (100 seconds)    This is not very impressive, as the speed actually dropped by using USB-3.0. I should note that I don't have a old, slow PC. It is a 2010 HP Win7 64bit with Core2 Quad 3.0 GHz (Yorkfield). I moved my files from an internal Barracuda drive connected with SATA that is significantly faster than any external drive. By comparison the same two files can be moved between two internal drives (SATA) on this machine in 12 and 19 seconds respectively (666 Mbps and 842 Mbps).    If moving big files matters to you, you'll probably see no improvement using this USB-3.0 card. Honestly, I can't tell if the poor performance is because of the WD USB-3.0 implementation or because of the Buffalo USB-3.0 interface card, but the combination does not live up to the hype.    UPDATE: I updated the rating to 4 stars. After installing a second USB-3.0 externaldrive, a new driver was apparently installed by the new drive that must have fixed what ever problems I was having. The new drive is performing very well with the same 2.0 GB file now loading in about 22 seconds!  This comes to about 742 Mbps, which is very respectable.

Quality feels pretty good although after heavy use I worry that the connection points will start to wiggle loose.

Wow! I just received my new, almost six-hundred dollar Dell monitor in the mail. I live in a rural community so many of my purchases are done on-line. I rush home with my new, almost six-hundred dollar Dell monitor and plug it into my new dual-DVI port video card. “Great Scott”, I proclaim! All I'm getting on my new, almost six-hundred dollar Dell monitor is a small rectangular box bouncing across my screen which states, “No VGA cable attached”! I've never had this problem with a monitor in the past. I normally just plug it into the video card port and it works. What is wrong here? I did all my research and studied the many new DVI configurations and what is compatible with what. So, knowing that technology marches forward (because they can't leave well enough alone), I also know that things are usually made to be backward-compatible. Right? Then I find, in the dark recesses of the internet, something about a new technology called HDCP. I read on. Instead of exclaiming, “Great Scott”, I now exclaim, “What the f...”! Because my new, almost six-hundred dollar Dell monitor makes barely a mention of HDCP compliance, never mind explaining the technology and what is required of the consumer who purchases this grand new technology. I learn that this new technology was developed by Intel and adopted by Dell, no doubt, to protect them from evil consumers such as myself. So, even though my new almost six-hundred dollar monitor has been capable of displaying graphics with all the technological savvy of a Pong game interface, it is currently sitting upside-down and backwards (because they can't seem to put the connections anywhere convenient) on my floor until I either do more research into what will make it work for me (because apparently Dell can't make things backward-compatible), or, I can blindly keep spending my money on products until something does work. But, I'm happy that you have seen fit to protect yourselves from the likes of people like me. How about just a clue, Dell, that the monitor will not operate with anything other than another HDCP compliant device! I will never purchase another Dell product or anything HDCP-compliant! Thanks Dell.

Purchased this to replace the existing board on my H87N-WIFI and also to free up current usb ports which I'd been using external Wifi and BT4 connector with. Gave up after 2 days attempting to get it working with a Hackintosh (consistent Kernel panics and BT only functional 50% of time). It took forever to find fully functional Windows 7 drivers but even after installation, I'd get the 'device disconnecting/reconnecting' sound every 15mins, even though noting was added or removed.

Company itself was quick to deliver but the hardware, itself is pretty lacking.

I'm using a MacBook Air (13-inch, Mid 2012) running OSX 10.10 Yosemite, which only has one thunderbolt port for video out. I write code professionally, and wanted to have 2 monitors and my laptop screen to do so. I don't need it to be low-lag, or have super high framerates, but I do need high resolution so I can display lots of text. This adapter does that (at 1920x1080 at 60 FPS as claimed), but not perfectly.

Firstly, you have to download/install drivers from their site, plugging in the adapter without them does nothing. This isn't a problem for someone like me, but may confuse new users, especially people who are used to Macs, since most Mac hardware is plug-and-play with no custom driver installs. On the plus side, the drivers were updated last week, which means they're being actively worked on, so the bugs I'm about to mention may be resolved later on with new drivers.

On to the bugs:
If you want to do triple-monitors on a Macbook Air, you'll need to plug in this adapter AFTER you plug in the thunderbolt adapter, or the drivers freak out, use 100% CPU, and your framerate becomes terrible with visible tearing and artifacting. Fortunately, when waking up from sleep this doesn't become an issue, and it takes 2 seconds to unplug/replug if you do it wrong.

Other than that, by far the biggest bug is that Mission Control (which I use constantly to switch windows) does not get along with the adapter. When it's plugged in, Mission Control causes the screen to freeze for 3-5 seconds before showing you the overview, though this can be significantly cut down if you run
defaults write com.apple.dock expose-animation-duration -float 0
in a terminal. This removes the animation at the start and end of Mission Control, though, which makes finding windows slightly harder, but makes mission control launch in a sane amount of time.

Also, if you want to use the adapter-connected monitor as your main monitor, the menubar loses transparency and can lose all its text, though it is still functional. Additionally, some applications (specifically Intellij Idea) don't like it when you use the adapter-connected monitor as your main, though they will run fine and display fine on that monitor if it's set up as a secondary.

There is also the minor issue of antialiasing not working in Mission Control, meaning text looks weird in the overview. Also, 10.10's new transparency stuff is glitchy and causes some weird colorations and small black/white squares sometimes, but you can disable it to remove this effect. [EDIT:] I have discovered that disabling transparency significantly improves performance of apps on the connected monitor. The setting is under System Preferences->Accessibility->Display->Reduce Transparency.

Lastly, though it does claim to be 60FPS (and looks like it actually is) there is a slight lag (maybe 3 or 4 frames) on the picture. For work, this is not an issue, but if you're wanting to use it for gaming (especially with a single game spanning two monitors), it would be very noticeable and problematic. The adapter gets warm while in use, which leads me to believe that there's some sort of processing going on, which is probably causing the lag, so this may not be something the driver updates could fix.

The Case Logic VCN-17 laptop case has some good points and bad points.    Here are the good points...   - Price - A good value for the money   - Storage compartments - Lots of nooks and crannies to store your stuff   - Well constructed - zippers work well, husky shoulder strap, lightweight   - Plenty of room - the computer compartment is quite spacious with an adjustable corner piece and cross strap to ensure a snug fit with any 15\\"-17+\\" laptop...    Here are the bad points...   - Not much padding - I was disappointed in the amount of padding for a laptop case   - Opens like a suit case - My current laptop case allows for any easy slide in & out of an integral sleeve, while the case is upright. The Case Logic must open like a conventional suit case to access the storage area, which takes up a lot of room. This is very awkward at airport security, in a hotel lobby, on an airplane, or other venue.   - A bit too long - My monster 17\\" HP Pavilion DV9417CL still has about 1 1/2 inches to spare in the storage compartment. This extra length makes it marginally too long to store under an airline coach seat. On a recent trip, a flight attendant told me to store the case in an overhead bin.    Overall a bit disappointing.

That function is set up oddly in the Tab A tablet. What the (exceptionally strong) magnet does do, is keep the case closed, and keep the back folded over as a stand when you want to use it that way. Much higher quality than I'm used to seeing from cheap cases.

I've been fanatical about Mediadevil and their fantastic Matte Clear screen protectors for a while now. I've told everyone I know about them when they've commented on the look and feel of the screen.

I've used the same Matte Clear screen protector on iPads (2,3,4) , iPhone 4,4S,5 & 5S. All have the fantastic feel and they resist fingerprints very well. I have about 18 different orders for MediaDevil screen protectors from Amazon (I just checked).

Normally, I'm the one who applies the screen protectors. I was out of town so my wife did it on our 2 new iPad Mini's. The ones I've received are definitely not Matte. The fingerprints show up immediately and the screen itself is smooth rather than that nice matte feel I've gotten on the other ones. Essential it's the Crystal Clear edition in my mind.

Mediadevil has always been fantastic when I've needed to deal with a problem. This time however they've told me that they've changed the material. I would think that if the material had changed it would warrant an update or new SKU on Amazon so people at least know.

To say I'm disappointed about the quality and response I've gotten from Mediadevil would be an understatement. Here is the quote from the email.

"I'm sorry to hear that you're not entirely happy with your Matte Clear iPad Mini screen protectors. Due to the increasing PPI of touch screen devices over the last couple of years we decided to update our matte material earlier this year, in order to ensure that the material strikes the best possible balance between the reduction of the glare from the backlit screen and the caused pixellation of the screen clarity. "

Even in their description they talk about the reduced pixelation of the screens and the Matte finish, "If you require a perfectly 'crystal clear' screen to enjoy the screen clarity to its full extent, we strongly recommend purchasing our (glossy surface textured) Magicscreen Crystal Clear edition instead"

Maybe the person I talked with is mistaken. Maybe I was just sent the wrong version. I'm not sure. Either she totally made up the line about the updating of the Matte finish or they changed the product yet didn't tell anyone about it.

Recently I helped a senior friend of mine purchase a new computer.  I was setting it up for her and when I went to take it online to her dial up provider, I discovered the computer had no modem. As I later learned, this is the case for all new computers now which is too bad because in remote areas many people are still forced to use dial up.      I went online and looked at several products.  The reviews on this one indicated it was plug and play and the price was better than some of the other products I looked at.  It has delivered as promised.  I just plugged it into an open USB port on her new computer, plugged in the phone line and away we went.  She doesn't use fax so I don't know about how that works, but as for a dial up service it delivers the connection with no problem.

For the price you can't beat it, it's a USB 3.0 extender that now allows me to share my external HDD with the entire family when they need it. Thanks amazon for the awesome product!!  quick shipping and nice packaging!

Many of the other reviews have complained about the limited connectivity of this monitor. I'm not going to do that. I knew what I was getting myself into because I read all of the information on it before I purchased it. I'm glad I didn't let the other reviews dissuade me because this super thin panel is amazing. The color and black level is superb. Setup is a snap as well with only two connections on the entire display; plug in the power and the Display Port connector (to a display port output only of course) and it worked immediately. The best part about the monitor is it's small footprint. Overall I gained roughly 6 inches of space on my relatively shallow desk. If you are pressed for space this is a fantastic monitor to consider.

The only downside to it is the fact that it does not handle resolutions below 1920x1080 very well. Text looks blocky and distorted whenever the display is not run at it's native resolution. As the Mac Mini that I have it hooked to is a Late 2009 model this can be problematic when attempting to run games at playable resolutions. If you buy this monitor make sure that your computer won't have any trouble running things at the full native resolution.

Other than that this is a fantastic display well worth the price!

I purchased the charger from EMBIZ. The shipping was very fast and the product was delivered in excellent condition.

The product works perfectly. Though I do not believe it could be a genuine apple product, it looks and feels exactly like an original one !

For a person (like myself) with \\"just-need-a-good-working-laptop\\" attitude, it absolutely suffices the need.

However, I have to point out one issue with the charger : Very often, the light (amber/green) on the charger does not glow. But, I did not feel it to be a complaint. I could always see the status either on the task-bar (when the computer is being used) or the glowing LED at the back of the laptop (when its switched off).

The bottom line is - I paid 25 USD for this charger; whereas I would have ended-up spending almost 90 USD had I opted for original one.

DISCLAIMER: This is no way an anti-apple propaganda. However, this would serve to be a very good alternative if you cant afford so much money.

Ordered it on Monday, got it on Tuesday through Prime.. awesome service from Amazon! Box came and it was packaged well, but oddly enough the plastic covering looked like someone had already opened it and packaged it.. although it was \\"factory sealed\\"!

So as I tried to start it up, it was dead.. not DOA but battery wasnt charged! So I let it sit for 3 hours and finally it turned on.. everything was honkadory until the wifi kept dropping.. this happened all day long! I even did a factory reset to see if it would fix the problem.. the factory reset actually opened up more problems...

1. The speakers started making weird white noises
2. The screen kept flikering on and off
3. There was random reboots
4. There was screen lag, especially when going from home to either camera or gallery (and yes I updated the software already)
5. The power button sometimes wouldn't work
6. Wifi just wouldn't budge, I tested the speed test against my Galaxy Nexus
7. When I restarted the tablet.. all my created playlists were resetted.. which sucks because I teach at the gym and I create playlists all the time

I ended up returning it today and buying the Toshiba Excite AT305.. sure the camera isn't that good on the Asus TF300, and sure its $42 more expensive, and the memory is only 16 vs 32, but I can deal.. Id rather have gorilla glass screen, a working WIFI, some what plastic metal casing and a lower version of ICS... I don't know Asus.. for some reason you went chincy on the material and hardware... It would be nice if they had the Infinity available but I can't wait.. and personally, if the TF300 had all these problems, I am pretty sure the Infinity might have it as well..

(This was my second TF300 this week, first one I bought from BestBuy on Saturday.. returned it because Amazon offered a better price with a larger memory.. didn't really get to play with that one too much, but all I can say, is that I should havegone with my instincts when it gave me wifi problems on Sunday..)

The first thing I would like to note about this case is that it is upside down. The default orientation of the Kindle Fire is with the camera on the left side when in the vertical position, however this case has the camera hole on the right side, causing the Kindle to have to reorient itself whenever it turns on. Not a major flaw but it is slightly annoying for those of us with OCD.

As a case, it functions well. The magnetic wake/lock works as expected, the stand grips enough that the Kindle doesn't slide and the strap to keeps it closed does just that. It does add quite a bit of bulk to the Kindle, more than expected, but seeing as it is for my Grandmother who has a habit of dropping things, the added bulk is a plus.

All in all, it's a good case that functions as a case should.

At first I was a little worried this would not work with my computer. I thought my computer wouldn't be able to keep up with HD but this device works amazing. Even on my slow computer I can record in 1080i with no problem. Right now I do want to say that it can not record any higher than what its outputting to (my TV is only 1080i). I usually use 720p for most my general videos because on a slower computer it will take a fair amount of time to export higher quality videos but the quality and clarity of the videos are amazing.

I have had 2 battery failures and while support sends me a new battery each of these has been at critical times. If you need to rely on this tablet for work or life then look elsewhere.

The charging adapter is also in a very annoying place, with my case on and charging I can not sit it up, but this may be a issue with the case. While the docking station is nice it is heavy and not easily transported.

I have used the Dell Latitude 10, Dell Venue 8, and a Microsoft Surface 1 Pro. The Dells have nice pricing but lack in quality. They feel solid but have some design and technical issues. I do not recommend them for long term (1-2 year) use.

However, I am still not completely happy because:
- I am not sure that the new one (still appears to be metal) won't eventually start shorting the Kindle out;
- They should make a firmware update that turns off the power ports - or every replacement case should simply come with the light so we don't have to worry about the system shorting out; and
- The customer service department should immediately fix this issue for anyone who calls.
Good luck to anyone whose Kindle seems to lock up, experience a battery drain, or completely crashes.

The seller answered my questions before the purchase. After a weekend and 48 hrs without a response, I filed an Amazon claim, which was fast and easy.

All in all, it was a disappointment. Great machine with all the bells and whistles, but one fundamental communications component ruined the experience. Though, if you don't need to rely on the wireless card, this is a great machine.

I debated between these and the III cards and decided to spend a bit more on the IV.    I have three of these cards so I can shoot all day if I am out and about (though usually shoot about 1-1/2 cards usually).    Each card has performed flawlessly and the speed is well worth it.  I have some slower cards and they do not perform as well, which is especially noticable when shooting a sequence of shots, I can get more with these cards.    Of course the burst may not be something you need/require, but I prefer having it just in case.  Also the download speeds to the computer does save time.  Again it reallly depends if it is important to you.  Usually it is not that important, just put any card in and walk away for a bit, but on the times when you are in a bit of a rush it is worthwhile.    Overall the little \\"would be nice to have\\" speed at certain times makes this card a good one.

The tablet is nice. I purchased the black 32GB version. It arrived in pristine shape and well packaged in a retail type package. It is a white rigid plastic that could be used for future storage but NOT for returning the tablet should it need repair (see below).

* The screen is very bright and has a beautiful color range.
* The WiFi reception is great. I used this in the hospital (main reason I bought it), my phone got a mediocre signal, but the Nexus 9 got great reception. I was able to stream Netflix at 720p and higher with no problems at all.
*The battery life is fairly good too. I use the tablet a lot for playing music locally and reading PDFs. I had used it for a long time before noticing my battery was quite low and I had to plug it in.

* Some of the features took me a little luck, guessing, reading the help, Googleing, and trial and error.
* Battery recharge time could be better, but it isn't too awful.
* I pre-purchased the Nexus 9 because it was touted as becoming the new flagship, but post release reviews have proven otherwise. Word to the wise: wait until release and wait for the reviews before dropping some serious cash.

The real bad:

* After about a month of light use, a dead spot appeared on the screen. the display in that are was fine, but an area the size of a dime became unable to detect a tap. I contacted HTC and they were very helpful, walking me though many different fix attempts before authorizing a return for "repairs", not a "replacement". You have to find your own bow that can safely return the tablet in.

* You will have paid full price for a new tablet, but end up with a repaired tablet at no fault of your own.

* Shipping and insurance cost are your responsibility (rather expensive) as well as repair costs if they are not under the limited warranty. Hope yours does not have a defect of you will pay more for a used tablet in the end.

I own the Kindle Fire 1st Generation, and until I got the Kindle Paperwhite (KP) as a gift I was satisfied with it. After I started using the KP, however, I'm sad to say the Kindle Fire now languishes in a drawer. The KP is half the weight, and quite svelte, with an easy to read screen, which includes PAGE NUMBERS (no, I'm not hallucinating) as well as the old \\"location\\" standby but also a little feature that tells you how long, based on your reading speed, you have to go before finishing the book.

So, that being said, here's the bad thing: there's a shadow monster resting at the bottom of the screen. Now, it's not a serious distraction but it's a distraction nonetheless. It appears there is a darkened area that invades the bottom of the reading pane and extends down to the bottom of the page. Again, it doesn't interfere with reading, or counting pages, but it really shouldn't be there. This is, after all, an Amazon product, a highly touted one, and I warrant that Apple wouldn't let anything out of their sweatshops that had such a glaring defect. So, it's because of this artifact that I can only give the Kindle Paperwhite 4 stars.

I have been an electronic tech for 35 years. I'm impressed with the quality/cost of this device. I did not buy it at Amazon. But at my local grocery store on Black Friday. I did a quick check on my android phone for it and quickly decided it was worth a try. The store was selling it for $88. I've used it for a week now and I'm very impressed with it. The device is built rugged with an aluminum case. It is light weight and has a nice feel in the hands. It has a resistive touch display. I recommend using the stylist over your finger tip, unless you have long finger nail. Then your finger nail would make an excellent stylist. In most cases your finger tip will work. But if you have a light touch. The stylist will be more functional for you. This is common with ALL resistive displays. Battery life has been as reported in the specs. It was very easy to setup. The only setup was connecting to WIFI and email. The true test of any PC is how well it plays games and videos. Both tax the processor, memory, and display drivers. It plays games very well with no jerkiness in the frame rate. Videos play clean and the sound is good. The display on this unit is 800x400. Which is to be expected for this price point. The display is sharp. Graphics and videos look very good. Its not the brightest display. Yet it is easy to watch directly under florescent lights. It comes with a YouTube ap on the desktop. YouTube videos look very good and play cleanly. I have to give a thumbs up on the video processor/display for this price point. I loaded about 100 albums onto the device via the tflash(micro SD) port. This was a memory card I use in my SanDisk Sansa. The card was originally load via Microsoft Media Player. The music imported without any need of conversion, seamless. Audio quality is excellent. It has a mono speaker built in and a stereo mini phono output jack for the headsets provided with the device. They too sound great. The only real let down on this device was it did not come withAndroid Market. It has GetJar. This is where you get your aps and widgets on line. I am not impressed with the GetJar service. This was repeated almost universally with all the reviews I read. There is an easy fix to this. You can find out how to do this on YouTube. Just search Kyros 7012 Android Market. Even a lay person can load the patch to put Android Market on this device. Then you have all the Android aps at your finger tips.  One nice function is it comes with a adapter cable for standard flash drives up to 4G of memory. No it doesn't have all the bells and whistles. No HDMI port, bluetooth, or built in camera. At this price you can't expect that. But if you want a basic tablet to surf, view photos and videos, YouTube, music,e-read, and play Angry Bird. Without blowing the budget. This device is for you. I also highly recommend this as a first tablet for the kids. Over all This is an excellent entry level tablet. I would have gave it 5 stars. If it had Android Market preloaded.

I really NEEDED to like it, too. Trying to figure why my dog keeps going crazy during the day and I needed a wireless webcam to do it. But this is just not cutting it.

First of all, it's really not wireless, which you already know if you read the installation info on the Amazon page. You have to plug it into the wireless server, and then you have to plug the server into a power outlet. Not the most ideal set up, but I really needed it, so I figured I'd try it anyway.

Problem #1, the camera is so light, it won't even stand up by itself. The cord keeps pulling it over.

Problem #2, it's supposed to be easy to install, and apparently everyone on here thinks it is, but it was giving me fits. I got as far as it telling me to unplug the temporary network cable, and then it asked if I wanted to set it up for the internet, and I said yes, and everything was downhill from there. It wouldn't find the camera at all without the network cable plugged in, and even when I had it plugged in, it would find the camera, but kept timing out trying to connect to it. And the couple times I did get the connection, it would drop almost immediately.

I finally \\"deleted\\" the camera, and ran the wizard again to install it, and said NO to the set up for web question, and then it worked.

However, problem #3, it can't see outside at all. I tried pointing it out the window and it was completely washed out, you could see a very faded tree and that was it. I thought maybe it was a reflection problem with the window, so I opened the window, and same thing. I have read about cameras not being able to see in the dark, but this one can't see when it's too bright, apparently.

The other complaint that I have is that they tout this wireless bundle as a security thing... monitor your house from the internet, etc. But then the camera they bundle it with is a regular webcam, not a wide angle. If you're going to tryto monitor a room, then you need wide angle. All it is is a USB webcam and a wireless server, it should have been easy for them to just put the Live Ultra (I think that's the wide angle one) in there instead of the Live. Or maybe sell the server separate so you can buy whatever webcam you want.

Oh, and my other gripe is that the phone tech support is only open M-F during normal business hours, so if you need help setting it up, you have to call from work. In which case, you won't have access to any of the equipment while you call, so they can't walk you through problems.

Annnd, one more thing... I was wishing that the software it came with had the same features as the Web Cam Center software (only for multiple cameras.) I like the feature that records a photo every 10 seconds and stores them on the hard drive... that way I can just put it in thumbnail view and browse through until I see something in the frame that's not supposed to be there. With the software that this comes with, it will take a photo every how-ever-many seconds, but then it puts it together in a movie, so unless you know what time something happened, you'd have to watch the whole movie in order to see anything.

I've been using Lexerd products since 2008.

Almost all my devices that has an LCD display, has a Lexerd TrueVue Crystal Clear screen protector.

So as soon as I ordered my Kindle Fire HD 7\\", I ordered a Lexerd TrueVue screen protector for the device.

This time instead of a TrueVue Crystal Clear, I decided to try the Anti-Glare version.

It arrived, opened the envelope and, well, the screen protector was just a bit larger than the actual LCD display. So, all remaining glass surface is left unprotected.

I tested the screen protector and it adds a mate texture to the LCD display and the glare reduction is more or less fine. The touch feature of the display is not affected by the screen protector, as expected by a Lexerd product.

So my suggestion for future buyers is, just buy the Lexerd TrueVue Crystal Clear screen protector. The Anti-Glare version doesn't add anything special, and the Crystal Clear version will look much better with the glass surface that is left unprotected...

I can sum it up in one phrase: I LOVE IT. I really did get it to replace an old kindle reader, and I still use it for that purpose. The touchscreen makes turning pages much less annoying than having to click a button... and hear that soft \\"click\\" every minute or so. Plus, it kinda replicates turning the pages of a real book. You can also set the paper color (I turned mine to a soft yellow instead of bright white) and can choose the font and size.   AND THEN - the tablet features. I can shop, surf, play games, watch movies - all on a big screen. My favorite part has been the Netflix streaming. I use the same account I have at home, and can stream movies and tv anywhere I can get wi-fi.  SO - it does NOT have 3G and works just like a computer in the sense that you have to connect to a wifi connection. However, those seem to be everywhere.  The only feature I probably won't use is the music and Cloud storage. My music library far exceeds the alloted storage. And I have an ipod, so I doubt I'll bother with that. I did however load (directly from my computer using the the USB)pictuers and a couple home movies to take with me on a trip to show to family.  The minimal CONS: It is a little heavy, and holding it one handed get tiresome. I often use both hands or prop it on a pillow. It needs to be charged each night if you use it a lot (battery lasts about 8 hours on a bright screen - be sure to turn off WI FI). You do have to convert your movies to a readable format, but my mac does that just fine and the transfer is simple after that.   The other caution I have is if someone is truly lusting after an IPAD, this isn't a replacement. It doesn't have a camera and some of the other apple-y stuff. So if someone on your wishlist has their heart set on an ipad, don't order this. However, if they don't really care about brand and just want a super awesome reader and tablet... this is the one... and the price is right.
