like other's have said, this is the one. Because of this case I actually use my surface pro a lot more. It gives that extra sturdiness that the Surface Pro lacks when resting on your lap or non flat surfaces. The pen holder is awesome. Way better than the stock holder. It always annoyed me that you can't fold the keyboard completely back when not using the keyboard while in tablet mode, but with this case when the unit is opened up and folded back in tablet mode and your walking around with it cradled in your arm like an ipad, the folio cover folded back creates a nice protective pocket to carry the keyboard around in while your not using the keyboard but still allows you to keep it all bundled up together and protected.

Coolest Pros:
* Sturdiness while using in bed or traveling on non-flat surfaces
* Ability to keep keyboard tucked in the folio case when using as a tablet when not using keyboard
* Pen holder

Cons:
* Well there's a little con, the surface keyboard does like to be completely flat. When the folio case is opened in tent mode and the keyboard is connected there's a little ridge whose edge depends on the angle you've set your display and creates a little uneven surface for the keyboard to operate. I've read others really slamming it for this, but its not a big deal. It's a few millimeters and not enough to affect performance. It's better then the alternative of using the Surface without a folio case.

All in all very happy and highly recommend. Great product.

UPDATE
For continuing problems I found that the unit sends it's signal from the modem after installation and not the wireless router (if you have one)
Go back in to set up and make sure that the level of security you set up matched and the security key is the same, if problems persist, reset the unit, go back to set up and set it up as a WAP instead of a wireless repeater, this should solve the problem. As before reboot all machines you are using to access via the new WAP

For reasons best known to my cable company my cable wall tap is on the second floor of my house next to my desktop PC. They are more than happy to come out and add more, but at what cost of course!
As a consequence reception in my basement even with a decent wireless router can be hit and miss - Answer - this little gadget.
Once configured you can use it as a WAP to turn a regular modem into a wireless one, a wireless repeater for an existing network, or an Ethernet bridge if you want to hard line an xBox or Wii or something.
It has a set up DVD, but you shouldn't need it.
First of all, plug the device into the wall (make it close to your computer as the supplied lead they give you is very short) and then plug the ethernet cable into the unit and your computer NOT your router, I know that may sound silly, but I did that first d'oh!
After a few minutes open a web page and type 10.0.10.254, you should be prompted for a user name and password, input admin for both, and then you get into set up.
If you are connecting to your own network use wireless repeater settings, get it to search, find your network, input you security key and you should be done.
Power off, unplug Ethernet cable and place in any outlet in the house.
Here's where mine got tricky though so be warned. My other computers connected to the same wireless network suddenly connected to the new repeater and threw out an error, so try rebooting first.
Failing that go into your network settings and look at the wireless connections, make sure you are connected to your home group with the right home group password. it can take a bit of fiddling around, but once it's working. it's so simple and the reception is great.
Should you run into a lot of problems and you want to do it all again, when you plug it in, use a paper clip in the little round hole on the bottom of the unit next to the ethernet plug and depress it for for 5 seconds, this resets the unit back to factory default, and you can do it all again.
I still gave it 5 stars despite some fiddling issues as for the price it's a great wireless add on, and much cheaper than getting someone in to rewire your house.s, make sure you are connected to your home group with the right home group password. it can take a bit of fiddling around, but once it's working. it's so simple and the reception is great. I am by no means an audiophile...but, secretly, I wish I were. I salivate over high-end audio equipment. However, on my student budget, I am left to dally in the world of using cheap-but-decent or used audio equipment. Even when it comes to live shows, I've been left to sitting in the cheapest seats (usually student rush) for the orchestra, opera or chamber music.
All that said, I don't think it takes someone with a huge bank account to know what sounds \\"good.\\" The goal is to try to get something that sounds close to being \\"live.\\" I'm of the opinion that this is somewhat impossible. There seems to be a certain point at which we all agree that music sounds good...but after that we are really concerned with preferences. \\"This isn't warm enough,\\" \\"this isn't bright enough,\\" etc.
This DAC, however, just sounds bad. I am amazed at the number of good reviews it has received across the internet (particularly Steve Guttenberg's glowing review for C-Net). Far apart from the noise problems (that have been written about ad-nauseum), this DAC plays music at a lower bit rate than my on-board sound card. I suppose that the sound stage was decent, but that hardly made up for the sheer harshness of the sound.

I played \\"Pet Sounds,\\" Tchaikovsky's 5th and \\"Rubber Soul\\" through Audirvana with Grado SR60s, Klipsh S4is and Sennheiser HD-202s. It sounded pretty terrible on all of them.

This case is so great in most ways and has a few major, glaring issues.  I'll say though, if you're on the fence at all, just get it.  You clearly want a small and sleek build, and this is the case to get.  I'll go over the good and bad and so so of this case.    The good of this is why you want it, right?  Well, this thing is TINY.  I clearly knew the dimensions by reading and compared to things I'd built before, but it's small.  It's as wide as many other computer cases, because it has to hold a real GPU, but the depth and height is amazing.  It includes a PSU that has all you need and is very efficient.  So, the price EVGA asks for isn't TOO out of the realm.  Both the case and PSU purchased separately might be cheaper from other vendors, but it isn't too out of the realm.  The PSU cables are sleeved which is nice and makes it easier to route the cables.  My PSU, unlike others, is very quiet running.  At load on stress tests that heat it up it stays pretty quiet and at idle, silent for all intents and purposes.  I do hear how loud it can get at startup, and if yours runs that way all the time, I'd say return it.    Everything will fit in this case, provided you plan as so many say.  I put my motherboard inside a few times and checked if I could put X cable in while it was installed or if I should do it before I installed it.  That made it MUCH easier to build.  I have huge hands and it's tight to build in the case, but if you plan and use patience, it goes just fine.  Space would be much better and cable routing if it wasn't for the infernal HDD cage.  That's one of the HUGE cons of this case that I'll get to later.  Space wise any GPU should fit within the Geforce series and many Radeon cards might fit if you do your homework.    This case looks awesome as the pictures shows.  That's the main thing that drew me to this case, just a simple design and it's small, which adds a lot to the looks.  The materials are very nice and it's a pretty sturdy case given the size.  I don't get why a few people are upset that some grey parts of the metal show - very few areas are like this and it's always going to be covered by a side panel.    The included fans - seem good, but I'll be honest they were the first thing to go.  I put in my old PWM Corsair SP120 fans because they move a ton of air if needed and they are very quiet when at very low RPMs.  These are very easy to replace and are just like any other case.  The cooler I'm using is the 92mm Noctua tower cooler - my favorite SFF cooler there is that I've used.  It keeps my CPU cool, but Haswell is toasty.  The case and component temps are fine, I live in hot Arizona and in the summer now, it's maybe 5-10c above my old mATX rig that had 5 fans well placed vs. the 2 in this rig.  So, not bad overall.    The bad things about this case and honestly, they pain me, but I must only give it 4 stars for this.  They are major.  The first is the DVD options - it says slimline, but only their one provided by EVGA works with the button and the sled they give you well.  This is seriously a drawback as many slim DVD drives could work here.  Installing it was fine, so at least that was a bonus.  The next, is the entire HDD and DVD drive cage.  This, at the very least, should be easily removed.  It would make building much easier.  I would go a step further saying that it should only fit 2.5'' drives - still leaves room for cheaper laptop type HDDs for bigger storage if you need more than SSDs offer.  Also, many mobos have m2 slots or msata so you can put a drive there too for more storage.  It also has some tabs on the HDD cage that can help with cable routing, but they also hinder it too.  Very, very poor design.  Those are the 2 major design flaws.  The less major one that I could fix by modding, is the fact the back of this has holes from the Hydro version that aren't very useful.  It also has some metal tabs in the area that look like it could mount up an SSD (more reasons to nix that cage).EVGA could have easily made this an optional fan mount for an 80mm (I checked by holding one up there).  It would also hold a 92mm fan, but that would be very tight.  This would have helped airflow greatly, by allowing you to actively force some cool air into the case.  Get a drill or other type tool and make some mounting holes and airflow holes and you have your own fan vent.    Overall, the 2 major oversights shouldn't let you not buy this case.  You have this, the inwin 901, and a couple others in this form factor that look good and work well.  So, do yourself a solid, and buy this.

Very happy with this monitor! Crisp with nice color. The stand is probably the best I've seen on a monitor since the days of the old CRT monitors (which were an entirely different animal, of course). The pivot feature is great for word processing and, surprisingly, also nice for a great many websites.

I'd only note two minor "cons":

1) The sound from the built in speakers is only "fair". I have much nicer exterior speakers already set up, so that's not a big problem for me.

2) And with the monitor pivoted to "portrait" orientation, the top of the monitor is so high that it would be nice if the stand permitted the screen to actually be tilted down a little more. I'm fairly tall, but I found that I have to look up to read the top of the screen. You could just raise your seat, if that did not make your work surface too low for you. The stand, apparently, has to have some height to it in order to be able to accomodate the pivot feature.

This case works pretty good. I do feel that it protects my surface well and fits it perfectly.  It's not flimsy like some others. This case allows free use of and access to the kickstand.  However, there are some minor cons.  1.  The kickstand cover has too weak of a magnet so it flaps around. 2. It does not allow for type cover to be angled...i miss using the angle.  3.  It's pretty thick. 4.  It does not keep the screen of the surface protected as well as it could.  There is no way to close the type cover to this cover, so it also flops around.  A magnet, velcro or clip would be nice.  Otherwise it suits my purpose.

This is the worst product I have ever ordered from Amazon. In fact, I am shocked that Amazon will even allow this dread awful item to be sold on their store. Reading the description you are told that you can use this with three (3) up to 24" LCD monitors. OK- good. That is what I want... so far. However, what it does not say is that when you have 3 monitors attached to it they will all be in one continuous straight line and/or the center monitor will stick out at least 2" - 3" above the side monitors. Who the heck wants a three monitor setup where all monitors will be side by side STRAIGHT. Don't you want the side monitors nicely lined up with the center monitor and angled slightly inwards? I know I do and that is how I expected a product such as this to be. I was disgusted when I realized what this item REALLY is and how different it is from the description and pictures. Oh, the center base is also A LOT bigger than how it looks in the photo graph and you WILL need to also bolt the thing down to your desk to prevent it from tipping over. The weight of the monitors on the sides will cause this thing to tip forward like you wouldn't believe.

If you are interested in a device (like this) that will let you setup a three monitor setup and have the side monitors flush with the center monitor and angled inwards then this is NOT the item you are looking for. I was extremely disgusted by this purchase and REALLY hope Amazon will give me my money back when I return it. This thing isn't even worth twenty dollars- it's that awful!

I have the Kindle Touch version in gray, and it blends in fairly well with the device. For this Kindle, I thought I'd indulge in a little color, so I chose pink. At first, I was disappointed, if for no other reason than the color was an unexpected and unwelcome deviation from what I expected, but I soon grew accustomed to the color. The fit is perfect. I have a little problem with the Kindle Touch version gapping above the button cutout, but I have no such complaints about this one.

The round keys have the function icons clearly etched into the skin, so there's no danger of them rubbing off (like might happen if they were simply screened on). The skin also helps fill the extra space in some of the cases that say they're designed for both Kinde and Kindle Touch.

+DirectKey allows direct access to the bios through case switch (can use reset sw)
+BIOS flashback button on motherboard allows for flashing through USB without turning the system on. This saved me from having to return it because all I needed was to wipe my flash drive and put the .CAB file into the USB port labeled for this function.
+Memory test button ensures a quick cursory check that the RAM you are using has no immediate issues or conflicts with the board.
+EPS 8 pin ATX CPU connection
+2x full PCI-E lanes
+Plenty of fan connections, especially if you had three or four fans for the NB/Mosfets/CPU HS&F/RAM
+CPU, NB, and SB heatsinks were secured tightly to the motherboard. Unlike one of the previous motherboards from another popular brand which I had to return twice which will not be named. (It starts with a "ge" and ends with igabyte and seem to be indicative of recent manufacturing or design issues with "Revision 3.0" motherboards.)

===

-SATA ports not angled out, allows large PCI-E cards to cover them up. If I had been using this with multiple SATA devices I would worry about my future GPU or other expansion cards.
-Electrical system not very robust. USB and audio pick up electrical noise often.
-Northbridge runs fairly hot, and the heatsink could easily overheat if not given a breath of air every now and then.
-Onboard audio not rated very well, nor is it well insulated from electrical noise in it's implementation on the motherboard. Would recommend a self-powered audio system if you do not have an add-on sound card.
-No way to set divided x8/x8 PCI-E x16 slots, effectively making crossfire or SLI completely unwanted.
-PCI-E standards 2.0, and not 3.0
-No PCI-E 1x on top, making use of my wireless card awkwardly positioned underneath the GPU. When a regular dual slot GPU is installed, you only have 1 1X slot left, and if you happen to be with one of those aftermarket three-slot GPU's, you have no choice but to use the 4x PCI-E for your 1x card.
-UEFI unnecessarily awkward and not very graphical, though easy enough to use and more verbose than some older BIOS systems I've used. Would not recommend for overclocking unless it happens to be a low power part.
-Still don't know what is up with the RAM settings on this board.

*Not tested for sustained and random USB 3 R/W or power draw
*Not tested for AHCI RAID
*Not tested for overclocking limits
*Not tested with a high end PSU
*Not tested with crossfire/SLI
*Not tested with Zambezi CPU's

Although this case came with elaborate instructions for removing the stinky smell that many users had apparently complained about, my unit did not suffer from this malady (or it would have gone back the next day). The case fits my Nexus 7 pretty well, and the magnetic lid mostly works OK at putting the Nexus to sleep and waking it up when closed and opened respectively. The case is a bit bulky, but I suppose it is offering some protection. Some function keys are a bit more troublesome to get at because of the thickness of the screen cover, but that is manageable. My biggest gripe about this product and the company that sells it is that they persist in describing it as PU leather. PU stands for polyurethane, which is not leather at all, but plastic. So the word leather is totally misleading, and probably in violation of advertising regulations. This would better be called \\"polyurethane with the look and feel of leather,\\" which is the way the lawyers would make us state it back in the day when I worked in advertising. Bottom line -- decent case for the money. But completely false advertising to call this leather. It's not.    UPDATE: After using this case for a few weeks, I am downgrading my review from three stars to two, primarily because the thickness and design of the case makes it very difficult or impossible in some cases to click hot buttons in the corners of the screen. So I now only use the case when traveling, which is not that often. For the price, I would still say it is a decent case, but for the most part, I have stopped using it in order to avoid having to periodically remove it from its case to click on a link. Too much of a pain. The support staff is very helpful and very eager to make things right. Since I still use the case for traveling, I declined their kind offer of a refund.  But overall, I would hope you could do better in finding a suitable case, albeit probably a more expensive one.

I purchased this unit on a different site, but wanted to post a review here so more people would see it. The TS-451 is billed as a media server solution, which is exactly what I purchased it to do. I have a large media library consisting of HD video and lossless music content and the TS-451 was meant to be a single location to store and serve up these files, locally and remotely, via the pre-installed Plex Media Server and a couple of the native Qnap apps. It serves files ok on my LAN, although a bit choppy, but the Celeron processor is not powerful enough to transcode and serve HD files remotely. It chokes and stutters constantly and is unwatchable. I have ample upload bandwidth available and upgrading to 8GB of RAM (as I did) does nothing to aid in transcoding, as this is a processor intensive task.

This NAS will probably work fine strictly as a LAN storage solution, but I cannot recommend it at all as an HD media server for remote access and Qnap shouldn't be advertising it as such, not with such a low-end processor.

I purchased this mouse to use with my laptop and to take with me on business trips. Firstly, the mouse itself is solidly-built; it feels like it should be able to handle getting slightly banged around in my computer case while on the move. I was initially not sure if the ability to add/remove/shift the included weights would improve my experience, however the "handling characteristics" were markedly improved as I experimented with the weight configurations. The laser sensor works well on all but the glossiest surfaces, and the size fits my palm comfortably.

However, the few complaints I do have:
- (Biggest complaint) The woven shroud over the cord does not move/stretch/slide/twist freely over the cord itself and will very quickly start binding the cord inside, creating corners and twists along the length that causing it to catch on itself and the edge of the desk or table. This is extremely annoying and was only remedied by actually cutting the woven shroud off the cord. Bad design, I guess.
-The non-slip grip on the sides of the mouse, notibly the area the thumb rests, while plenty grippy enough to prevent slippage, feels almost grimy, and you'll find yourself trying to brush off invisible dirt the first few times you use it.
-The right click is almost too sensitive, and if your hand gets the least bit lazy you'll start inadvertantly right-clicking.

All-in-all, besides the issues with the cord, I'd more than likely purchase this mouse again.

I have given this keyboard a lot of use and even dropped it from my lap onto a hard floor once early on. I've been quite happy with it, but now I think it is time to order a new one.

Updated Review:
I can't remember when I bought this, but I know I have had it for at least a few years. The letter e has worn off but that's not a big deal for me. Other than that I love this keyboard. I increased it to five stars because it has been a super product. I dropped it on a hard floor soon after I got it and panicked, but no fear. It has worked fine in spite of the drop. So it is very durable. I thought about looking for a foldable keyboard, but after looking at the keyboard arrangements for them decided to be content with this one. I love that the shift keys are big and there is nothing funky about this keyboard that I had to get used too and after typing on it I don't have to get used to my laptop keyboard. I would highly recommend this little jewel to anyone looking for an IOS keyboard. It is well worth it's weight in gold.

Positives:

I remember the online description saying there is a one year warranty with this, but there is nothing in the box that indicates this and nothing to send in to register it.

If it keeps working like it is so far, I think I will be quite happy with this product. It is what I am using right now to type this review. I am editing this review of this case. The ratings are a little a little deceiving. Apparently the ratings for this case include those from the others sizes as well. Initially I bought the 10.1-11.6 Inch Netbook Sleeve and it fit my chromebook perfectly. I was perfectly happy with the sleeve so when I got my Macbook Pro Retina I decided I would get the same case in the bigger size. Also when I searched the Macbook Pro Retina on Amazon, the case logic sleeve was the relevant item. The ratings were nearly five stars, just the same as when I got the 11.6 inch sleeve, so I figured it would be another perfect fit. Then when I put my 13.3 inch Macbook Pro Retina into the sleeve that I bought which was supposed to be for \\"13.3 Inch Laptop / MacBook Air / MacBook Pro Retina Display\\" it was about 1\\" too deep, 1/2\\" too thick, and 1/2\\" too wide so my Macbook was floating around in it. THIS CASE IS FOR 13.3-14 INCH LAPTOPS AND DOES NOT FIT THE MACBOOK PRO SNUG

So I went to the Apple store and found a Côte&Ciel zippered sleeve that fits perfectly. The Côte&Ciel 13\\" MacBook Pro Retina Display was exactly what I was looking for. I'm not sure if they are offered at every Apple store because when I browsed online I didn't see it there. Hope this helps

I have persisted with the Mac version of this keyboard for well over three years - to the point of purchasing several for various machines (and stored for future use) but today I resigned myself to the fact that the keyboard has a couple of major flaws that render it useless to me.  Firstly, the well documented connectivity issue - at least 2-3 times a day I would loose connection and have to re-start the keyboard to gain productivity. At this price point, this is simply not on.  Secondly, I've had two units in 12 months which have stopped responding to the charger - again, rendering them useless (i.e. no charge). This is another well-documented issue with this particular keyboard - both Mac and PC.  So, now I've gone back to the Apple wireless keyboard. Not quite as sexy or as nice to type on, but at least it is reliable and offers value for money.

This is a USB plug-and-play-microphone that works right out of the box. Plug the cord into a USB port on your computer and it is ready to go. It works with all operating systems which support a USB interface such as Windows, Mac and Linux.

The few instructions you may need for insuring the microphone is recognized as the default device for audio output and for configuring the device for optimal sound quality are contained in the instruction sheet that comes with the microphone.

The microphone is highly adjustable, from a height of 10\\" from the desktop down to desktop height if you want it down there for some reason. Proper height adjustment is important because the microphone is unidirectional, not multi directional. You may find it works best held in your hand with the mike close to the mouth. The cable is quite long

Conveniently placed on the base is a mute switch which toggles the microphone on and off. An easily seen flashing green light indicates the status of the microphone.

Not having the ability to easily test the noise interference claims, I searched internet hoping somebody done the testing. And somebody had: \\"Buddy Products made some pretty bold claims with the Amigo Cobra USB microphone and I have to say it actually works as advertised. I placed the Cobra on my desk and then blasted white noise followed by some music. In both cases it effectively isolated my voice and surprisingly diminished background noise and music without much voice degradation. It's very impressive.\\"

For anything ranging from making Skype calls to making recordings this is a good mike to consider, and especially if you are in a noisy environment. The built-in audio filtering is effective. The only limitation is that it is unidirectional.

As an IT professional that works on hardware in a computer lab daily, I would consider myself an ethernet cable connoisseur. That's kind of a joke since I'm really a snob about it, but at the same time I have so much experience with every kind of cable made that I think I have a very good base to report on this topic.

Pros:
-The jacket (plastic covering) is nice and thick. Should be good shielding for the wires inside and helps make the cable stiffer and less likely to crimp.
-It appears to be a real CAT6 cable. I didn't do the actual tests to verify this, but the shielding looks correct and the network devices show up as 1GB and the speeds look appropriate (best I can do without actually plugging it into an analyzer, which is too much effort for a cable at home).
-It appears to be the right length, although again I didn't actually measure it against a tape measure.

Cons:
-The clips/covers are not my favorite design (although not the worst out there either). That's the little plastic thing you press down to release the cable and the plastic covering over that piece. Personally I prefer the type of covering that is somewhat flexible and covers the entire clip, and slides down the cable. It provides the best coverage, but is still easy to unclip when you need to. The clip my cable has is like the first picture that is currently on the product page. It just has a small piece of plastic that barely touches the clip. That style is fine for a cable that is always plugged in, but when moving the cable, it's actually kind of easy for it to snag on a thinner wire like a phone power cord or something. I'm guessing by the various pictures for the product that this company gets different varieties in depending on what they can buy the cheapest, so you may get a completely different style.

Notes:
-The color on the cable I received was the darker blue that's very common nowadays, not the lighter blue that is shown as a customer image.tomer image.

Acer should be ashamed of themselves. I purchased new modem. Tablet(s), phone (Vonage) and Roku had no problems but Acer laptop was unable to receive the wifi signal. I've had the Sidewinder for ~2 years and I can affirmatively say it's the best overall gaming mouse I've used in my 10+ years of gaming.

Precision: Having owned several other gaming mouses (MX518, older Razer, etc.) I can say this mouse is on par with other high quality gaming mouses.

Comfort: Size is perfect for my hand. I can play all day without strain or pressure points.

Durability: No issues with laser, buttons or sw after 2 years of use/abuse. I use this as an every day mouse also, and it still works like new.

Features: For me, the best feature is the thumb buttons. The two buttons are perfect for programming moves that require combo buttons or double-taps. Record macros on the fly. The cord manager and spare weights storage block is a nice feature.

My only gripe is the scroll wheel. It has nice heft but I wish it had more notchy response when scrolling.

Overall, very satisfied customer. I should buy another before it gets discontinued.

I have had it for a few months now and the picture is very pretty. Used it for my PS3 and my computer and HD movies to HD games look nice. However I have noticed with Call of Duty Black Ops 2 for PS3(HDMI) and Sniper Elite via Steam on my PC(DVI) there is slight image tearing. Nothing too drastic as in the heat of battle it is not very noticeable. Something to keep in mind when purchasing this monitor. I am thinking that because they are both a darker visually based game that this is the cause. Battlefield 3 on PS3(HDMI) is beautiful with no tearing and Minecraft on PC(DVI) with various shader packs is also beautiful.

I am planning on getting another monitor and might get this one again, but I also am considering an upgrade to a larger size. Once the money starts flowing Ill think harder on the issue. For now, I am happy with this monitor.

*Forgot to mention- I recently learned the hard way that I was underpowering my PC and this could be the cause of the tearing. RMA-ed the MOBO and will hopefully see a difference in performance with a large PSU. That is all.

*UPDATE*
About 1 month ago, 9/1-ish (purchased 5/14-ish), I found out that my monitor audio output port was defective. It would only product raw sound. Nothing from my ps3 would work and I tried multiple speakers and inputs(HDMI, DVI, VGA). I RMA-ed the monitor to ASUS and the process is was fairly easy. It took about a month to get my monitor back after shipping it to them(which they paid for!) But what I am most surprised by was the return packaging. They had my fixed monitor in a bubble-case that completely, im serious- completely, enclosed it. And that was within the outerbox. It was the best return packaging I had ever seen and for this reasonalone I will be doing business with ASUS again. I would bump this 4 star review up to 5, but the audio output WAS defective so that lowers it to 1 star again. Thank you for excellent service ASUS.

I was very excited to replace my old D-Link DGL-4300 with this new router. The web interface is excellent. I was able to setup 2.4GHz and 5.0GHz wifi hotspots for different devices, such that no one bandwidth was overwhelmed. Port forwarding of my ip cameras was a snap, so was the setting of parental controls. Note, all of was this was done after I upgraded to the newest stable firmware. Initially, I was able to enjoy better wireless signal strength and speed. This lasted for about two months, after which I started having problems with wifi internet connectivity. I contacted my ISP (DSL) and was told that there were no problems on their side. With a huge sigh, I reset the router to factory settings and then went through the process of tweaking the settings. The router continued to work well until earlier this week, when internet connectivity became a problem once more. I again contacted the ISP, we disconnected the router from the DSL modem and made a direct connection to a desktop. No problems were discovered with the supply. I then decided to run an experiment by purchasing a cheap linksys E900. The short version is that we now have wireless connectivity with the cheap router. Of course the speed is much slower, and I'm left with a fancy door stop. In conclusion, does the product live up to the hype? hell yes!! briefly.

When buying the PromFlex tubing you must realize that this particular tubing has such a big inner diameter that you could fit a standard pen in it no problem, this means that it has more water capacity. Secondly as the name suggests, this tubing has a nice flex to it with about 8 inches of tubing being able to flex for about 5 inches without any signs of notable cink (cink is when you bend a tubing too much the tubing bends in a very sharp angle causing it to flex on the outside making it slightly weaker and slowing the flow of water). It has a nice Blood red color to it and looks great in your build but one of the things I didn't really like about this tubing is when I put LED lighting's in my case the tubing would appear transparent and that did not look really well with the build. Overall I love this tubing since it comes with a system prep for distilled water, a very satisfying length of tubing and it looks great. I would recommend to anyone who wants thick tubing.

This hub works very well. I have several of my external drives hooked up to this hub so I can turn on 1 to 7 drives individually. I have terabytes upon terabytes of content alphabetized throughout about 12 drives, and I don't want to keep them running 24/7. With this hub and others, I can access any of my content in less than 10 seconds. Transfer rate seems about the same as connecting directly to a towers ports. The only complaint I have is the same as other reviews, and it's about the bright blue light on the front. After popping open the hub I saw that the lights are micro LED's, connected directly to the board. No wires or connectors to clip to turn off the light. Black electrical tape it is! Takes care of the job and can look good if spread over the entire front of the hub. Good hub overall. Keeps cords running to the back, out of the way, very durable switches and no wiggle ports.

I am just stunned at the staggeringly, unbelievably miserable write performance of this device, especially with the stellar reputation the first-gen OCZ Rally had.    I just transferred 1GB of *large* video files (HD game trailers) to the stick.  Total time: 24 minutes.  24 minutes for 1GB of large files.  That works out to a beyond pathetic 700KB/second!  What on earth is wrong with this POS?    Transferring small files is even worse... I have spent an entire afternoon filling this stick with a few thousand files.  Don't EVER copy a lot of small files to this, zip them up or something first to a single file.    Delete performance is just as bad.  I have seen it take an entire minute to delete a couple of large files.  When I had to delete thousands of files, I literally gave up because it was taking forever (looked like it was going to take hours), and formatted the thing.    It's like this thing's FAT (File Allocation Table) is horribly slow, and any changes to it take an unreasonably long time.    Oh, as if the above wasn't bad enough, several times I have copied a huge file to this, and then found out later the file wasn't copied properly.  I was able to scan one of the non-working files using BitTorrent's hash checking (against a torrent of the same file), and guess what?  The first 1% of the (2.4 GB) file was corrupted or missing, which means ~24MB didn't get copied properly.  Brilliant.    The *only* bright point with this stick is it truly does have amazing read speeds... approaching 30MB/sec.  But the ridiculously poor write performance makes this thing basically unusable for me in real-world use.  Perhaps if you write to this extremely infrequently and read all the time from it, it would be adequate.    I have ordered an 8GB Corsair Voyager GT, and plan on destroying the Rally2 when it arrives.  It's that bad.

I ended up just reinstalling windows and it worked fine until quite recently, about a year after I first bought it.

I purchased this product to assist in upgrading a 60GB hard drive in an older laptop running Windows XP Professional SP3 to a new 120GB Western Digital drive.  Connecting the new drive to the adapter was straight-forward, and the included EZ Gig III drive cloning software was fairly easy to use.  However, once I installed the new drive into the laptop, it would work fine for a period of several hours to several days, but then fail to boot.  As I discovered later, defragmenting the new drive would cause it to fail to boot immediately.  I repeated the cloning process at least a dozen times with both default and various custom settings in EZ GIg III, with the same results.  This wasted about a week's worth of my free time, since I had to go back to using my old drive and restore files from backup every time the laptop would fail to boot with the new drive.  I contacted Apricorn technical support, and they suggested that I set the size of the new drive to something below 100GB, which in my opinion would defeat the purpose of the exercise.  I am aware of the 137GB drive size limit in older laptops, but I think that telling customers to set it below 100GB is unreasonable.  I was finally able to successfully clone the drive using the free Acronis True Image software available from Western Digital.  Caveat emptor!

Very good sound, I own the original Jambox, the UE Mobile Boom and the JBL Micro wireless, while each has their use and advantages, the Ultimate Ears Boom is the loudest and in my opinion has the best sound. This is definitely the speaker for a patio party. I look forward to pairing up 2 of the UE Booms. One feature that is not highlighted by UE is the removeable D-ring. you can mount the Boom on a gorilla pod or standard tripod. Great for placing it on a patio table. The quality of this speaker is superb, pairing is simple and there is a 3.5mm aux in if you of not want to use bluetooth.

Update: 7/3/13 - The first UE Boom I purchased was so good, that I bought a second one (a R/W and a Black one) - I am using with an iPhone 5 and pairing could not be easier with the UE Boom App, stereo separation is noticeable and I have not experienced any stuttering with the audio, the sound coming out of the paired speakers is incredible - loud, clear and decent fidelity. I have used the RDIO app to pump content into the speakers - 5+ stars so far! I the only quible I have with the iPhone App, when 2 speakers are linked to your iPhone, you can view the battery level on the second speaker only. Hopefully a future upgrade will give the option to view settings for both attached speakers.

To Double speakers:
1. Pair each with the iPhone. (BT)
2. Launch the UE Boom application, the application will recognize that 2 speakers are connected.
3. Go to the Double up menu (note, I have 2 different colored Booms, and the color representation is accurate in the graphics of the application, this is very Apple like - cool!)
4. In the Double up screen you can select to pump stereo thru the speakers or \\"double\\" - where you are sending the same mono signal to each speaker. In stereo, you can choose which speaker is right and which is left. (Stereo separation is excellent!)
5. To disconnect, there is a red button, all very well thought out and.. it just works! Nice job UE!

I use this sleeve for my Asus Eee PC 1000HE 10\\" netbook and I have no complaints. It hugs the netbook so it does not move around but its not too tight a fit... it gets in there easily and because of the stretchy neoprene material, you can add other things in there, no problem. I even dropped my netbook a few times with no damage.. I'm not advising it of course, but its nice to have some cushion.    The front pouch is great... I mean, sleeves without pouches look cute, but at the end of the day, you need to take your cables with you. This one gives the best of both worlds as the pouch can be as flat as you want it, or can hold a great deal (which will make it bulge, of course). I personally push it... I have my cables in there but also my slim external drive with cables, and sometimes a usb flash drive too! The neoprene just stretches, with no strain on the zip.     Cons  There aren't any, really. If I have to look for one, the straps... they're sturdy and flexible enough to push out of the way... but they could be cuter. Guess thats not really a con, huh? What can I say? Its a great sleeve.

I greatly minimized the amount of chatter by running a good defragmenter (MyDefrag4), which places all the files in the order that Windows wants to read them in, works much better than the built-in Windows Defrag, and is absolutely free.

The drive is OEM and does NOT come with cables, screws, or anything else. Also of note - the SATA cable will NOT lock or click into place on this drive: there's no plastic lip for the cable to secure to. That troubled me greatly at first, but the cable fits snugly, and it would take one heck of a jolt to accidentally dislodge it, so really - it's not a concern at all.

Great drive, great speed, great warranty, and 2TB for around $130 is fantastic.

Every serious retro/classic videogame collector or enthusiast who wants to bring classic game eras into the HD generation ought to have this! Most televisions come with basic upscalers. And while you may get lucky with a pretty good one, the Framemeister offers its own consistent upscaling, and native HDMI output. RCA, S-video, and even true RGB make this perfect for virtually all 16-bit consoles forward. Though I would've appreciated an F-type coaxial input (ATARI 2600, Intellivision, etc.) to make this truly perfect, it makes a very good case for itself managing so many others, having a new English firmware update, and other features like scan lines. SNES/PCE/Genesis and various 16-bit sprite-heavy games (even certain 2D Sega Saturn games) are a joy to see in hi-res and play, with settings to minimize input lag. Other systems need some fiddling around with the settings, but once you find settings you're happy with, you'll realize that it's not too bad at all. In fact, you'd be hard-pressed to find a TV or any other device that offers this much flexibility at this price, and all in such a small box.

It's not cheap, but if you can afford it and take your gaming hobby seriously, it's worth every penny. There really is nothing like it!

Based on some of the uninformed, ignorant _OPINIONS_ in the 1 star reviews for this product, I am driven to provide my review of the Cooler Master Jetflo 120 and supply some _FACTS_.

Disclosure: I own the Jetflos, I also own and use: Antec 120MMs (tricools and adjustable), Arctic Cooling F12 PWM, Cooler Master Blademaster 120, Enermax Magma's, Noctua NF-F12 PWM, Noiseblocker NB-SilentPro, and Scythe Kaze Maru 140MM PWM, also Corsair 200mm (700 rpm), Antec 200mm fans. I have also tried Silenx iXtrema's and Coolermaster Sickleflow 120 fans.

Out of the box/full speed the Jetflo 120MMs are 2100 rpm fans that also move a large amount of air. _ANY_ fan running at 2100 rpm is going to be loud. Any fan that moves the amount of air this fan does at 2100 rpm is going to be loud. (According to some websites, the Highest CFM ever seen at 2100 RPM).

Look at any fan claiming to be very quiet, all these fans are running at 1200 RPM (or lower). If you run this fan at 1200 RPM it will be quiet

I see some reviewers that say the Jetflo is not as quiet as a (for example) Noctua. While this is basically true when running both fans at full RPM, it ignores important facts. The Noctua runs a max RPM around 1400 with a CFM of 55, the Jetflo: 2100 RPM and 95 CFM. So the Jetflo has 50% more RPM and 73% more CFM (More CFM is good) at max voltage. Yes, common sense would say the Jetflo at 2100 rpm is going to be much louder than a Noctua at 1400 rpm. But this is comparing apples to oranges.

If you compare apples to apples (both fans at the same RPM) you will have a different experience. In other words: WHEN RUNNING AT THE SAME RPM the jetflo fans are as quiet as any antec/noctua/nexus etc. fan.

So lets compare(in detail) apples to apples. The Noctua and Jetflo at 1400 RPM: Noctua NF-F12 PWM: 55 CFM @ 27.5 dBA vs Jetflo: 58 CFM @25 dBA. (As independently verified by using observed values (not the values printed on the fan packaging)from websites like Anandtech, Silent PC review, Xbit labs, etc )

The JETFLO is quieter (25 vs 27.5 dBA (lower is better) and moves more air (58 vs 55) than the Noctua.

It's all about moving air and to move air you generally need rpm. But setting that aside, try all these fans at 1200 rpm and then tell me the Jetflo is LOUD.

What I have yet to hear is the Jetflo is louder than a Corsair SP120 High performance or louder than a Scythe Slipstream Slipstream (Model SY1225SL12SH -1900 rpm) fan or louder than a Scythe Gentle Typhoon at 3000 RPM.

Compare apples to apples, people

Most recent motherboards are equipped with HW/Bios SW to control fan speeds. (If not you can use free ware like Speed fan to control them by SW). It was very easy to set up my MBs so the fan doesn't reach 1600 rpm until 50C(which it should never do unless the CPU cooler has failed or is filled with dust). Then the noisy fan serves two purposes: 1) As a warning that something is wrong. 2) Assists the struggling CPU cooler by moving lots of air thru the case.

To quiet my systems (a HTPC, gaming PC and work PC) and improve airflow, I am in the process of swapping out some Antecs, Scythe Slipstream 120MMs (1450 RPM), and Enermax Magmas. In side by side comparison, at the same RPM levels (tested at 800, 1200, 1400 and 1600 RPM) I have found the Jetflo's quieter and move more air than any antec (I own), Coolermaster Sickleflow, Enermax or Scythe Slipstream fans.

I have two of these CM jetflo fans as intakes and an Noctua NF-F12 on the side and an Arctic Cooling on rear of an Antec 300 case. When all fans are at 1200 rpm, the CMs are no louder than the Noctua or AC. At 1400 the Noctua is not quieter. When the Jetflo exceed 1600 RPM, their noise is competing with noise from the CPU and GPU fans. But at high temps, any (properly functioning) system (using air cooling) should be loud or you are going to have components running at 80-90c. (btw, the HTPC system temperature typically runs from 27-33c, the 50c+ temperatures are individual components(each with it's own heatsink/fan). In other words system airflow is EXCELLENT)

As mentioned above my HTPC uses Jetflo's, at normal operating temperatures the system is silent (I have to look at the power LED to see if system is running). When stress testing there is fan noise but not enough to make me adjust the sound on my HDTV.

UPDATE 04/29: I've read some comments that lead me to believe the Jetflo may have a problem with the PWM controllers on some motherboards. (as the comment-er has not supplied details, I'm not sure which PWM controller). Either that or it could be another bad fan (which makes me wonder about quality control). Either way not a good thing

The Eye-Fi wireless SD card is a great idea; especially for those who get confused as soon as a wire is involved in connecting a camera to their computer. I got this as a gift for my parents for this exact reason (and though their new camera was using an xD card, so this didn't fit) I tried it out in my own two cameras as well. In my small Canon PowerShot SD600 camera transfers from the camera to my computer and my chosen photo service were speedy and seamless. In my big-boy Nikon D80 camera transfers were a little slow (since the pictures are taken in such a large resolution and are rather big) but still worked seamlessly.    I don't think I would use the card in my D80, only because I generally use it to take a lot of pictures and sync them as soon as I get home and want to review them right away. However; in the smaller camera that takes smaller pictures, it was nice to be able to take random pictures and come home and turn the camera on for a few minutes and let it do all the work.    To sum up my review, here's some pros and cons:    Pros: Decent transfer speed for smaller pictures taken with your typical smaller cameras. Seamless integration with the Mac (OSX Leopard) and PC (Windows XP). Compatible with many popular online photo sites; you are likely to already be using one of them.    Cons: The transfer speed is just a bit slow for larger pictures taken by more professional cameras. It's still only SD, so there's some camera incompatibility still. The price is more than I'd like to see still, but it's a new product fresh on the market that nothing else can touch yet.

I recently did a routine reformat of my old HP Pavilion 750n, which I do about once a year, and decided it was time to do some upgrades. I upgraded from 512MB to 2GB RAM and purchased this Radeon card to replace my Nvidia GeForce FX5500 whose fan was starting to go bad. Obviously the RAM upgrade itself made a difference, but even with more computer RAM the Nvidia card didn't perform that much better. Once I installed the Radeon 4650 I saw an immediate difference, no lagging while watching DVD's. And with the Radeon having it's own 1GB RAM it really freed up the rest of my computer so that I could keep other large programs open in the background without it slowing down my computer. I was a little weary about installing this in my almost 10 year old computer, as I read reviews where people had issues installing the drivers from other Radeon cards, but I had no problems with my install, I followed the directions by removing my Nvidia drivers, installed the card, put in the CD and the computer did the rest. Very easy install. So far this card works great. If you have an AGP video card slot and are looking to upgrade, this card is the way to go. I would definitely recommend this to a friend.

Hi all,
I ordered this Display last week from Amazon. I chose the yellow instead of blue display. SPI, because it takes only 5 wires to make it work.
I read from reviews that most users are having difficulties getting it to work.
First it is an ST7920 based display as indicated in some reviews here.
To make it work with existing codes, you need to download u8glib and here is the link:[...].
In this library there are sample codes and each sample has a bunch of different controller models in commented (//) lines.
Open one of this sample codes with Arduino IDE( I Tried \\"Hello World\\" and \\"Graphic Test\\" ), ignore all the commented models and just add this line: U8GLIB_ST7920_128X64 u8g(13, 11, 10, U8G_PIN_NONE);
This line assigns pin 13 to SCK, 11 to SID and 10 to CS as they are labeled on SPI piggy back board's 2x3 pin connector.
Connect SCK to PIN 13, SID to PIN 11 and CS to PIN 10 0f Arduino UNO. Don't forget VCC and GND. Here are your 5 pins.
The SPI switch on LCD should be set to SPI.
Amazon deleted the link, but you search for it on google.
NOT GLARE-FREE

This WD 2TB drive runs quiet and cool.  Price wise, it was a great choice for me.  If you do not have USB 3.0 ports on a desktop [how to tell? 3.0 ports have a little sky-blue interior plastic guide; it's black on older ports], you can add a multiple port USB 3.0 card for $30-40 (check for available slots and type inside first), and run this drive up to its potential (which I do), otherwise, it will work on USB 2.0 ports, only more slowly.  Also, beware, SOME external USB hubs (eg, cheaper ones) do not provide enough power to run an external drive.  The included WD backup software keeps this 2TB drive working for me continuously (or, optionally, on an hourly, daily, or monthly choice) backing up my 1TB internal HD on my new Windows 8 desktop. Set up was easy - I selected what folders to ignore (such as C:\temp and C:\Downloads), and it did the rest. WD also provides a drive cloning app called Acronis True Image which I have not used. Neither software does incremental backup, but Smartdrive allows you to keep 20 or more former versions of a file to give historical recovery. I have not had to use the file recovery yet [UPDATE: just did; keep reading...] but it provides options to recover to original location, or to a 'Retrieved Content Folder' of your choice ... OK, I just DID THAT for a spreadsheet I worked on the past couple days.  It showed me multiple backup copies (different prior versions) as expected. I selected an older one, clicked Next, and it retrieved just that file to my designated Retrieved Contents Folder.  From within that folder, it reconstructed the original sub-directory path down to the restored file so I could navigate to it just as I would do with the original file, down from C:\.  It worked reasonably quickly and the file opened in Excel flawlessly ... good to go.  Note: This is all with the free, included software (which I just upgraded on-line to their new free 2.0 version last week).  The Pro upgrade is (presently) $19.95 for up to three computers (I guess you could use this 2TB drive to backup multiple computers?)  The Pro version adds backup to non WD devices, and to a remote Dropbox folder - all features not of interest to me.  Note: I also use a WD 1TB Passport on a quad-core Mac mini with USB 3.0 and Apple Time Machine - also runs flawlessly.

PC1: bad video card
PC2: bad heat sink fan
PC3: bad heat sink fan

PC3 just failed today.

Avatar did send replacement parts for each bad component for PC1 and PC2.

I reported PC1's problem on 2/14. I received the new video card via UPS on 2/28.

I reported PC2's problem on 5/05. I received the heat sink/fan via USPS on 5/15. I am very leery of tearing off the existing heat sink from the CPU and replacing it myself, as it it possible to damage the CPU doing this. They did not send the thermal compound I'll need to reseat the new heatsink/fan, so I'll have to buy that now, as well.

All in all, I am very disappointed with the quality of Avatar and the HUGE time suck/stress it has placed on me. So much for Made in America.

I'd suggest you avoid their products - 3 out of 3 failures is not likely to be random.

Secondly there is no solid state drive included.  This is really not much of a problem once the laptop has booted and started everything but it is noticeably slow the first few minutes. Yes! It does work with Windows 8.1, and I'm going to show you how to do it because some of the other reviewers didn't give enough detail as I would have liked, so I will give you a more detailed version of how to get it working in just a few simple steps, it shouldn't take more than 5 minutes.

1. Do not install the disk that the game comes with!
2. Go online and search for Wireless(make sure it is wireless)Xbox 360 controller drivers. Hopefully this is the page you end up on: [...] When asked which operating system are you using, select Windows 7 64bit. Yes even if you are using Windows 8.1.
3. Plug in your wireless receiver, and find it using Device Manager > Other Devices > Unknown Device. That Unknown Device is your wireless receiver. If for some reason you didn't follow step 1, you need to uninstall the drivers that came with the device.
4. You want to select Update Drivers
5. \\"Browse my computer for device software\\" > \\"Let me pick from a list of device drivers on my computer\\"
6. Search for \\"Xbox 360 Wireless *Receiver* for Windows\\" Make sure it is the most recent version! There are multiple versions, make sure it is the most recent version! It will prompt you to say that it cannot verify the continuity of the driver with the device, click Yes/OK to proceed and install the software.
7. Once installed, everything should be running as it should.
EDIT #1:
If you ever unplug and replug the device, you will have to reinstall the driver by doing steps 3-6.

EDIT #2: After a week of heavy use, I am loving this device, having the freedom to interchange keyboard and mouse with Xbox 360 wireless controller on my PC is pure gaming heaven. Games I have tried and had success with so far are: Dark Souls, FIFA:World, The Witcher II, Battlefield 4, and Titanfall. I am sure that there are many more that will work.

I bought this to replace another cheap charger that I bought off of here (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0026LQZP0/ref=oh_o00_s00_i00_details). I was worried that I would have the same problem with this charger that I did with the other one. The other charger worked great for a few months, and then just died. It was apparently not getting enough charge to my laptop because as soon as it died, my laptop's battery began to drain way too quickly.

With this charger, I haven't had any problems. I bought it around three months ago, and it has worked great so far. When I take my laptop off of the charger (which I do more frequently now), it lasts as long as it did with the original charger. I definitely recommend this with the HP Pavillion dv4 laptop (listed here, specifically: http://www.amazon.com/HP-Pavilion-customizable-Notebook-Processor/dp/B00393WKO4/ref=sr_1_33?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1329951171&sr=1-33).

I would even buy one of these if you are getting a new laptop such as the one above. The original charger wore very quickly, and this charger is cheap enough, and it works just as well as the original. If I have any problems, I'll be sure to update my review.

UPDATE for 7/2013: The charger ended up dying and I bought a \\"real\\" HP adapter that has lasted this long (it is now 7/2014) because it was the only thing I could find in the store. However, had I had a choice, I probably would have bought the cheap one again. For the price, it lasts quite a while and I don't have to pay $70 to replace it.

After much research I decided on this pen for my wife and I to write on our iPad 2s.  We both have become avid note takers with the IPad and I use the Ayl stylus extensively for my sales job to take notes.  One of my favorite features is the side clip because I can clip the stylus on the edge leather of my Bear Motion leather case versus having the stylus in my pocket or hanging from the audio jack.  But then again most pens have a side clip.  Pen is easy to use and more responsive than any pen I could find in the Apple store.  One weird complaint...the soft rubber head makes a slight \\"popping\\" sound when writing.  Certinly not loud, but very noticeable to me when writing.  This is a result of the soft, hollow rubber head of the pen depressing when writing and popping back into shape when the pen is lifted of the iPad.  Seems to happen less the more vertical I hold the Pen.  When the wife and I are sitting together taking notes we have a little popping chorus.  FYI, I do not press abnormally hard and even when trying to write softly it makes the sound.  Functionally the pens are great yet that little popping sound does annoy me and if I found a pen that wrote as well without that little fluke I would buy it.  I figure this probably happens with any brand of soft rubber tip.

After researching various bluetooth tablet keyboards out there, I settled on the Belkin QODE for my Galaxy Note 8 (Jellybean Operating System for Android).

The tablet easily fits into the case. The brackets are made of rubber which are attached to elastic bands that stretch to keep the table firmly in place.

The keyboard is solid and durable. It's also non detachable so if you want to just fold the case back and only use the tablet, the weight of the keyboard does become cumbersome.

The case comes with it's own micro USB charging cord that will plug into any cell phone charging unit. Remember to charge the case first before attempting to pair it to your tablet or use it for the first time. When charging, a blue light will initially turn on to indicate the unit is charging. After a minute or so, the light will turn off. The unit is still charging however. When the battery on the keyboard is low, the light will turn on to notify that it needs to be charged.

To keep the tablet upright, all you simply have to do is fold the cover back. The same magnet that keeps the tablet closed also anchors the tablet to keep it upright when you're using it at a table.

One complaint I have about the unit is that it doesn't come with any directions whatsoever. All you get is a simple card with pairing instructions and a link if there are any issues. For an $80 keyboard, a more detailed instruction card would have been nice.

The biggest issue I had with this unit was getting it to pair for the first time. The unit finally paired up with my tablet after the third attempt. Also know that if the charge on the keyboard goes out, you will need to pair up the keyboard again with your tablet.

All in all though....it's a reliable unit.

Well I have waited for weeks so I could get the tablet dock amazon had to sell and it is finally here. I have to say it is not everything I expected. That is because it has the FCC sticker indicating TF201 and the firmware does the same. That said, I tested my infinity on a 201 dock and it didn't work right, and on this dock it is working flawlessly. In addition, the color matches, the weight distribution is good, and I'm having zero issues typing on it. The battery life is phenomenal and the seating of the tablet has no issues worth noting.

I am of course extremely disappointed that I could have ordered from any of the other sellers on here and gotten the same product weeks ago for less cash, but I got what I wanted and as of yet am very satisfied with it. I do think it was pretty crappy of Asus to reformat and sell the 201 docks as 700 docks, but at least if it stops working, I'll have ground to stand on against Asus (not that I expect it to stop working).

I can't recommend the dock enough. If you bought a transformer you should buy the dock as well, it completely changes the experience of using an android tablet. Just yesterday a coworker asked why I bought a netbook when I already had a tablet. I asked him how many netbooks have a removable touch screen display and it was awe-inducing. A great exprience overall.

Very satisfied!

UPDATE: Tested side by side with my Brother's Transformer Prime and I can confirm that the weight distribution/balancing is remarkably different from the Primes dock. I am absolutely certain that this is a TF700 dock regardless of the firmware name.

This headset was probably great prior to windows 8. The new drivers are garbage (mic hum, ridiculously high volume where even "2" will blow your ear drums) and Corsair support is pretty worthless. The only way to make this work on 8/8.1 is to download a really old version of the driver (which isn't even provided on Corsair's website), and run it in compatibility mode. Even then you should expect random disconnects. "WHEN" they decided to work, they were ok.

Do yourself a favor and pay close attention to the negative reviews on here and the thousands of posts on the Corsair forums about all the problems with this headset and the associated software, because you will likely have the same results. I returned mine as defective.

On another note, if you are just interested in the simulated 7.1 surround and already own a decent pair of over-ear headphones, give Razer's software a try. I am using it with a pair of Sennheiser HD280 pro's and the surround effects and sound quality destroy this Corsair, with the only downside being that I don't have a boom mic attached to them. You can get a desktop mic cheap though.

I was really happy with the device. Not only does it offer full protection for my iPad but it adds another layer of functionality to the device. The keyboard attachment is perfect for work purposes. Being a student at college it offers a perfect mix of compatibility an portability. For the price it is well worth it to. Where I would Have needed to spend hundreds on a laptop to do important work on the move, I just bought this device and combined it with a piece of kit I already owned. There is very little wrong with the device other tan the fact that as I gaze over the keys and functions of the key board I cannot see a pound sign. It is also rather hard to get the hard case to fit round the iPad 100% of the time, every now and then you find that you put the case back together and one or two of the latches wont click in without a considerable amount of force; bearing in mind there is a $500+ piece of kit within it it isn't somthing a lot of people are going to be comfortable with. That said It doesn't make a big difference. One or two latches don't affect the aesthetics or the protection quality of the case considering a thick silicon shell is there as an extra layer. The only other issue I have is that the instruction manual does not address the fact that the keyboard part is removable from the iPad section. Once I had figured that out I was over joyed. The device had suddenly become more free, the Case now lent itself to iPad gamers and rotational control, its a fantastic feature. Very nicely integrated and very user friendly, I just with I had been told. I put that down to a combination of my stupidity and a lack of direction, on reflection its rather simple, makes sense that the circular hold comes off however it is very well hidden, took me 3 days of use to figure that little Easter egg out.
In summary its a fantastic user friendly device with plenty of little features to make you feel that this is a device that took time and care to produce, its very wellexecuted. However, much like any product, there is room for improvement.

Where to start...

I have used a few capture cards over the last year - Avermedia Live Gamer HD, Elgato Game Capture HD and HD60 - so I do have a bit of experience on the positives and negatives of each.

The Live Gamer Extreme is a mixed bag, but I do like it for what I use it for - dual PC streaming.

The good:

1) It's small - nice and easy to unplug as needed and take it wherever.

2) Very little latency overall - pretty rare to see with as small as this is and not being an internal card.

3) Actually does 60 fps at 1080p as advertised.

4) Picture looks great.

5) Resolution options in the included software. I use some old consoles and use RGB cables, then HDMI out to send to the LGE, at which time I switch the software to use 4:3 video (1280*1024 in most cases) - so the pictures don't look stretched out. Works great.

Several things I'm not a big fan of though.

1) Limited options in the software. While I do include the video options in the above positive notes, there's not a whole lot else. Audio options are non-existent volume wise. If what you're using has relatively low volume, you'll need another program (in my case, Open Broadcasting Software - OBS) - to increase the volume of what you're playing.

2) The RECentral 2 takes a decent amount of resources to run, and Integration/usability with other software - like the above mentioned OBS, can be difficult, and take some CPU to run - likely because since this is not a PCIe card, it's more taxing on your CPU to run this than an internal card, like a Live Gamer HD.

3) It's an unadvertised nightlight. The LGE, when left plugged in, has such a bright blue light that it lights up my room at night. Which means I have two options. Either I need to remember to cover the light up at night before I go to bed, or unplug the LGE from the USB port of my computer. I turn my computer(s) off when I go to bed, and even with the computer OFF it still leaves the light on. I could see that as OK my computers were in my living room, but since they're near me in my room, I don't have that option. Having an off switch for that would be handy.

4) Integration with other programs, like OBS: While you can easily change some options while using OBS and not the RECentral 2, like brightness, while playing at anything under 1080p and using OBS for the LGE, it's difficult to play at anything under 1080p - the LGE just gives an 'out of range' message. So if you're hoping to use the LGE and OBS without using RECentral 2, playing, say, an old game at 640*480, it is currently impossible without using RECentral 2. You're forced to use the included software and just have OBS capture the RECentral 2 window. That takes additional resources from your computer if it isn't very powerful. Pretty unnecessary.

5) Unlike most other streaming devices, there is no composite support for older game systems. Even if they generally don't look good, it'd still be nice to have it.

I have not tested the RECentral 2's ability to stream to places like Twitch etc, I can't see that as an option for myself. The software takes enough resources by itself without trying to stream to a website, which is why I usually leave it up to a program designed for that, like OBS.

Conclusion
While there do seem to be more negatives than positives, I do like it overall. The actual size of the LGE is nice and doesn't take a whole lot of room, but the unwanted night light is a bummer. The software, while it works, needs more customization for me to care much about it - there are some video options, but audio is seriously lacking - even a simple volume button, so most of my options have to be configured through other programs. Little to no latency means that in most cases, you probably can actually use the program to play a game on if you really needed to, but can get delayed the more things you have plugged into it. For instance: PS3 > HDMI Splitter > LGE is about a 1 - 1.25 second delay - so the HDMI out is a must in that case. While using the LGE for dual PC streaming, however, it works with very little delay - maybe 1/10th of a second - I just hope you don't have to play a game under 1080p.

On a side note, it would be nice to see Avermedia get a working forum for reply purposes so you don't have to wait for 24-48 hours for an email if you're having an issue. They've had the button at their US website, but I've never seen it work once. They can usually get your issue(s) resolved through email, but it's a slow process.

Bought this item for my Ipad Air recently purchased. I got the product quickly as promised, and installed it with the step by step instructions from the link provided. [...]

I've installed various other screens on my other PDA's. This product is unlike some of the other screen protectors as it requires the spray that comes with the product.

As I usually do, I turned the shower on to knock out the dust in the air, washed my hands and wiped the screen with the lint free cloth provided with the kit. I then removed the screen from the sheet and sprayed it down on the contact side with the spray bottle provided. I also gave a couple of sprays directly on the ipad's screen, and then placed the protector as per the instructions. With the rubber wedge provided, I squeegeed the remaining fluids, and I wiped the excess with a microfiber towel.

After completing the process, I couldn't wait and turned on my Ipad sooner than recommended. As the product hadn't fully dried, there was a slight rainbow effect. About an hour after use, the rainbow effect diminished and was completely gone a couple of hours thereafter. At first there seemed to be some spray residue on the screen, but the next day all residue and rainbow effect were completely gone and it was crystal clear.

I've now used this product for several days, and have noticed that it feels great. It has a little rubbery give, and makes the screen more scratch resistant than my other harder plastic screens. I would recommend this product, and at $2, it's an absolutely great value.

I am a System/Network Administrator with 39 years of IT experience, over 15 years of network experience, and almost two years of daily experience using the WAP4410N (version 1), and it is without a doubt the most unreliable wireless device I have ever used. My 2008 $49 Linksys WRT54GS router at home is far more reliable and never caused me a single access problem in almost three years of use.     Without any notice the WAP4410N loses contact with the LAN and will not pass traffic from it to the LAN, so the wireless device will make a wireless connection to the access point, but it will never receive an IP Address from the DHCP server.     The process is random and can happen anytime. All of the fixes that are offered over the years have only delayed the process. The loss of traffic flow can happen many times over a single day or even days on end.  Powering the device via AC Power or POE has no effect. Sometimes a reboot will fix the problem, sometimes a hard reboot (pull power) will fix the problem, sometimes nothing will fix the problem and I have to wait for the problem to disappear on its own.     What connects the WAP4410N to the LAN side has no effect, because I have had it connected to different devices (routers, switches), different brands (AdTran, Dell, and Cisco), different speeds (100Mbps, 1Gbps) and even a brand new Cisco 2960-S switch ratched down to 100Mbps/Full Duplex has had no effect.     I have installed every version of firmware that has been released, tried every configuration change (including using SSH to access the CLI and making changes to the configuration that way to bypass the web interface), and I have read every post including a massive two year old post on the Cisco Community forum with well over 1,800 entries all reporting the same problem.  Cisco released version 2 of the hardware last summer/fall with a crystal on the LAN port to fix a jitter problem with some 1Gbps switches, but the people who tried version 2 all reported that they had the same problem.   Even crazier the problem can go away for two or more weeks or even for up to four months and then one day it pops up again.   I highly recommend that you don't purchase this product, unless you want pain in your professional life.   As you can tell it happened again today, and this incident was the last straw. I will start a search for a reliable access point tomorrow. I will have to replace four (4) of these devices and even though the rest of our network uses Cisco for the core, it is very unlikely I will replace these access points with Cisco access points, at least not at this price point. If you decide to purchase the WAP4410N, my remark would be \\"Caveat emptor\\"  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  UPDATE Wednesday, August 31, 2011:  I updated our four WAP4410N Access Points to the latest firmware version (2.0.4.2) last week as recommended by Diana from the Cisco Small Business Team and one of access points failed this afternoon in the same identical manner that they all have been failing over the last three years.  I have sent an e-mail to the Cisco Small Business Team and I will post a follow-up if there is a resolution or a lack of resolution to this problem in September.  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  UPDATE Thursday, January 5, 2012:  This is my final follow-up on the WAP4410N. This last Fall (September 2011) Cisco replaced all of our WAP4410N hardware version 1 devices with version 2 devices. We continued to have problems with all of the WAP4410N devices until I changed their parameters as follows:  Force LAN Port Speed to 100M:  Enabled  Wireless Network Mode:  G Only  Key Renewal:  36000  All other parameters are set to factory default and the devices all have with a Static IP Addresses.  I have to say that Cisco attempted to solve the problem and they where very nice about replacing all of our hardware version 1 devices with version 2 devices, but finally the only way to stablize the devices was to limit their wireless capability to G only and limit their wired interface speed to 100Mbps.  The WAP4410N access points are all connected to Cisco 2960-S switches, which are 1Gbps switches, but in the past they have been connected to Dell and AdTran switches and they have always had the same problem.  I do have to thank Cisco for making an effort to fix the problem, but at this time we have budgeted to replace all of the WAP4410N access points with an Enterprise controller based system and will donate the WAP4410N access points to charity.

But for her, DSL at the cheapo lowest cost slowest speed works good, and considering this is a "smaller" community they are not going to be getting Uverse or having fiber run to the street corner for Comcast or AT&T,

There really aren't many choices when it comes to PC gamepads out there, and Logitech is the best bet. I would rate it with 5 stars, but I've gone through one in normal use already, so the design could be a bit more rugged. I'm about as hard as you can be on a gamepad since I'm a competitive street fighter 4 player so it wasn't any surprise when my D-pad went out after almost a year of abuse from my vigorous street fighting. The Logitech gamepads are very responsive and have great dual analogs and a button setup identical to the Playstation 2/3 controller (even the buttons on the analogs you can push in) which is great for all the recent console ports to PC like Devil May Cry, Resident Evil 5, and the fore mentioned Street fighter 4. Really it covers all of your bases and shouldn't give out on you like mine did unless you are inputting ridiculous fighting combos for hours on end.         Save yourself the headache of getting an Xbox for windows controller, Logitech is more responsive, and doesn't stop working for no reason without a fix to get it going again (The xbox ones do this) about the only drawback I can think of is that they are not wireless, but with the pricetag and horrible performance of the wireless PC gamepad options out there, you will forgive having to be tethered to a cord.    What are you waiting for? If you need gamepads for your PC then order a used set of these on amazon already. Pick up new ones if you plan on punishing them as much as a Street Fighter tournament contender.

Memorex=2minutes 4 seconds
SD Titanium=9.3 seconds
I guess I'm stuck with the Memorex, as it isn't the seller's fault it's a pig, but my advice is DON'T BUY IT unless speed is NO concern to you. If you don't absolutely have to have 1GB, get the Titanium.

I've been using this card for a few weeks now. Enough has been written about the 6870 GPU itself, so you'll believe me that so far it has run every game I threw at it perfectly (paired with a slightly outdated Core 2 Quad CPU), and I have no regrets.  The only thing that's slightly annoying (and I'm taking one star of the rating for it) is that the default fan settings are less than optimal. On an idle desktop the fan runs at 40%, which is already fairly loud. Under load, however, it spins up even more, producing a noise level that I consider almost unacceptable.  However, with a utility of your choice (I used MSI's Afterburner in Windows and the simple aticonfig command under Linux) you can customize the fan profile. And lo and behold, 20% fan speed is completely sufficient to maintain a low GPU temperature when idling, while 40-45% seems to be enough under load (when gaming for instance).  All in all, a great card with a small flaw (that can be corrected to some extent).

I tried getting it out with my finger nails but no way. I had to use a razor blade to get it out,being extremely carefull not scratch or damage the tablet in any way.
