Just received these a couple days ago and I was surprised to find that the box came with two PLS400's but no PLE400, I tried connecting them expecting them not to work without a \\"master\\" but very surprisingly they worked without a hitch.

So far I have been very pleased with them as they allow me to extend my network into a room where I needed exactly four more network drops. I've ordered a second set to see if I can add them to the network as well (hopefully one in my garage and one in an upstairs game room).

EDIT:
I ordered a second set of these and this set also did not include a PLE400 but they work amazingly! I plugged in one of them right when they came in and it synced immediately. It's worth mentioning that they are dual voltage (i.e. can work on US or European power grids, 110-240v) and they seem to work on different circuits. The one I plugged into my garage is on a different sub-distribution panel (it supplies power to my garage/laundry room/patio but is a different breaker box from my main house) and works perfectly fine. I was also very surprised that the one in my upstairs game room works even though it is connected to a transformer (converts European 220v power to US 110v), I am extremely pleased with these!

This product does exactly what it says it does: I can record HD (or SD) video using component (or composite or s-video) up to 1080p straight to my hardrive. Audio is captured using either stereo analog inputs or the optical input for Dolby Digital. I can then view the file using the included Arcsoft software, Windows Media player, etc. The recorded picture is exactly the same as the original; I can detect no degradation if high bit rates are used.     The included TV scheduler works fine too. I use the \\"record\\" function on my cable box rather than the IR blaster, though. This assures the correct channel is selected and prevents someone else from inadvertently changing the channel during a recording.    It records fine using my dual core 16 GHz laptop. However, since the Hauppauge encodes the h.264 files on the fly, they are quite large and I need a faster computer than this to watch the original videos. But, if I further process them, even retaining the original 1080p resolution, the files play fine on this computer. Processing is very time consuming though, so I got a WD TV HD Media player. The WD plays the original, full resolution files fine.    So, this is a great product, and combined with the WD TV HD Media player, I have a complete package to capture and watch HD TV from any source.

I was not sure if there was an issue between this memory and my laptop, but it created a number of issues for me. It continually caused Internet Explorer and Mozilla Firefox to error out. It also caused the Blue Screen of Death a couple of times as well. At first I thought the problem had been the laptop since I just purchased it, but after reinstalling the OEM 1GB memory, all of those problems disappeared, so it definitely was the OCZ memory.

This thing shorted and fried my Surface's battery. DO NOT BUY THIS. Heed my warning. Listen to the other bad reviews. It is not worth saving a few dollars for something that could ruin your Surface and might even burn your house down.

The first thing I discovered was that the metal tabs on the part that plugs into the wall were so thin that they wouldn't make contact with the outlet - it just slipped out with no resistance. Luckily that part from the original power supply still fits this "replacement". The magnet isn't nearly as strong as the original so it pops off the side quite often during any amount of movement. It doesn't quite fit as well physically, so it's tough to get lined up and attached in the first place. Another bad feature is the little white LED that indicates charging on the OEM is replaced by a bright white LED that says on all the time, even when the Surface isn't attached which I suppose is useful of you need a nightlight.

Less than a week after I bought this, I was just using my Surface as usual when the magnetic connector popped off the side, as usual. When I tried to put it back, it made a audible POP, a visible spark, and my screen went blank. It wouldn't turn on and didn't show any battery status. Nothing at all. I was pretty sure it had just turned my Surface into a paperweight.

After managing to get some functionality back from my broken OEM charger, I realized all was not lost and this malfunction had only shorted out and discharged the battery to 0%, not even enough for the low battery indicator, but luckily didn't fry the hardware.

I then contacted Microsoft and it turns out you can still get refurbished OEM changers directly from them. Do that. Don't buy this. You might lose the whole thing.

I would have purchased the Silicon Power A60 (1 TB) which has an added feature of being waterproof; but at the time of my purchase there was a big price difference between the A30 & A60. As of this review posting, the price difference is just a dollar. Essentially these (A30 & A60) are the same 2.5" HD. Inside the so called "armored" case is a Seagate / Samsung ST1000LM024 SATA II HD with a rotational speed of 5400 RPM & a 16 MB Cache.& made in China. Although the Silicon Power EHD itself are made in Taiwan.
The main casing is made of black hardened plastic ( not ABS plastic) with embossed honeycomb design on top & bottom surface and a frosted textured 1/2" border. The 6 orange knobs surrounding the A30 edges are made of silicone rubber which serves 2 purpose: 1] to hold the supplied USB 3.0 cable and 2] to serve as a shock or impact absorber in case you drop it on its edges. NOTE:If you drop this drive flat on its top or bottom plastic surface; good luck. As with any portable EHD, including this, take care not to just flop it on the table. Lay it down gently to avoid early HD death.
The A30 comes with 13" ( end to end ) USB 3.0 cable.with Male A terminals on each end. Either terminal ends of the cable could be plugged to the upper left edge of the A30's USB port, which is also backward-compatible with any USB 2.0 devices. BUT the data transfer speed would be slower using a 2.0 attachment or device. Also the A30 has no blinking LED lights unlike other mainstream EHD, although the A30 has 4 micro ( philips) screw slots on each corner of its bottom plate to access the drive itself. This is a plus compared to other mainstream EHD out there, where you have to pry their brittle plastic enclosure and may cause scratches or damage of the casing.
The A30 comes formatted in Fat32 and upon initial opening (not physically) of the drive on my PC, I found some files already in it, mostly warranty, registration links, icons, images, etc.which amounted to a few kilobytes. But when checking on the drive's Properties it showed only about 930 Gb of usable storage, and there's the missing 70 Gb. This is normal on EHD's. In general, for each gigabyte reported on the box, you'll have about 70MB less space when you plug it in—which means that your 1TB drive has closer to 900GB as measured by Windows. For 'Gigabyte Hungry' users, this might be an issue and reformatting the drive to NTFS would hardly make a difference (which I did).
As for data speed transfer, it's up there with other big name EHD (Seagate Backup Plus/ Solutions, Western Digital Passport Ultra) reaching up to about 120 MB/s write speed (hooked up on a USB 3.0 terminal on a PC}. All in all, this is one portable EHD hard to beat when it comes to price to performance - value ratio. As for durabilty - it all depends on the users habits in handling their portable drives. All drives, no matter what the brand is, gives up when handled roughly.ounted to a few kilobytes. About me: I'm a techie, using this for the small lab I have to manage. I run VMs and use multiple protocols. I manage this box myself and I'm an advanced user/sys admin.

It is weird to write, but I love this product. In every way. Yes, there are few problems from time to time. For example, one of the DSM updates caused my NFS performance to drop by 80% or something. Synology fixed that pretty quickly and if I'd paid more attention, I would have just waited a couple of more days before updating. Also, some of the software packages don't work so well, like Plex, but that's not why I bought this box anyway.

This has been a fantastic device for me in every way. I'm using VMWare ESXi in a lab and I am also using it for backups and serving music via iTunes as well. It's also my main VPN server via the OpenVPN packages. I have AFP, NFS, WebDAV, SMB all turned on and being used by the variety of Windows, Mac and Linux boxes in my lab. I used Seagate 3 TB drives.

After a year of usage, the thing has been rock solid. It makes my day to interact with the software and it makes my day every time I complete another project with this device.
I have about 50 VMs, with about 15 loaded and running at any one time. The performance has been stellar, I've never noticed any lag at all, and the CPU and Mem are always below maximum as reported by the web based GUI.

I can't say enough good things. I would never consider another NAS device for a small lab.

I tend to upgrade my PC a lot. Over the last three years, I've gone through a GTX 480 (so hot and loud), 2xGTX 460s in SLI (great bang for your buck but hot and loud), and 2x6970s in Crossfire (extremely loud and too many driver issues!).

For my latest build, I went with the GTX 670 because many review said it wasn't worth it to get a GTX 680 because it was only 5-10% faster. I am happy with the decision that I made. This card runs not too hot and is surprisingly close to silent in my Fractal Designs Define Mini case. The performance is faster than two of my 6970s in crossfire and doesn't have any compatibility issues. I've tested it with games such as Saints Row The Third, Borderlands 2, and many others and I rarely if ever drop under 60 frames per second (i7-3770k @4.20Ghz, 16GB RAM). What's best about this card is that if I were to upgrade monitor resolutions to greater than 1080p, it'll have enough video memory (4GB) to handle it.

I would definitely recommend this card!!!

Got this card Dec 1st and was thrilled to see that it had the bios switch. I plugged it into my rig and it was good to go. I flipped the switch and the shaders unlocked by themselves. I didn't have to do any thing but flip the little switch. Two of my friends also bought this same GPU, one off of the egg, and the other off of Amazon. Both of their GPUs unlocked exactly like mine did. For those of you who don't know it is located on the top of the card, by the crossfire connector underneath the plastic heat sink cover. Took me a while to find it, but it works great. For BF3 I run it unlocked and at 950/1350 @1120 in Sapphire's TRIXX software. This makes it so easy to turn it into a 6970 at $100 cheaper. At default high settings for BF3 I get 40-80 frames a second. Most of the time it is at 60, but when alot of things are exploding or falling down it drops to 40. Haven't seen it below 40 though. I also play WoW @ ultra and get great frames(60-100). Although WoW is more CPU limited than GPU limited, an upgrade to my processor will help my frames out alot. For $220 after rebate this card was a great purchase. I purchased this laptop after buying my Husband an Acer laptop about a year ago. That computer was a great price, and we bought it in a retail store. We both use our computers to play WoW and it runs perfectly on the \\"good\\" graphics setting.

This laptop is a slightly better model than our first one, and wasn't that much more expensive. The upgraded graphics card and audio output of this model is fantastic, a definite step up from last years purchase. I haven't had this specific laptop very long, but based on the other Acer we purchased, I expect this one to last a while also.

My only suggestion is to spend a couple hours when you first get it set up to delete all of the trash programs they pre install on these. That's my only complaint with Acer, and I'm sure it's part of what makes their machines so inexpensive, but it's really annoying trying to figure out why it's lagging and then realize there's about 40 background programs I have no desire to have on my computer running in the background. I also recommend uninstalling Norton and McAffee and downloading AVG free edition. :)

I own an Acer 725, which I like (AMD processor).  When I saw this model & price & it appeared to have a deal for Windows 8 upgrade, I bought/bit.  Actually, with Win 7 Starter the product is beyond slow.  Internet hangs, aps take eons to open & close & it is just very frustrating.  After many, many hours searching for solutions, I was even more upset.  This model & ALL Intel Core processors are not & will never be compatible with Win 8.  Furthermore, even if you try to upgrade to a better version of Win 7, Acer will NOT support your device, as it is not original OS.  I am not very computer savvy.  I would like to rely on companies to properly advertise and promote their products and maybe even make them user friendly.  This is more of an Intel issue, but Acer needs to be a a lot more open about the fact that this product cannot be upgraded & not warranted if you do. When ordering from this company (which sells through Amazon.com), be aware that they do not ship on week-ends, so next day or expedited delivery service means at least a week out.  They do not tell you this in thier promo.  I needed the product within two days, and paid for expedited delivery, only to find out it would be over a week before I would finally receive the product.  After contacting the company with a complaint about this, they did refund me the money I paid for the expedited delivery service. However I will not order from this company again, nor do I recommend it to anyone unless you are not in a hurry to receive your product.

This Phillips sleeve fits the I-Pad snugly, yet it is easy to slide the I-Pad in and out.     The envelope design of the sleeve with two velcro closures is practical.  The side with the flap that folds over is covered in a leather-like material with an additional filling that is firm and more substantial to protect the viewing surface of the I-Pad.  The other side of the sleeve is simply a stretchy material that allows for the ease of movement, BUT this side is not the same leather-like material. This factor was a surprise to me since I expected the same outer material to cover the entire product.  That being said, this Phillips sleeve does the job of protecting the I-Pad during travel which was the reason I purchased it.    When I bought this product on Amazon in early August, it was much more reasonably priced that it is now.  At the current listed price, I would also consider some of the other options that may be slimmer and made entirely of the same material.

When I bought this keyboard it was priced at $50, quite an attractive price considering that the same model is $80 at almost every other retailer. The board does exactly what I need it to, however my biggest issue was it's poor paint job, which is overlookable, but annoying.  Pros:  Lights - There are three colors of backlighting, as opposed to this board's near competitor - the Sidewinder X4.  Macros - The macros are easy to program, either on the fly or with Logitech's macro editing program.  Sound - Sound quality through the attached headphone jack is excellent for a keyboard.  Cons:  Poor Paint Job - The first thing I noticed when I pulled the keyboard out of the box was that the \\"J\\" key was a dark black, while the rest of the keys are a dark steel grey. Not too noticeable when it's on my desk, but it's the main reason I decided to review the keyboard. On closer inspection I also discovered that a few of the other keys are splotched, partly black, partly steel grey. It's almost like the final coat of paint didn't make it onto parts of the keyboard.  No Anti-Ghosting (though this was never advertised, so I wasn't expecting it) - You can press a maximum of four letter keys, haven't tested all the others. This is not an issue for me when gaming but it does pose a problem when I am using Ableton (music program) and need to press multiple keys for multiple notes.

The product description says, \\"Connect any 3.5\\" Serial ATA (SATA) or SATA II Hard Drive to your computer through an available USB 3.0 port on your desktop or laptop.\\" Well, I tried to connect my Hitachi Deskstar 3TB drive, and it didn't work. My PC only recognized it as a 2TB drive. I first thought it was a problem with the drive, but after doing some investigation, I confirmed with Sabrent that it only supports up to 2TB. This was purchased on the Amazon website but fulfilled via Tiger Direct, so I've got to contact them to return it. Hassle.    In addition, one other thing I really don't like about it is that the fan comes with a really bright blue light presumably to convey how effective the fan is in keeping the drive cool. I have my PC in the same room as my TV, and when I'm not using my PC, I keep my monitor off to keep the room dark. Unfortunately, there's this really annoying bright blue light that I can't get rid of.    On the positive side, it is very quiet and was easy to set up.    In sum, if you are using this for a 2TB or less hard drive and you don't mind a bright blue light, this enclosure should work fine for you.

We have the original Kindle (V2 w/ wifi & cell), a Kindle keyboard & a Fire in our family. The Paperwhite is my favorite by far. I read at night a lot & it's great to be free of the attached book light. The back-lighting is great & when turned way down in bed lets my wife get some rest while the insomniac reads. A bit easier on the eyes in a dark room than my iPad Kindle app - much cheaper too!

11/20/2013 UPDATE:

After a bit over a year of use, my 1st gen Paperwhite dropped off our home WiFi network & would only re-connect occasionally, & then for only brief periods. No change in our home network equipment or carrier. No problems connecting with other Kindles, iPads, laptops, phones etc... Tried every possible solution on Amazon & other forums w/ no success (reset Kindle & modem, firmware update for both, every setting under the sun scrutinized for Kindle & network....). I did however discover I'm not the only Paperwhite owner w/ this problem. Many others out there asking for help/ solution to this issue as well.

Finally, disgusted w/ lack of support/ fix & thinking the WiFi radio in my unit had died, I ordered a new 2nd gen Paperwhite. Unfortunately, this one had the same issue & I've returned it.

I have always been a big fan of Amazon's service & support. However, I've found their Kindle support structure sub-par. I guess I'll resort to loading books via USB from my PC until this has been fixed. Steer clear of Amazon's Paperwhite.

This is a SUPER-CLEAR film - NOT MATTE!!!  It's not as easy to apply as the Griffin or others, but once installed, it is crystal clear and nearly invisible. All of the other screen protectors I've used have some level of blurriness or a sparkly look to it. I highly recommend this as an economical way to get three well-cut crystal clear films. It will show fingerprints a little quicker than, for example, the Griffin Screen Care protector, but it's FAR easier to clean vs. matte protectors.  That said, it is VERY difficult to install without bubbles/dust/etc underneath. To do it properly requires two things:  1. A dust-free environment: I highly recommend doing this in a a bathrom after you've had a shower. This will reduce both the dust in the general environment and the dust/particles generated by your hair & skin.  2. VERY carefully line up the camera and the home button. Then push down one corner, lift up all of the rest, then start from that corner and work the bubble toward the opposite corner across the screen.  With this method I've applied 5 of these with only one small bubble on one of the iPads, which was on the border, not the screen. Good luck!

I'm a PC gamer. I meticulously assembled my PC with after market purchases of all high grade high value components. My rig is a dedicated gaming rig. My rig is highly tuned to the perfect balance of speed and stability. My OS is squeaky clean. I'm highly selective of my peripherals. That is why I purchased the Logitech Performance MX 7 years ago. It was the best wireless mouse in the market. With Windows 8.1 (UI/UX nightmare of an OS), the Logitech Performance MX struggled to communicate efficiently with the OS. The 125Hz polling rate and 1500DPI was simply too slow. It lagged, it jumped, it was stuttered both in and out of games.

It was time for a new mouse. It has to be wireless. It has to be a gaming mouse. It had to be fast and accurate. The G700S was exactly what I needed. With a polling rate of 1000Hz and 8200DPI, it performed literally 10 times better than the Performance MX. The difference was night and day. Everything, and I do mean everything is now completely fluid. ZERO lag. No stuttering, no choppy movements whatsoever. The weight, feel, and grip is drastically better. My only regret is not having upgraded sooner.

UPDATE: Use this with the Logitech G440 gaming mouse pad if you want the most exact and accurate mouse movements. Logitech engineers have tuned the lasers and optics on the G440. It makes a HUGE difference if you need pixel precision movements.

When I first got my Kindle Fire for Mother's Day 2012 my son got the Grey/Black one-- It was so great that I saw Amazon selling them for 9.99 and I bought 4 new colors.  This green is great -- I carry it everyday in my pocketbook and the protection if just FAB!!!

I was very excited to receive the opportunity to review this Kyasi New York 3-in-1 Ballpoint Pen at a reduced investment in exchange for my fair and unbiased review.
The quality of the pen is wonderful - it's well put together! I've seen similar pens that aren't threaded well or seem flimsy & this one is far from that!
The pen writes very well which is important to me. It's doesn't leave inky spots or leave me hanging without a consistent flow of ink.
The stylus is perfect because it's not a sticky rubbery tip so it glides easily across the screen of my phone as well as my tablet.
The laser pointer has given me some great pleasure in playing with my puppy - I haven't had a need for it in the office just yet but I'm sure it will draw attention to the presentation just as it has for my pooch.
I recommend this pen as a gift for the professional in your life or as a treat to yourself!

On Amazon site, it claims    Windows® 7/Windows Vista®/Windows XP (with Service Pack 2 or higher)   Intel Dual-Core 1.6 GHz or higher and 1 GB of RAM (recommended: Intel Dual-Core 3.0 GHz or higher and 2 GB of RAM)   1.5 GB free space   CD-ROM   USB 2.0    I bought it and find the driver does not support xp64. First off, let me state that this is an excellent laptop for any user.  It has any basic requirements that a casual user would want such as: wireless internet, easy-to-use mouse pad,  fast start up speeds, DVD/CD player and recorder, and a beautifully sized screen.  For the more advanced user it is also more than suitable comprising of 4 GB of RAM, 300 GB of hard drive space, and a 64-bit CPU.  Not only all does it contain these features, but it is extremely simple to set up.  Dell makes an excellent laptop.  All the parts run smoothly and placed into a very durable shell that comprises the Dell Inspiron laptop.  Not only does it look great, but with the the new Windows 7 operating system this computer runs faster than ever before.  I have owned this laptop for over a year and half and have still yet to come up any issues involving my laptop.  The only downside i have to this laptop is the battery life.  After about a year of usage the battery life seems to start dropping more rapidly than most other laptops do.  Other than the battery life, this laptop contains all the specifications most anybody would be more than pleased with and for the price this laptop is the best buy in the market place.

I got them as a gift for my birthday. I loved the sound and mic quality while gaming. And continued to use them for almost a year... until they snapped into two pieces. I managed to get the warranty replacement before it expired and got a new one which I am currently have been using for a good year. This time I found the critical problem with this headset: There is this small plastic seam across the phone connectors. Right now, there is a clear sign of the plastic connection stretching (it looks whitish). I don't know how long these will last, but I will be very careful with them. Get them if you want, but be very careful with them, and check the warranties with these.

Update 31/12/2014:
After a few more months of wear, the headphones are about to snap. The white spots (signs of plastic stretching) are now on both sides of the headset. I am gonna try to melt some of that plastic with a soldering iron to make it last a bit longer, but I doubt it will last long. Sound and mic are still in top shape, but I have decided to reduce the rating of this product. For only lasting a year, I cannot recommend it. but i will give it a point for the good sound and mic (sound is dolby digital 7.1, c'mon).

Love the ZBOX. For an HTPC it works perfectly. Slapped 4 gb of ram into it and installed Linux on a thumb drive. Took a bit of work to get HDMI working but it's all set now. Also read about noise issues, I can't hear the fan unless I press it onto my ear, and that's at full speed. The box looks slick, is tiny and lightweight and packs a punch. Would buy again in a heartbeat.
Quick delivery. Item as described.

WNDR3700V2 - Bought March 2012 - Despite some years ago a previous Netgear Router(WPN824) starting to drop service after just over a year, and necessitating the reversion to the D Link DI-624, it was meant to replace, thought would try Netgear again.

Setup was not quite as straightworward as would have hoped and eventually got it up and running within an hour.
Wireless connectivity was great and an improvement on the DI-624.
Problems arose when connected a storage device (Seagate Freeagent Go Flex 500GB - on the Netgear 'compatible' list for this Router) to the USB port. It originally worked but was incredibly slow and then on about the third time of use it could not be found. Following which the wire connection to a laptop on a docking station failed to work - the laptop on the docking station could 'see' the Router but not the network or internet, other wired computers were fine and turning the wireless on (and then off) on the docking station laptop resolved the problem. But it occurred every time the laptop was undocked/docked. The USB storage could still not be accessed from any computer.
OK so it probably has something to do with the laptop being taken back and forth on and off the docking station, and if all it had required was a reboot of the laptop each time then that could have been lived with but with paying extra and the USB not working, it is going back before being stuck with it and the (almost ten years old now) DI-624 is back in service.

This case is nowhere near as good as the other case I have which is not made by Gumdrop.  It Otter fit as good as the "other" case I have but it just doesn't, and to think this one cost a lot more.  The screen protector is a joke.  It doesn't fit tightly against the screen so whenever you tap on it, you get that annoying clicking sound that shows that the cover isn't snugly fit on to the screen.  It makes it annoying when playing something like Clash of Clans.  I'm going to have to remove it.  Removing the screen will make me happy because the case is a nice rubber feel and I feel confident that it will absorb the shock of an accidental fall, but still the case has issues.  The case doesn't feel solid, and when you pick up the tablet you hear (and feel) that annoying creaking sound as if the case isn't 100 percent fitted.  This is a nice looking case and again the rubberized feel gives me confidence, but it is most definitely not worth the money.  They are charging a premium price for a product that has a long way to go.

Hi Dell Users with a \\"really bad connection\\"...
My new\\"ish\\" Dell 1545 had a connection problem. There are 2 pieces to the A/C adapter, the one that has the rectangle box and inserts into your laptop for power and the 2nd piece which plugs into the rectangle box and then goes out to the A/C - electrical outlet. Well, the first piece that plugs into the computer - the wire failed, broke apart from the plug side,AGAIN.

It is imnportant to get a new adapter so you are not moving the cord around trying to hit the spot where you can see it is really charging your machine... when the wire goes bad you are jangling the connection cord all around like crazy trying to keep your computer powered up. Well, my cord came apart - it literally broke away from the \\"plug\\" part that you insert into the computer. BTW, if you keep jangling this cord around to get juice, you will eventually screw up the plugs' receptor on the \\"inside\\" of your computer; and no one, repeat no one will repair/replace that internal receptor. How do I know this you ask? The A/C adaptor to my previous Dell 600m broke the same way this A/C adapter broke... Tried to have it fixed after all it is a cord connection issue - wouldn't electrical tape work??? The wire/cord attachment of the adapter) couldn't be fixed. So I bought a new A/C adapter for my 600m (really expensive laptop) and by that time the interior receptor was loose, almost broke and no A/C adapter cord/piece would stay inside the laptop and power it!!! I was totally bummed, all my stuff was on that laptop.

So here I am with my 1.5 - 2 y.o. Dell 1545 and the SAME DARN THING HAPPENS AGAIN!!! I look all over the net and what should I find??? Zillions of people with the same problem!!! What a surprise. It's not just me, it's not just the way I use my laptop, or the way it is situated in relation to where/how the A/C plug fits into the computer - is your wire straight coming out the side? Does it make a turn around your computer in the back or front to reach your electrical outlet, etc....

The problem is the totally rotten vendor Dell uses for this A/C Adapter. Since this is such a well documented problem, I cannot for the life of me understand why Dell does not, can not or refuses to listen to their customers and improve the manufacture of this vital part of our laptops??? Totally beyond my comprehension. This incredibly irritating problem - alone - may make this my 3rd and final Dell machine.

Now, onto the seller of the new A/C Adaptor: GREAT, it is actually the perfect part, it is plugged in and my laptop's battery is 100% charged and I am working from the actualy electrical outlet, not draining down my battery while the machine cannot be charged and I have to turn off my computer ;-((( The price was reasonable, the new A/C Adaptor has the same wattage, the piece/round plug like thingie is a hexagon shape vs. the usual round plug and my laptop is once again usable whenever I want. Kudo's to the supplier of this part. No tricks, no frustrations, plain and simple - it is the right part for the job and it took a few days (I was waiting with baited breath for its arrival), but it really, actually works! 100% - you can buy this part from this supplier and get what you need!!!n the back or front to reach your electrical outlet, etc.... I love these speakers.  Not only are they incredibly inexpensive, but the sound quality sounds exceptional to me. Granted, I am not a 'hardcore' music listener, so I couldn't say if they would be good enough for someone wanting *the best* sound quality. However, I can't hear a difference between these and my roommate's high-end speakers.  I mainly use them to watch movies, listen to music, and voicechat online, and usually keep both the subwoofer and the master volume at about 60%, which is more than enough (max volume is MUCH too loud for my small room).  I had no problems setting them up, and splitting the cord between the speakers gave me sufficient room to space them out.  The volume control feels slightly flimsy but is easy to use and I haven't had any problems with it.  All in all, I would recommend them to anyone without hesitation.

Does what it says.  Turns your old GoFlex into a USB 3.0 device.  I actually used it to convert my GoFlex Home into a GoFlex Desk unit. The reason why it is rated 4 stars instead of 5 is because of how THIN the base is.  The GoFlex fits directly on it, so there is no extra to the base.  It is not very sturdy.  I recommend placing it somewhere on your computer desk where you will NOT be working or moving.    Additionally:  Some devices do not recognize this as a USB 3.0 dock.  I have an ASUS RT-68R router that will accept this device as a USB2.0 device but not as USB3.0.  I tested the dock on my computer to ensure it is read as a 3.0 and it is.  So maybe this might be my router. Ultimately I resolved this by using a different external hard drive on the router, however I wanted to input this information in case others run into the same problem.

I had no trouble setting this drive up with my network (buffalo router with tomato firmware) of Vista, server2003 and XP machines.  I only used the driver disk to set up the device on one machine and just mounted the drive through the network on the others.  I had no problems with any firewalls.    The ishare internet sharing ability is a nice touch but is limited to just one file at a time.  It would be nice to be able to grab a whole folder and upload it from the internet.  It would also be nice to have some monitoring abilities to see when/if someone is accessing the drive from the internet.  As it is, when I hear the drive tick or click I know someone is getting the file I left for them.    I've had the drive plugged in and operational for two months now without a glitch.  I am somewhat concerned with the heat.  I had a 250gb drive fail recently (not a simpleshare) and the data loss was devastating.  Heat wasn't the cause but in reading about drive recovery I learned that heat is not good for drives.  We'll see how long this drive lasts.  I plan to attach a 500gb usb drive to the NAS and mirror the contents for backup purposes.    Overall I am happy with the drive and think the price, especially here on amazon, was spectacular.  A NAS for a few bucks more than the cost of the drive!

I purchased this item because it has an individual on/off switch for each port.  And inexpensive.  But one port failed within one month, and the remaining 3 viable ports do not recognize USB 2.0 devices.  It's too late for returns now, so I'm just using it for PC cooling fan.  A $8.99 lesson, I guess.  Pay a decent price when you want an electronics appliance that works.

This is the second time I've used Kingston SSDs for a personal build. The first time I was building a workstation from scratch, but this time I was replacing an old HDD with an SSD so I needed to use the cloning feature.  I was able to successfully clone a 500GB drive, with only 170GB used, onto this 240GB SSD.  The included cloning software worked perfectly and was very easy to use.  The partitions re-sized automatically.  After the cloning was complete I went into the BIOS and selected the new SSD as the primary boot drive, and it booted successfully on the first try.  The experience of adding the second drive, cloning the old drive then discarding it, and using the new SSD could not have gone more smoothly.  I have more than 50 Kingston SSDs at work, which is why I did not hesitate to buy Kingston for my personal use.  Performance? Yes they are fast, you will like them especially if you are replacing a conventional HDD.

I purchased this Verbatim 16 GB flash drive last year and wrote a number of files to it without a problem. Nearly a year went by before I used it again, but this time the computer would not recognize it. I plugged it into another computer, but it didn't recognize the flash drive either.

I also purchased the 4 GB model which works just fine.

WARRANTY:
Since it was still under warranty, I decided to submit a claim via the Verbatim website. I received an email reply one or two working days later with directions to get the computer to recognize the flash drive. When that didn't work, Verbatim requested my contact information and the receipt.

After customer service provided an RMA, I mailed the defective flash drive. Soon after, I received a brand new flash drive in the mail... about two weeks in total duration from when I submitted the claim.

This is only the second time I can recall returning a product under warranty and I am satisfied with the outcome. The process worked well, with no delays and no run-around. So 5 stars for Verbatim's customer service.

RED FLASHING LIGHT:
I also am pleasantly surprised that the new flash drive includes a red activity light. The original one didn't light up. I suspect this is a new feature since the 4 GB flash drive that is working doesn't light up either.

PROS:
- Verbatim lived up to their warranty with no fuss and no runaround.
- The brand new replacement flash drive works just fine and has 4 years left on the warranty.
- The new flash drive has a red indicator light.
- It has a slider instead of a cap which can get misplaced.
- The opening for a key chain is big enough.

CONS:
- I had to mail the defective drive back, but I'm satisfied that Verbatim made good on their warranty.

TIP:
- I don't always keep receipts and warranty information, but it's not such a bad idea, especially for bigger purchases..

I use this SD card in a Samsung Galaxy S3.  There have been some reports of problems with larger SD cards, but I have not yet experienced any problems.  Transfer rates are quite good when moving files to the card, and video plays back without any problems whatsoever.

This is a review of the Eye-Fi 8GB Pro X2 SD card [[ASIN:B002UT42UI Eye-Fi Pro X2 8 GB Class 6 SDHC Wireless Flash Memory Card EYE-FI-8PC]]  I also have a 4GB Eye-Fi that I had fewer issues with, so I think that this card or this version of the card is buggy.  Cons:  - Camera (Nikon D7000) shows a card error occasionally. Pulling the card and reinserting corrects the problem. Since the card error locks up the camera until you clear it, I can't rely on this card to let me take that once-in-a-lifetime shot as the camera may lock up unexpectedly.  - Desktop software is awful. I delete files from the desktop software interface, and they don't go away. When you open a thumbnail, you see a relatively small photo with no options to zoom, see exif data, etc. If you click the \\"i\\" button, you see a map and the option to open the photo using other software. Why even bother showing me the photos in the software if you can't do anything with them - just show them in the operating system.  - Transfer is erratic. This problem also exists in the 4GB card I have. You may need to cycle power on your camera to get the card to \\"wake up\\" and send its photos to the net. This problem occurs on both my cameras.  - Ad-hoc network transfers were erratic and error prone. In ad-hoc mode, my phone frequently lost connection with the card and re-initialized wifi search. There is no option to configure where files are stored using ad-hoc mode on the phone, so they quickly fill the internal memory, making this option basically useless.  - There is no way to configure enterprise or gateway type wifi networks that require multiple authentication steps or user name + password.  - The card draws a lot of battery power from your camera.  - The web site does not let you group photos for different clients and provide access on a per user/group basis. It simply groups them by date and you can share a simple link to show photos, but only links within a date group. If you want to share links from differentdates, you must send multiple links.  Pros:  + The concept is great, and when it works, the option to not pull cards to upload pics is nice.  + It usually works as a regular SD card.  + The web site does allow you to multi-select photos and packages them into one zip for downloading.  If I can correct the card error problem, I will live with the other shortcomings, all of which have workarounds. It's too bad this doesn't work as well as promised, as the concept is really nice.

I wanted to use this to get an old IDE DVD Writer connected to my new PC that only has SATA on the motherboard. I plugged the power into the board, the board into the writer, the board into the PC (via the IDE HDD -> SATA Host port) and gave power to the writer. Booted up the computer, and nothing. I went into the device manager and under Other Devices I saw a device with a garbled name comprised of random unicode characters. Windows said the device was working properly but gave no other information. I restarted my computer and this time it displayed correctly and showed that it had my old copy of Ghost in the Shell (I wondered where that was) in the drive. It played fine, I tested it with a few other DVDs and those all played fine. It seems to be fine after several reboots. Bottom line is that it does work, but I will consider this a temporary solution until I acquire a proper SATA drive.

This is my first Kindle purchase so I can't speak to the pros and cons of the evolution of the Kindles. I am an avid reader but a traditional one. I dislike reading on an electronic device rather than a real book. While there is no replacement for the real thing..the look, feel, cover,etc, the Kindle Voyage makes me honestly forget that I'm using an electronic device which is pretty darn amazing. I broke down and splurged on this because a lot of books are starting to come out only on e-books/kindle formats or it takes years for a paperback version of it. My public library, has a vast collection of books and does have e-book checkout now however there are still many books not available through my public library and our interlibrary program doesn't always gets the books I want (not really the library's fault though). I also purchased on Prime Day for 40% off a 2-year Kindle Unlimited subscription. Without the Prime Day deal I would not have purchased the 2-year subscription maybe just the 6 month one. In order for me to use my Kindle Voyage to the fullest it was really required to get the Kindle Unlimited subscription since a good number of books I read were available via Kindle Unlimited (really the subscription pays for itself if you consider buying just a few books on Kindle). I would also say a case for the Kindle Voyage is a must. I can see where the PagePress might accidently be touched in error if holding the Voyage without a case. I also think the case make the experience more like reading a book for me at least. I bought the "Fintie Kindle Voyage Slim Fit Folio Premium PU Leather Book Style Case Cover with Auto Sleep/Wake (will only fit Amazon Kindle Voyage 2014), Navy"-(currently at $13.99) and it works very well and is comfortable to use with the Voyage. The auto sleep/wake function is just awesome. Me being left-handed I really love the feature of the PagePress. Ultimately the PagePress and auto-brightness setting (which I use all the time) are why I chose the Voyage over the newest Paperwhite (not sure if I would have noticed the 0.9 oz difference in weight). I do agree with others that the price is a bit steep (I paid $219.00 as I chose the Voyage without the special offers which only cost $20 to do and seemed worth it to make my experience less intrusive) and that would be my main gripe about it. Still ultimately this is a great device and if anything doesn't turn out right I will update my review :)

I had read many of the negative reviews, then some of the positive. I decided to purchase this cover based on the arguments in the positive reviews. It seemed that most of the negative comments were due to a lack of understanding of the product.   Some of those negative comments:  1. Very thin (Yes, that is correct. However, thin equals lightweight in this case, as well as not adding bulk to the Kindle Fire.)  2. Plastic - seems cheap. (IMO, the plastic has a high tech look and feel to it. It is the lightly rubberized/matte plastic that you see in many iPhone covers. I'm very pleased with its appearance. Comments that I received when I showed it around were all positive.)  3. Difficult to insert the Kindle Fire into the cover. (I read the instructions and placed one edge in first. The other edge easily clipped in with no effort. Incidentally, the clips do NOT impinge on the front of the Fire at all, leaving the entire face uncovered. I like that aspect quite a lot.)  4. Cheap elastic band to hold cover closed. (I do find the elastic a bit awkward to use. You reverse it whey you go from closed to open. Cheap? It seems sturdy and adequate for the job.)  5. The slot to hold the cover in place when you turn it into a stand doesn't work. (It actually works great when the Fire is in the cover. I'm pretty impressed with the minimalist design. It does look like it won't work, but does its job great.)  So....  I am very impressed with the cover. It's a fine bit of very successful industrial design - simple and functional. I recommend this cover for purchase if you're looking for sleek, understated, high tech look, and functional.

I bought this for my Mum for her Christmas because I wanted something that was small enough and light enough, but had a decent sized screen and a full sized keyboard. It will be her first laptop so I didn't want to spend a lot of money this time.    I received the Acer 2 days after I ordered it, which was great. I'm now playing around with it and setting it up for her before she comes next week. I hadn't used Vista or Windows7 before and I wasn't too hopeful but so far I've been impressed. It seems very stable and quick to boot up and shutdown. I have a very expensive Dell laptop for work, and all this weekend when I've wanted to use the internet I've actually used the Acer as its faster than the Dell.    Battery life seems very good so far.... single charge and more than 5 hours and counting on this first charge. Despite the very low price it doesn't feel cheap. My girlfriend has a Acer Aspire one, which she bought for 350USD a few months ago, and for the extra 50USD, there is no comparison.    The only negatives I had read in reviews was the mousepad but so far I've found it to be quite nice. The proof of the pudding will be whether my Mum can use it, so we'll reserve final judgement on that till she's played with it for a while.    I would have a really, really hard time convincing myself to spend any more money on a laptop after using this Acer for a few days. I work in the semiconductor industry so there's a kind of conflict here for me.... it's great you can get this functionality for this price, but it makes my job a lot tougher !

Over all, when I first purchased this computer, I was very happy. It is one of the few 14\\" light weight computers that offer an optical drive and finger print identification which I love. As others have mentioned, the volume keys are right next to the internet key, and I have frequently inadvertently turned the internet connection off... this is very annoying to have to wait to re-log-on when you have a lot to accomplish in a short amount of time. This is a very poor design flaw, and clearly indicates the product was not adequately people tested before producing it. Seems like a no-brainer that having these keys side by side is a bad idea. The second major problem initially was that because the key labels are red, they are very difficult to see. Good lighting is a must especially when you are trying to avoid inadvertently pressing the internet key thereby disconnecting the internet. Lastly, and more importantly, the computer just stopped working entirely last week. After taking the computer to my campus IT (who were at least as confused as I about what the problem was), after trying to reboot and trying to re-load windows (because windows wasn't being detected) found that apparently the hard drive cannot even be detected. This is very bad... So, as we all know, this means I will need to spend exorbitant amounts of time in phone jail with HP reps who will forward me to multiple individuals and who (because English is not their first language) will be difficult to understand, and will also have a hard time understanding the gist of what I am saying as well. I can also likely count on this being an extremely time consuming process during a time when I don't have this kind of time to waist. I purchased this computer specifically because I am writing my dissertation, and my prior computer was getting old. I didn't want to take the chance that my old computer might crash, and I might then lose all my dissertation work. As it turns out, my old computer might have been a better gamble, because although this computer is brand new (purchased in June 2012), I lost all my work anyway. So, on top of the time I am likely to spend in phone jail with HP, I also must try to re-write material I was trying to avoid losing (and having to re-write) by purchasing this computer. What a tangled web we weave... I will update you when I get a resolution, but I don't look forward to the battle ahead with HP.

Pros:
Finger print log on (not often offered on light weight computers)
Optical drive included (not often offered on light weight computers)
Light weight
Fast

Neutral:
Audio superiority- It is not a noticeable difference

Cons:
Volume keys right next to internet key causing multiple inadvertent internet disconnections
Red key board littering makes seeing the keys extremely difficult
Computer hard drive crashed and is not even detectable now (computer only purchased 3.5 months
ago)
Too much bloat-ware

We've only had our Kindle a little over a month and I must say it's a neat way to read a book.  It's great for traveling in the car or airplane.  The device is small in size, but larger than a cell phone and easier to find, especially in the bottom of a purse or bag.  Page turning is quick and the display is crisp and easy to read.  Downloading of books were quick, but you do need to be able to access wi-fi, which is not always convenient or easy when traveling.  I can see future generations where you don't need to purchase a separate device with a light for night reading and damage protection.  We have a lot more to learn of its other capabilities, but if you're an advid reader, especially one that is on the go or waiting for children to finish ball or cheerleading practice, this is the perfect gadget for you.

Update April 24, 2013: I'm still using this case to protect my iPad2 and it continues to look great! The only minor issue I have is that if you don't pay attention, the little blocks/slots embedded in the case to allow you to adjust the angle of the iPad2 slip more easily than when the case was new, but it's more of an annoyance than a true problem.

Update October 26, 2011: I'm still using this case on a daily basis and it's holding up great! I'm very protective of it, but it still looks new and the elastics are holding up just fine. Coworkers keep asking where I bought my case :). I accidentally dropped my iPad2 from the edge of a table, but it was in the cover and fortunately fell flat, parallel to the floor. My iPad2 remained intact and continues to work well.

I should point out first that the case I received is not the case shown in the picture at the top of this page. The case I received does not have a small button clasp thing on the front of it. Instead, it stays closed because there are small round magnets lining the edge of the case. This also serves to put my iPad into sleep mode whenever I close the case.

I've had this case for two months now and these are some thoughts based on my experience using it daily:

PROS:
This case looks very professional and all my coworkers asked me how much it was and where I bought it. Unlike other reviewers, I had no trouble using all four viewing angles without it falling over. I am also able to use the camera that faces me easy and it is very easy to put my iPad into the case or take it out whenever I need to. When I use my other (skintight, not folio/stand) case, I definitely miss the ability this case has to angle my iPad towards me and keep it stable so that I can actually use it.

CONS:
If your ipad is jailbroken and you use the SBsettings menu/toggle, the edge of the case that holds the iPad snug covers up the very top status bar of the iPad. This makes it difficult to activate that menu using the default swipe action. I was also worried about scratching or denting the edges of my iPad, since this case does not provide any protection for them. To this end, I bought a thin skintight case for my iPad with the hope of using that to protect the edges while it was in this case. But, this case holds the iPad so close that it does not fit even with such a thin cover. Also, the elastics that hold the two corners of the iPad in place so that it doesn't move feel secure even after two months, but i dont know how long they'll last.

OTHER THOUGHTS: I'm not sure what the red accented elastic running down the side of my case is for. My best guess is that it is for holding papers.

Overall, this is a really sleek-looking case that is very useful if you're tired of finding random items to prop up your iPad2.

I got this headset to use for voice chat for gaming. I wanted the single ear style so that I could still hear what was going on around me and so I could pipe the game music and sound effects through my speakers and hear voice chat through the earpiece. It's worked out great! The headset is flexible and feels like it's made out of high quality materials. The earpiece has good sound and as for the microphone, my chat partners tell me they can hear me loud and clear. The headset also has a crazily long cord, and I've often ended a gaming session with wire draped all over me and wrapped around my chair. The long cord would come in handy if you're actually intending to use this for internet telephone calls. There's also a volume control with a mute button built into the cord. The control also has a clip so you can clip it to your clothes and adjust the volume easily without going to the computer. I'd recommend this to anyone looking for a microphone headset.

i've been pleased with this router, except for two issues :

1) The first one quit working after a few months, so I had to send it to Netgear for repair/replacement. (I actually bought a second one waiting for the repaired/replaced unit to arrive, because I couldn't handle the downtime.)

2) I do not trust the Readyshare USB port. I have had some trouble using two different companies' backup software, one hard drive, and a couple of flash drives--generally working, but with occasional errors very difficult to diagnose.

Check what Netgear says on their website regarding this Readyshare port : [...] : \\"All Routers should work with most USB-compliant external flash and hard drives. Do NOT connect computers, USB modems, printers, CD or DVD drives to the router's USB port.\\"

The website shows 11 hard drive models and 12 flash drive models as working with the WNDR3400--in other words, almost none !

One of their tech support people told me \\"Only those devices that are available in the compatibility list will work with the WNDR3400 NETGEAR router.\\"

A primary reason to buy this router over another model is the USB port, which I intended to use for NAS !

Most annoying.

**Update** a prior problem I had using the ReadyShare port I finally traced to a defective flash drive. Once bitten, I have not again tried a flash drive. I am using a hard drive on this USB port and all is well since.

So, I make it 4 stars instead of 3.

I have now experienced multiple data loss events with this drive.  I knew I was in trouble after about 2 months when checkdisk ran on boot.  I had to reinstall 2 applications after that.  Knowing that complete failure may not be far behind, I made sure I kept current with backups.  A week or 2 later, a boot file corrupted, and my laptop running drive encryption meant I could not recover an individual file.  Contacted Kingston and was told, \\"oh yea, you need to update the firmware on the drive\\".  Did that and restored the drive.  Within the month, complete drive failure.  Returned to Kingston and they replaced it.  This time I would not put it back on my system, just can't afford the downtime and potential data loss.  Put in my wife's laptop which is only used for internet access.  Two months of use there and dead again.      STAY AWAY - and God help you if you already own it.

What garbage! The router worked for four days before I started experiencing dropped packets and disconnects from my ISP. I bought this router because it has four ethernet ports. I need one for my printer, one for my server and one for my VOIP phone. For the first three days I was very happy. I get a full 15Mbps transfer rate when I'm the only device connected but as soon as my wife starts watching Internet videos while I'm working (either wireless or wired), the router starts dropping packets. Pings to a first-hop DNS server go from 30mS to 400mS and more. Some times pings go to 2000 mS which is just unacceptable.

Of course, there's no way for ME to update the firmware on the router --- that's left to the ISP (Time Warner Cable) to handle so there's absolutely nothing I can do to fix the problem on my side.

Again, it doesn't matter if I'm connected wired or wireless. The problem happens on all devices. I should have just gotten the forty dollar off-brand wired-only router and hooked up a DDWRT wireless access point.

UPDATE:

I took the router back and got a new one. Same problem. What complete garbage. This thing can't handle Netflix (or any streaming content for that matter) without everyone on the entire network -- wired OR wireless -- from suffering. Packet loss is in the 5% range which is totally unacceptable. VOIP is almost unusable because every five seconds I get terrible jitter and have to ask the other person to repeat what he just said.

Pings to Google's name server at 8.8.8.8 increase by a factor of TWENTY. One hop pings to my ISP go from 9ms to 520ms and slower.

Get this: Using the router's diagnostic PING utility stops everyone else from initiating ANY new traffic whatsoever. The router won't even ping Google. It actually drops ALL pings. My ten year old Cisco DSL router was far superior to this piece of junk.

I had purchased this laptop directly from Sony about two years ago.  Immediately I noticed that the fan is loud!  A fresh boot, wait your four minutes for everything to load and the fan is just noisy.  After a while you kinda got used to it.  The second thing is the keyboard would stop functioning after a reboot.  No lights, no buttons, nothing worked.  To fix, I had to close the lid to sleep mode.  Then reopen the lid and wake up computer, to find that the keyboard now works fine and all lights are working also.  The last thing was the screen is now black.  After some research, two different techs examined it (one at the Sony Store) and both said to replace the motherboard.  The video chip is broke, so the whole board needs to be replaced.  I've 'googled' new boards and cant seem to find a replacement board online.  The Sony Store said I could send it in for repair and that a motherboard repair is considered a 'major' repair, its minimum $300, no parts.  At this point it just be cheaper to buy a new, cheap laptop for that and buy an extended warranty to cover future breakdowns.  Or just consider building a desktop.  Either way, $1000+ laptop, worthless.

This charger was truly a godsend. My pet chewed through the cable of Dell Inspiron M5030. The cable still worked fine though the drive to replace it came when I unplugged the laptop and the powerpin that goes in the laptop touched the site of the chew causing the cable to spark. Normally when I need to replace a new power cable, I'll buy a brand new one from the manafacturer or by a Targus adapter. This time I didn't want the Targus adapter because they have alot of connectors, I mean alot, so much that I would lose the right connector in the sea of connectors and I really didn't feel like giving Dell a ton of money for a brand new adapter. So I took a chance and deicided that maybe Amazon would be a good place to buy a cable. So I searched and found this one. It was cheap, too cheap to someone used to paying at least $80+ for one normally but I took the plunge and haven't been dissapointed ever since. The adapter works and looks great and seems sturdy. I also like the fact that it has an 18 month warrenty. Me being a brand loyal consumer means I will probably be a customer for life should I ever need a new adapter, which knowing myself may be very soon when the Surface tablet comes out..

I work as an architectural engineer in AutoCAD and Solidworks all day.  Because of the nature of my work, I do a LOT of zooming/panning.  I am only 25 and I was starting to worry that I was not going to be able to keep mousing much longer without giving myself a nice pile of carpal tunnel.  After trying some different mouses, including the oddball Perific, I stumbled on this mouse.    All of my problems are gone.  If the scroll wheel is your archnemesis on a daily basis with what you do on a computer, buy this mouse immediately, even if it puts your bank account into the negative.  Zooming and panning are now effortless and much more elegant.  Modeling large scale objects (corporate skylights in my case) is now a breeze.    In short, for CAD users the freewheeling scroll wheel is an indispensable addition to your selection of input devices.  This more than makes up for any shortcomings this mouse has.  Also, you can completely disregard any reviews that complain about not enough programmable functionality in the included software.  UberOptions is a free modification you can find easily on the web that more than makes this mouse as customizable as you want it to be.  Do yourself a favor, and go get this mouse!

I purchased for replacement of the built-in optical drive in a 2009 Mac Mini, which operates sporadically at times (discs don't always appear on desktop).  The SE-S084D will work for simple burning of CDs and DVDs, if that's all you want.  However, it will not display icons needed for starting Mac programs on some important discs.  It will not display all chapters in a tutorial disc.  You are out of luck in that case.  Why not buy a burner from a company that has a telephone tech support line or similar?  This is a Windows peripheral which has faulty Mac implementation of software/firmware.  Updating firmware is a joke for a Mac user.  The files will only partially download and no help is available except for e-mail from Samsung website.  Trying other options will give you .exe files that are useless.

The one star rating may seem unreasonable for anything but, as I will explain in a moment this keyboard has some very bad problems.

I ordered this keyboard since it was one of the few I found that had the same style keys as my HP Pavilion laptop, and also because it had media keys.
While the keys did turn out to be like my laptops and nice at that, the media keys are pretty unresponsive and the way the volume strip is set up is just weird.

The real problem however is the case of the keyboard ( or whatever you would want to call it ) it's flimsy to say the least, and flexes when used and the 'adjustable stand' thing at the back is horrible, it's thin, bendy and doesn't add any real support.
The footing on the keyboard is awful too, it would move a bit when I typed even though my desk isn't even slick at all.

Also, if you intend to do anything that requires the arrow keys, then don't get this keyboard.
I thought it would be fine they seem large enough but they're still a pain to use.

I can't comment on the reception since the keyboard was only two feet away from my desktop, but I didn't notice any dropped keys.

So I would not recommend this keyboard, I let looks and such get the best of me when I bought it and now I regret that.

If you're interested the closest I have been able to find for around the same price that is like a laptopkeyboard is the HP Wireless Elite Keyboard V2 which looks a lot more stable than the HP Ultrathin keyboard.

Amazingly, I have had the identical experience as other reviews.    When my computer first arrived, it did not work. It simply would not boot. I have never had that happen before. It was an awful experience. The customer service from Gateway was horrible. It was like that nightmare commercial with \\"Peggy.\\" They suggested I have the computer shipped to Texas. I suggested they were out of their mind.    I had a very important project due that week!    After much confusion, crying, screaming and shouting, I reached a woman at Amazon who solved the problem. She immediately shipped me a new computer and adjusted my bill to reflect the ordeal I had went through. This customer service rep at Amazon was so great -- I later called her boss and put in a good word for her.    My new computer arrived in a day, and it worked like a charm. I have never had a single moment's trouble since! I have no complaints about the computer itself. It is fast, fun and extremely stable. I love my DX-4840!    However, if anything goes wrong, it it clear that I will not get any assistance from \\"Peggy\\" at Gateway. It's too bad because I used to trust Gateway. While I am extremely satisfied with this computer, I cannot recommend buying Gateway.

The quick disconnect is a nice feature, but I'm not too lazy to just take them off. The mic. transmits clearly and doesn't pick up too much background noise.     My only con is that I am a large man, 6'3 240, and the ability of the cups to rotate and lay flat on your chest would be a nice feature, but my neck is too large and the cups just end up choking me. I had a really bad experience with the first one I have got, it has defects displaying 3D images with the included DVI cable. The replacement from Amazon is working properly now.    Generally, the 3D quality is OK, the biggest problem is ghosting depending on the actual image and colors. It seems that there is always 5-10% area showing some degree of ghosting effect(even with LG's own 3D samples) no matter how optimal view position and angle you have adjusted. Sometimes you won't notice it much when watching videos, so the quality is not perfect but acceptable for most of the time.    The 2D quality is disappointing to me primarily because of the bad displaying quality for small text characters(your standard Windows GUI text), it looks somewhat blurred compared to my old HP 20-inch monitor, though the color looks much brighter. The resolution is at the recommended 1920*1080.    If you want an inexpensive way of enjoying 3D movies occasionally and not reading text too much then this one may be a good option. If you want a perfect 3D experience, this one will make you disappointed.

I have one of these external hard drives, I received it as a gift, and I've been using it for almost two years. I connect via a USB mini cable, I run Windows XP OS.    I haven't had any problems whatsoever with this hard drive. It's been working since I first plugged it in. Take it out of the box, plug in the power and connect it to the PC. I've stored large files on it even in the FAT mode. I keep ebooks, videos, movies, music and pics on it, and I use it every single day.     I have no problem with the speed of downloads and transfers, and frankly I can't understand anyone who does. The only possible conclusion I can come to, is that some people are so used to instant gratification that any delay is intolerable. *Shrug*    I've had no problems with the computer acknowledging the drive, it operates quietly. But then again I have mine set up on a wire rack that doesn't impede airflow around the unit. There are airflow vents even on the bottom of the casing. I can touch it right now and it's cool to the touch. If you've got one set up on a solid surface you're blocking 1/3 of the cooling vents. I suggest investing in a small wire rack. They're cheap. It may not be sexy, but your external hard drive will thank you for it. And if you care more about how it looks than your data. Well what else is there to say?    Maybe all these people with horror stories just got bad units. It happens. There are lemons in any kind of manufacturing. But I can assure you that I will be buying another one of these units to back up the one I have just in case. If you're that concerned about your data, back up your stuff on DVDs or CDs as well, and keep them in a safe location.    There are no guarantees in life and that includes technology, but I've been very pleased with this hard drive. As much as I use it, you would think that if it was going to fail it would have failed already. But everything we buy does age and wear out, so before the next year is up I will be buying a new My Book toreplace this one before the one I'm using wears out.    Having said that, I'll say this. Recently I discovered, to my shock, that good shills, and bad shills, haunt review sites and post good things and bad things about products. This disgusts me. The whole point of reviews is to get information from other people about the product.    I've seen competitors write crappy reviews and the seller shilling with good reviews. The only reviews I trust are my own because I don't spend enough time doing reviews to know who is who, I'm sure a great majority of other people don't either.    Amazon needs to make people reviewing these products sign an agreement that they don't work for the selling company or a competitor and prosecute those who violate the agreement.    I've gotten to the point where I don't trust the reviews here on Amazon. I just find someone I know that has one and I ask them about it. It's too bad corporate America can't produce products good enough to stand behind and feel like they have to put their employees online to tout their products.     If the flipping product is good, you don't have to shill it. And I'll die a thousand deaths before I buy any product I find being sold in that manner. And I won't buy anything from a competitor that uses dirty underhanded tactics to undermine someone else's products.    After all if a company engages in that kind of behavior, how are they going to treat their customers?

Cons:

Pros:

- Red light stays on when you have the proper connections
- Inexpensive!!!

I bought this to connect my old IDE HD and DVD writer to my new SATA motherboard that had no IDE connectors.

No instructions came with this and took a bit to get it to work properly.

NOTE; This is very important: The "IDE Host to SATA HD" had to be used as the SATA connector from my IDE Harddrive or IDE DVD unit to my SATA motherboard and not "SATA Host to IDE HD" (maybe HD does not stand for HardDrive??). "Host" appears to be used as the unit you are connecting this adapter to, thus, in my case, my IDE host was my IDE harddrive or IDE DVD writer and the "HD" was my SATA Motherboard.

NOTE: Make sure you connect a power cable from your power supply to both the adapter to power it up and also your IDE drive to power it up. Thus 2 power cables are needed. I used my 4-pin power cable from my power supply instead of the 4-pin to IDE power cable adapter that came with the unit - both worked, but the power supply 4-pin cable was easier to bend so I used it instead.

Once the right SATA connector on the adapter was used, the red light goes on and my Windows 7 OS recognized both my IDE HD and IDE DVD. I set both HD and DVD to "Master" using the jumpers and all worked fine. I got this tip from other reviews listed for this product.

The only problem really is the length of the SATA cable included and the length of the adapter itself. Attaching this to my IDE DVD Writer added about 2.5 inches to the back and I had to bend the SATA and power cable to make it fit. There are 90-degree adapters, but I could not find one that was bi-directional and one in this price range. I actually used a 90-degree SATA cable that was attached to my SATA harddrive to connect to this adapter and used another longer SATA cable to attach my SATA harddrive to my SATA motherboard since the harddrive position was such that I didn't actually need the 90-degree bend.

All-in-all, I'm very pleased with the adapter so far. Not sure how long it will last but at least I can used my IDE drives now with my SATA-only motherboard.

It looks great, its small, and I like the front USB / audio jacks, but because its small it can cause some problems if you're not careful. The PSU is directly above where the CPU will go on the motherboard (it covers about half of it) and with the heat sink / fan, at least the one I'm using, is only about a quarter of an inch of room between the PSU and the top of the fan so there is very little / to no room for air flow or getting a non stock heat sink and fan. The case is about 5" tall, the PSU takes up about half of that (2.5") and my CPU heat sink/fan is just over 2" tall. This in itself can cause the CPU to overheat VERY easily. Make sure your CPU heat sink and fan will fit before buying this too!  Absolutely use the side mounting brackets for the HDD!! If not you will get very cramped and make it extremely more likely the CPU will overheat as mine did. Once I moved it to the side, there were less cables directly above the CPU fan and provided more air flow. I would also definitely recommend a fan or 2 or 3 if you can. I think there is only one 4 pin connector for a fan but you can buy splitters to put more fans in. The more you can cool this tiny thing, the better because it gets hot in there!  Overall I like it for my HTPC but I have had struggles with it.  UPDATE (4-22-15): Until recently I haven't had much need to leave my HTPC on constantly. Now that I'm about to get rid of cable I've been leaving it on more to transfer files and test it out. Just recently I went to it after it would've been on for about 3 days and at some point it restarted due to what I expect to be from overheating. I've constantly struggled with overheating with this box and I've gotten to the point where I am going to buy a new case to see if that helps. There is barely any room for the PSU, CPU, DVD, and HDD to keep cool, and I have a fan and there really is no room either for a non stock CPU heat sink/fan.   I don't recommend this for a high power machine at all.

I have been thinking about buying a Linux based small form factor device for a while and looked at many different types, Raspberry Pi, Gumstix, Panda and the Beagleboard's, among others. I had leaned toward the Beagleboard's, but got caught up in the popularity of the "Pi". Although the Pi is a great "starter" unit, especially when packaged with a basic electronics kits for learning GPIO, I found the Pi a bit.... lacking. Finally, one day, frustrated with it, I decided to bite the bullet and buy an $85 Bone (heck, I had a $45 Amazon gift card, so why not). Unknown to me, the day before, Beagleboard released the "Black" for $45. So I got excited after looking at the specs and ordered one.

When I got it, I plugged it in, and after mucking about on the embedded webpages for not even 10 minutes... I was totally taken aback by the quality, engineering, thorough (and clean) design choices. I have read notes from several hard core Beaglebone developers and there are some things they have minor issues with, regarding GPIO (Which appeared to be a distro problem more then a Beaglebone problem), but for the most part even they couldn't fault the new design. It is clearly, a more mature product then the "Pi", which makes sense, Beagleboard has been at it longer.

There is one "CON" if you want to call it that. the "Black" has one USB A jack, whereas the "Pi" for example has two. That is, the Pi can handle "keyboard" and "mouse" whereas the "Black" can only handle one or the other, without a USB hub. This is a little inconvenient, but considering its other qualities... its barely worth mentioning.

Anyone that gets a 133x card instead of a 233x pretty much knows what they're getting. [...]    The rated 20MB/s speed is enough to use as an alternate hard drive with a CF-to-IDE adapter. Going from pressing the power button on my laptop to being fully loaded at the desktop (cpu idle, no processes loading) only takes 10 seconds! Battery life was also extended roughly 30 minutes to an hour, since not only is there no hard drive spinning, I've locked down most system writes to only the essentials as well.    Keep in mind I'm using WindowsXP Embedded features and a custom setup. Installing regular windows on this card and expecting it to run fine will cause it to lock up and stutter constantly, as well as completely trash your card in record time from disk writing. Unless you are willing to invest some serious time in to getting it running perfectly and have the technical know-how, I do not recommend trying this for the average user. I managed to burn out a few of the sectors on the card being careless and doing a live setup of XP to integrate the embedded features, instead of setting it up on a virtual machine and prepping the card, but that's the price I paid for being lazy and not too much harm done.    In retrospect, getting a 233x card would have been a much better option, but the 133x is definitely up to the task of turning my old laptop into a speedy web browser and portable music player (through Winamp Remote). Being out around town and stopping in places with free WiFi access was the driving factor, which meant boot times has to be as low as possible. [...]    For anything more than browsing though, definitely without a doubt invest in a higher-speed card if your budget allows.

What a pleasant surprise. I had bought similar kinds of covers before, with the knowledge that they will be fun but feel somewhat cheap and will wear out after a few months. Here are the pros of this one:
- Cover texture feels really nice and soft! You want to touch this!
- No chemical smell
- Pattern is lovely and classy
- Magnet clasp gives you space to hook a stylus into it on the inside
- Inside of the cover is smooth - so even though it's white, you can wipe it and it won't get dirty like some of the "fuzzy" ones
- iPad fits snugly
- iPad stands up in a sturdy way on all the ridges
- It rotates smoothly from the first time
- There is a hole for the camera in the right spot
- The whole cover is slim and elegant. Looks more expensive than it is. I would bring this into an interview no problem. Shame the black color is out of stock, but the lavender is also very grey-neutral and classy because of the subtle pattern. It looks elegant rather than "girly," if you know what I mean.

Downsides: the plastic case that you snap the iPad into has really sharp edges. This is not a huge problem, but it does take away from the product. Other covers have a more rubbery smooth seal. Kind of feels like someone forgot to glue the rubber seal on! So you might want to run your finger over the edge to make sure it's not really sharp anywhere.

Overall: the best rotate/standup iPad cover I've purchased to date. Great value for the money. I ordered two other colors.
