So this lapdesk is essentially just a slab of wood. That being said it is worth every penny and is the best lapdesk i have ever owned and far exceeded my expectations.

I purchased this lapdesk to replace some aging POS I got from Bed Bath and Beyond.

First, while it might be just a slab a wood, the wood is solid, lightweight, and sturdy. It feels wel crafted. The angles of the cuts and beveling simultaneously allow for a compact design while making me feel like my available surface area is more than I could need, all while being comfortable to place on my lap. The vent holes provide adequate ventilation and during this summer my ASUS ROG with a GTX 870m GPU and i7 CPU has not had any heating problems whatsoever, despite me using this desk in bed with covers. I have not had any discomfort with the bevel edges of the vent cut outs scraping my bare legs in shorts or anything, but if I could make one improvement to this it would be to sand another small bevel to the underside of the vent cut outs. The rest of the wood desk feels like a solid, single piece (because it is) and the grain is even aligned in a pleasing manner. I have had no issues with my laptop sliding or moving on the surface, and the wood texture makes the PC feel almost "glued" in place, as if they were one piece, even while tilting it to get up and move about or surviving a random toddler attack.

The embedded mouse pad is of high quality, with supple yet firm yield and smooth transition from pad to desk surface. I see no indications of it wanting to come up or the edges fraying any time soon. The pad is very large and can accommodate games with fast reaction times and wide view swings (frantic FPS and the like). It overall is a tad narrower than a traditional gaming mouse pad (by about an inch or less) but it is taller and that extra room is appreciated when doing other tasks like reading long web articles. The material feels like a roughed felt texture, smooth on the mouse by not aggravating to your wrist or hand as you glide it across the surface.

The tablet holder works wonders, but it will not hold most tablets that are in a protective case. This makes sense as if it accommodated most cases, some cases still wouldn't fit and most not in cases would not fit either. It fits my 10.1in GalaxyTab Pro just fine but I often find myself using it to hold my phone, baby monitor, or 7in tablet instead. I have not utilized the power cord cutout, but it would work fine for my 10.1 in wide mode, but it wont really work for smaller devices except as a method of cord organization. Works well with my wife's iPad (3rd Gen).

All in all this desk has revolutionized my free time. Now I can easily and comfortably move my 17" gaming laptop around while never being cramped for space on the work surface. I can sit on the couch or recliner and surf the web or play any game I want while my wife watches her TV shows and I don't have to go into another room or sit at a desk. The height of the computer and mouse when the desk is on my lap makes it comfortable to use even for long periods (2-3 hours) and I find I can sit up against the backboard in bed with the same results. When moving to a new location the mouse area has enough space for my mouse, headphones, baby monitor, phone/tablet, and ac adapter for the PC without them feeling crowded or screens getting bumped. The beveled edges and solid construction make it easy to pick up and move my heavy pc with ease. I couldn't be happier despite the hefty price tag.

Had one of these in 16GB size for years, managed to find this 32GB still new in box and jumped on it.  The 32GB size is in itself nothing special.  What is special about this drive aside from it being USB 3.0 is the fact that Lexar used SLC flash chips in the Triton series.  Most other USB flash drives offered today use MLC or TLC flash chips, which allow higher capacities but are slower and wear out sooner than SLC chips do.  So when you see this Triton drive in 32GB at nearly the same asking price as some other 64GB drive, that is because the 64GB drive is using the lower grade MLC or TCL chips.  SLC chips have, on average, a 10x longer lifespan than MLC chips.  You're paying more because this drive will last longer.

In a notebook, predecessors of these drives have failed. I hope these last.

Matching manufacturer and size for a dump / restore of a disk image is what drove me to get this particular drive. I have not been very impressed with the series up until now but my options are limited to retain the correct drive format. These will be spares, since I just had to use my last spare to rebuild a RAID array component. I bought *two* only *because* of the track record of failure, and I can't afford to lose the machine they are in due to disk failure. (Yes, it's backed up too!)

So, I gave these drives 3 stars because I can't really comment on them otherwise than comparing with their earlier versions.

It's possible it's a bad design in the particular notebook - the mirrored pair are stacked back-to-back with no place for heat dissipation - which is what I suspect has killed a series of these Seagate Momentus 500 drives over time... (as I say not *this* particular one, but several previous ones in the ST95004XX-- series).

Perhaps if I ever get to needing to use these drives they will be just fine.

If you are going nuts trying to figure out why your computer shuts down right after
start up and have been replacing power supplies, graphics boards and ram and reconfiguring
your set up and the thing still shuts down, REPLACE or DeoxIT THE FRIGGING SWITCH!

You can also (with the computer power turned off) cycle the switch a few times just in case
the switch spring is just hanging up, and you should ALWAYS do this first BEFORE replacing a switch.
Also, you can spray a little DeoxIT D5 into the switch (take the cover off the front of the workstation)
and (again) cycle it a few times.
These things have a limited life cycle before the spring inside will start to hang and hold the momentary switch closed and your CPU will go nuts trying to turn off and turn on all at the same time, and you get the dreaded \\"Overclocking Failed\\" Press F1 or F2 message the next time you get your computer started again.

This is a good replacement switch, as I used it for about a year and it started to hang as the original did until
I used DeoxIt on it, and is working just like new now. (Also fixed the original switch this way)

I never write reviews on products, but I have to on this one....I had my tablet for about 6 months and it stopped charging. I went through the proper channels to send it off to get repaired by Samsung as there is a 1 yr warranty on the tablet. Once they got my tablet it took them 2 weeks to get back to me to tell me they weren't going to honor the warranty because there was a scratch on it (not even near where you connect the charger), but I could pay the $199 out of warranty fee to get it repaired or have them send it back to me not fixed. What does a scratch have to do with it not charging??? They wouldn't tell me why it wasn't charging; if it was the battery or the connection on the tablet, just that I had to pay them $199 to have it fixed. This is what the email said, "In order to repair the unit, we would need an out of warranty fee of $199.00. If you would prefer not to pay this fee, we can ship the unit back to you unrepaired at no cost." I will NOT pay this "out of warranty fee" nor will I EVER purchase another Samsung product again! I would not recommend this to anyone as they do not honor their warranty! My girlfriend had the same problem with her's too and they refused to honor her warranty as well!

I only needed a dvd drive for the sole purpose of installing windows 7 64bit on a brand new machine.
Keep in mind that if this is your first windows install on a new sata HDD you may require a sata raid driver from your motherboard to get windows to run properly. This is not the fault of the dvd drive but windows will not see the dvd-drive to install the raid driver from a disc. You must use a USB stick. This happened to me during setup and I had to fumble around looking for my motherboards sata raid driver using my husband's laptop and copy it over to my usb thumbdrive.. Once I found it and told the windows setup where to find it on my usb stick I had no other issues.

I would assume if you already have windows installed that this wont be an issue. Another thing to keep in mind is that this a bulk drive, meaning it does not come with software.

This cable is NOT LEGAL to install in virtually all States -- because almost all States have adopted the NEC (National Eletrical Code) as part of State Law, and NEC 800.179 states that communications cable SHALL BE COPPER.  Stay away from ALUMINIUM wires (clad in a few micros of copper).  AVOID Cat5e cable that claims to meet "all Category 6 specifications", as this cable does.  It that were actually true, they would have labeled the cable "Cat6", not "Cat5e"!

Pros: Good build, fit and finish. Large keyboard. Decent screen size. Great features in a small size. Win7 Home Premium.

Cons: Slow overall performance. 320GB hard drive is partitioned into 4 smaller sizes (annoying when installing software). Shareware!!!

Comments: The first thing I do with every new PC is as follows:
1) Uninstall all Trial editions of Windows Office, etc from the Programs menu in the Control Panel
2) Download Revo Uninstaller (free)
3) Uninstall all secondary software (especially Norton but not your drivers) as there's about 10-15 useless programs installed that impede performance
4) Download Ccleaner (free) and clean the registry (dramatically helps performance)
5) Download Malwarebytes and Avast Free Anti-Virus (these do the same Norton does but do not slow your computer down)
6) Run a Windows Experience Index to determine how the system performs

Conclusion: Expect a Windows Experience of...
Processor: 4.1 (this is pathetic for a dual core. single P4s run in the 5s)
Memory: 4.9 (Again pathetic even for DDR2 800Mhz ram)
Graphics: 3.1 (this is expected with integrated video)
Gaming Graphics: 4.6 (will still display some weak 3D games)
Hard Disk: 5.8 (for reference, 7200 RPM drives = 5.9; SSD = 7.3)

Very disappointed that I went out of my way to find a netbook with a dual processor only to find it performs worse than many single cores. In addition, you also sacrifice the later ATI video cards (most are now HD4250). Bottom line, I would buy the ASUS Ece netbook instead.

Other Thoughts: I cannot fathom why anyone would waste time installing an SSD when the processor, ram, and video are slower than the 5400RPM HD. This is a waste of money.

Received the unit well packed in it's retail box. In fact the box itself was aesthetically pleasing (akin to Apple product packaging).

Pros:
- The form and fit of the protective case is very good. I have a skin on the back of my iPad which made the shell fit a little snug, but none the less it still fit perfectly. The corner \\"clips\\" were small enough that the edge of the case didn't intrude onto the front of the ipad but meaty enough to provide a firm grip. The case stayed on the iPad even as I put the unit through a series of maneuvers (open, close, spinning the unit horizontal/vertical, adjusted viewing angle and removing from keyboard and mount) without popping off. Even though the corner clips held firm, they were easy to remove and allowed for removal of the iPad without nearly breaking the case.
- The access cuts for the headphone jack, microphone, camera, power button, volume control, mute switch, charging port and speaker we spot on. Not only did they fit but the ports, switches, etc were centered perfectly, thus adding to the aesthetic quality.
- The ports are also accessible with the unit attached to the keyboard. Charging (both the iPad and keyboard) can be done without having to remove the units.
- Another plus is the adjustable viewing angle while using the keyboard attached. By sliding the case mounting tab back you can adjust the viewing angle to meet your particular preference. Sliding the tab out to it's last stop, I was able to create a comfortable viewing angle while holding the unit on my lap.
- You can also fold the iPad open all the way down and rest it's back on the keyboard and use the iPad as a touch tablet. The keyboard makes for a solid base. It also provides a slightly elevated viewing angle in landscape mode.
- One feature that I particularly like is the ability to remove the protective case and the stand from the keyboard. You can adjust the viewing angle in both portrait and landscape (to a certain degree), unlike Apple's smart cover (which only has 2 viewing angles) (there are a few shortcomings, however, see my comments in the Cons section below).
- The ability to totally remove the iPad and protective case from the keyboard and mount allows you to use the iPad as it was originally intended while maintaining the protection of the case.

Cons:
- When using the unit with the keyboard you'll need to be careful on how you open the unit. The hinge was a bit stiff (as I realize it needs to be to hold the unit in position) and the tendency is to open it as one would a laptop. At a certain point the bottom of the iPad will pull away from the keyboard and slide forward (how quickly depends on how much pressure one applies). Once you realize this, it is easy to open using two hands or just pushing the middle of the iPad back after you've separated the units a bit.
- With the keyboard removed you can adjust the viewing angle from 90 - 45 degrees (both in landscape and portrait mode). Anything beyond approximately 45 degrees causes the iPad to slide and fall flat on it's back. While there are rubber feet on the bottom of the mount which keep it from sliding the iPad case is smooth and there is nothing to stop it from sliding.

Neutral:
- Keyboard: It is functional and is on par with most of the better made keyboards on the market (think Zagg). The small form factor takes some getting used to, but again it's a trade off everyone makes for portability.
- Weight: It does add considerable weight to the iPad (the full unit is slightly lighter than the iPad itself), so this is something that one must take into consideration. Do the pluses of the added functionality outweigh (pun intended) the negatives of the weight? Comes down to personal preference.
- Matt black plastic finish. Again this will probably be a personal preference issue on whether someone likes it or not. I noticed that oil from my hands show up on the finish (although it's easily wiped away).

Suggestions:
- If there's a way to build in a rubber/silicone strip along the edges of the protective case this may allow for more viewing angles without the case sliding. Not sure how to do this without making it too obtrusive.

Overall the Pros outweigh the Cons and I would give this a 4 out of 5 star rating. I can't comment on the battery life of the keyboard nor the effect the weight will have in the long run until I've used the unit for an extended period.

I have been using Kindles for book reading since 2009 and was VERY excited about the Kindle Paperwhite. I have long been waiting for a lighted display on an ink reader and my husband pre-ordered a Kindle Paperwhite 3G as soon as it was released as a birthday gift. I received the item today and am immediately returning it. After plugging it in and turning it on, I immediately saw a VERY bright spot at the lower left corner and a corresponding vertical shadow from the dot upwards. I felt the surface of the display with my finger, and a dented defect can be felt at that location. The Kindle was only in my hands and set on my bed during the minutes that I had it out. I went to my Amazon.com account to see about an exchange, and was instructed to call about a replacement.

I spoke to a foreign customer service agent and she was clearly following a script. I was REPEATEDLY asked if I had traumatized my Kindle device. The answer was absolutely not because the device was in my hands or on the top of my quilted bed. I was asked >4 times for my address, and the customer service agent registered my Kindle to my Amazon account against my wishes. Why register the device when I will never use it? I also did not feel comfortable returning a registered device because someone else could have access to my Amazon account through that Kindle device. We were told that we could return the defective device for a replacement, and the new Kindle Paperwhite 3G would take up to 12 weeks to receive. The current time for a new order is 4-6 weeks. My husband pointedly asked if we would have 30 days from receipt of the new device to return it if that 2nd device has a problem. The answer was that our 30 day return window is from the time the first device was received so we would have NO return window on the second replacement device. We chose to return the device for credit rather than a replacement.

The phone conversations took about an hour and ended with complete frustration. I am an Amazon Prime member and buy items weekly from Amazon. Worst experience we've ever had with Amazon - shockingly bad. The display does have vague green/pink hues also and irregular lighting from the bottom. We bought the Kindle without ads and there are still book ads on the display. The resolution of the display is clearly inferior to my iPad. My husband said one pixel was \\"on\\" fully and would not turn off at the defective display location, and he is a computer engineer at a major computer firm. I plan to look at the new iPad mini before decide what device to buy for the future. Truly a horrible, disappointing product. What would happen if the Kindle screen were actually scratched with use??? I had mine for less than 5 minutes before it was clear it was defective, and the exchange/return process was unpleasant.

UPDATE 10/31/2012 - I paid $199 for the Kindle Paperwhite 3G without ads. After seeing the device in person, I think I will not like using it at night due to the white background (a bit of ambient light and brightness) and irregular display. I read more about all of the Kindle devices and decided to buy a Kindle Fire 7\\" HD for $199. It does have ads on the opening page, but the book suggestions can be turned off. The book reading provides an option for a black background with white words, and I can also stream free videos with my Prime membership. I feel much more like I'm getting my money's work with the Kindle Fire HD, and the book reading is working much better at night (less ambient light that could disturb my husband then the Kindle Paperwhite). This is an option worth considering for the cost. I still plan to use my iPad for the apps, 4G, email, photos, etc but the Kindle Fire 7 HD is smaller, has a great display and appears to be a decent way to access Amazon content.

I consider a 5 rating to mean the product is perfect in all ways and is the best of the best. The Fire is not however for what it is if you have an extra $200 in your pocket it's not a bad investment. First it's not a full size tablet killer. I have a under rated and low price ($350 32GB) 10\\" Lenovo K1 tablet which I love to use and a Kindle 2. My review is based on comparing all 3 side by side and realizing that they each have a specialization.
Fire set up a piece of cake and seeing all the apps and books I have purchased from Amazon on the bookshelf was great. Seeing book covers that I have on my K2 in color (no real big deal) brought a smile to my face. Read a couple of chapters of a book I've been reading and decided unless I'm in a dark room I will continue to use the K2, print seems to be better on the eyes and when you use small font easier to see on K2.
I was pleasantly surprised by screen resolution - even thought the Lenovo has much better specs the Fire held its own especially on games. The negative it is a 7\\" screen and if you are reading articles on the net to see a full page the font is much harder to see including Amazons Home shopping page but portability makes up for that.
Speeds- for some reason it took twice as long to download apps from the cloud then if you bought them from the apps store. Down loading books from the cloud also took a long time. You Tube watching is pretty bad - tried several videos and it seems to be in constant buffering mode- a 3 min video took 7 min to get through. Other video-Netflix which I subscribe to have no issues - watched a complete 30 min TV show with no problems. Of course side by side with a 10\\" screen no contest. Surfing net was slower than the Lenovo but not much. The Fire always showed 1 bar less than the Lenovo on the wireless connectivity everywhere in the house and for some reason slight movements would cause major changes in reception bars.
Sound is what it is for such a small tablet--both it and the Lenovo should be listening to with headphones.
Touch screen was not as sensitive as the Lenovo, had to repeat movements a lot and the keyboard in portrait and landscape are too small for my fat fingers and lacked quick response.
Bottom line it's a nice $200 portable piece of electronics however I will find myself using the 10\\" tablet when ever portability is not an issue.it and the Lenovo should be listening to with headphones. I purchased my Kindle Fire HD in October and started looking for a case immediately. While on Amazon I found this leather case for a great price.  It came long before the arrival time and I was very pleased that it fit great.  So far I've had it for a few months and there aren't any defects. The wake/sleep when you flip open the case always works well. The best feature is the stylus pen and loop on the edge of the case to carry it.  Overall very satisfied with the quality, durability and functionality of this case.

It is a decent amount of storage for graphics files and is an ok size.

The only drawback is the little, tiny, hole provided for a lanyard. A key ring would never fit neither would a clip. Even my other lanyards would not fit without carving the openings a little larger. The hole appears to be meant for dental floss.

Nice little travel computer.  Definately not a replacement for my regular laptop, but easy to travel with and be productive.  Fires up quickly and does all the Office documents and websurfing I need it to.  Based on other reviews I immediately upgraded the RAM to 2GB.  Made the computer run much faster, with 1 GB of RAM it seemed slow to open documents and webpages.    The screen is bright and easy to read.  My only complaint it the backspace key is slightly out of position and I sometimes hit the = key instead.  The touchpad works well, but I bought a wireless mouse as that is more comfortable to navigate lengthy documents.    I am still using Starter 7 as I have not found a need to upgrade to the full edition of Windows 7.  I did put the full Office 2010 suite on the machine as the Word starter was awkward and the large ad window distracting on the small screen.  The Word and Excel starter would work for most people if they were not inclined to buy the full suite.    Great value and meets my needs as an easily portable laptop for travel.  I would consider myself a power user of Word and Excel and use this machine easily for both.  With a \\"cloud\\" service to manage documents it is very seamless to use this machine to be productive on the road.

Pros: The mouse feels great - good weight, moves well across surfaces, has good smooth scrolling - and it works well on-screen.

Cons: The primary issue is battery life. I'm not sure how folks are achieving 10-month battery life, as I'm lucky if I get one week, and have never seen the \\"low battery\\" indicator lit. A lesser secondary issue is the lack of a dedicated \\"forward\\" button, which I find very helpful sometimes when web surfing or navigating between windows in some apps (such on between note pages in OneNote).

I have a similar HP mouse ([[ASIN:B0029L4NX8 HP Wireless Comfort Mobile Espresso]] and while the weight and shape aren't quite as nice, it has both \\"back\\" and \\"forward\\" buttons, the battery lasts for several months, and it always provides about a day of low-battery warning before the battery is exhausted.

Does a fine job, starts up fast and shuts down fast.  Needs a lot of updating and I am not that fond of the operating system.  I am writing this review on this computer.  It connects to the wifi easily in the restaurant where I am currently enjoying Italian food and wine while trying to write my book.  I had to get on Amazon and review this just to tell everyone that what you have heard about the keyboard is somewhat accurate.  It does not support overly fast typing speeds unless you are very careful and press hard. That being said it does improve your ability to push the keyboard buttons down as you get angry that you have so many typos.  I have had to correct this review twice so far were it has missed letters that  pressed too lightly.  The trackpad sometimes clicks in my text while I'm typing as well when I use the spacebar.  This could be avoided if the computer was lower than me and my hands were not on the laptop.  The battery life is good if you are not doing anything too intense.  It is sometimes hard to click with the trackpad as well.  I have played and enjoyed a few steam games on this computer, Postal 2 mainly, which is an old game but awesome.  I don't have virus protection because I use my Mac for browsing sites that could be dangerous and stick to what I know here.  I do use spybot s&d free and it has found various things to fix but takes a while.  I would have liked blutooth but bought a $10 kinivo transmitter and it works great.  Sound is as expected, pretty good but it's a laptop, what do you expect?  Not as much bass as a subwoofer because the laptop would shake.  I do like that it has a numerical keypad but they put one of the arrow keys where zero usually is so I get out of order sometimes.  I only paid $229 when it was on supersale here and have had it for six months with no issues.  It doesn't come with an installation disc like everything else in the world and I uninstalled most features of which I later needed but the serial key I retrievedfor Windows did not work to download Windows Media Center which I no longer need but heck if I'm going to pay for Windows features!  If I were really concerned with keyboard functionality and the trackpad I would get an additional keyboard and mouse.  I do use a usb mouse for gaming.  Can't go wrong for the price and RAM, my primary reasons for buying.  I like it because I don't worry about it getting hurt (I do everything in the cloud) or stolen.  It is the closest I could get to a good but inexpensive laptop that is basically disposable if need be.  Like if I have it in a hotel room while I am on a mission and the enemy gets the upper hand and I must leave in haste, then I can burn the harddrive remotely.  Yes the camera is lame and not very good quality, don't buy it for that, just get a usb hd camera for $50.  One thing to love over a mac is the extra buttons: home, pgup, pgdown, end, delete, prt sc.  These features are invaluable to me and I have always been disappointed in macs because of them even with the shortcuts that they provide for prints screen functions.
This is exactly what I was looking for.  The associate at the local Radio Shack suggested I order online and he was correct.  Arrived promptly.  Thank you!

Yes, this is what the iPad so awesome...flexibility. Car, Plane, train. Great adapter, good price. Held its place on a three hour trip to the mountains. No problems.  Also no issues on the way back.  used it on a second trip with zero problems. It's part of the family now.

I have a large 17 inch HP Pavilion g7 laptop. I use it constantly for either school or downtime. I had previously purchased a cheap $3 plastic cooling fan for it but it did nothing for my laptop. It would get so overheated that it would turn off. It was flimsy and not powerful at all. After my third fan I decided to splurge on a cooling fan that might actually work. From the moment I got it I was impressed! It came in a nice secure box so there was no threat of it being damaged and fits my laptop perfectly. It is made out of a sort of metal which makes it very sturdy. The cord connects to my USB port and then converts to another USB port so I don't lose space for my cords. The fan in the middle is HUGE (about the size of a small plate) and keeps my laptop cool no matter what I'm doing. I can actually feel the cool air from it unlike my old fan. I can even watch movies without my laptop overheating. I definitely recommend it for anyone with a laptop that gets overheated easily!

Just got this little thing today, but...I have some grievances about this product- not bad, just...read on.

First off, only 3 of the 4 ports work. It's the first port, perpendicular to the port that goes into the computer (my laptop) while the remaining 3 work just fine. I get it, it's not as expensive as others and compact, but it works overall.

Secondly, it feels a bit "loose" once I plug it in. I sat for about 10 minutes, going through the motion of "accidentally" getting this snagged on random stuff. I have a dog, he likes to sit with me, sometimes he kicks my laptop while he sleeps. I also have an external wired-mouse and check to see if I lose connectivity if it snags. I know something like this isn't meant to be jiggled or tossed about, but you know, got to plan for everything.

TL;DR: Great product, 3 of 4 ports work, plug-in feels loose, but still works as advertised.

My laptop used to freeze up while gaming for more than an hour, and I suspected the problem was overheating. After using this cooler for 3 months, I haven't had my laptop freeze up a single time. This cooler, along with a RAM upgrade, has prolonged the life of my laptop for at least a year (unless something breaks).

When I first powered it on, I didn't think it moved a lot of air. It is quiet, even at full speed. I haven't done any temperature tests, but the cooler moves enough air to solve my overheating problem.

I live in a dusty climate and there is a perfect 220mm circle of dust on the bottom of my laptop, so I can tell that the air only flows where the fan blades are located. To reiterate, although the entire surface is perforated, the air really only flows in a 220mm circle.

One thing I wish had been made more clear was the following: Unless you have the AC adapter (purchased separately), you will only gain one extra USB port as this takes up two ports on your laptop.

I've had this purse now for 3 months and I love it!  It is durable and holds everything I need (laptop, fullsize notebook, numerous folders, Kindle, and various smaller stuff in the pockets).  I also love that I can zip this across the top for when I take public transportation.  When I took a trip I used this as my carry-on.  Hands down the best work purse I have ever owned!

This Vera Bradley Tablet sleeve is the perfect sleeve for my iPad to protect it during transport.  I bought is specifically for when I was flying so that if it got jostled around, it wouldn't break.  I have a Griffin Intellicase cover on my iPad and it still fits in this Vera Bradley Tablet sleeve with some room to spare. I particularly like that on the side, there's a small pocket that I can put a cleaning cloth for the screen.  Outside is the traditional Vera Bradley cloth quilted material and it's cushioned to protect the iPad.  The zipper is sturdy and it unzips on the top and halfway down the side, making it easy to get your iPad in/out. Also, the zipper has a nice, big ribbon tab on it, making it easy to open and close.  I got the Provencal cover which is a combination of yellow, reds, browns, and greens.  I really like this color so that I can locate it in my dark bag.  I would highly recommend this cover for traveling and transport!
This product gives you exactly what you need. Super easy to use, small, 4 usb ports and a great price. I've had it for a month now and have no complaints.

I love this tablet cover, for the price I paid.  I looked at the store when I purchased tablet and they were pricey and I did not love them.  I will be surprised if this cover lasts longer than a year, but that is ok because I did not pay a lot.  The stand which I never used before seems flimsy.  Does not stay well, but this is also first time using any stand.  My expectations of what stand should do might be too high.  I love the black & white design on the cover.

Overall I really like this case. Way better then the one for my Macbook Air. The plastic is a Matte finish for those who are wondering (red color). The plastic pieces that clip to hold the top and bottom case are much thicker and stronger then the one for my Air. The plastic also seems thicker so I'm thinking it will take a beating much better. The plastic around the ports is cut back enough to allow adapters to plug flush with the port which is a great. Overall the design of this case is perfect. There is only one...minor...thing that I'd change on the design. The bottom risers are made of this foam like substance and I don't that that will survive well, especially pulling it in and out of my bad multiple times a day. For now I'll have faith in the materials choice and keep you posted on my findings.

Uploaded a picture so you can see how the case curves around the ports to allow proper input connection and the foam risers.

-Kris.

After waiting 12 days for this item to arrive, I was eager to install. Following the directions provided I removed old ATI drivers and began install. First the card is long, I had to move a hard drive to another location to install this card. The install disk did not list 4850 as an option (3800 series & 4870 only) from past frustrations with ATI installations I didn't want to try until I stumbled on the correct driver so I downloaded recommended drivers from the ATI site. Installed without a hitch.     Performance is terrific, screen looks great (24\\" 1900x1200). Played a few games COD4/5, Far Cry, MOH Airborne (which would not play on my old ATI 1950xt) not sure of frame rates (don't know how to determine) but all played and looked great (I'm not an avid gamer). Temp runs about 41-47 degrees when i have checked, my old 1950XT ran 20 deg warmer. Instructions recommend 750W PS, mine is 500W no-name and seems to work fine. Package was complete with all necessary adapters and crossfire cable that one might need. I'm using dual monitors (one at 1900x1200 the other 17\\"CRT at 1024x768)and set up was simple. After one week I would have rated 5 but for long delivery time and apparently incorrect or mislabeled drivers disk.

The fan is great, I love the adjustable speeds, and I can feel it from where I sit without any problems. The adjustable goose neck is great, however, the 4 port USB is not as great as advertised. It is USB 1.1, which is noticeably slower than 2.0 and 3.0. I plugged my phone charger using the hub, and it was noticeably slower in charging my phone. I also attempted to move some music files to my phone while connected to the USB hub (which surprised me, I didn't expect the USB hub to do anything but charge my phone), and it was slower as well, but not that bad. Basically, the hub useful if you have run out of USB plugs, otherwise, not so much. I also wish the ring around the adjustable speed adjuster wasn't always lit, it only turns off if the computer is off/it is unplugged. Even if the fan is off, the ring is still on, but that's minor. Also, the cord is very long. I was able to wrap it around behind my monitor and back down to my computer, and still have a lot of flexibility left.
But all in all, its a great value buy. The adjustable speed, well powered, silent fan does its job.
UPDATE*
The USB port became useful, I recently bought a wireless mouse, and some of the USB ports on the front portion of my computer won't actual connect, except one, and I didn't want to have to unplug my mouse. All the back hubs were taken, so I used the USB Hub. It found the device, installed the software, and its working flawlessly. So, increasing my rating to 5 stars.

This Easy Transfer Cable for Windows by Cable Matters has solid durability and fast transfer speeds. A sample was provided in exchange for an honest review.

I recently bought a new Windows computer for my parents, and this cable came in handy to transfer all the files off their old machine. One computer runs Windows 7, and the other runs Windows 8.1.

In my tests of durability of this cable, I found it to be quite good. A 24 hour test of keeping the cable bent under a book showed no signs of fraying or wear of any kind. The connectors are solid, and so is the cable, especially near the ends where it is most prone to issue.

The cable has two green indicators at the middle of the indicator that show activity from both ends, or in other words, the two computers it is connected to. My newer computer recognized the older one very easily after inserting the included CD for software.

Transfer speeds were quite quick. I was able to transfer a 2TB file in about a minute using this cable, to give you a real world idea of how fast it is.

Overall, this cable works great. I also measured it, and it’s as advertised - 6 feet! I definitely recommend this for a quick and painless windows file transfer.

First off I've had a few Laptops and Panasonics and Toshibas are the best in my opinion. If you have unlimited resources go with a great Panasonic, they really are killer. Hey this laptop does everything I want and with Windows 7 and an i3 core, 4GB Memory and 500GB HD this is an awesome laptop for a student, with the power of a Desktop. I only rate mine 5 stars because of the price I got, went to Orifice Max and they had them for $545.99, A SUPER DEAL! If I had to buy it at this listed price I'd say a solid 4 star would be warranted. Either way it's a very good deal, but I hear these models, and its close siblings are being discontinued, so if you want one now's the time. They're being moved for newer stock, and if you don't grab one when you see it you may not see another one for sale again.

*REVISION*
Well exactly one week after the one year warranty expired the thing locked up and never worked again. Toshiba wanted $200 min to even figure out what was up so I said to He11 with it and cut my losses. If it took a dump that quick I just wasn't willing to invest more in it just to have it take a dump again in a few weeks. I took it to a local tech who said this generation of Satellite had a lot of cut backs and basically Toshiba used the guise of the Satellite name to sell a bunch of poorly made laptops for a few years. When I got it the reviews were probably close to 95% positive, now if you look it's closer to 50/50, NOT GOOD!

The first problem with this fan is that it kept coming loose from the heat sink. The 2 clips that are supposed to clip onto the heat sink did not clip because the ridge that was cut into the heat sink was too low for the clip to grab onto. Secondly, when the fan was attached and the switch was set to quite mode, the fan made a slightly audible hum sound that was louder than the minimum 15db that the specs say. It was clearly audible. Comparing this to the [[ASIN:B004PLWJCC Rosewill RCX-Z775-LP 80mm Sleeve Low Profile CPU Cooler]] fan, not only does the Rosewill fan have a lower profile, but it also is completely silent at idle and also while working in Photoshop, converting videos, and playing music CDs or blu-ray movies. The minimum noise level of the Rosewill is 16db, but I could not hear it at all. However, I could hear the \\"15db\\" SilverStone CPU fan. I had no overheating issues with either fan, probably because my CPU was the low powered Intel Core i3-2100. One more thing, the Rosewill RCX-Z775-LP fan is 1/2 the price of the SilverStone fan. If you need a low profile fan and need silence from your computer, get the Rosewill RCX-Z775-LP CPU fan.

*************** ADDITIONAL INFO - SILENT BATTERY RECALL BY LENOVO *************************
In doing further searching, I found that my original battery died because of a flaw and lenovo is doing a \\"silent\\" recall of the batteries. Go to this lenovo page: [...]APPLYCOUNTRY to determine if you are eligible for a replacement battery. If the link gets disabled by amazon, the title of the page is ThinkPad battery has low capacity or shows an \\"Irreparable damage\\" or \\"Battery cannot be charged\\" error message - ThinkPad T60/T61/R60/R61/X60/X61 - a search in google should find it.

I ran the utility, and filled out the form and lenovo is sending me a new battery.

Once you start typing and are doing so regularly it does a decent job keeping up, but still drops a key input every now and then. Keys also do not spring back up nearly as nicely as the old apple bluetooth keyboard. Overall I would not recommend anyone get this keyboard for serious work. It is simply not robust enough.

UPDATE [3/3/14] (original post 1/29)

Had the keyboard for less than three months now. Still having the issues stated in the original review -- keyboard disconnects after less than five minutes of inactivity from my macbook pro, takes ~15 seconds to reconnect every time; even when connected, if you weren't immediately typing the second beforehand, the first key input is dropped every time, regardless of the given key* and connected or not; keys do not spring back to default position as well as the macbook pro laptop keyboard or a dell desktop keyboard. Now I am experiencing a new regime of problems.

Keyboard routinely disconnects every ten or so minutes. Doesn't matter what I am doing -- typing, idle. Tried replacing batteries and uninstalling and reinstalling software. (For example, in the middle of writing this paragraph the keyboard disconnected and took a solid minute to reconnect) This is in addition to all the times it simply disconnects when idle for a few minutes. As compared to when I first purchased to the keyboard, the lag times when connecting to the computer and first stroke key inputs actually making it to the computer have both increased at least two-fold.

There was a moment when I suspected that maybe the connectivity issues were on my macbook pro's end -- the bluetooth receiver going bad or something like that. This entire time, however, I have been using an apple wireless bluetooth mouse without any issues. Sure, it disconnects after a few hours of inactivity, but otherwise it stays connected, responds immediately when nudged, and shows none of the other signs that the keyboard has.

Disposing of the keyboard. It isn't worth the hassle. Not a good experience. Is there a keyboard out there of the same geometric profile and functionality as the apple brand wireless bluetooth keyboard, but with a less than 70 dollar price tag?

*surprising to me, if you aren't doing work requiring a lot of typing, one can get used to this nuisance. The nuisance quickly grows into quite a hassle the more typing you start doing.

When I needed a travel stand for my iPad 2, the choice came down to the Griffin Loop and the Compass. I went to the Apple Store and asked the saleswoman if I could test both out. The Griffin does NOT work with the iPad 2, despite what it says on the Griffin site. The Compass works great with the iPad 2. Just keep in mind that what you're getting with this stand is a compromise between sturdiness and portability, but it's an EXCELLENT compromise. I'm a reporter, and I bought this to bring with me while covering conferences and conventions. I need it to prop the iPad up when I'm using a keyboard or showing photos/videos, and to hold the iPad when I'm typing or editing images/video. The Compass has already proven itself on one busy trip.

The Compass comes with a carrying case that looks like it's meant to hold chopsticks--that's how small this thing folds up to. I store it in a pen pocket of my iPad carrying case. What surprised me most about this stand is how substantial it is: It's solid metal, with durable rubber padding where necessary, and the folding parts have a decent amount of resistance. The way that the supports fold away is brilliant; if it weren't so well built, this stand would be just a gimmick. It IS well-built, so it's a practical accessory.

In display mode, you will need to hold the iPad with one hand while you press buttons. This is the case with most stands; if you think about it for a second, to make a stand that will let you type and swipe while the iPad is upright, the device would need to be solidly attached to the stand, and the stand would need to be either weighted down or attached to a surface, all resulting in something too big to put in a briefcase or purse. For a gadget that folds to the size of a pair of chopsticks, the Compass holds up rather well. The grooved rubber pads on the bottom part also help.

In typing mode, I still have to be a little careful when pressing the Home button, or the iPad may slide. I do not recommend playing games with this stand, as any aggressive poking or swiping may dislodge the tablet. Comparison to Apple Smart Cover: I've had the Apple cover collapse more often and more easily when typing or attempting to do things on the iPad while in display mode; the Smart Cover does not do portrait mode. Compass wins as a stand.

Pros:
Solidly built
Compact for travel
Looks like something Blade would use to kill vampires
Good support for most uses outside of gaming

Cons:
Not sturdy enough for gaming or angry emailing
May raise suspicion of astute airport screenersying games with this stand, as any aggressive poking or swiping may dislodge the tablet. Comparison to Apple Smart Cover: I've had the Apple cover collapse more often and more easily when typing or attempting to do things on the iPad while in display mode; the Smart Cover does not do portrait mode. Compass wins as a stand. Do not EVER be fooled by the junk that LOOKS like a pogo sketch. Those pretty colors and cheap prices are going to give you heartburn. I learned this lesson well and can say that while I still think it's overpriced, it does do an order of magnitude better job than the knock-offs.
Biggest thing here is that the capacitive foam is properly attached and rounded while others are not. Next, and more importantly, is that pogo uses a little black rubber o-ring between the foam and the aluminum stick so that when you apply pressure and as the foam wears, you do not hit the screen with the metal shaft. The others do not have this feature and when you wear out the foam, you smack your glass screen with a sharp aluminum stick. That's what makes these guys better.
While this is not my first choice for writing (boxwave and alupen are) this is a great stylus for sketching and painting. The foam will wear down and change shape which scares you at first, but it in no way changes the quality of the product. I don't know how long they'll last before the foam gives up, but I've abused mine for over a month now. LIght, cool looking and easy to use. Good to go.

After 1 month of ownership (as of tomorrow), I'm extremely impressed. However, I'm giving it four stars simply due to a few things that ASUS could easily change to make it even better.    First, before you consider buying one of these, you should realize what it's designed for. It's meant to be thin, light, and have extremely good battery life; it's NOT meant for extremely intensive tasks (video encoding, number crunching) or gaming. The machine is still very capable of everything I throw at it, and unlike netbooks you won't find yourself making compromises in every-day tasks to avoid slow downs.      Pros:  - GREAT battery life. I've seen about 6-8 hours on average, with 9-10 hours during very light use (and that's all on the moderate \\"Entertainment\\" battery setting). 12 hours may be achievable using the \\"Battery Saver\\" setting, which dims the display quite dark, throttles the processor even more, and reverts to the non-Aero Windows theme.    - Excellent size and weight. 13.3\\" really is the sweet spot for me; it's very portable, and really seems significantly smaller than my previous 14.1\\" laptop. This thing really seems as light as a feather compared to many other laptops. Too bad I just got out of college, I would have loved the \\"lug\\" things thing around.    - Decent build quality. The brushed aluminum cover is a very nice touch, and really makes the UL30A look very classy (though it would have been nice to see aluminum used on other panels as well). The screen is firmly hinged and it takes some force to make it wobble. Unlike other reviews I've read, the battery is locked in very securely by two locks, one on each side. There are a few small areas on the laptop casing that can be depressed, causing an audible click, but it takes a decent amount of force and the chassis seems to be very sturdy overall.    - Decent keyboard. The chiclet-style keyboard is a breeze to type on. Having the extra space between each key is very nice, especially when hunting for an unfamiliar key. There is some keyboard flex present, but it's much less pronounced that my previous laptop (ASUS N80Vn) and I generally don't find that it causes any problems with my typing speed (~90 WPM).     - LED Backlit Screen. After using one on my previous laptop, and now this one, I don't think I could stand to go back to a standard CCFL screen. The lighting seems much more even, and the colors are far more vibrant. I find that the screen causes less strain on my eyes over long periods of time, and even when I dim it to save battery life, it's still MUCH brighter than other laptops. With that said, the laptop most likely uses a cheaper TN panel (are there any laptops available with MVA/PVA/IPS panels?), so it may not be ideal for professional photo work.    - Great overall specs. Graphics card aside, you get a Core 2 Duo that sips power and is still capable of every day tasks, 4GB of memory, a 500GB hard drive, and Windows 7 Home Premium.    - Some multi-touch support on the track pad. Two-finger scrolling really beats a dedicated scroll bar once you get used to it, especially since it frees up more track pad real estate. The three-finger right click gesture is also nice. Why can't we have more?!      Cons:  - Intel Integrated Graphics. The X4500MHD (a.k.a. GMA 4500MHD) just plain sucks. It's more than plenty for basic desktop use, watching videos, and surfing the 'net. However, if you're looking to do any gaming, you should look elsewhere. For example, I read one review that stated they experienced stutters even playing World of Warcraft at a laughable 800x600 resolution. If you're not looking to do any gaming (or if the games you want to play are graphically simple, like Bejeweled, or over 5 years old, like Starcraft), the X4500MHD should do the trick. I REALLY wish the UL30Vt (user-switchable graphics between the X4500MHD and a Nvidia GT210M) was out when I purchased this one. If I had the opportunity to return mine and get the UL30Vt instead, I would in a heart beat.    - No Bluetooth. ASUS, really... it's 2009. Bluetooth is popping up everywhere. Sure, I can buy a tiny, cheap USB Bluetooth adapter, but that ties up one of the three USB ports on the machine. Ugh... this is probably the only thing about the laptop that really irks me. Integrated please.    - So-so track pad. The dimpled effect takes a little getting used to, but it's not horrible. I still prefer a smooth, recessed surface like traditional track pads, though. The available multi-touch gestures (mentioned above) are really nice, but I'd like to see more. I'm hoping more can be added with driver updates, and it's mot a hardware limitation. The biggest downfall to me is the buttons; they work fine, but they're a bit too stiff for my liking, and they emit a loud click when pressed. I use a wireless mouse (Logitech VX Nano - highly recommended) most of the time anyway, so it doesn't make much difference to me.    - Atheros Wireless card instead of an Intel card; lack of a gigabit network adapter (it's only 10/100), only 3 USB ports.      Overall, it's a a wonderful laptop for anyone looking for portability and battery life over raw performance. However, there are still a few things missing that would really make it a smash hit.

After some issues with my previous provider, I decided to go Comcast internet in the North Atlanta area. I called and they said they could install the next day, so I ran out get a modem and found this one along with several more expensive ones at a local electronic mega store. I decided to go with this one because 1) It was cheap and 2) I have owned several Zoom products over the years and never had any issue with them.

The cable guy came out, he did not really approve my modem selection, but was impressed with the performance. It has been working with any issue for 3 months now, so I am quite happy with it. It is not the latest standard, but I figured I would get a few years of use out of it before it dies, or I need to upgrade. My only issue would be that it is very light and the cable will drag it off the desk if you are not careful.

So that's it, it is cheap and it works, what more do you want.

So far, I am very happy with this keyboard, because it works very well and makes my desk look a little bit nicer.

I used this adapter to connect my Acer laptop computer to my car's cigarette lighter; and, adapter worked perfectly. I frequently use my laptop in my car while visiting WiFi spots; but, the limited charge of my laptop's battery has always imposed a limitation. This adapter will add another option for me whenever I am using my laptop computer from my car.

The adapter has two different L.E.D. lights which become illuminated when the adapter is plugged into the car's cigarette lighter. While the L.E.D. lights aren't necessary as far as the overall functionality of the device, they do provide further confirmation that power is flowing through the device (and, the colored lights are pretty, if you are into that sort of thing).

When I connected my laptop computer to my car's cigarette lighter, the electrical connection was solid and stable. My computer functioned in the same way as if it had been plugged into an outlet inside my house. As of this writing, I am very satisfied with the unit. I'll continue to test the adapter and will report anything new. I would like to thank Amazon for the opportunity to be the first person to review this product!

I bought this machine almost 2 months back. I was looking at buying a lightweight and portable notebook. The notebooks from the more well known brands were quite expensive - typically $1700 plus. And then I saw this Averatec 3250HX-01 at CompUSA. I was impressed with the specs - and especially the 8O GB HDD and DVD burner.

But the Athlon processor was a turn-off. I have always used the latest Intel processors in my machine and I just was not sure about the AMD Athlon processor. A lot of research led me to the conclusion that while the Athlon XP-M 2200+ processor may not rank with the best but it is more than adequate for the job.

Also, Averatec was a brand new to me. Had never heard of them before. They are a Korean company - part of a larger group. Checked with CompUSA, Circuit City, and OfficeMax (Best Buy did not carry the machine then) staff and I heard positive comments from them.

Bottomline, the machine had all the the specs I wanted but the one drawback was the Athlon processor. I'd have liked a stronger Intel processor. Although the brand was new but everybody had positive comments and at sub-$1000 this was the only lightweight and portable notebook I could get. So I bought it.

The machine has lived up to my expectations overall. I have only 3 issues with Averatec on this machine:

1. The 3 USB ports are placed on the right side of the machine. This is an awkward position - which means that my DSL wire crawls all over my table and my wireless mouse stick sticks out outwardly and I have to take care not to hit it when moving the mouse. Also since the USB ports are so close together I cannot use the third port (usually the middle one) when the other two are being used. I have to buy a USB hub.

2. The battery lasts for around 2 hours. Could have done with a longer lasting battery.

3. Beyond 1 hour of usage the machine gets warm, beyond 2 hours it gets hot. And beyond three hours it is very hot at the bottom. Although, the top part gets only mild warm at the hottest of times. I have now used it for as much as 8-10 hours continously a few times, and have had no problems in response times. But I believe its best not to get too hot - so I'm now limiting my conitnous usage to not more than 3 hours.


The software that comes with the machine is OK - although I have not used it much. I am using other software which I have installed on this machine.

The after-sales support is OK. But I am basing this on just one experience. I got thru to the representative after 5 minutes of wait and he was able to guide me.

My net take is this. Buy this machine if you are working on a tight budget and want good specs in a 12.1\\" machine. Brand conscious people need to look elsewhere.

I purchased this product to connect a 37\\" 720P Vizio TV to my early 2009 24\\" iMac running Mac OS X 10.6. I purchased this model becuase another reviewer noted that this adapter allowed audio to be streamed through the minidisplay port. Unfortunately, I did not do enough research to discover that the early 2009 iMac did not have a graphics card that supported audio-out through the minidisplay port (at least not for my base 24\\" model).     I also purchased a 25' long HDMI-to-HDMI cord, and the picture that came across on my 720P Vizio TV was fine. It looked like at least as good as DVD quality, although perhaps not quite as sharp as Blu Ray (if my uncalibrated eyeballs can actually tell the difference).    I can not attest to its ability to stream audio.    I think this adapter may work well for folks with late 2009 iMacs and newer. The build quality of this adapter is such that I wouldn't want to swap it out constantly because it does feel a bit like cheap plastic, so I don't know eactly how durable it would be. However, for the price, you can't go wrong.

This is a replacement for a similar new Lenovo Lenovo 4334-EGU G570 that came with a broken WiFi adapter and whose hard drive failed after a couple of hours. This 43302AU model has a faster 2nd generation i3 processor. Most laptops being sold now with an i3 now have the 3rd generation i3 CPU. This must be a leftover model.

THIS LENOVO *ALSO* CAME WITH A BROKEN WIFI ADAPTER. This is certainly not this vendor's fault. Both models came with a 320GB Caviar Blue 5400 rpm hard drive. WD is probably the most reliable hard drive manufacturer, or at least tied at top place with Toshiba hard drives, so I consider the first laptop's hard drive failure as just an infrequent fluke.

Instead of sending the whole laptop back to its vendor *again*, I called up Lenovo customer support and got them to send me a box with free shipping to send just the wifi adapter back for a free replacement. The wifi adapter card measures 1.5 inches by 1 inch. Lenovo sent me a 22 inch by 15 inch laptop shipping box ! It barely fit into the FedEx mailbox. An alternative would be to give Lenovo an 80 dollar loan paying no interest for 6 to 12 weeks in order for them to first send me a 10 buck replacement wifi adapter. I would then send the broken adapter back to them and eventually get my money back.

I bought a compatible Intel wifi adapter. It worked for about 2 hours and then failed in the same manner. (Win 7 networking said they were connected to the router, but no data would transfer.) I'm wondering if the Lenovo wifi adapter slots are mis-designed and actually burn out any model of wifi adapter. I'll have to wait to see what happens to Lenovo's replacement.

I purchased this router because of the predominantly good reviews it received everywhere I checked. It was easy enough to get up and running. With the dual band I am able to get 300mbps speeds on an N only band. The other band was for G and N and that worked well. Then over time the router began to fail. The wireless doesn't work and when it does there is huge fluctuations over time with the speed. Every night I have to reboot the router at least once. Fortunately I can do it remotely from my upstairs laptop. I know it is the router because re-booting just the router almost always solves the connection problem. So it is not my modem or my provider (Comcast). In addition every few days I get the message \\"You have set the wrong dynamic or static IP address for your RT-N56U\\". When you search on the web for the cause and solution for this error you find scores of threads about it and how there is nothing much you can do about it except reboot the router. I have the firmware up to date but that doesn't help. I am considering using third party firmware which some people say fixed the problem. I am hesitant to use 3rd party software but the router is essentially worthless. It went from being the best router I ever had to the worst over the course of a few months. This seems to be a very common issue with this modem as seen in the hundreds of postings online. Very disappointing.

I am now in the process of looking for another dual band router to replace this one. I will probably buy a different one and before I open it up and install it, I will try the 3rd party firmware with the Asus and see if that keeps the router stable and up and running.

Also, while the design of the router is very cool it is somewhat impractical. With the wires attached it is unstable on the stand and it is very difficult to wall mount. Plus when the remote re-boot doesn't work I have to walk down 3 flights of stairs to my family room and un-plug and re-plug the router power to cold boot it so I need to be able to get to the power cord.

I would avoid this router if you can. You may be like the 5 star people and have absolutely no problems. Or you can be like me...a big fan for several months and now...it is a pain the neck. I have a straight vanilla setup. Comast is the provider. I have a top end Motorola modem of my own. I do nothing fancy. Good luck to everyone who owns one. Hopefully you don't have the problems I and hundreds of others are having.

I bought this to pair with a USB 3.0 card reader, as my computer is older and does not have on board USB 3.0.  Installation was straightforward, and the supplied driver CD worked without issue.  I've only used it a few times, but so far so good, and a great value as well.

To suggest that this soundcard is a dramatic improvement over on-board sound is a massive understatement.  I recently purchased a new computer, one far more powerful and speedy than my old one, but I soon discovered that my media didn't sound nearly as good as I was used to hearing.  I'd had a Sound Blaster Live card in my old unit, but I could not install that in the new computer: It was not compatible with Windows XP.  Hence, I had to buy a new soundcard, not something super-fancy or compatible with speakers in 100 different rooms: Just something that kicks out good stereo sound for a good three-speaker setup, not to mention the ability to utilize more channels should I ever decide to go that route.  The difference in the sound blew my mind: So much richer, deeper, more full in both lows and highs.  This thing makes my computer sound wonderful, whether I'm playing it through my computer speakers or running it through my stereo.  Helps with cd burning as well, as it allows for full-range copying of discs with 24-bit sound.  Highly recommended!

The ergonomics of this mouse may be good, but there are two slight annoyances:  1) The mouse is taller than a typical mouse and so my hand frequently hits it when moving from the keyboard to the mouse and knocks it over. 2) The clicking motion, or the act of clicking the buttons is awkward.  Whereas with a typical mouse your finger pushes down as hard as possible, in this case you are not pushing against the table when clicking, but rather against your thumb.  This makes clicking more like squeezing.  It can also make the clicks less-accurate as it is easy for the click to move the mouse.  I find middle click uncomfortable, right-click less so, and the typical left-click acceptable.  But I am often frustrated when my right clicks end up moving the mouse.

Although the sales copy says it's \\"The Industry's First PCI-E Gen 2 x1 USB 3.0 RAID HBA for the Apple Mac Pro and OS X Operating system\\", it will not work in OS 1-.7.5 or 10.8 machines.

Highpoint finally admitted in a support message that \\"This card doesn't support OSX 10.7.5. Currently there is a technical issue needs Apple design team to fix. We've filed the bug report and still wait for Apple's reply.\\"

When pressed, HighPoint blames the card's limitations on Apple again;

\\"The ball is on Apple design team whether they want to fix the bug or not. From Apple's reply, the bug won't be guaranteed to be fixed. Currently we don't have RU series HBA that can work in OSX 10.7 and OSX 10.8.x\\".

Highpoint will not accept a return, nor will they offer to issue credit toward the purchase of other drives, RAID products or even cables.

The manufacturer seems to be in denial that their product does not work on current Mac OS systems, and they have not corrected their marketing materials to address this limitation.

La Cie and Sonnet claim to make compatible PCIe to USB 3 cards, but I will carefully research these items before I buy;
* The Sonnet card is the USB3M-E, and Sonnet's website claims Mountain Lion compatibility.
[[ASIN:B0054D8G0E Sonnet Allegro USB 3.0 PCIe Card (2-Ports, Macintosh/Windows) USB3M-E]]
* Amazon's listing of the \\"LaCie USB 3.0 PCI Express Card\\" suggests Mac compatibility, but LaCie's data sheet only says it works with Windows XP, Windows Vista and Windows 7. Am waiting for a clarification from their Tech Support office.

The rubber grip is very comfortable and that quirky little disk that glides on the glass allows you to use a real point instead of a squishy foam nib. I wish I read more reviews earlier, but I can confirm (what another indicated about the black version of this card) this card does not allow booting an OS from a flash drive.  I did install the latest driver from Silverstone's site, checked if Windows Update might reveal another driver but nothing.  Lastly, I called their US support number listed on their site & spoke with \\"Ernie\\" who said he was unsure. He later called back leaving a voice message verifying the card is incapable of booting from.  You can only use the card within windows or Linux, just not be able to boot from any drive plugged into this card's ports. Any drives connected to this card's front ports during boot will not be seen in your bios screen.  It seems really short-sighted for Silverstone to not include this capability in the design phase.  I am thinking of returning it for this reason alone  but don't think I'll consider this brand again until I see more straightforwardness on bootability.

This is a magnificent keyboard for the money. Ergonomically typing with the keyboard is very comfortable, tactile response from the keys is excellent, love the multiple adjustments available on the keyboard legs and the eject button for the cd/dvd is great and should be standard for all multimedia keyboards. Mouse is equally comfortable to use with programmable keys, scroll wheel has two settings for hyper scrolling and one click scrolling. I am sitting 15 feet away from my HTPC and the response is instantaneous, no lag or hesitation. The LCD indicator is indispensable as far as I am concern when it comes to knowing if the number lock or cap lock keys are engaged, especially when typing in complex passwords. I have owned Logitech products for years and have never been disappointed, and their customer service is exceptional. As recommended be sure to download the latest software from the Logitech website and not the included disc. Have used multiple keyboards and so far this has exceeded them all. Highly recommended

A fantastic monitor. Truly, an exceptional value. Works great out of the box with Apple products (macbook pro).

I bought and returned a few monitors before finding this one. Initially I bought the Dell S2440L at my local best buy. It was a hasty decision, and I did it in part because I was desperate for a temporary monitor. The s2440l had bad colors, poor black levels, and a bad glossy screen. The base also felt very wobbly and cheap. For some reason, the I could really notice the pixels too. I knew I needed an upgrade.

Since I saw pixelation in the 1080p Dell, I thought I wanted more pixels. I thought this was reasonable since I was use to the retina screen anyway. I jumped up a notch and bought the 4k Samsung U28D590D. The colors where more vibrant, the blacks where much deeper, and it was fun having the 4k experience. It was also nice stepping up into a 28inch monitor, but after a while, I knew it was a bit much. The primary reason for returning the u28d590d was because of an area of the screen which had a a strong green discoloration. It was especially noticeable on darker scenes. There was no way I was going to keep a $600 monitor that wasn't perfect. It also wasn't adjustable, or VESA mount compatible.

After seeing what 4k felt like, I didn't think a higher res was worth it. Sure I couldn't see the pixels, but it wasn't worth it at all. So I decided instead of a low grade 4k monitor, I should get a nice 1080p monitor with the features I want. I bought both the Dell u2412m and u2414h. I had read online that some people actually preferred the screen on the older u2412m. I didn't want to wonder, so I bought them both anticipating I would return the lesser one.

Both monitors have a solid, fully adjustable stand. In fact, both where much much nicer than the more expensive Samsung.

The newer u2414h is better overall. Its colors also resemble those of Apple's monitors, which was important tome. One thing I noticed about all the other monitors was the whites where much warmer than Apple's white. I like the way Apple monitors are calibrated, and this Dell u2412h was very similar (after some small adjustments of course). I actually bought a second one, so now I have a nice dual monitor set-up.

The Dell u2414h also comes with a minidisplay port to displayport 1.2 cord, so it is directly plug and play the MacBook Pros. I actually needed to buy an adapter for the older u2412m. If you have a MacBook Pro and want a monitor, get this one! Make sure to go into your Display settings, Color Management, and change the input to Apple RGB if you want a matching set up.

The thing is a beast, and to go along with having as much power as you need for OC it also is fully modular and it comes with its own ties that can be taken off easily and does not involve any cutting. The only thing I have to say is that I had to replace my case with a full tower because my mid tower did not have enough room in it, but with the NZXT phantom red case its plenty of room.

After 3 solid months of trying to find a computer that was compatible with me, I went back to a brand I have had before, HP. This computer has everything I want and is perfect for me!  I know some people have issues with windows 8, but I took a class on it  when I bought a doomed Toshiba in December. (Plasma screen cracked in 3 weeks, and no, I didn't drop it, it just happened!) I'm an old hand at networking - I've been doing it since I was 12 (I'm 22 now). This device works AS ADVERTISED. In fact, I was only running a 10 Mbps thinnet network in my home before, and my new HPNA network (made of 3 of these cards) marginally outperforms the coax. Over telephone wire! Without interfering with the phone (or vice versa)! Wow! WOW!
This is a great time we live in.
A note: If you're a novice with networking, I don't know how well the included networking software works. As I said, I'm very familiar with networking, so I just installed the drivers and configured Windows' built-in networking myself. If you know what you're doing, however, this is a definitely a GREAT product.
Got exactly what I paid for. Now I can utilized all on Motherboard USB3 ports

The Acer Aspire One is actually a family of various models of netbook computers available in dozens of different configurations. The size is comparable to an Ipad, but with the addition of a touch pad and a real keyboard. Perhaps its biggest advantage over a tablet is that you get a big hard drive and an operating system powerful enough to run several major applications at once. I bought my Aspire One four years ago and am still extremely pleased with everything about it.  Even so, the specs just keep getting better and better with every new edition. Multi-gesture touchpad, 4GB memory, HDMI output, 320GB hard drive, LED backlight display. I wish all this had been available four years ago! You may be tempted to buy an external optical drive to install additional software, but that may not be necessary. If you have another computer you can probably just copy your installation disks to a memory stick and install from there.
Love the color.  Exactly what I wanted.  It seems to be holding up well!  I am happy with it.  The color is exactly what it looked like online.

Very surprised at how good this is. The one I got was the red light color and it is too cool. Makes you want to turn the lights down and get your groove on looking at the hypnotic red silhouette of the box and two speakers.Got a good deal at a great price on this item. When I opened the box I really thought that I paid cheap and got a little plastic toy. But my mind changed when I turned it on knew that I got something good. The red lights are really nice and I just didn't expect it to do to much after that. I watched a you tube video and thought the sound was very clear and nice. There was some music in the background later in the video and that kicked in and boy what a surprise. It can play some big bass. Had to turn it down.  Plays great highs and lows. The speaker wires are joined together when you get it and it took me a moment to realize you have to pull the wires apart to better place and locate the speakers. Now that is the only down side on it but it works, looks good, sounds great and was good purchase for me.

The monitor's display is beautiful, but the speakers are not very good. The display went out after a year and a half, then the problems began. ASUS brags about their quick service, but it took exactly a month from the time I turned the unit over to FedEx before I got it back. Upon it's return, the monitors bezel, which was absolutely pristine when I sent it in, was scratched up, as if it had lain on a workbench and been scooted around on it's face during repair. When I reported that, I was told it was too late to get that taken care of on the same RMA, so I would have to request another! I was not about to do without it for another month, but I received damaged goods back from warranty service. By the way, I was also told that I got the wrong agent when requesting my original RMA, and that if I had spoken to the Customer Loyalty (later) agent, she would have offered me options for quicker service and shipping! Whose fault was that? The display is still very good, but I don't have anything good to say about ASUS!

Pros:

1. It's a Bose
2. Relatively easy to set up even for a non-technical person
3. As would be expected, great sound
4. I didn't expect the ear buds to be comfortable with that funny looking rubbery plastic thingy that fits into your outer ear, but I was wrong (using the smallest size - it comes with three sizes) Plus, they don't fall out of your ears if you make sudden movements.
5. Control for volume and the audio jack are on the same speaker, so easily kept within reach
6. Sleek modern look
7. Not designed for noise reduction, so you can still be aware of what's going on around you.

Cons:

1. No \\"off\\" position - the volume can only be turned down, but not off
2. Speakers are a little on the large side if you're limited for space on your desk - just over 7\\" tall, 3\\" wide and just about 6\\" deep
3. Ear bud case is nice, padded and zippered, with Bose logo, but is too big to fit in your pocket. My iPhone actually fits comfortably inside the case.
4. Ear bud packaging requires a chainsaw and jaws of life to open

Overall, a good acquisition for me as my computer speakers went kaput some time ago, and this is way better.

Amanda Richards, January 1, 2013

I highly recommend these speakers.

If you need a 32GB flash drive with some extra performance, this is the one to get.

I rarely write reviews, this card though deserves one. It gets about the same power as any 2gb 570 card and even 580 cards with 2gb and less - these are 320-bit and 384-bit card respectively, but with only 480 and 512 cores Vs 960 here which about evens things up. And now the kicker - you pay $100-$150 less and have far more energy efficient card, it is as quiet as your loudest fan in the rig and just won't overheat. As another reviewer noted, this card's performance is very close to 670, and the overclocked version (such as Gigabyte's) beats 660 TI.

Very worth it, SLI it and you will have far more powerful setup than with one 680 for the same price. And if you add something like 650 as a dedicated PhysX card you can drive anything in any resolution, 2D or 3D.

I finally got my Netgear wireless upgrade to work, and I wanted to post here in case anyone else is having this problem. I upgraded to the WGR614v3 router and in my remote computer I upgraded to the WG311T 108Mbps wireless adapter. I have Win XP on both computers.
I could not get the remote (wireless) computer to connect to the internet through the router. The local (hardwired) computer worked just fine through the new router. The remote computer's "Netgear proprietary" status display showed the connection was fine. However I couldn't even ping the router from the remote computer. After trying different PCI slots, de-installing and reinstalling the Netgear software and drivers, and everything else you could think of, I finally found the problem!
The Netgear status display software was screwing up the connection. Their own software, and they can't get it right. So, DO NOT USE the Netgear status display software from the CD that comes with your wireless adapter! If you do the normal installation from the CD, you will automatically get this bad software installed on your computer. So don't install straight from the Netgear install window that pops-up when you insert the CD.
If you already installed it, go to "remove program" and delete it. Take the CD out of the reader. Restart the computer. Let Windows sense the device and pop-up the "install new hardware" wizard. Now insert the CD and point the wizard to the CDROM to get the drivers.
Now you have the correct drivers, without the problematic NETGEAR status display. Good luck. Took me 7 hours to find this out, I hope I helped someone. By the way, the network now has a stronger signal and much faster internet.
