On one hand, it does the job as advertised; on my Kindle Fire HD, it definitely charges faster then using a USB cable connected to my computer, and it seems to charge faster then using other USB chargers that I have from other devices such as my cell phone by a few hours. In that regard, it works just fine.

As other reviewers have said, it's also an annoyance that Amazon didn't elect to angle the adapter or have the USB port face to the side opposed to the bottom, as it can block some other outlets on your surge protector or power strip depending on how the outlets are oriented.

The big problem is that I don't like the idea that Amazon is charging $20 for a charger when it should be something that comes standard with the Kindle Fire or Fire HD. I know Amazon is trying to keep costs low, but given that this sort of basic power adapter is included in all other devices I have that charge via USB, it's quite an annoyance. Yes you can wait for it to charge via USB on a computer, and yes a lot of people have other Micro USB charging devices laying around, but customers really shouldn't have to pay extra for it, even if Amazon has put it on sale for $10 regularly.

Had to give it one star because these are cheap and they work-barely. I purchased three of these to archive some old vhs tapes and they serve the purpose for this, but their performance is comparable to a good USB2 thumb drive or SD chip.

I benchmarked this unit with SiSoftware Sandra tool in USB2 mode since I don't have USB3 interface on this machine. The overall benchmark score was 18 MB/s and about 16 MB/s random read/write. Perhaps the results would be better with USB3, but if the performance on USB3 was twice as good it still wouldn't be anything to write home about.

So if you're buying one of these for performance purposes, forget about it. You should look at this drive like a high capacity thumb drive or SD card.

I bought this SSD for around 65 bucks with high hopes. I read a lot of review on it and seemed to find generally positive review for the build and the SSDNow line. I put this into an early 2011 2.7 i7 macbook pro with 16gb of ram. It installed fine with no major issues, 6gbps on SATA III. Upon installation, i ran a Blackmagic Benchmark to find i was consistently getting 80mb write and 125mb read speed. Very slow for an SSD touting 450 and 450 (these are written on the package). I had trim enabler running on my SSD.

I did some research and found that kingston moved from a previous NAND chipset provider to an outsourced and cheaper version, and patched the fix with a 5.06 firmware update, effectively cutting the performance of the drive in half. I decided at that point to keep the drive, since it was much faster than my stock 5400rpm drive, and would purchase a better SSD later.

2 months pass, and my SSD is failing. Kingston knows about it, and has yet to modify their drives. Amazon offered me a refund, which i happily took. The only commendable company in this whole ordeal is Amazon.

Long story short, steer very clear of this SSD unless you aren't booting from it. It won't give you good speed unless you positively get a drive with the faster NAND and the 5.05 firmware. Would not buy again. I returned it and bought a crucial m500

This cooler is amazing, and should be for the size.  I bought a Cooler Master Hyper 212+, after seeing large praise for it across the web.  Well, I'd say that cooler is great if you don't plan to overclock.  On my i5-2500K, I took it from stock 3.3 GHz to 4.7 GHz and my temps were pushing 90C on the Hyper 212+ on full load under Prime95.  Much too high!    I installed the Noctua NH-D14, and my temps immediately dropped to a max of 70C under full load.  That's a 20C difference!  This was using the included ULN (ultra low noise) adapter, which decreases fan speed to make the fans more quiet.  Even with the reduction in speed, cooling was more than adequate.    The unit is of very high quality, instructions are flawless (if you need them), and installed in about 10 minutes.  I will say the heatsink is huge, so definitely make sure it will fit your motherboard, case, and clear your RAM.  Noctua has a compatibility list on their website.  Once it's installed, it really feels rock solid on there.  I have no worries it's going to break my motherboard.  With the Hyper 212+, the heatsink isn't even secure completely once it's on there, because it swivels left and right.  Apparently this is part of the design, and normal, but I didn't like it.  The Noctua is clearly a much more sophisticated design.    I'm only comparing to Hyper 212+ because that's a value cooler that people really like, and I personally experienced.  The Noctua NH-D14 is overkill if you're not going to overclock, but if you're seeking high overclocks, you want it.  It's well worth the price.    Highly recommended!

Many other reviews here are right on, so I will not repeat everything.  I had some persistent and reoccurring wrist pain, carpal tunnel.  I use to roll my eyes when people complained about that kind of thing- not any more!  Holy cow, I couldn't do anything with my right hand (holding a fork, turning the car on, etc.).  Since using this keyboard at work (and similar 4000 at home) for a couple years I have little or no issues with pain any longer.  Don't remember the last time my wrist hurt at all.  That is the primary consideration for me.  I am not super picky about minor details.    I also get an occasional \\"delay\\" as I type fast.  I don't know if it is the wireless (interference perhaps) or just the drivers (PC is busy for a moment).  Not really a problem- it catches up in a few seconds.  I also have used the keyboard for many months, and have found it easy to adjust to.  The mouse was a little harder to adjust to but worth the effort (just remember to move you arm and not your wrist for best results- it's not that hard).  I type by touch 95%.  Expect it to seem odd at first, but really after a few days or weeks it will probably become \\"preferred\\". Other non-ergo keyboards seem tiny and cramped when I have to use them.    -------------->>> I have one suggestion for everyone with this keyboard.  Get some CLEAR nail polish.  Cover your key labels.  The one drawback for this keyboard for me is the most-used letters rub off in the first six months to a year or so.  Clean the keyboard well, then put the nail polish on as a clear protective shield over the keys.  A second coat the next day will help.  Let it dry at least an hour.  You will have to refresh that maybe every 4-6 months for best results.  Well, try it on one key first and make sure it dries well before using it.  Then you can see if it changes the feel for you.  I had to find a silver metallic paint-pen (fabric store) to re-label a couple keys.  [Elmer's Painters Metallic Opaque Paint Marker].  Get all the keys you use- arrows, etc. are easy to overlook until they are blank!  I read other comments where people report calling Microsoft to complain or comment and they are told basically \\"tough, buy a new one\\".  At $50+ I don't think so.  As this is an EASY workaround I won't downgrade the product review, but I am not happy with MS on it.
The description didn't say it was original parts, but when it arrived it was and at a 50% discount from ASUS!  I am in love!

Steve Jobs had returned to Apple, which had been a struggling company, and it was time to align it once again with world of creative users. In 1997 an ad was run with actor Richard Dreyfuss reading the voiceover, which began with: \\"Here's to the Crazy Ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers. The round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently.\\" Think Different... that was the 1997 slogan and theme for Apple's comeback to the world of serious computing after the return of Steve Jobs, and perhaps it was a cynical reference to IBM's famous \\"Think\\" slogan. Whatever it was, this was the ad campaign that restored Apple's reputation under the leadership of the late Steve Jobs.

Take this [[ASIN:B005CWIVYI MacBook Pro]] review as one from a dedicated Windows PC user who made the switch awhile ago, with time enough to put it through its paces, to do side-by-side comparisons. I've owned a Mac before, back in the day of the Macintosh SE, and though I found it to be extremely useful for desktop publishing in the days when Aldus PageMaker reigned supreme in that area, I saw things blend as Microsoft slowly got its act together, for the most part. When it came time to upgrade back then, I stuck with the Windows PCs... until recently, when I found the need to diversify a bit.

To make this easy for those who just want to get to the facts quickly, I'll list the positive and negative points that I've personally found with the MacBook Pro first, then elaborate with details a bit further on. Please also remember that these are coming from a satisfied Windows 7 PC user, and one with multiple computers.

◆ MacBook Pro Positives:

+ Well thought-out packaging, easy out of the box setup
+ Excellent build quality, unparalleled detail in workmanship
+ Superb aluminum unibody chassis construction, has a good solid feel
+ Sharp 13.3-Inch backlit display, first-rate 1280-by-800 Resolution
+ Screen display has excellent color resolution and contrast for photos
+ First class backlit keyboard, easy to use in low-light situations
+ Very fast boot up even with password protection enabled
+ Proven Mac OS X operating system; based on UNIX (like a server)
+ Built-in SD card slot; great for transferring photos to computer
+ Responsive ergonomic multi-touch trackpad; no buttons, excellent cursor control
+ Well-engineered 60W power adapter with decent cable management system
+ Automated incremental backups with Time Machine, works with almost any external HDD

◆ In Between:

± Claimed 7 hour battery life; 5-6 hours is more like it, depending on the apps that you're running

◆ Negatives:

- No built-in HDMI or VGA output, adapters must be purchased separately
- Only 2 USB 2.0 ports, and they are too close together

◆ The Details:

We each have our reasons for the computers that we own. Mine were primarily to have a compact yet sturdy platform for word processing, accessing the Internet, and digital photo processing. That stated, there's little to not like about this MacBook Pro. The Intel Dual-Core Processor is fast and efficient, and even better than the Pentium Dual-Core 2.20GHz processor on my Windows 7 notebook PC. It's one thing to see it in the store, but when one gets it home and takes it out of the well-designed box, it's apparent that this is a better grade computer than might have been anticipated. The first thing that is noticed once it's unwrapped is the workmanship. The unibody main enclosure, constructed from a single block of aluminum, is proof of this attention to detail and it helps add to its durability.

The 13-inch backlit LCD display is sharp, and has the excellent color resolution and contrast that I need, especially when working with photos. The glossy screen actually helps to see images with their full clarity. Using both Adobe software apps and Nikon Capture NX 2, having clear and sharp resolution is an absolute necessity, and this MacBook Pro offers that. The backlit keyboard is a pleasure to use, and quite functional in low-light mobile locations. I'm also very impressed with the quick boot up, even with the password startup screen enabled, a security necessity when at some mobile locations.

It's hard to fault OS X in any way. This operating system is UNIX-based, and therein lays its strength, along with its ability to run 64-bit applications. It works right out of the box without fiddling or tweaking. It's far better than Mac OS 9 and its predecessors, and the security while on the `Net is reassuring.

The tiny built-in SD card slot has proven itself to be good for transferring photos from the digital cameras to the computer. I've also used it to transfer other media files and documents between computers in a pinch. It took awhile to get used to the trackpad, with its so-called \\"multi-touch gestures,\\" but once mastered it's easy to use. Must admit that I do revert to using a mouse when using the computer at home... call it years of conditioning.

This computer really shines with the inclusion of the Time Machine application, and I was happy to find that I could use a reasonable priced off-the-shelf hard drive to do automated incremental backups. I have a [[ASIN:B005J7YAWI Toshiba 500 GB USB Portable Hard Drive]], and all I did was reformat it to HFS+ Journaled file system to use the Time Machine backup software. It works like a champ.

The external 60W power adapter is well engineered and keeps my computer running cooler than PC notebooks with internal power supplies. I appreciate the magnetic DC connector as it pops off easily if some klutz trips on the cord, necessitating a costly repair as I found out when someone did that to one of my PC notebooks. The LED in the connector head helps: amber it's charging, green it's charged; very simple and effective.

◆ Other Notes:

The battery life being less than advertised I can live with. I would have expected HDMI and/or VGA output to be built-ins with a computer of this quality. But I have yet to buy the adapters. But to have only two built-in USB 2.0 ports is irritating, and those are too close together. Problem solved with an external 4-port ISB adapter, so that issue is closed.

I have had issues with laptop carrying bags in the past, and now carry my MacBook Pro in a [[ASIN:B0016LNJXM ThinkTank Artificial Intelligence 15 V. 2.0 Laptop Bag]]. I picked this one over many others from heavy experience with photo gear, and know that Think Tank makes exceptionally good pro gear. It protects my computer from the elements quite well, holds more gear than I can explain here (I have reviewed it), and can highly recommend it to anyone who wants to protect their MacBook with the kind of case that it really deserves.

Browser note: I've used the included Safari browser, but my de-facto standard remains Google Chrome. Safari is a decent browser, but because I find it necessary to synchronize my email on the Mac, the PCs and even one older Linux-based notebook (it's a geek/support thing), Chromes just works better, and I find it faster. Your experiences may differ, so try whichever works for you.

I'm running [[ASIN:B003YCOJB2 Office for Mac 2011]] and have found its interface to be even better than Microsoft Office 2010 or 2007 on the PC. Didn't know if the implementation of Outlook for Mac 2011 would be better than Entourage, which was buggy, but Outlook turned out to be excellent, and it's become my mainstay over the PC version.

Heat is an issue that I had heard of by some, yet I have not experienced. The heat level is better than my old HP, Compaq or Dell, and far better than my VAIO (which was very bad). The only one that has been better heat-wise is my current ASUS notebook running Windows 7, but not by much. Had been tempted to get a keyboard skin for general protection in the field, but heard that these interfere with the ventilation, so that idea has been tabled for the present.

◆ Future:

I may upgrade to 8GB of RAM, which has been recommended by a number of people if and when system performance issues arise. The RAM upgrades are quite reasonable, but I'm pleasantly surprised at how well it runs with the standard 4 GB at this point.

◆ [Updated 3/10/2014]

This MacBook Pro has been in continuous use for over two years now. In the summer of 2012 I did the memory upgrade to 8GB of RAM using the [[ASIN:B001MX5YWI Crucial 8GB (4GBx2) Kit]] in anticipation of the OS X 10.8 (Mountain Lion) release. Detailed notes of what I did can be found on my review of that Crucial 8GB kit, which my be helpful to first-timers. Have also been doing the OS X upgrades, usually about 2 - 3 weeks after they were released to see what bugs may have been encountered. Currently the computer is running the OS X 10.9.2 (Mavericks) update, and though I went through some hiccups with the initial OS X 10.9 release, OS X 10.9.2 has been running fine on this computer.

Am using the Time Machine backup software application in conjunction with a [[ASIN:B008R7FC74 Seagate Expansion 1TB Portable External USB 3.0 Hard Drive]] which has been partitioned; one segment is for automatic backups, and the other segment is reserved for manually saving photo, MP3 and video files. The main thing is to let the Time Machine do your backups automatically as a security measure.

◆ In Conclusion...

I could say more, but the best advice that I can offer is that if you get a MacBook Pro, regardless of which model, take it out of the box, plug it in and charge it. After that, turn it on and see how easy it can be... the MacBook Pro just works, as you'll see. Think Different is a reality, and this one proves it.

JW ▪ 1/30/2012; Updated 3/10/2014ery simple and effective.

I recently spent 4 hours troubleshooting a new installation of this WAP which I purchased to increase signal strength and range. (It was a WAP54G). After much troubleshooting where the Xbox network adaptor (MN-740) would drop the network connection as soon as I attached the XBOX itself to the network adaptor, I realized that the reason this was happening was the MAC address filtering. In order to have the network adaptor actually join itself to the network, you need to add BOTH the MAC for the adaptor itself AND the MAC for the XBOX into the MAC address filtering ALLOW table for the Linksys access point.
I believe that this may solve other issues that people are having with attaching multiple devices to through wireless to these WAPs.
I was very surprised that this information was not documented. It should be stated in the user's manual that if you are using MAC filtering, that you need to add all MAC addresses of all units that are bridged into the WAP into the ALLOW table of the MAC filter.
Right now I'm working fine with MAC filtering enabled and 128bit WEP turned ON as well. FYI - with these Linksys units throughput goes from 54mbps to 18 when 128bit WEP is turned ON. Must be due to the cheap CPUs in these units.
The speed drop when WEP is enabled plus the lack of MAC filter documentation keeps this from being a five star review.

Bought my Dad an iPad and this case for it. Saved a ton of $'s buying this vs the models offered at the big box stores. Very good quality - my Dad loves it and has used it for 7 months now and the case is holding up great. Excellent quality for the money.

I ordered my ASUS Infinity Tablet from Amazon on Wednesday 8-1-12 and payed the $21 for 1 day shipping. They estimated a delivery date of 8-3-12 but I received it on 8-2-12. Its pretty nice to order an item online and have it the next day. The first day I was able to sit down and use the tablet was that Friday. From the very first time I used it I had problems with the screen registering a touch when I was not touching it. The problem got progressively worse the more I used it, until Saturday when I decided to call ASUS technical support. The guy on the phone was as helpful as he could be, but the cold reboot and the factory reset that he had me do did not fix the issue. At that point he told me I need to send it in for repair and possible replacement to ASUS. But ASUS requires you to send the tablet back to them so the can inspect it before they will send you the repaired item or a replacement. Knowing that most people would be upset having to go without their brand new tablet for at least a week he suggested that I try and return to Amazon as they are much faster sending out replacements. Within 5 minutes Amazon had a replacement item ordered with free 1 day shipping. Also you do not have to send back the faulty device before they send the replacement. Once you receive your new device you send the bad on back in the same box. Although it is upsetting to spend upwards of $500 on a tablet that I have literally been waiting almost a year for, Amazon once again steps up the to the plate and makes the return and replacement process as quick and painless as you could possibly want. So for all you people trying to go through ASUS for a replacement just skip them and go straight to Amazon. A big thank you to customer service representative Angelica B for being so helpful and polite in my time of great need. And all you tech nerds know what I mean lol.

And as much as I am impressed with Amazon and their customer service, I am just as impressed with this Tablet.Even with the screen issues straight out of the box, everything about this tablet blew me away. From the awesome HD screen to the screaming fast CPU to ICS preloaded, this thing is just an absolute pleasure to use. Cant wait to see this with Jelly Bean. I have heard people complain about the lack of 4g compared to the new Ipad, but once its connect to my Galaxy SIII's hotspot its just like being connected to WiFi. Got to love Verizon 4G LTE.

This is the first time I have written a review on something but I think you need to know that this tablet is a piece of $*#€!! However there is no app store so he cannot download any games or movies he can only play the ones already on the device which he would find boring. It only has 2 age settings on it so I set it to ages 9 and up but there were a lot of preschool games on there such as Dora. Second: while trying to figure the thing out it kept on freezing on me so I was forced to shut the tablet down and turn it back on!
If I were you I would just buy a regular tablet and then buy a heavy duty case for it. I would also suggest buying a different brand like an iPad or a galaxy note. You know one that doesn't freeze up!

A mixed bag...  The hardware lives up to its hype. It's vastly more powerful and sensitive than my notebook's built in Airport Wifi card. The notebook's built in card picks up three networks in my neighborhood, but the Alfa USB adapter picks up eight! In tests with my own networks at home and work, the useful wifi range is extended considerably.    Unfortunately support is almost nonexistent. I sent an email to Alfa with a question and never received an answer. I also wanted to be sure I had the latest driver for MacOS and discovered the only driver available on the site was for Vista! What about all the others flavors of Windows?...Linux?...and the the Mac? (Alfa claims to support them all.)    After doing more research, I found that an apparently separate company, Realtek, actually writes the software, but I couldn't find any info on the Alfa USB adapter on their site either. This is all the pits.    Further research also shows that at least with the Mac, it's only possible to connect with networks that are either open, or using WEP security. Anything else is problematic. I could not, for example connect to my Airport Express using WPA, and others have reported similar problems.    Another major irritant: The included setup instructions are for Vista only. Again, what about all the other versions of Windows, Linux and the Mac? They are left to figuring things out on their own...    Fortunately for me, I only intend to use the Alfa when traveling and having to deal with weak open networks. For this purpose, the Alfa appears to work great.    Nonetheless, I am severely penalizing the rating because of the absolutely terrible support and terrible documentation. This is not a product for the casual user. If you have any problems, forget about getting any help, unless you can afford to hire an expert, who might figure things out.

Newtrent Portable Keyboard Review

Full disclosure: I received the keyboard case directly from Newtrent as a test model. The entire review was written on the keyboard case, and I feel that I can type just as fast on this as any other keyboard.

The Newtrent keyboard case came in an attractive package, so immediately I knew there was some level of thought and quality to the keyboard case. Upon opening, the keyboard and a USB to micro USB cable awaited inside.

The keyboard case comes partially charged, but Newtrent recommends you charge it fully before using. Once done, my iPad 3 snapped easily into the case and the iPad feels sturdy inside its housing.

I haven't used the keyboard case long enough to tell if the keys will mar the iPad screen in any way when the case is closed, but I plan on updating this review in a little while to report on long-term use.

Pairing was easy as turning on the iPad's bluetooth and then holding down "connect" near the power button, located at the top of the keyboard. The power button is an on/off switch (which I prefer to "auto connect" types because I can then turn off the keyboard's power at will instead of relying on software to do it form me).

To set the iPad up, you open the case and pull back on a sort of slider, which gives enough room for the iPad to rest in one of two notches. I wasn't a fan of this. Additionally, the little latch that keeps the iPad and the keyboard shut when closed was small and troublesome.

Like most bluetooth keyboard cases, the function keys double as alternate abilities for the iPad such as a key for the home button, brightness keys, copy/paste keys, music playback control, volume and a lock key. The keyboard itself had nice travel despite the slightly smaller-than-standard keys (no fault of Newtrent—all iPad keyboard cases need this because of the iPad's size).

Some other miscellaneous notes: on the back, the silver attachment thingy was actually made out of metal, although it looked like plastic in the photos; the iPad can make this case top-heavy, but using the notch for the iPad closest to the keyboard alleviated that somewhat; charging seemed fast; the keyboard had a nice "click" to each keypress that I liked.

PROS

- Relatively lightweight
- Fast charge time
- Three indicator lights tell you what's going on with the case (charge, battery and pair)
- I like physical on/off switches, which this had
- Standard alternate function keys worked well and are beneficial
- Haven't had any pairing or disconnecting issues since I've been using it
- Key layout and size is good given the circumstances
- Nice tactile "click" with each keypress
- Silver thing on back turned out to be metal instead of plastic, so it's more solid than it looks
- iPad can swivel 360 degrees when not in "keyboard typing" mode
- iPad can be propped up into portrait mode while typing (although that's a bit less stable)
- Thinner than some of the other bluetooth keyboard cases I've seen, and it seems to protect the iPad well (I won't worry about taking this thing out and about
- Will most likely replace my magnetic cover/case + apple bluetooth keyboard combination I had been using previously

CONS

- Not a fan of the slider on back to get the iPad into place
- Because of the slider on the back, the iPad has to be propped on one leg if you're using it on your lap
- Latch that keeps the iPad shut was small and flimsy

Overall rating: A-

A very short review:

This drive is a good choice for upgrading or replacing your Tivo drive. I've also used the WD20EARS, which is the older version. This HD offers no advantage over the older drive for use in a Tivo.

Use JMFS to transfer the data from your old Tivo drive. I used the Expand/Supersize options and I have over 300 hours of HD capacity. Also, remember to turn off the idle timeout (using wdidle3) or set it to 300 seconds, and you'll have no problem. Yes, it does work great in a Tivo.

Just bought the 23\\" Apple Cinema display. It works at full res with a GeForce 4 4600 and Windows XP. It has no hardware brightness/contrast controls, but the NVidia driver has these controls + gamma. You can save configurations (such as nighttime, cloudy, office etc) and access them quickly from the taskbar. I have one dead pixel, but at this resolution it is hardly noticeable. You have to buy the DVI to ADC converter to get it to work with an NVidia GeForce card ($$$). There is no loss in quality when using the converter (it is all digital). Color quality and brightness are even across the entire screen. The pixel response is fast for an LCD, but not as quick as a CRT. Still, DVDs and flight simulator rarely exhibit ghosting. Definitely happy with my purchase.

I can't believe the cr*p ratings people give products simply because they have no idea what they are doing or how to use the product they purchased. I did not let the previous 1-star rating affect my decision to buy this card and I hope you will not either!

I am connecting this card to a 1080p capable television (Sony KDL-40XBR6) which was manufactured in 2008, as my computer monitor. I have had ABSOLUTELY NO PROBLEMS with this card. I am giving it 5-stars because the card does exactly what it is supposed to and does so without any issues, and an excellent value at that.

Physically, installation was a challenge routing wires around and over this beast. You must acknowledge the warnings when I say beast. According to the box allow 7.87\\" x 12.6\\" for installation space. When you open the box, the size of this card is breathtaking--especially for me since this is my first card on the higher end of the value range. Measure your case BEFORE you buy or you will be in for a world of stress. Especially ensure your cables are long enough to go around if they have to be stretched over or around and that drives or chassis parts will not contact this card after installation. If you want a quieter cooler rig, then this card will not disappoint.

I only use this card for video, and web surfing--no gaming, but I am more than sure it is quite capable. The card also requires an extra 6-pin power (adapter included) to power it so please be sure you have a powerful enough power supply! The heat sink is so cool to the touch even at an ambient room-temp of 75F. The copper pipes faintly feel warm after running for several hours and even having FOUR 1080p videos scaled and simultaneously playing on my screen with no shutter or lag whatsoever.

I am so happy with my video card and if you are even considering this card, then you will not be disappointed either.

Some notes on installation: I was upgrading from an ASUS HD4350 to this cardto be ready for a descent experience when upgrading to Windows 8. I installed this card under a 32-bit Vista OS. On an alternate drive (SSD) I have the preview version of 64-bit Windows 8 and I have been switching between drives when I want to experiment or I need to work/play. I have had ZERO issues under either environment. In case you are wondering on the performance index under Vista I attain a 5.9 out of a possible 5.9. Under Windows 8 I attain a 7.3 out of a possible 9.9 which is truly respectable with respect to the value of this card. My old HD4350 only attained a 3.2 under Windows 8 for good reason--there are no supported Windows 8 drivers for the 4000 series--and there will not be according to a response I got from AMD.

This is how I suggest you move from your old card to this one if you buy it and you will have minimal issues (this is how I installed mine):
1. download current drivers for your new video card for your current OS from the AMD website and save to your desktop
2. remove software under 'programs and features'-- Catalyst center or software driving your current card (may force restart at this point)
3. uninstall drivers for your current video card in the device manager; if the screen stays blank, that is fine just move to next step
4. do not restart but rather shutdown PC; you don't want your video card reinstalled after startup
5. swap/install your video card
6. reconnect and power-up -- windows generic drivers will get you going until you install the new catalyst software previously downloaded on your desktop
7. be amazed (if you are upgrading like me)

Notice I opt to not use the software that is boxed with the card. I use AMD's software. Two reasons for this: 1)the software I downloaded is the most absolute current version driver; 2)AMD's Catalyst gives me all the control I will ever need over my card (including overclocking).

Hope this review helps. And if you want to see the true satsifaction rating of this card over a greater population, checkout that new egg website.

This item works perfectly fine with the 3DS as long as you are using 3DS functions or games. HOWEVER. If you wish to connect to the Nintendo Servers for a DS game, some problems occur. I found I wasn't able to play normal DS games on Wi-fi with my 3DS, as it could connect to the access point, but not the internet. After a considerable amount of time on the phone with Nintendo, I was able to get it (sort of) working, and while we couldn't narrow it down, try the following fixes if you encounter the problem. As far as I can determine, however, these fixes last only until the next time you use 3DS functions, after which you may have to re-fix:  1. If possible, connect a normal DS or DSlite to the access point, then try reconnecting with the 3DS.  2. Unplug the USB, reconnect it, and toggle the mode from Access Point to Station, then back to Access Point. At this time try reconnecting.

I already purchased two Gripsters for iPad 2 and can't imagine having an iPad without one. This one is fine, but not with the cover. The cover is too stiff and doesn't lie flat, and every time it flexes a little, the iPad goes on or off. I tried bending it a bit to make it flatter, but no luck. I also have a Kensington keyboard/cover for my iPad Mini, but unfortunately it will not fit with only the Gripster back cover and stand, because the cover plastic wraps around the iPad where it would normally fit into the keyboard. In other words, I can use one or the other (minus the wrap) but not both.

One solution (not a good one) is to turn off the Lock/Unlock feature that allows the magnetic cover to turn on/off the tablet and simply turn off/on the iPad manually. Instead of a wrap that has six magnetic sections, Native Union should have made it more like the Apple cover, with three sections. The larger magnets would stick to the surface better and avoid the problem of the two closest to the "hinge" refusing to lie flat. I'm hoping the cover will loosen up with use and eventually work as it is supposed to do.

As with the full-size Gripster, the back cover and stand are very well made. The stand rotates and adjusts for any angle and holds the iPad exactly where and how you want it. The stand also acts as a handle, which I find extremely useful when a surface is unavailable to use the stand. I haven't tried other stands, so I don't know how they compare, but I cannot wholeheartedly recommend this product as I would the full-size Gripster.

Aside from it blowing up within a foot of me, the only thing I can complain about was that it suffered from coil whine. At that point, I was still willing to trust Seasonic for further PSU purchases. I filed for an RMA and received the replacement within a week. Wow. I figured, Seasonic must really care about its customers. Wrong. The replacement I received was a dud as well. It seems to be suffering from internal electrical discharging (you can literally hear the discharges). Worst part about the experience (so far) is that, I believe it killed my motherboards audio during one of its surges. My motherboard did give me a surge protection notice, but I have no way of proving it was due to the faulty PSU. Would they compensate me should it kill my next motherboard? Probably not.

[Update]: Uploaded a video so you could hear the replacement unit I received. Seasonic was initially hesitant to take it back. They only offered another replacement because I kept complaining about it. Third unit was the one that toasted my video card.

I've been trying to contact Seasonic for the past two weeks (through emails and through their automated online forms), but it's all getting rejected. People don't like filling RMAs for the products they buy (especially PC products) anymore than a company wants to fulfill their warranty claim. It's a weeks worth of downtime, and for every shipment, it's at least $10 (without insurance) to ship it. Take note: should the PSU get lost in the mail, they're not responsible. It'd be nice if they actually tested their refurbished PSUs before slapping an \\"OK\\" sticker on it and shipping it out to a customer that has already been let down the first time around. Bottom line Seasonic? If you're replacing a faulty product, make sure the replacement works.

I'll post an update down the line, but for now, to me anyhow, Seasonic represents flaky products and flaky customer service.

[Update]: PSU sparked on me again, melting the PCI-E cables connected to my video card and burning the connects on my video card as well. I complained to Seasonic that the video card has not been the same since the spark -- no real support. They asked me to ship the video card out to them, since they wouldn't cover the cost of repairing it through the original manufacturer. They cleaned out the burnt plastic from the PCI-E connectors and shipped the card back out. What a joke.

The upside -- they sent me a new unit, but only after requesting and complaining over the last 3 units I've had. It wasn't a retail box unit -- just a new PSU with some extra cables tossed on the side.

My advice? Go with another manufacturer, even if the PSU is made by Seasonic (such as Corsair, EVGA).nyhow, Seasonic represents flaky products and flaky customer service.

I initially bought this hub for my Microsoft Surface Pro 3 in order to be able to use my external mouse AND external DVD ROM, however it took a few AC adapter purchases before being 100% perfect.

This hub does it's job out of the box; splitting a single 3.0 USB slot into four potential ports. HOWEVER, this hub in combination with the Microsoft Surface Pro 3, specifically requires an extra cable to be fully functional. The Surface Pro 3 USB port does not supply significant power to USB devices, so this hub (having a AC adapter input) was a great solution to supplementing power to USB devices that have higher power requirements (SDD, DVD ROM, etc.).

The problem is, this hub does not come with an AC adapter, nor did it come with any indication of which AC adapter is needed for it (no included manual, no indication on product page). PLUS, the AC adapter that is suggested on the Amazon product page is entirely incorrect and does not fit/work!!!!

The vast majority of people are not familiar with AC adapter specs/sizes, so I purchased three AC adapters before successfully finding one that fit/worked. For anyone who's interested, it was this one:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003059FAI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
I plugged it right into the hub and plugged the USB end into the USB power slot on the power cord for my Surface. It immediately worked perfectly.

Now, I have a fully functional, power-augmented USB 3.0 hub for my Surface that works flawlessly. I just wish I didn't have to waste $20 getting there... This would easily be a 5-star product if the power cable was included with the hub.

Other than the power-cable issues, this hub is great. Four ports is more than enough for me, the speeds are right on, and it has worked perfectly with every device I've plugged into it.

Although DSI's catalog does not explicitly say, this model uses Black Cherry key switches called \\"MX Linear Action\\". The Black Cherry has linear (=non-tactile; pressure increases linearly as keys are pressed down) and mechanical characteristics; the latter means that the actuator is spring (not rubber dome).  SMK-88 is a rare model coming with such good parts in the compact body.    I found that SMK-88's look is identical to FILCO's FKB91JU (Japanese keyboard) that also uses Black Cherry switches except key arrangement, color, and FILCO's logo. Both models are made in Taiwan and I think by DSI.    The keytop is manufactured not to be slippery. The font being used is very similar to that of Apple keyboards. Black Cherry sound is not noisy like Blue Cherry's. As you learn you don't need to hit keys to the bottom, the key sound will become softer. Overall, it's nice.    For those not familiar with Cherry switches: The Black Cherry has a comfortable but little heavy feeling. Input is finished when keys are pressed to the mid point, but you'll never know it by key touch. You need to get used to it. If you keep hitting the keys to the bottom, your fingers will get tired. I think DSI's Modular Mac Keyboard KB-MODMAC-U is a good alternative. The Blue and Brown switches are available.  I recommend the Brown Switch model that should give you a lighter key touch (but not as light as the Blue Switch model) and a modest tactile feeling. When you pass the tactile point, input is done.

I gave this product a solid 4 stars, would have gone 4.5 if I could have, because of how well built it is and that it does as says. I wanted to write this review to give some future buyers this food for thought.

Besides being mechanical, I loved, in principal, that there are no keys markings; it seemed more elegant and unique, in principal. but in practice, I struggled.

I think this keyboard is very well made and works exactly as advertised. I used this on a macbook pro (yosemite) and windows 7 pro, and had no issues technically of any kind--truly plug and play. no drivers needed. And the hub worked great. The top case is very glossy (not sure if that was noted, but it was noteworthy to me), the keys are a 'normal' / muted finish.

If you are a Mac user and reading this, you probably read about the recommendations to switch your option key, which was very helpful for me, but of course, not necessary. (just a preference thing). and coincidentally, one of the keys worked to pull up the mac dashboard, cannot remember which one.

Unfortunately, I decided I needed to return this. it improved my typing skills (since I could no longer cheat for the parentheses, asterisks, slash keys, etc.), but I had a hard time with passwords, to the point where I felt it would only get worse.

Here is the "food for thought" part:
The tricky part for me with this keyboard was trusting when I create new passwords: am I typing what I think I am typing? When I create a new password, especially a complicated one, I like to look at the keyboard. As a workaround with the Das keyboard Model S, I found I needed the clipboard to create new passwords (typing the password to something like notepad then copying-pasting). But this became cumbersome and offputting for me, and could theoretically become a security issue as well.

Also, I ordered the Cherry MX Blue. I love the feel and clicks of the blue, but it is very loud. Mostof you probably know what you are getting with a Blue, Brown, etc. But my advice would be to go find a store that has one before you buy it if you never have. For me, it is not that the MX Blue is loud, it is that it is very high-pitched, and annoyed me at times. I wonder if my neighbors can hear me typing. At night, when I typed on this, it did seem extra loud.

Finally, the reason I don't give this keyboard a full 5 stars is the price. I think there should be some hotkeys of some kind - a volume mute or control of some kind for the $125+ price. A well made, simple mechanical keyboard feels more like a $75-90 purchase. Are we paying extra for no labels (something that surely saves the company money)? Again, there was nothing unexpected for me - Das Keyboard represents this keyboard very well. And supposedly made it well too - whatever gold keys are (?) It is a texas-based company I think, but my keyboard was made overseas somewhere in Asia.

I have already ordered the Das Keyboard 4 as a replacement. It seems to have more of what I want in a keyboard, and I ordered brown. If I had not been impressed with this keyboard, I would not have ordered another Das product.

Bottom line: if you are aware of the cherry mx blue high-pitched clicking and truly ok with no labels, and want something unique, then ignore my comments, and I am sure you will be happy.

I just finished working with and trying out the Kindle Touch as my first choice of eReaders based on reviews and my son's recommendation.

I have a few observations of this Kindle that ended up with me returning the Kindle Touch and getting a Nook Touch.

There were a number of relatively small issues with the Kindle Touch and then a couple big ones that just tipped me over the edge to the Nook. In no special order they are: Placement of the on/off button is bad, you do inadvertently turn it on and off when you don't want to. The overall feel is just not quite right for me. The screen was slow to respond. The library organization is cumbersome when you get a large number of books in your library. Software interface also has an \\"unfinished\\" feel to it. Not very intuitive. Finding your way around is just not straightforward. The Kindle also does not come with the ability to expand storage memory. The two major issues with it had to do with paging through my library. When I was creating a grouping of books the Kindle would freeze some place in the library and it was definitely frozen. I waited for a long time to see if it would recover but it never did. Hard reset to start all over. The second was at times I would touch the screen to execute a command, wait, then touch it again to try it again, then wait, then try another command to get out of where I was, then wait, then all at once about 5 to 10 seconds later the sequence of commands I had apparently entered were executed in the order I had entered them. Hiccup.

I suppose I could have tried to work around some of these minor issues and get used to them, adjust my habits, but I thought there might be a better option. The Nook. I have to say that after switching to the nook I have had none of these bad experiences. It has been working well and except for a couple of \\"training\\" oversights in the manual I eventually found out all I needed to know through some internet searches to make the nook do everything I expected or wanted to do. The storage memory can also be expanded with a micro SD card. Easy to do but not present in the Kindle Touch. I also like the fact that you can customize the screen saver on the Nook Touch. Small touch, but nice. Also, contrary to the Kindle the Nook tells you the percent of battery life left instead of a coarse icon indicator like in the Kindle. Software interface is simple and intuitive for the most part and for the little issues you may have to start with once your find out how to do something it makes some sense. Again, small differences but to me it shows more careful thought and better software. Sure, the Nook Touch could be improved, like the procedure for checking out books from the library, but nothing really significant.

Summary/Comments: The Kindle Touch seems to have been rushed out to production with a poor software package installed that could account for most of my issues. The nook itself is much nicer from a hardware and form factor standpoint, buttons in nice places, no accidental button hits, with a better touch and feel, and better, easier to use software.

If Amazon comes out with a significant software upgrade to the Kindle Touch it would probably fix \\"most\\" of the issues and it would approach being competitive with the Nook. Still, there are some form factors and feel that make them different that software could not fix.

I purchased this mouse because I was looking for a wireless trackball-like pointing device to replace my other pointing devices.  I've had some trouble with my wrist using touch-pads, mice and trackballs.      The Good:  This device has a standard optical mouse mode, as well as the presentation mode.  It has 5 buttons and the ability to use the trackball to move the cursor while presenting.  Most presentation mice are designed for running PowerPoint presentations, but this device can be used as a primary pointing device.  It also has a laser pointer built in.  I haven't had any issues with battery life, although I don't use it for extended periods of time.  It also comes with a nice carrying case for the mouse, optional USB charger, and USB transmitter.    The Bad:  The trackball sensitivity can't be adjusted, and it lacks accuracy.  the ball itself doesn't move as smoothly as I would like, and it makes it difficult to point and click on certain things.  The buttons are limited in their programing.  There are preselected lists of options for each button and it is not as customizable as I would like.  Also, while trying to use this as a mouse replacement, I found it cumbersome to pick up and put down the mouse whenever I needed to type, so I still use the touchpad or a trackball as well (although this is specific to my attempts to replace my pointing device).    Overall this mouse has the most functionality of any mouse at this price.  If you can deal with the limitations of trackball accuracy and button programing, you'll probably like it.

I received the Amazon Kindle for Christmas, and right of the bat let me say that is a very good reading device. Not only that, but it is from Amazon, and they have some of the best customer support out there. There is no other dedicated eBook reader that can compete with the Kindle; it is a fast device that makes reading easier (especially if you are on the go a lot). The problem has only just set in with the release of the iPad. Obviously the the price gap is over $250 dollars (and I'm sure the Kindle will become even more affordable in the near future), but that extra cost buys you a device with many upgrades, including the Amazon Kindle iPad app. The Kindle still has the advantage of the E-ink screen and free Whispernet access, but the iPad offers so much more that now you really have to sit down and think things through before you buy a new reading device.

The Kindle though is about one thing really-reading. And it does that very well. There are some formatting issues with books that have graphics or tables in them. You will find there are time when the wireless simply will not connect. It feels somewhat fragile, as though holding it the wrong way could crack the plastic front. And you are going to see new release prices going up, not down. But if you are somebody who want a simple, lightweight device for reading. The Kindle is probably your best choice.

Avoid the frustration and just buy the logitech case. It will cost more money, but in this case, I got what I paid for. If I could rate the product with zero stars, I would.

Just as advertised - plug and play. Effectively connected my computer (PC laptop with Windows XP) to an amplifier (connected to speakers) and played everything from the laptop (Pandora, Windows Media, youtube), no software or configuration required. Several months ago, I decided I wanted to have decent spealers to play music from my laptop after bad experiences with small ones ([[ASIN:B000ZH98LU Logitech S150 USB Speakers with Digital Sound]] are weak and sound terrible). I am a complete audio dummy (didn't know what an amp was before buying speakers and reading in the manual that they need to be connected to one). This review is what I learned, hopefully it will help some other dummy. My setup is as follows:

Speakers: [[ASIN:B000OG6I6A Sony SS-B3000 Bookshelf Speakers with 8\\" Woofer (Pair)]] - they are huge, but attractive. The built-in 8\\" woofer technically qualifies as a subwoofer; the sound is good enough that I don't feel a separate subwoofer (a large-diameter speaker that generates bass/low frequency sound) is necessary. These are passive speakers, they don't even have a power plug, and come with only thin wires that have to be connected to a receiver or amplifier.

Amplifier: [[ASIN:B0013CDZDI Pyle PTA2 Mini 2x40W Stereo Power Amplifier]] - an amplifier is connected to an audio source on one end and to speakers on the other end. Most amps are large and heavy; this one is the cutest thing you ever saw. It's small and compact, the size of half a sheet of paper, fitting easily on top of one of the B3000 speakers. The wattage determines how high the volume can be turned out without degrading sound quality. 40W is more than sufficient for home entertainment. I haven't yet turned it up more than 25% of the volume up, and I like listening to loud obnoxious rap music. I chose PTA2 over RCA2 model because PTA2 had more than one audio input, which might come in handy, and according to other reviews, the input plugs are more standard and don't require buying additional connectors. Also, it says it's meant for 4-ohm speakers, while Sony B3000 are 8-ohm speakers, it works just fine anyway.

Wireless audio transmitter/receiver: [[ASIN:B002BDU95A Creative Labs Sound Blaster Wireless Audio Transmitter and Receiver Bundle]] - the box says \\"for iTunes\\" and that kept me from buying it for a few weeks, but it indeed works for everything that I play on my computer from hulu to Windows Media.

This is all I needed. All connectors came with. The actual setup process was ridiculously simple.

1. Connected the Sony speakers to the Pyle amplifier using the thin wires that came with the speakers, matching + to + and - to -, and connected the amp to the power outlet.

2. Connected the Creative Labs receiver (tiny and cute! fits easily on top of the Pyle mini-amp) to a power outlet, and to the amplifier using the provided connectors. The one-ended prong went to the receiver (hole labeled Line Out) and the two-sided prong to the amplifier under AUX2 (matching red-to-red and white-to-black. Made sure the knob on the front of the amp was turned to AUX2.

3. Plugged the UBS stick (Creative Labs transmitter) into my laptop.

4. Opened a new brower and went to Pandora. Voila! Music from my speakers. Bask in euphoric disbelief. Didn't install any software. You may want to go to Sounds in your Control Panel and check that Sound Blaster is selected as the default device.

Listening to music is fun again. I hadn't expected everything to work as well and as easily as it did.ional connectors. Also, it says it's meant for 4-ohm speakers, while Sony B3000 are 8-ohm speakers, it works just fine anyway. Wireless audio transmitter/receiver: [[ASIN:B002BDU95A Creative Labs Sound Blaster Wireless Audio Transmitter and Receiver Bundle]] - the box says \\"for iTunes\\" and that kept me from buying it for a few weeks, but it indeed works for everything that I play on my computer from hulu to Windows Media. This is all I needed. All connectors came with. The actual setup process was ridiculously simple. 1. Connected the Sony speakers to the Pyle amplifier using the thin wires that came with the speakers, matching + to + and - to -, and connected the amp to the power outlet. 2. Connected the Creative Labs receiver (tiny and cute! fits easily on top of the Pyle mini-amp) to a power outlet, and to the amplifier using the provided connectors. The one-ended prong went to the receiver (hole labeled Line Out) and the two-sided prong to the amplifier under AUX2 (matching red-to-red and white-to-black. Made sure the knob on the front of the amp was turned to AUX2. 3. Plugged the UBS stick (Creative Labs transmitter) into my laptop. 4. Opened a new brower and went to Pandora. Voila! Music from my speakers. Bask in euphoric disbelief. Didn't install any software. You may want to go to Sounds in your Control Panel and check that Sound Blaster is selected as the default device. Listening to music is fun again. I hadn't expected everything to work as well and as easily as it did.

Purchased this, and set up was no problem.  Followed the advice here, and immediately downloaded the latest firmware. Moved all of our data, and started to set up backups.  Two weeks in, the unit would make constant beeping noises, and seemed to be hotter than it should be. This was intermittent, but consistently on Sundays just after noon. Tried moving the unit around, to alleviate any heat issues. Looked up any diagnostic information on the beeping, but documentation is insufficient. Contacted LG support online on February 5. TWO WEEKS LATER on February 20th, got a response, not helpful in diagnosing the issue, but merely asking for more documentation about when and where I bought the unit. Unfortunately, this put me just outside the time-frame (2 days) of Amazon's return policy.  I would stay away from this item for two reasons:  1. based on other reviews, there seem to be more than a few defective units  2. LG's support is awful  This is probably a good product, if it worked consistently, but I am very unhappy with my experience.

[[VIDEOID:248763e90f92554b16c7e178a7bd1dee]] I have a ton of USB devices that need charging all the time. Tablets for the kids, my phone, my wife's phone, speakers, headphones, etc..... Using an individual power brick just wont cut it. I have used a variety of different smaller USB hubs and while they work I would still run out of ports or they wouldn't deliver ample power. I had tried a larger USB hub but with that many ports it didn't have the power to truly drive them all.

This solves those issues. The unit itself has a tiny light to show that it is receiving power. The ports are laid out in an easy logical manner. And there are rubber pads on the bottom which are a nice touch. Whats great is that this requires one of those bulky power bricks to power all of those USB ports. It has a separate power brick that is about 3 feet from the unit with an additional 3 footish cord.

Update 8/4: I just got back from a family vacation with 6 children and 4 adults. Everyone had stuff that needed charged. I was a hero with this guy. It worked extremely well and has not disappointed.

I ordered and received three of these tablets, and had to return them today. While we followed the directions and charged them for the full 10 hours upon receipt, the most battery life we got out of any of the three was about three hours. All three heated up to an extent that was alarming. Yes, I know that the lithium batteries heat up, I've had tablets and laptops before, but, this was excessive. I was concerned about my children using them, leaving them on a bed or other soft surface.

With one of the tablets, the home button stopped working, and then the next day (yesterday) the operating system stopped loading.
Tablet 2, the charging cable plastic melted and exposed wires.
Tablet 3 would reboot without provocation.

For all three, the charging cable sparked whenever plugged in to the outlet. The tablets were not plugged in to the cable at the time. Since these did not charge through the USB cables, I was concerned about long-term use.

I wanted these to work. I homeschool my kids, and we use a lot of kindle books. If I had ordered only one and had issues, I would have more of the benefit of the doubt as to whether I simply received an uncharacteristically low quality one, and requested an exchange. The heating issues were pretty consistent across the three units, so, unfortunately, I must return these and search for another option. Any suggestions?

I have a Dell Latitude D430 laptop plus the factory PA-10 series charger that came with it. I was looking for a backup AC adapter and was concerned about getting one that, like the factory version, has an internal ID chip that tells the laptop it is an \\"approved\\" charger. Without the ID chip, an AC adpater will run a Dell laptop but not charge the battery so long as you have the factory Dell software loaded that is used to manage various functions like docking.

After reading the positive reviews, I decided to take a gamble on this Anker AC adapter. I'm happy to say it does indeed function just like my factory charger. This unit will run my laptop and also charge the battery. I verified this using the Windows battery/power monitor function. I also verified it works when plugged into my Dell Pro1X docking station.

As far as heat dissipation goes, both are similar. I used a Raytek MiniTemp gun to measure how hot both got. Under various conditions, both run in the 100F to 110F degree range.

From a distance, the Anker charger looks very similar to the factory Dell charger. The biggest functional difference is the Anker doesn't have the handy rubber strap used by the Dell version to secure the cords when they are wrapped around the plastic body (the rubber strap is attached to the body of the charger so you can't lose it). Instead Anker went with some velcro straps - usable but not as handy as Dell's rubber strap.

Weight-wise with cords, the Anker weighs 13.5 ozs while the Dell weighs 18 ozs. The total lengths of both AC adpaters are nearly the same.

As far as longevity, the Dell charger has been working for almost 4 years now. I only recently got the Anker (fast shipping!) so the jury is still out, but at least it comes with an 18-month warranty. More importantly, the feedback here indicates Anker is honoring warranty returns.

In summary, this Anker AC adapter functions just like my factory charger from Dell.

- Not 32GB, closer to 1GB
When plugging in the USB key, my Windows OS recognizes the drive capacity to be 32GB. I can even transfer what seems to be 32GB of file to the drive. However, upon dis/reconnect, I find that the only contents of the drive are the directories that were copied over, and only the first 1GB of contents worth of files.

- Not built to last on a key ring
If by some off chance the capacity issue is a manufacturing defect, the durability of this USB key is still something that should steer away any buyer. After two days of keeping this thing on my key ring (before noticing the memory issue), I noticed the two lips of the plastic casing next to the hole for the ring beginning to separate. I removed the drive from the ring and with almost no force I pulled the plastic apart and revealed the insides of the drive. I would feel uncomfortable carrying this drive around unless it was taped/re-glued shut.

- In conclusion: Don't skimp on price for this. Stick with Lacie's line of key flash drives. Last I checked they had a 32GB drive for ~30 bucks. I've had an 8GB Lacie key flash drive that's lasted for 6 years on the same key ring that started deconstructing this drive in a few days. I had hoped to upgrade in capacity for a low price, but will end up trashing this drive because it doesn't reliably store data. Even if it did, you'd be better off paying an extra $20 for something that'll last several years, whereas you would otherwise be buying one of these every few months.

In a photograph, it looks simple; in person, this backpack covers all the bases and shows a certain understated \\"\\"classiness.\\"    It has four compartments.   = The front zips down fully to give access to a range of possible items, like keys, flash drives...there's even room for a full-size portable headphone in the full pocket.   = The second compartment, just behind, zips open to a small but deep compartment for miscellaneous items that are somewhat flatter and with less width - good for emergency materials.   = The main section has plenty of room for a MacBook (secured by velcro and protected by a plush lining), with an even larger space in front. Just perfect for my needs.   = Finally, there's a wide section on the bottom for pens and other smaller items.    The material is thick and quite tough, but I was surprised how relatively light it was. Given the loads it carries, the lumbar support makes it easy on your back in transit. Since it's carrying some valuable gear, the design is simple and unobtrusive - you might not think there was so much expensive gear inside. I liked how it keeps bottle-holder out of sight in its  own hideaway velcro slot. At $20-something, it's an exceptional value.    A caveat: If you wear your pack on one shoulder, as I do, you may find that  the lower strap may tear away from the backpack. This has been noted repeatedly. I was able to remedy the problem by sewing monofilament to reinforce the strap. It's not pretty, but this fix extends the life of a pack you might otherwise have to trash. The stitching on the lower left corner is also given to tearing; a hooking needle is your only solution here,    This pack might have profited by being a bit smaller overall. If you're looking for an all-purpose pack, something like the Wenger Synergy might prove more fully versatile -  at twice the price.  This Kensington does the job with panache and restraint - a real winner (if you're willing to do the mod).

I checked out many ereaders before I bought this one.  This by far is the best and easiest to read out there.  Like they say, it truly disappears in your hands when your reading a book (especially how thin and light it is!).  Downloads are lightning fast even with the 3G.  It may not seem worth the extra 50 bucks, but it really is.  It's free wireless downloading FOR LIFE.  Especially great if you plan on getting newspapers or magazines.  The browser is \\"experimental\\".  I hope to see some nice software updates that might make have some improvements.  Don't get this device for web browsing (your will no be satisfied).  That is not what it is made for anyway.  I feel like if it didn't have it already, I wouldn't desire it at all.  One of the other improvements that would be nice with the software would be a clock somewhere in the corner.  I know it's something small, but if you travel a lot and need to keep track of what time it is, that would be a simple yet useful addition.  A lot of people don't seem to like the Kindle because it isn't color.  I've had this one for a while now and honestly, I don't even notice.  As I have read in descriptions before, this is a purpose driven device.  It's made for reading.  It's not an iPad by any means.  The biggest thing that sells me on the Kindle is the screen.  If your going to fly for 4 or 5 hours and want to read a book the entire time like I do, this screen will not strain your eyes at all.  When you first get it, it looks like you need to peel off a plastic cover (that vivid and realistic).  The screen looks like a newspaper or book as it should!  Good job Amazon.

I have been your stereotypical gamer/geek/pc user since i was in 8th grade, and all the time have been deftly opposed to anything with an apple logo on it. I had always accepted Macintosh as a sort of \\"stupid person's computer,\\" since we had used them in grade school to a)type things, b)play oregon trail on game tuesdays, and c)learn to type. Also, while growing up my friend's dad had a Performa PPC that he used to a)surf the internet (what little internet there was back then), b)taxes on quicken, and c)check his stocks.

Now fast-forward. I had just finished my first semsester of college, and i needed a laptop. At first i run to the nearest box store and pick up a thin and light HP notebook, which had respectable specs for what i needed. 60GB hard drive, 512MB DDR Ram, 1.5Ghz Centrino, and an (advertised) over 5 hours battery life. Wow! for only $1399, i grabbed it in an instant. I had it for 5 days. Right out of the box i booted it up and it ran as slow as my roommates 466 Mhz Celeron that we pulled out of a dumpster b/c he is a cheapskate. 10 seconds to boot up Office? C'mon! I had just spent $1400 on a cool-looking piece of plastic that get beat out by 5 year old celerons. Then that amazing battery life was actually around 2-2.5 hours. Wow again. All that low voltage technology and it can't even get past 3 hours? My god i needed something else. So i returned it promptly and started shopping again.

The School Bookstore has always had a plethora of apple products on display because they are one of only two apple dealers in the city (what, Bozeman MT is a small town!). They definitely looked infinitely more sexy than the Performa that my friend and I had grown up with (playing Gridz-- Yeeehaw!) I spent about a week researching this 1.5 Ghz Powerbook. about 19 of the 20 Amazon review gave it 5 stars or (if they could) higher. So i decided to spring for one, because of the Bookstore's return policy and the fact that i needed something before the next semester.

Even at purchase i was still skeptical of buying a mac, and at $2500, i thought, it better be a DAMN perfect computer.

I have had this powerbook for a week now, and i must say: PC users who hate everything apple: you just need to experience it. I thought i would regret the incompatibilities between XP and OS X, but instead, i spend all my time thinking to myself \\"Why the hell didn't MICROSOFT think of this!!!\\" This is hands down the tightest software i have ever had the pleasure to use. OS X is not simple, it is logical. Unlike XP, there are never unavailable options because of your incompatible hardware, and best of all: no baloon info! When was the last time a PC user actually needed to be reminded that they had just removed their Usb Key??? Or, in case of a re-install of XP which i did more often than not, Usually an hour or so is spent making sure the OS worked with the computer as best as possible. OS-X works. period. No tweaking, no secret options to increase performance. OS-X is a PC user's dream! Imagine an OS, out of the box, that is already a finely tuned and stripped of its useless features and software, that doesn't crash, doesn't need drivers, doesn't need setting up, and best of all: WORKS!!! If apple can find an easier way to communicate this with the PC population, i'm sure they will have majority market share in a matter of years.

I love my Powerbook! I'm sure if you're reading this, you've read other reviews that go through all the \\"duh\\" features and battery life, blah blah. Actually, unless you will use this on your lap for very long periods of time (99% of the time it will be on a library table or airplane tray) it get warm(not hot) but i guess it gets annoying unless its cold out. Also, if apple can create a computer like this, they can definitely make a longer battery. i don't think 5-real life hours is impossible with the additional use of lithium polymer batteries to fill up any extra space inside (like the iPod battery) Also, the screen, when closed, is a wee bit wobbly. I want to see AIRTIGHT seals on the lid, but, again, this really doesn't matter. the 12\\" version is rock solid in this aspect, with the lid closing perfectly tight. I guess it's just an ailment of having a big screen. But these are very minor gripes for a guy wishing apple to create the perfect laptop. Although not quite perfect [yet] This is still far superior to any PC notebook on the market today. One more thing: two buttons and a scroll function on the touchpad. Seriously apple, even that crappy HP had that!

But, my minor issues aside, all you need to know is this: I hated macs, am a very literate PC guy (CCNA, A+ certification) who never thought he'd buy a mac. I haven't \\"switched over\\", persay, but my mac is now \\"my computer,\\" and the pc is kept for stuff that doesn't work on the powerbook. Incredible Job, Steve Jobs! An to think, a month ago i was telling friends that Apple should drop computers and just sell iPods! This is NOT the case. My biggest surprise was that this tablet didn't come with a calendar app. I could have sworn the ads said it did.    The Apps Store that comes with it is ok, but doesn't have all of the apps I really wanted (i.e. a calendar app). However, after I updated and rooted it, I was able to get the Android Market, which gave me access to Touchdown that connects to my work Exchange server giving me the contacts and calendar functions I wanted -- plus a nicer email client than the default one.     The touch screen works pretty well, but I seem to do better with the stylus it comes with.  Also, it comes with lots of other accessories...usb to mini usb, mini usb to female usb for keyboard connections, and a case.  HDMI out works pretty well also, but you have to buy that cable.    In terms of an ebook reader, it comes with Aldiko, which works very well.  However, after being rooted, I was able to also download all of the various reader apps...Kindle, Nook, and WordPlay.  All work very well.      If you're just interested in a reader and a bit of browsing, it works great. For other more robust tablet functions, it works with some effort, but is slow.  Then again it didn't cost near as much as an iPad :-)

I got this keyboard after getting the non-micro version because I needed a smaller keyboard for a different workstation.  It is well built and the keys have good responsiveness.  The deal breaker is that the people who designed the layout of the keyboard are not people who use the right shift key (i.e. anyone who types correctly punctuated documents).    Here's the details: they placed the backslash (\) key in between the slash/question mark key and the right shift key and so every time one reflectively goes for the right shift key one gets a result of a \ in front of whatever you wanted to capitalize.  Needless to say this really slows down anyone that is trained with regular typing skills.      Looking at the layout, this poor design is even more obvious when you look at how big the Enter key is and how the \ key could have been placed to the right of the right bracket key (]) as on many other keyboards and had the right shift key be the same size (and distance from pinky finger) as the left shift key, without otherwise affecting the layout.  Very ill-thought design.    The number of times I have had to hit backspace to correct for a \t type error in this review alone is proof of the lack of design input by touch typists.  Needs to be sent back to the drawing board to make that one revision to get real praise.

I ordered the keyboard cover to protect my MacBook's keyboard and, as one might surmise, because it it fun looking.  I also ordered the green snap case at the same time, but the snap case came first.  The silicone cover skin fits almost perfectly, and works just as it should. I've owned my headset for quite awhile now. My previous Logitech headset was crap, some foam-padded, low-level-mic, POS that barely worked correctly for me. I tossed that piece of junk years ago and opted instead for just headphones. After years of using just headphones, I felt it would be best to finally get back into using headsets to communicate--I skype a lot more, I'm a better gamer because of it (TF2, BF3, L4D2, SCII (to a lesser degree)) and I won't be changing headsets.

The set feels very well built. Unless you like to take your rage out on devices, this is going to last you a long time. Yes, it is bulky, so if you don't like massive things covering your head, then I wouldn't recommend sticking with this device. Volume is easy to control, function buttons are nice (although I rarely use them), and the bar mic is actually bendable.

However, there are some slight frustrations with this. First off, if you have an external set of speakers, there's no pass-thru if you have the USB receiver plugged in. I have my receiver wire plugged into the back and it's a pain just unplugging it if I want to hear things through my speakers. Luckily, my desktop speakers are crap, so I only play things on them if I want others to hear.

Secondly, there seems to be some mystery as to how long one must depress the power button for this thing to actually turn off. I'll hold it for two seconds, release, and it'll remain on. Sometimes I hold it for less, other times I hold it for five seconds and it finally disengages. It would have been nice if Logitech just put an 'on-off' switch instead of a power button, so I don't have to hold the thing in and hope that it turns on/off when I release it.

As for other reviews that I've read on here, I doubt that this thing will ever break with normal, continued use. Also, I've never experienced a buzzing or interference when I enable the mic on it. I've read just to drop the mic gain and seeif that works, but as far as this unit goes, it's not a problem.

Pros: AWESOME AUDIO, comfortable, wireless and it's LOGITECH!
Cons: Difficult buttons, no pass-thru for external speakers

I have written a review for the green case- I have now had it for 3 months, and am buying a black case for 2 reasons, 1) this case is the best option I can find, and I've been really satisfied with it. BUT .. 2) it doesn't last long. I think the key is to have a couple of them and rotate to reduce wear and tear.     Here are the reasons why I am buying a second one: The materials are really light. Though light cardboard does not wear and tear well, it is light. the other leather cases I have come into contact with are super heavy, and weight for me is a crucial factor. The design is better than a lot I have seen, and it's actually a nice, soft cover - it feels good in the hand and in the bag. The other options, pcu back and smart cover, make for a hard, sharp little tablet. In my purse, it gauges me, but more importantly, I would be more worried about dropping it than I would in the ipearl case. cardboard, though bulkier, is softer- I think it will absorb shock. maybe I'm wrong, but it feels safer to me. The stylus thing is really handy (replace the stylus!), I like the hand strap, the prop works well.     Cons: the strap. It's a great idea. It's losing it's strength after 3 months, and the ipad is slipping in it's case because of the strap and the cardboard becoming more flexible. Waah! it drives me nuts.     So, it is not going to last for years, but I can't find another one as well-designed or as light, and it's working really well despite these annoying issues, so I am going to try the idea to have more than one case and rotate to reduce wear. ($40 for two, instead of $40 for one I am not thrilled with...)    bwt. it does have the magnetic thing, my ipad turns on and off when I open/close the cover.
