Microsoft Takes on Chromebooks with HP Stream 13 and 11

Microsoft has always been competitive in the PC market. With the growth of Chromebooks, there has been some concern that Microsoft is losing its edge, especially in lower-priced computers. The HP Stream 13 is one of the new models that may provide a solution to that problem and become competition to Chromebooks.

The Good and the Bad
For those of you who want the bottom line right up front, the HP Stream 11 and Stream 13 has both positives and negatives about it. The main reasons to purchase this PC is its price and its ability to run desktop apps, including the full version of Windows 8.1.
On the other hand, the main issues that users may have with this smaller device is that it is slow to boot up and only has an average display and touchpad. However, with a price of $200, it has a lot to offer budget-conscious users.

In-Depth with the HP Stream 11/13
The HP Stream 11 is attractive to look at and will visually appeal to many users with its bright cobalt blue shell. You can also select the magenta shell. Either option is more fun than traditional laptops. The smaller size provides the feel of a netbook, and it is lightweight enough to carry around with you at 2.74 pounds.

A white keyboard contrasts nicely with the interior colors and makes it a fun device that you don't usually see at this price point. It has a modern design that will appeal to a younger generation or anyone who is tired of the plain black and grey designs that you usually see in budget laptops. With the same ports you would find on a full-size device, the HP Stream 11 is fully functional. It provides 3.0 and 2.0 USB ports and an SD card reader along with a headphone jack and HDMI socket.
The one downside of the hardware for both the HP Stream 11 and 13 is the lower quality display. It doesn't have HD-resolution and the colors can look dull. However, that is common at this price and just a trade-off that you expect to make.

Performance
In this area, there is good news and bad news. The good news is that the battery life on the HP Stream 11 as well as HP Stream 13 is decent. While it isn't the longest running computer, at just over eight hours, it has a decent run time. It beats out many other Chromebooks in this area and competes well with others.
The bad news is on speed. It uses an Intel Celeron N2849 processor, but it runs much slower than many Chromebooks to boot up. It can take up to a half-minute to be ready to use while many Chromebooks take less than 10 seconds. If you aren't in a hurry, this may not matter to you, but it is a fact to be aware of. File transfers are also likely to be slower than on more expensive models.

A Winner in Software
One of the big wins for the HP Stream 11 is the ability to run a full version of Windows 8.1. Microsoft is also providing 1TB of storage on OneDrive free for a year, which is plenty of storage for the average user. You can also download apps onto the device for convenience. It features a one-year subscription to Microsoft Office 365 to allow you to do all of the things you need on the device.

Can It Compete?
What it comes down to is if this new device makes Microsoft competitive to Chromebooks. The answer is both yes and no. Yes, because it offers many of the features that you see on Chromebooks that appeals to users. No, because the truth is that there aren't many competitors at this price point. Most of them start at $250 and go on up from there.
What this means for Microsoft is that the company is not only being competitive with Chromebooks through the HP Stream 11 and 13, they are winning on price. For the user focused on price, they definitely get their money's worth with this device.

This is easily the best keyboard I have ever owned.  The keys are very quiet (including the spacebar, which most keyboards have a snapping sound to) as well as the mouse.  The mouse has a \\"stuffed\\" click sound, which is very gentle and very useful if you have roommates or have a baby napping nearby.  The layout was a tiny bit weird at first, mainly because the backspace is touching the 6-key rotation to its right, which took about 1 minute of typing to get used to.  The keys themselves are tilted at a certain angle for comfortable typing and have sticker-based letters so they don't fade if you're an avid typer.  It's the same sticker-like letters that was on my old keyboard which I have owned for 3 years and not a single letter has faded away on it.  It's very good for gamers, as I use the QWER very often for games.  Mouse is comfortable to hold and move and the scrolling is natural.  It even has a slot at the bottom of the mouse to hold the USB for easy transportation without losing the little fellah.  I also like the low-battery indicator on both the keyboard and the mouse.  It's very sturdy and has nice grips on the 4 corners at the bottom and when lifted for the higher adjusted it has 2 grips, but just as stable.  It's very sleek and polished, which gives it a nice feel-good look when typing.  Overall a great product and a great price for it.

It works! There really isn't anything to say after that, but I'll try to make the 20 words. OK. The main thing is the quality looks pretty good, and it's real time, so it is only takes as long as you make it. For people with a more modern DV recorder, I guess you could consider a two step process, moving the VHS over to a mini DV tape, then to you computer, but if your Digital Video Recorder is a little older, this is by far the best way to go, if you are a MAC user, unless you want to spring for a lot more $$$. The directions could have said to install the software, make the hook up connections, and turn the VHS Recorder ON! It forgot that part, but no problem. You can screw up completely but you will eventually get it with this device because it is so EASY. I went up to the Elgato site before starting, to obtain the most current software, since I'm on a Lion IMac with a targetted Mac Pro, just to skip the potential need to upgrade. You probably don't have to do that but why not! The bottom line here is that this is a flawless device with software to match. I'm giving it 4 stars, so that I don't look like a groupie or something. I would be hard put to come up with a negative but I gave it 4 stars because it was just to dam simple. It has a lot of potential, so it's going to be a lot of fun to work with and not have to worry about everything going crackers on you. You just do video. All those home movies that only you will watch. The kind that bring tears to your eyes, not because they are so bad (they're pretty bad, though) but because it's about family and the little things you did together that were so BIG.

I purchased the 500GB model of this SSD. Used it to replace a 1TB WD Black being used on a Windows 7 gaming rig. The difference is night and day. I use Linux most of the time, which handles being ran off of a regular HDD just fine. But Windows just runs horribly on them. Upgrading to SSD has dramatically dropped boot times, load times, and overall stutter that I was previously experiencing on the computer. If you're on Windows, you absolutely need an SSD.

The price on this drive is just right. The perfect balance between size and price. The drive itself isn't top end, there are much better SSDs out there, but at this price point you really can't complain. If you want to drop an extra $100 just to get the best SSD out there, go for it, but in reality you probably won't experience much of a leap ahead of this drive.

it is OK for $200, at $400 it would be a complete rip off there are much much better made and higher spec windows tablet devices in the $400 range. Not even close.

For $200 you get a somewhat hot running tablet, that sports a rather poorly sensitive screen. The Keyboard is very cheap, flexes when typing and suffers from some bad ADHD (it that it cant stay focused for more than a few minutes.) The keyboard and tablet combo completely fail to be useful because while typing focus jumps from one box to another. Same thing happened to other using the machine so it is not my typing style.

We got this because it is cheap and we would not have to worry about it getting stolen while we travel. It serves that gap nicely. But this is not a primary device in any way shape or form, it makes a good surfing tool , but really requires you to sit at a table to type, there is no way to use this on your lap without it falling over and focus jumping around.

The magnetic connection with the keyboard is very weak and breaks with the slightest movement, where as most two in ones have much better mag connections that require force or a trick to disconnect...

overall if you need a short term , cheap device this is OK, if you want something to last 1 or 2 years, I suggest finding something else.

I have this side-by-side with my original IPAD. This device blows the IPAD 1 out of the water with regards to speed. But, no matter what the angle, the IPAD display is beautiful, colorful and bright by comparison and this looks dull. Also, the IPAD looks the same from all angles and this display changes with minor head movements. I went to the store to compare all the tablets (Surface, Surface 2, Galaxy Note/Tab, etc.) and realized that this is just the way of things. Speed and performance can be had for low prices and this tablet is fine in this regard, but display quality still costs extra. For me, this is the reason that the IPAD, Galaxy Note and Surface are 3 times as much. Another friend who viewed the tablet noted that the display looks different from the IPAD in that it *looks* like it has glass over it. Or, put another way, the display looks a little sunken beneath the glass when compared to more expensive tablets.

Update #1 - the power charger died after today. It still charges, albeit much more slowly, with the USB cable. I tried to find the charger but no luck. The model is SBC-05020. This is one very hot wall wart although I guess that could be because it's dead :). Still a tablet without a charger isn't much fun.

Update #2 - a friend showed me that not all miniUSB chargers are the same. He leant me his old samsung laptop charger which provides 2.0A at 5V and this charges my Matricom about 10% every half hour. This will do as an alternative charging device.

On the other hand, the tablet had performed flawlessly all day. I installed XBMC and it drove my HDTV through the HDMI cable with no problems whatsoever. Now that's impressive. I do experience what others are saying about the wireless, however. In fact, while download XBMC, the speeds went from 100kbs to 200kbs depending on my distance from the router (30 ft to 10ft). Still, it's not a big deal since I should extend the router's range anyway. Eventhe IPAD and iphones will disconnect in the furthest corners of the house and the difference between these devices and the G-Tab is only 10 or 20 feet shorter in range.

Update #3 - I have now emailed Matricom customer support about the dead link to the recovery image with no response.
Here's the help page about how to recover:[...]
and here's the dead link: [...]
My old slow IPAD is still a supported product after all these years, this product seems unsupported right out of the box. How do I recover when/if it crashes? Where do I get a charger?

Update #4 - Customer support exists! I had no luck with the emails or ticket system but I got an instant response from the \\"online chat\\". They provided me with an updated link and I now have a recovery image for the G-Tab:
matricom.netSLASHwikiSLASHRestoring_the_Quantum_10

That is much better. Thanks. So how did I miss this. I must not have searched correctly.

I'm glad that it worked for you! We've recently added a Wikipedia to our website. Here is the general link for it: [...]

Background:  I'm using the WNDR3800 in a 3-story wood-frame house, in a medium-density neighborhood.  The router is on the middle floor, and I get a good wireless signal throughout the house.  I am one of those people who have good luck with routers; my last one is still working after 2 years, and the previous one lasted many years before finally dying.  I bought the WNDR3800 because testing comparisons at smallnetbuilder dot com indicated that it would have a better wireless range than my old router, and have features that I wanted, like a guest network, built-in OpenDNS support, and a Traffic Meter.  Initial setup:  I was impressed with how easy this router was to set up.  I simply unplugged my cable modem, disconnected the old router, and connected the WNDR3800.  I powered up the cable modem and the new router.  I went to my wired Windows 7 desktop and pointed the browser to routerlogin dot net.  I clicked on the big button that said \\"Take me to the internet\\".  A few seconds later the desktop connected.  I updated the firmware to V1.0.0.24 by clicking a button.  Wired networking:  My old router used the 192.168.0.* address space, and this one uses the 192.168.1.* address space.  Most of my wired devices, including my Windows 7 PC, Canon printer, TiVo Premiere, and Windows Home Server, grabbed a new IP address without having to reboot them.  My two older TiVos had to be encouraged to get a new IP address by going into their network settings menus and selecting \\"get (an IP address) automatically from a DHCP server\\", but this took less than a minute and did not require restarting them.  My wired Blu-Ray player had to be rebooted.  Wired transfer speeds between two gigabit Ethernet devices (my desktop and the server) averaged 100 MBps (800 Mbps) for a 0.5GB file.  Netflix streaming to my wired Blu-Ray player and TiVo works without stutters.  DLNA video streaming from my home server to to a wired Blu-Ray player works great and is snappy.  Both my husband and I use Cisco AnyConnect to connect to the VPN servers at work, and neither of us has had any trouble connecting through this router.    Wireless networking:  The router is preconfigured with SSID names and a password for both the 2.5 GHz and 5 GHz networks.  I dreaded setting up our two notebooks, Wii, three iPhones, iPad and a Kindle again, but it was as simple as selecting one of the network names, and typing in the easy-to-remember but hard-to-guess password.  The 2.4GHz gives an excellent signal throughout our 3000 sq. ft. house.  The range on the 5GHz network is somewhat shorter, but there are no other 5GHz networks close by to interfere.  My iPad 2 is the only device that can connect to the 5GHz wireless network; Netflix streaming and DLNA streaming to the iPad works without a hiccup, one floor up and two rooms over from the router location.  My iPhones and iPad are running iOS 5.0.1, and we have iTunes 10.5.1 running on our PCs; Wi-Fi sync between the PCs and the iOS devices is working well over both the 2.4GHz and 5GHz networks.  The Clear Channel Selector worked as advertised.  In my neighborhood there are six 2.4GHz networks on channel 6, two on channel 1 and one on channel 11; the WNDR3800 chose channel 9 for its 2.4GHz network to minimize interference from the other networks.  Administration:  Setting up parental controls with my existing OpenDNS account went smoothly, and now I don't have to run the OpenDNS updater desktop client on my PC, because the router takes care of that.  For my Windows Home Server, I was able to reserve a fixed IP address and forward several ports for remote access.  I turned off UPnP, because I saw that my son's computer was trying to forward several mysterious ports.  The Traffic Meter, which is a great feature, is listed at the end of the Advanced Setup menu.  The reported bandwidth usage seems consistent with what I had measured previously using the Tomato bandwidth meter.  I found it easy to save current router settings to a file from the Advanced menu; I like to do this before a firmware update.  The guest network was simple to turn on:  just check a box, pick an encryption method, set a password and click \\"Apply\\".  Guests cannot see other computers on my regular network, and I can quickly turn the guest network off when I don't need it.  One week later:  The WNDR3800 has been working perfectly, no dropped connections.  I'm glad I bought this router, its wireless range is better than my old router and wired upload/download speeds are improved also.

Probably the most affordable, and well featured 4K out there right now. Totally solid. Some of the other 4Ks I looked at didn't support 60Hz at the full resolution, which is just ridiculous, but it can be hard to tell without really digging in sometimes, because they'll still list that it's "60Hz capable", which is ridiculous. I bought this for a coworker, and he's loved it, though I don't personally have one of my own yet.

I'll mention that my light Carbon X1 Lenovo running a recent Ubuntu plugged in and utilized the 4K without any issues. Apparently some driver changes in recent OSXs means that most MBPs will not be able to handle 4K. There was _one_ short range of the Retina machines (perhaps late 2013?) that do not have this problem. My friend just happened to have one, and this monitor monitor worked fine for him, though he might have had to go tweak some settings to get it to work at the correct resolution or refresh rate; don;'t remember exactly. So, long story short, do your homework. OSX may have already gotten better about supporting 4K, but you should make sure before purchasing. If you're running Ubuntu, don't worry, you're fine. My computer doesn't even have a dedicated graphics card and it was flawless. No idea what Windows might do.

I needed a simple tablet to run a single purpose application. I was skeptical at first due to the price, but the reviews were good so I tried it out. It's been working great so far. My only complaint would be with the Windows 8 OS. Microsoft did improve battery life, load times, and reduced some bloat, but I personally hate the Metro stuff and the lack of a proper start menu. Fortunately, the Classic Shell app takes care of this and brings the start menu back, which negates the issues. The only other possible issue would be the lack of storage space. It's about 5GB left after Windows, but we only needed about 500MB, so it didn't matter. If you do need more space, you can just add an SD card. All in all, a solid tablet that's a great value for the price.

I have gone through 2 of these in one year of daily use in an office environment. When the first one broke I thought it was just bad luck, so I bought a second one. IT BROKE EXACTLY THE SAME WAY! What happens is that the wires on the left side speaker are poorly constructed with poor isolation/insulation material, so eventually you get a short circuit of the wires as the chaffing inside the left-ear piece wears down the lacquer electrical insulator, creating a short circuit, which causes the left speaker to work intermittently, and eventually stops working completely. Then if you keep using it, eventually the right speaker wiring will also short. The company that makes these needs to redesign them with better quality materials, even if it costs a few dollars more. Stay away from this product until they redesign the wiring.

Being visually impaired, I have not been able to use most reading devices since the print is too small or if I was able to enlarge the prinit, I still  had to scroll back and forth to read the lines. I was given the Kindle for Christmas because it has the \\"text-to-speech\\" feature, which allows me to hear the book rather than read it; however, it also has the option to enlarge the text so, whith the help of strong reading glasses, I can actually read it. Even when set on the largest text size, the lines are contained within the screen so no scrolling back and forth is necessary. Large print necessitates clicking the page turner often, but the back/forth page buttons take very little pressure so their use becomes second nature quickly. I have only run into one \\"glitch\\". One of the books I ordered from Amazon.com came in such small print that I was unable to read it even when the text size was at its largest. (Make sure when ordering a book, that you first try the \\"sample me\\" version to see if the text can be enlarged enough to read). Other setting options include a choice of number ofwords per line and line spacing, which make a great difference for the visually impaired reader. The screen itself differs from a computer or ipad screen in that it's not as bright; however, I purchased a small clip-on book light that compensates when more light is needed. The Kindle is advertised as being able to be seen in sunlight and it really is true which makes it possible to read outdoors or in the car. The buttons are much too small for me to see without assistance so it was necessary to memorize the most important ones, ie, the 5-way controller, home, menu and back buttons. (If the keypad were bigger, this item would be perfect for the visually impaired!) Also, the text on the menu and homepage cannot be enlarged which is a drawback, however, instead of ordering books from the portable Kindle, I order them from the Amazon website from my computer which sendes them quickly to my Kindle. Another great feature is that I have installed the Kindle for PC on my computer which syncs it with my portable Kindle, so when necessary, I can go to the computer version to \\"see\\" what I can't see on the portable version.  Curling up with a good book used to be a long-lost dream for the visually impaired, but Kindle has made it possible at a very affordable price! The Kindle iteself is comparitively moderately priced and the price of books is not bad. I've found many that are free and the most I've spent is $9.99 - unheard of for giant-print books if you can even find them.  My only problem now is being able to put my Kindle down long enough to get my work done! :)

Let me first say that I have no talent to install protectors. Over the years, I have not been successful applying the thin film protectors on any of my devices without bubbles. I had a Tempered-glass protector professionally installed on my iPad when I bought it and loved it. When I got my iPhone, I order a Tempered-Glass protector for it also. I Installed it myself and it went on perfectly with no problems. This gave me the confidence to put one on my iPad-mini. So I order Anker Tempered-Glass thinking it would be just as easy to install. I was wrong. I followed the instructions, touch the center as instructed and it started adhering perfectly. But four bubbles developed toward the side and bottom edges. I tried to work the bubbles out and it reduced the size of the bubbles but did not eliminate them. I removed the protector 4 times trying to reapply, but more bubbles developed each time. After a while I just gave up and through it way. I can't say it is a bad product because it looks and feels exactly like the ones that cost me a lot more. However it is not fool-proof and people with no talent like me should just spend the extra money to have a protector professionally installed, even the temper-glass ones.

Early Adopters Beware - I'd be a bit wary about the GTX 970 right now, based on my experience with it from two different vendors. My EVGA GTX970 SuperClocked ACX 2.0 card arrived recently and I did a straight up replacement for my GTX780.

I believe I received a defective version of this card. On first boot, I noticed red lines streaking the monitor, which made me immediately power down and reconnect everything. Same result. So then I switched to a different PCIe slot, and even a different computer - with same results. I finally allowed the card to boot, which it did, and installed the most recent Nvidia driver. The card proved very unstable - the red lines persisted, and Windows kept blanking out reporting that the display driver had stopped responding. Once, this resulted in blue screen. After about an hour of trying to troubleshoot, one of the fans on the card began making a noise like an air raid siren, unlike anything I had ever heard before. Immediately powered down, validated all internal and external connections, and tried to power up again with same results. Unreal noise and still had red lines and stability problems.

So back in the box it went, and it's on it's way back to Amazon as we speak. I couldn't get a replacement sent from Amazon as the card is out of stock with no estimated date. (Of note, I have also previously tried a GTX970 from MSI, which arrived DOA -wouldn't even boot). This makes me think that this is an Nvidia issue more than an EVGA issue. So I'm back to my tried and true GTX 780 for now, and will be a way early adopter of Nvidia products in future.

I don't doubt that there are people whose 970 cards are working fine, but 0/2 is enough to make me pause for a while on this generation until they've had more of a chance to work out the kinks.

The default RAID 5 settings appear to work just fine. But, I really wanted to set it up as a RAID 1, with strict mirroring.

I tried RAID 1, RAID 3, and RAID 5.

My RocketRaid 4 port eSata card would NOT see all of the drives, except in RAID 5.

If I tried any other configuration, the RocketRaid bios could only see the first drive in each enclosure.

I purchased 2 of these units, and eventually wanted to purchase 2 additional units, for a total of 4.

Using RAID 5, I managed to get the RocketRaid controller to see all of the available disk space in both units.

Again, any other configuration, was useless.

It appears as if the manufacturer may have tested the functionality under RAID 5, as that is the default configuration, out of the box.

But, it appears as if they just threw the other RAID options into the box, without testing their functionality.

As I've only had the units up 24 hours at the time of writing this review, I can not comment on their reliability.

I do LOVE the front panel, as it is very informative, and I love the ease of disk insertion.

It's just a shame that the units only allow for a fractional use of their potential.

Bought this unit in October of 2012 exclusively as a second back up of all my iTunes
music and my modestly-sized photo collection which normally live on my MacBook.
(My first back up is on/in the Cloud.)

Very easy to connect, set up, and use. Nice and flat, compact. Resides in a locked safe
for most of it's existence, so any observation with reliability is unfortunately useless,
since it only comes out and gets hooked up once a month or so for updating of the
files.

** But one observation I did notice was that the cable connection was very questionable.
The cable would pop off from the LaCie if I happened to move the LaCie hard drive.
What I found was that the orange rubber cover was actually preventing the cable from
seating properly! Taking off the rubber and carefully enlarging the port hole with an
X-Acto knife allowed the cable to seat just a bit deeper into the drive connector. Hasn't
fallen off since. **

Overall, I made a good choice buying this unit.

I have upgraded the firmware twice and still there are bugs. One bug has even been introduced by the latest firmware. MAC filtering no longer works after the latest update. The router requires physical rebooting at least once per session. It assigns IP addresses that are not in the allowable IP string, thus disallowing the connection. When it drops my connection, it must be physically restarted before allowing me to connect again. It's a horrible waste of time and money. I will never, ever own another D-Link product. I have owned and operated Linksys, Netgear and D-Link routers. D-Link is the worst by far. Buyer, beware.

When I decided to finally get a wireless mouse, replacing my Logitech MouseMan dual optical, I tried a few bluetooth mice first. Bluetooth mice just aren't as responsive as a wired mouse, and while you might not notice it immediately, within a few hours you will be annoyed. I tried mice from several vendors (Logitech, Kensington, MacMice) and all exhibited this. I was about to go back to wired when I decided to try the MX700, and I haven't regretted it for a moment. Just as responsive as a wired mouse, comfortable feel, great battery life. I only charge it at night, and haven't had the batteries run out once in several months of use!

Bluetooth is great for keyboards, cell phones, and the like, but for a mouse, forget it. Go with a high-quality RF mouse like this one. You won't regret choosing the MX700. And to top it off, it's cheaper than Bluetooth.

My house is just large enough to need an access point in addition to my main router (ASUS RT66U). So setting this router up in access point mode does some strange things that I worked many hours one night to correct with no success.

When you select "Enable Access Point Mode" other fields such as the router's IP address don't work. In my case I'm stuck with the router assigning itself 192.168.1.175. It's been long enough that I don't remember everything I tried, but having configured several routers in my days I finally concluded this was simply the only way it was going to work.

I've never had much luck getting good speed over wireless-n but here's a warning that's written right into the specifications. Since the wired portion of the router is 10/100, your wireless-n will definitely be throttled down to something less than 100 Mb/s. My connection speed is generally 75 Mb/s so I've had no opportunity to test this out.

However with the quirks in the firmware (and I only mentioned the one that bothered me the most), and the limitations, I think it's a good little router for 95% of people. Well actually I can only attest to the Access Point part of this box so maybe regarding actual routing functions, take my review with 175 grains of salt.

I ordered this from another manufacturer (a new something that you eat for breakfast) last October and it is now August and this PSU literally just exploded during normal use and probably fried some other parts in my computer.  I had just started a game and I heard a loud pop and a flash of light and the PSU was dead.  I already ordered a better brand so I took this one apart and saw several capacitors burnt and melted together.  STAY AWAY FROM THIS POWER SUPPLY.  It could ruin your computer or burn you house down.  It sparked so hard it charred the wall behind my computer.  I have never had a power supply last less than a year only to blow-up during routine use.  I should have taken the hint and bought one sooner when this PSU also blew up a power cable I was previously using on it.

I own two of these V7 22\\" wide screen LCD's which I use in a wall-mounted, side-by-side configuration. Typically I have a browser or other research app running on one monitor and a document that I'm working on is on the other. I've been very pleased with the performance of the V7's in this configuration. This has turned out to be a great monitor for browsing, for office work for viewing photos and even for watching movies. Some reviews suggested using a DVI digital connection, so I changed to DVI. Wow, it made quite a big difference! The results were excellent. For the price, these monitors can't be beat. I am typing right now on this \\"Classical 104 keys mechanical gaming typing keyboard\\"!

When I decided to buy a mechanical keyboard I was hesitant. Isn't the keyboard that comes with the computer good enough? And could I justify buying a mechanical keyboard for $100 bucks? Well, this suspicious product from a suspicious company was the happy medium. For $40 I would get a chance to test a mechanical keyboard... even if some of the keys looked a little funky.

Considering any type of hardware coming from a sketchy company, I was surprised that it plugged and worked right away. The keyboard is heavy, and definitely feels like a quality product. While some people might not be fond of the orange keys... they actually make little to no difference while typing.

However, in my opinion the main issue with this keyboard is the damn backspace key. The backspace key honestly seems to be the smallest key on the entire damn keyboard, which means you'll really need to practice on this keyboard for quite some time before you truly are able to make some gains in typing speed over a 'friendlier' membrane keyboard.

All in all, nice solid product, and I figure I would do them the courtesy of reviewing (now that it is back in stock!). Clickity clack my friends

I'm giving this 5 stars, because the current rating is way off. The problem people have with this computer is that it's a low end computer and they are expending it to perform much faster than it will. This computer should be compared to an HP Stream line of laptops.

Next: Make sure you should read this review: (http://www.amazon.com/review/R2WSA678YAXX25/ref=cm_cr_dp_title?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B00SIJH3TG&nodeID=541966&store=pc) by Johnny Gonzalez (March 24, 2015). He's an owner that tells you what to expect and how to improve the machine. I have to correct Johnny on one point. I looked up the memory size limit and Dell specifies that this laptop has one slot that will take a 16GB memory module.

You should also note in your research that being able to upgrade is a big plus, because now days in the low end market [Windows and Chrome] memory is soldered on and not upgradable. And on most Chromebooks the HD are not accessible for upgrading.

Plus the Windows version is 64Bit so you can use the full use memory past 4GB. This isn't true on many of the other low-end Windows machines.

Also I found this machine on sale today at Dell and Fry's for less than $200 while at couple of online stores I note the price at over $300. So be sure to shop this machine.

Now for the most surprising thing I found: Dell sells two different machines in the Inspiron 14 3000 series. The better of the two isn't listed on Amazon, but you can find it on Dell's site. The other machine comes with 4GB of RAM and the Pentium N3540 quad-core processor (almost twice as fast as the Celeron N2840 dual-core found in this machine). And the best part was that it was only $80 more (sale price at this time) for the much better computer.

One last point: I think it's extremely unfair to rate down this machine because it has Windows 8 on it, because you're going to get Win8 on any Windows machine you buy today. So if you rate it down for this one you have to rate all Windows 8 machines down the same amount to be fair. IMHO: If you don't like Windows 8 you can replace it with a copy of Windows 7 OEM ($100), or Linux Mint (free), or Windows 10 preview (free).ir. Summary: if the "ultimate protection" is what you want and don't frequently need a keyboard, this is definitely a candidate.
Installation: The installation is almost exactly that of the NT610KR. The same tabs, same TPU (rubberized outermost layer, silicon skin). The only difference is this unit doesn't have a keyboard. There's a potential adjustment for the leather hand-carry strap.
Features: This feels like a bulletproof shell over the Air. It feels substantial, safe, secure. The ports are all securely covered, except the camera. Odd, for I thought a claim is this unit is splash resistant. I'm not sure what happens if water gets splashed onto the cutout for the camera (and I'm not going to try any experiments!). There's a collapsible arm stand that unfolds at a great angle for my use. It is metal and strong. The large "wheel" on the back lets one rotate the arm stand in 360 degrees, locking in on 45 degree angles. The only downside is the protective front screen. It is not quite as clear / transparent as the Air without a protective film and actually shows moire patterns. Perhaps this is a small price to pay for the degree of protection. Last, as a burgeoning aviator addicted to ForeFlight, I'm better able to secure this device in the MyBigClip kneeboard velcro strap than the NT610KR.
Conclusion: If one prefers the durability, the security of the NT610KR without the need for the keyboard most of the time, this unit is for you.

I use this adapter alot, especially for my Xbox and and LAN parties.  The adapter has the full set of Wi-Fi channels that you can toggle between so you can connect this adapter and another one via Adhoc mode for head to head gaming, an autosense mode that connects to any unprotected 802.11b wirless router, and then 3 profile modes that you can configure special network settings for, such as Wirless Encryption.  It's the configuration of the 3 profiles that can get real annoying when you take it to somebody else's house and have to use the supplied CD in their home computer, hardwire the adapter to their router, and configure it using the software to recognize their wirless network, then disconnect it and then connect it to your gaming console. If you forgot to bring the disc, you will have a fun time digging on linksys's website for the software. The antennae on this adapter is not spectacular, expect to get a little more than half the range you would with a wirless notebook. Problems aside, this is still the most affordable option for wireless gaming, not to mention the adapter's other uses as a wireless ethernet bridge for computers and other devices (since "wirless bridges" usually cost 99 bucks) it's still a great deal

I've been webcaming for 5 plus years, started with Windows 98SE now using Windows XP desktop--using Skype, MSN Messenger to Windows Live Messenger. My first Logitech webcam was the Pro 4000. About year and a half ago I purchased the STX (because it was on sale) and wanted a backup just in case the Pro 4000 gave up the ghost---this December (2008) had to retire the 4000 and installed the STX. Wished I had installed the STX sooner because the STX has a far better picture/video and sound/audio quality over the 4000.

I've read here, in the user reviews, where some people are having \\"issues\\" with their Logitech webcams not working correctly after installation and with Skype, Messenger, Yahoo etc.---maybe I can provide some helpful info to correct those problems.

First, when installing the Logtiech software from either the CD or directly from the Logitech website---if it asks you if you want or has a checkmark in \\"Logitech Desktop Messenger\\" say NO or UNCHECK it (if you find that it was installed then un-install/remove Logitech Desktop Messenger) there is \\"something wrong within it\\" which will cause your webcam not to perform correctly---I discovered this while doing some research on the Logitech forums.

Secondly, after the installation, when you are done selecting your webcam's video/audio settings to your liking---and you have any of the \\"video chatting\\" programs (Skype, Windows Live Messenger, AOL, Yahoo etc.) then go to each individually and do the webcam settings (audio/video) to make sure audio/video is working correctly and that that program RECOGNIZES your webcam---do this BEFORE making your first \\"video or audio chat\\".

Hope these helpful hints help those who maybe having problems.

PROS - much improved sound in a sleek unified unit, adjustable settings *****
CONS - cover not durable, inaccurate set-up instructions, some sound artifacts ***
These speakers make me want to start watching movies and tv on my ipad. Seriously, once I set it up and heard a bit, I started looking for available movies which I had missed. Previously I found the ipad too weak of a player to be interested in online videos, but the results with this device are impressive. I really like the way this sleek case with multiposition cover becomes part if the ipad itself, making it so much easier to use and move around than other ipad external speakers. I don't mind the extra width needed for the speakers themselves, but if you carry it around a lot, the added weight could be annoying. Two+ people could easily sit together and watch something.

These speakers also do a great job with music, letting you hear more instruments with clarity, and bass notes, than with either the poor little built-in speaker, or earbuds.

MY CAT: was alternately captivated and frightened by the meowing sounds that came out of these speakers when I played some cat videos from youtube, which shows how much better the sound quality is (previously she has never been interested in cat videos before, either online or over-the-air on our tv). I tried to find technical specs on the Belkin site about frequency response (so I could compare it to my old audiophile equipment) but I couldn't find any; however the verizonwireless site's description of this product claims it is 40-20,000 Hz, with a signal to noise ratio of 91dB.

With the (non-required) app, you can set music source to either music, cinema, or gaming, for different sound qualities, and you have three degrees of speaker separation. Apparently lots of this is done through digital signal processing with a chip and amplifier in the device. As the sound channels are more widely separated, however, some echoing appears as an artifact (which some may enjoy).

ISSUES: Overall, I am really happy with this device, however:

- Regarding design, when the cover is closed, the little Belkin charging light in the speaker area is covered (I am considering punching a hole). Also, though it is \\"smart cover style\\", it doesn't have the little magnet that automatically turns the ipad on and off as you open and close the cover (I am thinking of trying to add one myself). Additionally, if you need to connect to the ipad for some other reason (e..g camera connector, moving files to a laptop), you have to take it out of the case, not that big of an issue however. Otherwise it does a great job preserving access to all the switches and ports and cameras, and it is nice that it charges the ipad itself as well as the Thunderstorm speakers. (However, I am concerned that wattage is not optimized for the ipad and may cut battery life).

ETA: After little more than a week of use, the edge of the cover has started separating. This does not affect the great sound of this product, but is quite disappointing. It still works fine as a stand, but is a bit fussier to open.

- Regarding documentation, they said to install the Thunder app (implying that it is necessary), then start using it. Well, once the Thunderstorm was installed and the app was opened, all it did was direct me to a web page of support info, which only told me how to mechanically install the Thunderstorm (which I had already done). It didn't tell me how to get from the app support page to actually allowing me to change the sound settings, and there seemed to be no way beyond this window. It took me a long time to contrive a way to make this work: leave the app, start playing a video in youtube, and then restart the app which finally realized that I already has the Thunderstorm installed, then finally it let me change sound settings. But it turns out that the app itself is not required to use the device, only to change sound settings -- you can just install the Thunderstorm and start listening (without the options that the app offers). (It would be nice if settings could be changed in some way within the video playing, instead of having to leave the video and fire up the app.) And, as noted above, the only place I could find technical specs were on a third-party page. Belkin needs to be more accurate and complete with information both in the box and on the website (this may have improved by the time you are reading this).o use the device, only to change sound settings -- you can just install the Thunderstorm and start listening (without the options that the app offers). (It would be nice if settings could be changed in some way within the video playing, instead of having to leave the video and fire up the app.) And, as noted above, the only place I could find technical specs were on a third-party page. Belkin needs to be more accurate and complete with information both in the box and on the website (this may have improved by the time you are reading this).

Dear Toshiba,

I regret to inform you that I am returning your computer. I've managed to beat the deadline for returning the computer by 4 days. Amazon has agreed to pick-up your slack and refund me my money. This is the second Toshiba I've owned and oddly enough they both have the same problem. My battery should charge when I plug in my power supply. I should not have to turn the computer off, take the battery out, push the power button for 30 seconds, do a rain dance and say 5 prayers to get my computer to run right every time I take it off the charger.

I commend you on your selection of your customer service company you outsourced to. I was not fooled though, "Ivan" sounded suspiciously Asian. I do not dislike Asians, but don't try to fool me by tagging them with a different name. Some of my best friends are Asian or of Asian decent. I digress.... back to the topic at hand.

After purchasing your computer I immediately had problems. Your website said I needed to change the power supply. I did and there was no change in status. Computer still broken. I tried your all wise website again. It felt I needed to try changing the power supply.... again. No, I'll take the guy with the heavy accent this time. After an hour of waiting and being transferred, the guy was very polite and actually a good credit to your company as I have said earlier, but he was only authorized to tell me to send my computer away to a service center and inform me that I'll get it back in a few weeks. No thank you. I can do without coffee for a few weeks. I can go without human interaction for weeks. I can't do without quick books for even a few days. "Please send me a new computer so that I may transfer files and YOU can have the broken one," I said. Better yet, "Give me a refund so that I may purchase a different brand. You can still have your broken computer."

Ivan was nice enough to inform me that I had run out of decisionson his end and that repairing their broken computer would still cost me two to three weeks of downtime. The best he could offer me was an address to Toshiba in California where I could write a letter and let it rot on someone's desk. No thanks, I'm hoping this gets your attention sooner than that snail mail letter.

In case you want to find me, you can look up my contact information through my computer serial number which is 8D338950Q.

Sincerely,
JPL

As the title states, this product is entirely useless outside of purely data file transfers. This is due to a decision made by SanDisk to strictly enforce the recognition of their flash drives as hard disks rather than removable media in Windows.

My particular issue with this product is that I bought it for work to help with installing Linux on some computers. Unfortunately SanDisk has decided to take the stance of non-cooperation. Almost every other vendor of these devices has either 1) Not arbitrarily decided to change the industry standard of having flash drives appear as "removable storage" in Windows 2) If they have, they have provided software to allow us the users to best decide which mode suits our needs.

In order to create a USB "LiveCD" of Linux a common tool used is Unetbootin which cannot recognize this drive as a result of SanDisk's incredibly consumer-unfriendly design choices.

This product is one borne of indifference and no one should contribute to the decadence of SanDisk any more than they have to.

Also, it takes multiple seconds for the keyboard to reconnect to the bluetooth when I stop typing for a minute or so... this is a great idea to save battery but it's a nightmare when researching and writing or chatting with friends. I wanted to love this and I have given it a solid period of time to test it out but I guess now I am going to have to shell out more money for a different keyboard probably from the fruit company themselves.

If you do not plan to do a lot of typing or type slowly this is a great keyboard for you! Otherwise beware!

This recently became my full-time mouse, and I will reluctantly attempt to adjust to it until a better option that fits my needs as well appears.

PROS:

It's a small form factor, the palm rest is adjustable but even at maximum (15mm) it maintains it's small appearances. I like this because mobility and not creating clutter is important to me.

This is a right handed mouse, my hands are not overly big and it feels comfortable to me to use. I have always used my mice with a claw grip or relaxed claw grip and this mouse allows for comfortable operation using these grips.

The extra buttons are well placed and handy for gamers of all genres.

Feels solid and sturdy, nice soft materials for the non glossy finishes.

CONS:

This list could be quite large mainly due to the fact that while aesthetically it is a very appealing mouse, functionally it severely falls short of expectations. I would have returned this mouse had I not thrown out the packaging prior to using it for a period of time.

I have not experienced the connectivity issues that many here have experienced. The Bluetooth connection initiates fairly quickly when resuming from sleep, and after extended mouse inactivity the delay is minimal. However, connection after start-up is buggy. At times I have had to wait up to 30 seconds, and at times I've had to restart the connection all together.

The USB dongle also feels useless, it fails to provided an added performance benefit over the Bluetooth when it should be expected. When I plug the dongle in it always has to install drivers, every time, and it takes up to a minute for the connection to finally establish and the mouse to be useable. I've tried multiple methods of installing drivers and software.

Now the the real issue. The 6400dps laser sensor is very poor, inadequate, and inaccurate. It fails to track on many surfaces, including a Razer mousepad. The movement seems awkward, jagged, delayed, as if the cursor was refreshing at 20 fps. I've attempted numerous settings and registry adjustments to eliminate mouse acceleration and provide a smoother experience but it simply remains very sup par when compared to wired mice like the Thermaltake Ventus or very old Razer mice.

The price is reflective of the looks rather than the performance. The performance is poor in-game as well as desktop and the price is very high compared to it's value in my opinion.

*********** PLEASE READ LAST UPDATE FIRST. THERE IS SOMETHING SERIOUSLY WRONG WITH THIS ROUTER*********
The router arrived in the mail today. Setup was extremely easy and quick. Instructions were clear and simple. Unplug modem, connect router to it, turn both on, go to your laptop, open browser, go to routerlogin.net, update firmware and you are done. The whole thing took less than 5 minutes. My first netgear router took 5 hours to setup.

Performance: I have not tested ac speeds yet, but on wireless n it is really great and stable. I noticed that I am hovering around 25 Mbps download on all devices with little change. I also noticed that speed is remaining relatively stable on other devices while say streaming video on iPad or syncing large files to Dropbox and so on. In case you have not used netgear routers before, this is a huge deal. Previous models used to bring speeds to a crawl on other devices once you stream video or sync to a cloud service.

Range: I live in a 900 sq ft 2 bedroom apt, and I am covered all the way down to the parking lot.

Software: this is not news but netgear making software is like a chicken writing poetry. This is my 4th netgear router in about 8 years and they still have the same bad, constantly freezing, unresponsive, unintuitive software. In case you have not guessed, I am talking about the so called \\"genie\\". It is really bad. I tried it online, on desktop and iPad. And it is frustrating and confusing in every which way it could. Besides, it does not like chrome. It works much better and freezes a lot less on Internet explorer. It does get the job done but you want to get away from it ASAP.

Customization: this is a new generation of device, meant for the non-techie public. As you might know, the router got a bad rap from early adopters who tend to be demanding highly knowledgeable users. The router comes already set up with typical settings down to network name and unique randomly generated password. If you start fiddling around, for tighter security, more control, custom channels, device priority etc... You will run into a lot of trouble. However, if you keep the typical settings, it works flawlessly. Don't try to bake a pie on a toaster, use it for what it is, a shiny toaster.

Looks: I have to put the router in my living room close to the tv because I need the wired connection for The various netflix streaming devices. And I have to say it is BIG and UGLY. It has less lights than previous models and no blinking lights but it has a big NETGEAR brand name front and center. It feels like I am running an infomercial for netgear in my living room. Note: its large footprint makes it a lot sturdier than previous models, much less likely to tip over.

Now, I have owned this router for about 12 hours and I will be updating over the next days and weeks as I gain more experience.

Update 12/07/12: can you say stable. This router continues to amaze. The wifi connection on both bands, multiple channels is just
stable. I can't believe how fast my iPad is downloading apps. Note: my frame of reference is my previous netgear WNDR4300.

UPDATE 01 11 13: I have had R6300 router for a little over a month. Initially it worked perfectly, consistently giving 25 MBPS down and 4 Mbps up wirelessly on my windows laptop, iPad, samsung galaxy nexus, and Asus android tablet. A few days ago the speeds dropped significantly on all devices for no apparent reason. I can barely get 1-2 Mbps down and 4 up. IT is like a slow death where the download speeds keep dropping daily. I called Comcast and they advised to connect laptop directly to the modem (Motorola SB6141) via Ethernet. That gave 25 Mbps down and 4 up indicating it is not the modem or Comcast. So I turned off the router and unplugged for a minute then turned it back on and the same problem continued (1-2 Mbps down). Then I reset the router through the orange reset button andset it up over again, updated firmware using genie and kept same network names, passwords and security as configured by factory. Again I am still having the same problem, download speeds are miserably low (1-2 Mbps down and 4 up).
Note 1: I tried streaming Netflix over a wired connection from the router to the Sony bluray player and it streamed fine.
Note 2: I disabled my laptop wireless adapter and connected through wireless USB adapter A6200 on 2.4 and 5G but also got 2.33 Mbps down and 2 Mbps up.

the connection is not getting dropped, the router is not rebooting, no blinking lights. All my devices show a good signal to router locally. Just slow internet and slowing further as we speak.
I do not know what to do next. Something suddenly went wrong with this router, and I cannot figure it out. I contacted netgear but have not heard from them yet. I also posted on their forum but have not gotten any good answers yet.set it up over again, updated firmware using genie and kept same network names, passwords and security as configured by factory. Again I am still having the same problem, download speeds are miserably low (1-2 Mbps down and 4 up).
Note 1: I tried streaming Netflix over a wired connection from the router to the Sony bluray player and it streamed fine.
Note 2: I disabled my laptop wireless adapter and connected through wireless USB adapter A6200 on 2.4 and 5G but also got 2.33 Mbps down and 2 Mbps up.

the connection is not getting dropped, the router is not rebooting, no blinking lights. All my devices show a good signal to router locally. Just slow internet and slowing further as we speak.
I do not know what to do next. Something suddenly went wrong with this router, and I cannot figure it out. I contacted netgear but have not heard from them yet. I also posted on their forum but have not gotten any good answers yet.

I am overseas and purchased the Kindle International Version because of frequent travel.  I like the Whispernet feature of being able to receive books and subscriptions even internationally -- when it's AVAILABLE.  Usually it is, but when it isn't, I'd still like to be able to get the products and subscriptions.  Amazon offers a download to computer and transfer to the Kindle via USB option, but they seem to have disabled it in order to \\"encourage\\" people to pay the international delivery surcharges.  I've ordered a number of items in the last few days, not to mention the already paid-for subscription to the International Herald Tribune that I wrote to customer service about a week ago and have yet to receive a reply.  I am unable to download any of these e-books or other Kindle products via my computer which is supposed to be an option. I bought it because it was cheap and near the top of an alphabetical list of Bluetooth adapters with good support in Ubuntu. I plugged it in and it worked out of the box in 64-bit Kubuntu 13.10 and I was pleased as punch. It paired with my phone and headset with no issue, but after 30 minutes of playing with PulseAudio, I still couldn't get music or GTalk calls sent to my headset. Fine, whatever, it's also a cheap headset and this might not even be related to the IOGEAR USB Bluetooth adapter.

What IS related to this product, is the lack of support for Windows Server 2008R2, which is in almost every way identical to Windows 7. I haven't even been able to get the crapware installed that everyone else is rightfully complaining about. I've used both 7-Zip and Universal Extractor to dig into both the CD and the downloaded driver installer and I've extracted what appear to be two usable .inf files complete with their .sys files, but Windows has problems installing each one, giving me a generic error and all but a sad trombone of failure.

Judging by the rest of these reviews: even if I could get it installed, I'd probably regret it. If you're on a Linux-only system, you'll probably like this adapter.

I bought this because I didn't need high transfer speed. I am just using it to play music. Ordered this drive from Amazon on Feb. 28th, 2013.

BUYER BEWARE ...

NEW REPLACEMENT DRIVE FAILED IN JUST 10 DAYS !!!!!

Corsair forum has listings of people complaining that their drive also failed ...

I can see maybe one drive failing, but TWO in less than a month?

NEVER AGAIN ... IF YOU BUY THIS PRODUCT, DO NOT PUT ANYTHING YOU NEED ON IT AND EXPECT IT TO BE THERE!

I eagerly bought a magic trackpad as soon as it was announced. I love the trackpad on my MacBook and I was thrilled at the thought of having a trackpad on my Mac Pro.    What a disappointment.    I spent a week using it. By the end of the week I wanted it to die a slow painful death. Perhaps I could put it in a shredder or drive a car over it and cackle as it was destroyed.     The problem with it is very simple, and perhaps even correctible. Clicking.    Tap-to-click is far too sensitive, and the sensitivity is not adjustable. It was constantly thinking that I had tapped on something when I was thinking I hadn't. My laptop's trackpad doesn't have this problem. If there was an adjustment for the sensitivity, I could have adjusted it and probably ended up happy.    You can also click by pushing down on the trackpad; it's all one giant button. But it takes vastly too much force to click that way. I don't have any way of measuring, but I estimate that I have to push 10 times as hard on the trackpad to get it to click as I do on a mouse button. It literally wears out my finger, and it's very clumsy. And, again, there is no sensitivity adjustment.    If Apple comes out with a revised version of this trackpad I'll buy one and try it, because I really want it to work. But this one doesn't work.

If it's open network for free, like in McDonald; then you should be able to connect.      The definitely of open network, is it free network you have known\\"      I'm at a loss. I haven't been super impressed by this one. The computer is pretty enough (although I share the frustration expressed by other customers regarding the touchpad/mouse area). I've only had it for a few weeks now, and haven't really added any major software other than a Windows/Office Premium upgrade, and yet it seems to be bogging out (if not outright crashing) fairly consistently. I mean, I know that the i5 processor isn't a maximum unit, but I certainly would've expected more reliable performance than I've gotten out of this machine.

I just can't quite figure out if the issues are with the hardware architecture itself or some issues in the ways that the Acer software interacts with the Windows system, but every moment is somehow connected with a crash, either just recovering, trying to feed me crash reports, or getting ready to crash again...

This unit provides what looks to be a decent platform at a good price, but in practice I kind of wish I'd made a different choice.

Let me tell you a story, of how I pictured yesterday going. I would get the Fire, plug it in, charge it load a bunch of content on it and to my cloud storage and go!  Reality though was a bit different.  Anybody that calls this a cheap tablet needs to be taken out and smacked with a stack of Ipad 2s until they come to their senses.  It is not a tablet, it isn't even that good of a book reader.  For as long as Amazon took to work on this, it feels rushed and buggy.  When half of amazons own content wont even work with it at this point and the plans for fixing that are months or years in the future.  It does have a few good things.  The sound is good, as are the colors and the sharpness of picture.  The fact I could at least drag and drop part of the content directly to a folder was very nice indeed.  There are 3 main issues.   #1, as has been said by many.  The Information and  buying have to be shored up. Look Amazon, I know you see this is a way to sell stuff any time somebody wants, but you need to use a bit of common sense.  #2, It is SLLLLOOOOWWWW.  If this is Amazons idea of a speedy unit, I would hate to use one they considered slow.  Changing from one thing to another has a noticeable pause, and if the unit is on for a couple of hours, the pause can be in the 3-5 second range before it does whatever you want.  #3  The big ZERO for me though, is the fact though Amazon has had many months to get ready for it, content they themselves are pushing, such as the Unbox has no timetable for an update as I was told sometime in 2012.  It forced me to upload content I purchased from Amazon, to their Cloud service to load it on my device.   If you want a device that does everything the Fire was advertised, I would wait until the Fire 2 or 3 comes out, or do like I am going to do, return this and buy a Nook.

So, a month later and we're still fighting to get Linksys or Marvell to fix critical issues with the router.  It hardlocks on both stock and OpenWRT firmware due to flaws in the wifi driver.  Marvell has now been saying for 3 weeks "will fix later" which is absurd.  If you buy this and use devices on the 5GHZ spectrum (which is EVERY AC device), expect the router to hang up on you at least once a month without warning.    Neither Linksys nor Marvell have put in any effort to correct this.    Original review from more optimistic days: At least the latest trunk build as of May 2015 works.  I have pretty much all of the functionality of OpenWRT although not all of the bugs have been fixed yet.  Still it's been going strong for several days now.  The stock firmware is both unintuitive and limited.  It was apparently designed to be pretty, but for the price this router normally goes for, I can't see paying that kind of money for this thing.  It's selling point is getting the Open Sourced fancy firmware's running.  Which is what I have going right now.  Codel QOS, Dual-Band 802.11ac, partridge in a pear tree.  The refurb box I got says its Linksys Certified Refurbished.  It came with the router, antennas, ethernet cable, quick start guide.  Pretty much everything you'd expect.  And the price of the refurb is more in line with what I think this router should cost anyway.  Thumbs up.

Garbage... I wish I had purchased an apple product. Out of the box it worked fine for two week... After that, it takes forever to load a web page, constantly needs updating. Its fine for most features.  Light weight, nice picture, fast enough, etc.  Specifically, though, the sound quality and overall volume is fairly poor.  This is important because it is something that asus specifically advertises as a feature of the this model.  From their website: "High-quality stereo speakers with extra-large audio chambers give performance that surpasses their miniscule size! Crisp, high-fidelity sound can be enjoyed anytime, anywhere with Chromebook."  This is not true.  Not at all.  Sound is no better than my 2 year old outdated samsung chromebook.  Overall volume is surprisingly low.  Plus, the speakers are on the bottom.  That means, when this is sitting in your lap, the speakers are muffled.  What the hell, Asus?  Why not put the speakers right next to the screen, so the sound is projected right at the viewer?  Seems simple enough.  I have contacted Asus about this issue, I'll update this review when I hear from them.  Update:  Just heard from Asus.  They got back to me very quickly, but their response, probably automated, was "sorry" and please contact technical support.  Hmm, thought that was what I did.  Won't be spending money on Asus in the future. I have the old 7\\" Kindle Fire and have enjoyed using it.  So much so that I pre-ordered the 8.9 Kindle Fire HD as soon as orders were accepted.  I guess I expected too much.  I really wanted to like this device, but Amazon has missed out on some important details.  The on-off button is impossibly small and difficult to locate.  There is no tactile feel to the thing.  You have to visually locate it and then use the edge of your fingernail to get it to depress.  When you attach the charger there is no visual indication (light or LED) to confirm that the unit is, in fact, correctly attached and charging, and, of course, no way to know that charging is completed short of starting the thing up and checking the on-screen battery icon.  I have purchased a number of apps from the Amazon app store using my desktop computer, but when I go to my kindle, they are nowhere to be found.  Only way I can find them is to go to the app store on the Kindle and download them, of course this won't work until you return to your Amazon account and delete them first.  You also have to buy the charger separately.  The \\"Fast\\" charger costs $19.  Fast meaning 5 hours or so.  Sure, you can charge form a computer USB port, but if the \\"fast\\" charger takes 5-6 hours, I'm thinking maybe 10-12 from the USB port.  Oh, by the way, did I mention that the battery life is very poor.  I get maybe 3.5 to 4 hours out of mine, then it has to be recharged.  Amazon really hyped the audio quality.  Another letdown.  Audio is OK, but certainly nothing special.  The cheapest little external speaker you can stick on the thing beats the internal speakers.  Bottom line is that I really wish I had saved the money I spent on this thing and ordered the 10\\" Google Nexus.  I have been an Amazon Prime member for a number of years and am a big fan of the company.  They have always treated me fairly.  But boy, did they miss the boat with the new Kindle.  Don't know who was in charge of the development project, but maybe he/she could get a new job developing a map function for Apple.she could get a new job developing a map function for Apple.

HOWEVER, I was very disappointed to find that the replacement battery does not even fit properly. When locked it place, the battery pushes up against the trackpad mechanism making it impossible to perform a mouse click. When I lay this battery next to an old Apple battery on a table, I can see that the \\"OEM SYSTEMS COMPANY\\" battery is obviously higher than the Apple battery. I've decided to eat the cost and simply vow never to deal with this company again because I just don't have time to mess around this junk any longer. I was very excited to be able to review the Logitech FabricSkin cover for iPad. However, I was disappointed in this product.

One of the reasons I bought an iPad was that I was tired of carrying around my laptop and wanted something that didn't weigh me down. The iPad was perfect, but it was not without its detractions. Using it as a writing tool was difficult. So when I saw the Logitech cover with it's built-in keyboard, I was hopeful my problems were solved at long last.

Unfortunately, the Logitech cover added weight to my iPad and once again I was weighed down by my technology. I had difficulty getting the Logitech connected to my home wi-fi, and nothing I did could make it work.

Finally, it didn't take long to realize that the cover - as pretty as it is - is a magnet for animal hair. Don't ask me why because my animals were not interested in the cover, but I found myself cleaning off hair every time I wanted to use my iPad.

I so wanted this product to work for me, but alas, I've returned to my baby blue Apple cover that has served me well.

The product is made of metal, which looks good. But some keys are hard to reach as they're placed differently from normal keyboards. I tried to contact the seller for a return but never got a reply. If you like this keyboard's layout and won't deal with the seller, it's a OK purchase.

This hunk of junk has just earned its place as THE WORST WEB CAM I'VE EVER USED! Its a complete piece of crap and not worth a single penny. I really wish you could rate something zero stars.

CONS:
- When plugged in it caused other USB devices that normally work flawlessly to either completely fail or to disconnect/reconnect every few minutes.
- Does not support white balance. The colors are terrible, everything in the image was very orange.
- Night vision doesn't seem to work at all. In low light image is nearly black.
- There is an in-line adjustment knob on the USB cable. Its how you adjust brightness, how incredibly manual and inconvenient of them. Even the $4 super cheapo web cams have auto-exposure that works.
- The instructions are a single page and say nothing useful. The back of the page is blank, so they had space to say things they just didn't.
- I downloaded the \\"manual\\" from their web site. After un-RARing it was a single 1MB JPG image. A photo of another single 8.5x11 sheet, but different than the one that came with the camera! This one talked about drivers.
- There are no drivers that come with the device, but there are drivers on the iMicro web site. There is no information available anywhere that says what the driver does, what operating systems its for, etc. Given that their hardware won't play nice and conflicts with other hardware, I fully expected the driver to corrupt my system or do something equally horrible to other software. Needless to say, I was not willing to install it and take a risk.
- I'm only 90% - 95% certain about this, but I believe its only 640x480 and not the 1.3 mega pixel they claim. I'd have to plug it back in to check and its not worth the hassle of my other devices freaking out again.

PROS:
- It looks pretty and has a handy clip. It really does look nice, probably the best looking web cam I've used. Too bad EVERYTHING else about this hunk ofgarbage is worthless.

AMAZON WINS:
I put in for a return since this thing is useless. Amazon granted my refund without my even having to ship it back! Way to go Amazon. This makes me particularly happy since I had a very, very strong urge to literally smash this thing it frustrated me so much. But I'm responsible, so I wanted to ship it back both to get my money and to make a point that I won't pay for useless junk. Now I get to do both. Win. :)

As Kristie \\"shoppe-a-holick\\" said on March 18, the product Amazon shipped is not what is seen in the picture.  The picture shows a rectangular mouse pad with the padding along the bottom.  The one Amazon actually sent is rounded to the right (see this link: [[ASIN:B000EFM9PA Mouse Wristrest Pillow, 7-7/8\\"x10-7/8\\"x7/8\\", Black (KMW57822).]])  Notice the model number on the rectangular mouse pad and on the rounded mouse pad: they're both 57822.  That's a tell-tale sign that Amazon mislabeled the rectangular mouse pad with the model number of the rounded one.    As long as the rectangular Kensington mouse pad is labeled with 57822, don't buy it, or you won't get what you expect.

I purchased this shelf to mount into a 12 startech rack with a mounting depth of 35.94 inches. The rack can be configured to be shallower, but it wasn't necessary for the other equipment, so I left it at it's maximum. Given that the startech website (and others advertise this shelf as having \\"adjustable rails which allow the shelf to be installed into cabinets or racks with mounting depths from 20in (510mm) to 38in (974mm)\\" I wasn't worried.

Today the shelf arrived and as it turns out, the maximum extension of the rails is just shy of 30 inches. WTF? After some more poking at the startech website, I dug into the \\"technical specs\\". As it turns out, that tells a different story. It says:
Maximum Mounting Depth: 29.29 in [744 mm]

That a pretty damn big difference. Sure, I could take the time to re-mount all of my hardware, but had I known that was going to be the case, I would have ordered something different. As it stands, I am waiting to hear back from startech, but I'll almost certainly be returning this to Amazon due to the inaccurate information on the manufacture's web site.

The first battery I received appeared fine: system ran, ran the battery down to about 10%, then recharged, etc. However, when running under full load (e.g. 100% CPU, video encoding/playing, VMware/Parallels running etc.) the system would suddenly halt (not a clean shutdown). This happened whether the battery was 100% charged (just unplugged), 60% or 30%. The replacement battery they sent, wouldn't even power up (charger light was green indicating full charge) and the battery indicator would blink when queried for status via the button. After this, the company gave up and just said to get a refund from Amazon. So it seems that if it works, count yourself lucky; maybe you're not stressing the system, but if it doesn't, good luck trying to get one that does.

I've successfully installed hard drives before without any problems, but this drive has been ridiculous. I too am upset with the fact that this Maxtor Box came with a Quantum Fireball drive inside. I read in another review that someone was upset with the note they received in their box telling them that they could not use the utility software that came with it. I either missed that or didn't get it. Call me crazy, but I just assumed that the software that came with the drive should work.
I've been trying to configure this drive as a primary drive on anyone of three systems for weeks now. Two systems didn't have a new enough BIOS for the drive even though niether of them were more than a year old. So I decided to use the third system which is brand new. The problem is that I have a full version of Windows 95 and upgrades for Windows 98 and Windows ME. The Windows 95 setup won't even run, probably because WIndows 95 is only capable of handling drives up to 32 gigs. So I decided to try Windows NT 4.0, which I also have. After all sorts of problems, I got NT installed only to find out that it believed the 40 gig drive was a 2 gig one and that it was just about full.
During all of these problems, I've been exploring the Maxtor Knowledge Base for answers, which sure didn't come with the drive. It was only then did I learn that I probably shouldn't be using the MaxBlast software that came with it. Ridiculus.
It seems that most of these other consumers have installed it as a second drive or with a newer full version of Windows, such as a Windows 98 OEM. If you plan on using it as a primary drive, good luck. You're going to need it.
