LifeProof nüüd Case & Cover/Stand for iPad Gen 2/3/4 - White / Gray.
I liked the look and feel of the case as well as it not seeming to be as heavy as the Otterbox. The "likes" stop there. Most of these dislikes are personal as some people probably love these features.
I HATED having to have a headphone adapter. It was difficult for me to screw in and if its not tightened properly, headphones do not work right. I use my headphones every night so this is a big deal for me. I also knew I needed extra adapters because what if I forgot it and needed my headphones? The prospect of having to carry the adapter in my wallet and hope I didn't lose it was not something I was looking forward to.
Next and almost as important is the cover/ stand. Oh my gosh what an epic failure. It was hard for me to get off, flimsy and the angle for typing will promote carpal tunnel syndrome at the very least. I watch T.V. in bed and with the Otterbox cover/stand my Ipad is steady without me having to constantly re-prop it. Otterbox also snaps off a whole lot easier. There isn't a magnet in the Lifeproof cover so my Ipad didn't go off when cover was on unless I did it.
My next observation just might be me, but I have had to charge my Ipad daily (battery level 5%) since having the Lifeproof case. I have no idea why unless it was staying on all the time.
I already have a Zagg screen protector installed on my Ipad so not having one with the Lifeproof case was not an issue to me.
As far as protection goes the LifeProof case is like having your Ipad in an armored tank.
I am returning the Lifeproof case and cover. The heaviness of the Otterbox seems very minor compared to all the things I did not like about the Lifeproof case and cover.

Purchased this drive for my mid 2009 macbook pro 15 inch.  First drive was defective.  Requested a return.  Received the replacement.  Defective as well, as verified by the Apple store.  Waiting on my refund, and will never be ordering a new drive from this company again.  The end.

This was a gift to me to allow me to first experience Android devices. I've experienced multiple ones, and this is by far the worst. I cannot recommend it. It does function, to a degree, but needed a lot of tuning to even reach that.

Noteable issues:
1. Fast battery drain, even after utilizing many options given on the internet for extending battery charge. Mine drains in about 1 hour, maybe a bit more. I usually leave it plugged in nowadays. There also does not appear to be a way to replace the battery without destroying the device. So when the battery goes, apparently so will the device.
2. Poor touch-sensitive screen, even after calibration. Finger-touch sensitivity is very poor. It often won't respond, or will trigger another key/feature. I've found better success using a capped pen as a stylus, though it still sometimes misses. You also have to go slow on the keypad with password, or it will fail to register a few character. Very awkward and frustrating at times, though adaptable.
3. Incompatibility with Google Play Store app. This despite being a Google product. I've looked over Google's compatibility list, and X-Treme is not list. This means a lot of apps, notably Chrome for Android in my case, are not installable. (Apparently someone has created a work-around posted on YouTube. I've not tested that.) The manufacturer has installed their own apps market instead. Much fewer options, though some are useful.
4. Terrible default browser. Very slow and often locks up. I tried installing Chrome,only to run into the problem in point #3. I did gain a measure of success by downloading Opera Lite, which proved much faster and better overall, though I'm still not able to run certain things like videos on CWTV.com's website.
5. Poor speakers. Almost inaudible at maximum setting. Headphones work pretty good, however.

With the limitation, I've ended up using the device mostly for video viewing on Youtube,and occasional light internet surfing.

The following is my original review soon after I bought these speakers. I ordered two sets of these speakers because I was so happy with the first set. It's been a year and both sets of speakers I bought died out of the blue. So I am reducing my ratings to one star. They were great while they lasted.

Original review:

These speakers sound great for both music and speaking voices. Another reviewer mentions that when he uses headphones with these speakers, he hears a clicking noise. His speakers or headphones must be defective; I tried these speakers with headphones and did not find anything wrong. No annoying noises at all.

I also bought these cheaper speakers from Amazon: [[ASIN:B000R9AAJA Logitech S120 2.0 Multimedia Speakers]]. The cheap ones are good enough for talking voices but not for music. Any music sounds noticeably poor coming out of the cheap speakers, even if you are not picky about music. The Z130 speakers are worth the money in that the music sounds excellent. So, if you listen to music or watch movies on your computer (or any other gadget), these are worth it. If you only watch news and other such mostly talking programs on the internet, then the cheaper speakers are good enough.

Also note: The cheaper speakers' knob fell off the first day I used it, but it stuffs right back in. The Z130 doesn't have this problem. The design is elegant, giving the impression of being a set of expensive speakers.

So, I am letting my husband use the cheaper speakers on his computer while I use the Z130. :)

Having worked in information technology for several years I am more than comfortable working with technology. That said...    There were three primary issues I experienced with this device which earned it a solid one star rating.    1. More than seven instances of the system becoming unresponsive in less than 12 hours. (I stopped counting.)  2. Complete hard drive failure of one of the four drives in the system.  3. Complete failure of the Manufacture customer service department. (Do they exist?)    While I have seen my share of disks fail and I would otherwise not consider that a fatal flaw if the manufacture provided customer support. Trouble shooting the device in the 12 hours I had it in my possession showed that even removing the failed drive, the system continued to lockup. So the lockup issue is separate from a bad disk. The fatal flaw is a combination of the poor execution of software and operating system and a complete lack of support by the manufacture.    During the moments the system appeared to be working setup was straight forward. The idea is good however the execution leaves much to be desired.
The fit of the plug where it connects to the transformer body is poor, so you have to jam it in with too much force (and it doesn't quite sit straight). But, it is cheap and it does work.

Hoping to get a relatively inexpensive case, that had some functionality and would serve the purpose of protecting the unit for the times I wanted to carry it in a case. I didn't want to spend a lot of money and I should have known going the inexpensive route never really works.

Case was very stiff, barely fits way way too tight, and once in the cover would not snap should without bending the clip some. Smart Cover functionality was not evident and did not turn the unit on when opening the cover.

Basically very disappointed with the quality and would not recommend you purchasing this. I'll try another case and see if I can find one that works!

I would have rated this laptop fairly high, we got it at a good price, and it was perfect for my son to use to access the internet (and not tie up our other computers).     BUT...we had a problem with the video component of the laptop after only about 6 months.  We returned it to Acer (they have no local service facility and they REQUIRE that you ship it back to them at YOUR cost) for repair because it was still under warranty.  About two weeks later we received the laptop back, with an apparent puncture in the screen and huge cracks emanating from that down either side of the screen.  There was no note or explanation from Acer.      I called Acer Tech Support and I was told that there is a crack in the screen and I had to pay $199 for them to repair it.     I told them that there was NOT a crack in the screen when I sent it to them, that I shipped it to them following their instructions to the letter (actually it was packed better than they suggested, in about 5 inches of bubble wrap all around), and I expected them to repair or replace the laptop.      They claim that the damage must have been caused in shipping, but I disagree.  I honestly believe they caused the damage and are now trying to cover it up.  In the interest of customer service, you would think they would just fix or replace it (what would that cost them in real costs?  $100? Come on Acer, grow up).  As it was I was on the phone for two hours straight, first with foreign (India) tech support reps, and then with US based (I think) Customer Service reps.  I spoke to 4 different people and they were all steadfast in their determination not to help me - to them, apparently, I was a liar and therefore I had to pay for the repair.     I asked for a mailing address so I could file a written complaint with their company, and the CS rep said he didn't know the address where he came to work every day (this exchange provided the only comic relief in hours of painful exchange - I said \\"OK, when you drive in in the morning, what does it say on the front of the building?\\"  He replied that he didn't know).    I called Amazon customer service the next day, and was told it was the manufacturer's responsibility to take care of this and that Amazon couldn't (or rather wouldn't) help me.      Acer says I have to go to the shipper and try to get money from them.  I believe that Acer caused the damage (and if they didn't, their product is inherently defective if it cannot be shipped in a closed position) and they should do the right thing and replace the now completely unusable laptop.     I would avoid buying any Acer product unless you are prepared for a Customer Service nightmare.  A good deal on a cheap little laptop isn't such a good deal after all when the company won't stand behind their product, and when Amazon won't stand behind their most faithful customers.     If you have already purchased an Acer product, and find that you need to return it for service - take pictures of every aspect of the product before you ship it.  This way when they call you, their customer, a liar, you have photographic evidence to the contrary.    If you haven't purchased an Acer product yet - think twice.  You may pay a little more for Sony or LG or another higher quality brand, but you might find you have a partner rather than an enemy when you need their help.     I am giving this one star only because you can't go any lower.    Shame on you, Acer and Amazon, for the awful treatment of your customers.      Addendum:  I sent Amazon a copy of this review and they offered to refund the purchase price.  They did this within 20 minutes of my sending an e-mail through their \\"Contact Us\\" page.  Way to go, Amazon - you have restored my faith in you.  Acer, however, continues to battle me every step of the way, and regardless of Amazon's noble action, I plan to file a complaint with the BBB and elsewhere.

I ordered this and installed it myself per the given directions. The software on the disk was not recognized, but no problem I downloaded the latest version from TP Link's website. Windows 7 was unable to install this on its own so I had to manually install the drivers, again no problem I should only have to do this once.

After installing it I got an error code on the Device Manager that "The Device cannot start. (Code 10)" I did some google searches and found no solutions. The only way I could get it working was to restart my computer, again not a big deal. I did so and it worked as expected. However, upon complete shutdown and subsequent startup my computer could no longer "Start" the card. I got the same Device Manager error. I had to restart the computer again for it to work. After another shutdown and startup it still would not work without a computer restart. I uninstalled an reinstalled the drivers many times.

I contacted TP Link's support and their answer was prompt but useless. The told me to turn off my virus protection(Norton 360) when installing the drivers, which is ridiculous. When was the last time anyone has ever done that? If you have issues like that its time to hire better programmers. They also said to try it in another computer. I was already very fed up at this point so when I pulled the card out I sent it right back to Amazon. Not buying this one again.

What a disappointment.  I bought this after seeing a company rep recommend it to a person who asked if another model would help extend coverage in his home - the very reason why we thought we'd replace our old Netgear 150.  Well, after a very challenging setup process, not only did our coverage not extend - the speed dropped!  From averaging 2.5 MPS to .5 MPS!  I tried every configuration - selecting specific channels, using auto for channel, etc.  I spent many hours over a few days to make it work better.  To no avail!  Finally, I decided to try it as a 'satellite' for my 150 via power over ethernet system (ZyXEL) that I had set up for another purpose, and we are now able to get on to the network consistently from the back room.  This is NOT a very big house (1500 SF).  I decided it was better than the hassle of returning it, so the use of it as a satellite to the base router (the original 150 I've had for 5 years) works, but did I need to spend $70 for that?  I won't even go into how hard it was to get documentation/help for this.  I typed in AC750 into the Netgear support site, and the result was Not Found?  Turns out they call it something else (R6050, the number at the end of the model name) in their support system.  Wouldn't you think you'd be able to type in the model number as advertised to find support for this device?  Bizarre.

I purchased the Q190 primarily as a music (media Player) for home surround sound. Lenovo claims to support via HDMI for 7.1 Channel Surround, lossless audio, Bit streaming, Dolby HD, Dolby DTS, Intel HD 3000 Graphics but there is a problem. None of it works. I tested the machine at the Intel site and Intel says the HD graphics are the 2000 series (half the processing capabilities) and NO higher level audio processing seems to be taking place!
The HDMI needed to support the sound capabilities listed above (as the optical can't do them without the HDMI) simply does not pass the higher level audio through to the receiver or can't decode or even support them. IF the machine could do what Lenovo advertised maybe they should take a few moments to train the support staff or possibly make sure they ship what they advertise and that it works!!!!!
After 5 days of calls and hours on the phone with Lenovo support they told me they couldn't figure it out and I could return the model to Amazon (great-wait 30 days for my money before I can replace the machine) or I could be transferred to software support where I would have to pay to fix a problem that was shipped to me (if they could figure it out).
Lenovo - \\"advertise what your product does, and when it doesn't you can pay again to fix their lemon computer\\". This might be a great business model IF IT WASN'T ILLEGAL.
Lenovo should be ashamed - conducting business in such a shoddy manner. If you are considering buying the computer take the advise given to Forest Gump - RUN FOREST, RUN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I've used screen protectors on a number of mobile devices but have never gotten so frustrated with trying to apply one!  I've learned how important it is to have a clean screen before applying the screen protector so I take a lot of care in cleaning the screen and making sure its oil and lint free.  For the last step in cleaning I use rubbing alcohol and then the lint free cloth.  So, the screen is pristine and I pick up the Cellet Screen Guard.  I read the instructions and the remove layer mask 1.  As I'm removing layer mask 1 I feel the hair on my arms standing up from all of the static it's creating.  When I get the mask off I notice that the \\"sticky\\" side of the Screen Guard is now covered in lint and who knows what!  I swear it must have pulled every fragment of lint from the air and every surface for a distance of ten feet!  Needless to say things just got worse from there.  I was finally able to get the majority of the lint off the Screen Guard by holding it over the sink and pouring the rubbing alcohol al over it.  After nearly an hour screwing around with it I was able to get it applied with only about a dozen bubbles. Then came time to pull off mask 2.  Of course when I tried to carefully remove that mask it pulled up every edge I just spent many minutes trying to get down.  OK, enough of the whining. I bought this computer in October of 2012 at Best Buy because they had a promotion sale on the laptop. I have now owned the computer for 7 months and I feel I can now write a proper review on it because I use it everyday.

I am still able to use the letter but it's a pain in the butt because I can't breeze through when typing for words that need the letter \\"L\\" - instead I have to bang down on it to get it to work which is super annoying.

The speed of this computer is nice though but when it freezes up then everything else does too and I have to restart my computer or it will continue doing so. I regret this purchase and will NOT be buying an ASUS in the future.

The idea is great, and the surface has a very good feel to it. Fit on the MacBook is good: It goes on pretty quickly and seems to stay on just fine. I expect this will protect the device quite well over the years to come. My goal wasn't so much to keep the laptop from scratching, but rather to give it a little bit of heft -- I know, it seems counter-intuitive to add bulk to such a thin device, but the two additional layers add a little strength, and when I carry it around, I know it's there.

However, immediately when I opened it, I noticed that there was a large, unsightly glue-drop on the lip of the bottom side. If it were just a cosmetic problem, I might have let it slide -- although, when paying almost $50 for what is essentially two pieces of plastic, I would expect something that doesn't look like factory seconds. However, the hardened drop is just high enough to keep the MacBook from closing properly and actually pushed the lip of the top shell up and, I fear, eventually off.

Let's hope this will be resolved between Amazon and the reseller quickly. When it does, I will revise my review accordingly. If it's after March 2013, and this review is still unchanged, then my complaint wasn't resolved and I recommend looking for this product from a different reseller.

I have an Alienware Area 51 desktop computer which was really sluggish due to the minimal amount of ram that I had installed. I had been looking to beef up my ram for some time and the Corsair 2 GB ValueSelect had a very appealing price tag. Installation was a snap and my system initially booted up and ran. As soon as I attempted to go online, my system crashed, went to the 'blue screen of death' and dumped all memory. I tried repositioning memory modules to no avail. Removing the newly installed memory returned my computer to normal. Amazon was great about the return. I printed off a return label and had no issues returning the memory for a quick refund. I have since added 2 GB of PNY memory with no issues yet. (I still have my original packaging though!) My computer is up and running faster than ever now...

The description of the item, along with comments in the roku stick description, are deceptive. Reading them makes you believe you must get a USB cable to power your roku stick from the TV instead of an outlet.  You do not. The roku stick power cord has a removable plug that reveals a USB connector.  I guess if you really don't want to coil the not-too-long cord that easily fits behind the TV (without showing), then you can spend the extra money. Beware though the 8 inch USB cord is 8 inches from end to end including the connectors, not just the cord. If the distance between your TV's HDMI and USB ports is more than 6 inches, it won't be long enough.  The ports on my Vizio are 7 inches.

The concept of the this device is really really cool. Being able to accurately track your hands and not requiring you to wear gloves? If this were true, the possibilities would simply be endless. Sadly this is not the case.

Me and my professor wanted to created a sign language recognition system using this device. For starters we tried to get this thing to recognize the the sign language alphabet. The problem we were having is that leap motion has absolutely terrible hand tracking capabilities (we were using the version 2.0.4 of the API). The device will often think you are using your left hand instead of your right and it will think fingers are closed into your palm even when they are fully extened. To make this worse there is considerable "jitter" in the tracking even when you hand is completely still. I sympathize with the developers of this device. I understand that the problem they are trying to solve (proper tracking without gloves) is really really hard, but If the solution is barely usable, don't make some stupid promo video that makes the device look amazingly accurate! The developers KNEW this thing had crappy tracking capabilities yet their main selling point is the accuracy of the tracking! This product is a scam.

I have previously used:  iMicro SP-IM942 Headset with Microphone (lasted about 6 months to a year)  Gigaware® USB Stereo Headset from Radio Shack(lasted about a year)  Cyber Acoustics AC-850 Internet Communication USB Stereo Headset and Boom Mic (Black).(did not even last a week)  This is the most comfortable one I have used. I will try to update in several months.  -------------Update 11/4/2014:-----------------  These head phones still work great. You can wear them for hours. The sound quality is the best out of the ones that I have used and the microphone is great. I would definitely recomend.  -------------Update 4/21/2015:-----------------  A couple of months ago, the cord started to cut out the sound when you moved. Now the headset hardly works at all. They are great if you don't use them for very long and you don't use them that much.

See UPDATE at bottom for a long range review.***    I loved this computer from the start but there are a few drawbacks.     Firstly, it is heavy but it is a desktop replacement and I expected that.     Secondly, finding a case to fit it is hard because it is about an inch wider and longer than most 17.3 inch notebooks.     Thirdly, the CD-DVD drive is in an awkward position. Every time I pick up the computer I accidently open the tray and I have to pop it closed again.     Thirdly, I tend to rest my hands on the side of the touchpad when I type. I have never had a problem with any other computer. But this touchpad is extremely sensitive and it will interfere with using the computer. I also noticed that when the touchpad is on I will lose letters in words when typing. I will type all the letters but the computer will skip so I have to go back to correct. This does not happen when I use a mouse and turn off the touchpad.    Lastly and most importantly, it is difficult to get someone on the line at ASUS customer service. I had a problem with the charging plug and have to return the computer for repair. I have to go through the usual dance with automated answering. But when I am waiting to talk to a real person on my cellphone, I get cut off every time. I have never had a problem with my cell phone and it is consistently doing it when I am on the phone with ASUS. So I got on a landline and had to wait almost 20 minutes just to talk to a person. Then, when I did he said he had to wait a few minutes while his system came back on. (This is a computer company rep. telling me he is having problems with his system - which I find frustrating and ironic.) I gave him my service no. and he had no information on me, this after he had to keep putting me on hold for some reason. Keep your serial number handy since they keep asking for it every time you call.    Would I buy this product again if I knew then what I know now? Probably because it is wickedly fast and works great. But Iwould take every precaution to never have to deal with customer service from ASUS.    ***UPDATE: I have had this computer for four months and I have had to return it twice for the same thing. The pin in the charger plug came out with the AC charger and I could not recharge the computer. I had not been rough with the unit and, although inconvenienced, I returned it to Asus for repair and replacement of the AC charger. Well, got it back and two weeks later the exact same thing happened again. I was just pulling the plug of the AC charger out and the pin came with it again! I am sending it in to Asus AGAIN with a complaint about how delicate the charger pin is. I don't know if they will charge me for this second repair but I am furious at having to go through this with a $1700 computer. I have been working with computers since 1989 and never had this problem. I suspect the pin is much too thin and breaks easily. Now I may have to pay for a repair. I have revised my opinion of this computer and would NOT purchase it again! It is not worth the trouble.

It doesn't start working until Windows is booted, so if you have it hooked up to a computer, and you need to get into the BIOS, it will not work. Horrible. I have had to unplug it, grab a real keyboard, get into the BIOS to do whatever i need to do, then plug in this mediocre keyboard back. I have had it. It is going in the garbage.

This router worked fantastically for about a month. Speeds were great and coverage was excellent. I was thoroughly impressed. Then after about a month, the router would start randomly lagging on the wireless interface every 20 min or so. I could ping the router and see a build up in return delays. This would persist for a few minutes and then it would go back to being a great router. I tried every available firmware I could find, but after attempting to re-configure everything I could think of, I called customer service. They proceeded to ask the same questions I had already considered (have you tried turning it off and on again?) and after I described all of the steps that I took, they agreed that they thought it was a hardware issue and offered to RMA it (I had to pay for shipping).

Unfortunately, the router they sent back to me was worse than the first I had received! Multiple devices were unable to connect to it over WPA protected 2.4Ghz and I can see (with a spectrum analyzer mobile app) that the signal is dropping precipitously as I go to the next room. I have an OLD D-link DIR-600 that is getting better coverage around my house.

The worst part is that I contacted customer service again to explain that I was having issues with the unit they sent me. After talking on the phone with someone for ~ 1 hour, they agreed again that it looked like a hardware issue (I'm not sure they have any actual idea what they're talking about except for the script they have) and gave me another RMA. I told them I didn't want to pay for shipping again and they hooked me up with free shipping (only good thing that I've experienced with customer support). I just received the "repaired" unit, and all they did was reset the device! No info about what they think was the culprit, or why and it doesn't work any better than before!

If I could give this back and get my money back I would do it in a second. It's been nothing but trouble - I can't evenimagine what it would be like to purchase a laptop or some other expensive device from them. If you're thinking about buying from asus, I would just suggest googling "asus customer support" and looking at other reviews. This router could have been amazing - and for others I think it is, but it's just not worth getting stuck with a lemon.

1.) Color: This wasn't a deal breaker for me. I ordered the teal blue like the picture. It was supposed to have two tones of teal. The one I got was all one color and a light blue. Again, not a deal breaker...
2.) Smell: It was putrid. I figured it must be the new faux-leather smell. Again, I'm sure over time this would go away. Still not a deal breaker so let's put my nook in.
3.) Damage: On the inside there was a small scuff a little bigger than a hole punch. They fixed it by globbing some mismatched paint on top of the scratch. Not a deal breaker because my nook would cover it.
4.) Fit: I could tell immediately that my nook wasn't going to fit. It did... sort of? I got it in, put the straps over and noticed that the bottom thread was unraveling. Very disappointing. I figured I would have a good few months from this... STILL not a deal breaker (Very generous, eh?)

I have already reviewed Razer's Carcharias headphones unfavorably. If Razer would get its act together, it would not be getting two negative reviews from the same customer in the same time-frame. As I said in the other review, it serves me right for continuing to purchase products from a company that has provided me with so many frustrating experiences.

The original, wired Naga, was a real treat for me. As I said in my other review, Razer's products provide this immediate, out-of-box satisfaction. That, to sound like a paranoid old hobo, is how they get you.

As a google search will very likely show you, plus another couple of reviews on Amazon, the left and right mouse buttons seem unusually prone to failure. The brand new one I had, this was, indeed, the case, but it was sporadic enough that I didn't consider replacing it. After all, I'd bought it new and it wasn't cheap. I was mostly able to deal with it. Then, the thing slows down. The cursor wasn't following along. Next thing I know, the whole thing is dead. And two months outside of warranty, of course.

Now, the thing didn't last very long, considering the price, but the reason this is a 1 star review is simple. I decided it was time to replace it, and saw that Razer was selling these, refurbished. I jump on it. Free, two-day shipping yields me nothing for five days before I contact Amazon. The order just stalled.

Now, people can talk a lot of guff about Lasership, and I'll admit, while I haven't had a bad experience, personally, a lot of people obviously have, so it could have been them. However, though Amazon squared things away quickly enough, Lasership seemed to indicate that they'd never received the item to ship, in the first place.

I got comped one-day shipping and, today, I receive my refurbed Naga.

Dirty. Greasy finger-print on the left button, no teflon slider on the bottom. Didn't come with the stickers my original came with (good for finding your place on a twelve button thumb pad) which the product info did not make clear.

The kicker, though? No serial number. I read a review of this thing and someone else said they got a filthy, beat-up mouse with no serial number. Honestly, even with what Razer's put me through, I couldn't believe that. Then, I received the exact same thing!

I'm not even plugging it in. What's the point? Without a serial number, once Amazon's return policy wears on, Razer doesn't owe me a thing. Without a serial number, I can't even count on a 90-day. And, given the Naga's track record, that doesn't seem like a remotely safe bet.

This quality of service and assembly just KILLS me. Razer's ideas are awesome. The Naga proved a useful tool, for everything from MMOs, shooters, even macros for work. The Naga even helped me file my taxes a little faster. But the experiences I've had from Razer are inexcusable at any price, let alone the somewhat steep prices they charge.

The worst part is? I'm still considering maybe trading this thing in for a Naga 2012. I heard they improved its durability and corrected some defect issues. That's how good the Naga is, and that's why it's such a shame that they can't get their house in order.

Once you try their stuff, you'll wind up like me, coming back for the same abuse, year after year. Do yourself a favor: go elsewhere.

During last five days, I spent countless hours with D-Link and LinkSys support in trying to make my home network run flawlessly. I was using D-Link DI-713P for last year and half, before it died last week when I upgraded its firmware so it won't lock up whenever I accessed internet using Windows XP. I decided to buy DI-614+ model hoping it will work better than the old one but on the contrary, I had so much trouble in setting it up that I thought I was going insane. For any changes in setup, I had to reboot my cable modem, wait two mins, reboot D-Link router, reboot my computer(BTW, I was told by tech support to do this). It drove me nuts. To top it off, the range of wireless was extremely bad. I consistently lost signal, downstairs from my office, in living room just 30-35 feet away. The admin GUI was complicated and any time it rebooted the router, I had to go through the whole reboot sequence. I called tech support, the front line tech support guy was a novice. I am a computer professional, not really a network professional but I knew much more networking than him. Later, I got a call from "supposedly" higher line of tech support, woman had nothing else to offer except resetting the router and see if that worked.
LinkSys and Microsoft wireless routers also suffer from poor wireless signals. I didn't even bother trying Microsoft router when I read about its locking up problem. Linksys' poor wireless range, though not as bad as D-Link was also unacceptable.
I had almost lost hope in all the wireless devices on the market before I used Netgear's MR-814. It has user friendly gui and various options to make the network and wireless access secure. Over that, you don't have to worry about rebooting all the devices to make any change. Its signals are great, and I am totally impressed.
My suggestion, don't even bother looking at other routers. I would hate to see others get frustrated trying to make other products work, like I did.

At the time I order this product the currently released Cisco ASA version was 8.3 around June 2010.  The product arrived with Cisco ASA version 7.2 installed which is quite old.  This is the version release history for the product: 7.1, 7.2, 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3 so it not like it was just one version. One has to migrate from 7.2, 8.0, 8.1, 8.2, and 8.3 in that order.  Missing several updates, it is very frustrating to be face with maintenance work right out the box.    For those who care about such things 7.2 has known security vulnerabilities, see 'Cisco Security Advisory: Multiple Vulnerabilities in Cisco ASA 5500 Series Adaptive Security Appliances' or [...].  Meaning the product basically ships in an unsecure state. I am not willing to put the device online without it being fully patched.    I called Cisco several times about using the devices warranty period to get updated firmware so the product would be fully patched. Cisco would not do this.  It has been a real pain working through their email and phone tree support. They often would not respond. I had to keep calling back over and over and restating my problems.  Honestly, those guys do not care.  At one point I was asked for the size of my annual IT budget.    I eventually bailed on the idea of getting phone-email support and looked at getting a Cisco SmartNet so I could get the updates myself. They are not free downloads.  This is unbelievably expensive. I tried to get a cheap one off of Amazon from Restockit but they were unable to fulfill the order at that low of a price and ended up not charging me.    I am a home user who wanted to move up from my Linksys firewall to something more secure, fault tolerant and VPN friendly.  In the past, I've used an old pc running linux but the pc fan, power supply, and hard drive have never beed designed as fault tolerance equipment.  The Linksys router has been great in this regard but that community is not as active at keeping pace with the newer hardware. I bought this the day before Christmas as a present to myself. I vacillated between the Western Digital and the Buffalo before finally deciding that I'd give Buffalo a try. I transferred 2.5TB of movies, television shows and songs. I wanted to be able to access my information without having to leave my computer powered on.

I tried to access my information off my network and noticed that my computer was not recognizing the drive. So after about 45 minutes of fiddling with the program, I powered down the drive according to the directions. After the drive powered down, I turned it back on. Nothing. Just 7 red flashes.

I looked on Buffalo's product forum and was informed that this was a problem with the internal controller card. And that it was not communicating with the drive. This left a sinking feeling in the pit of my stomach.
I looked at their warranty information; all returns in the first year must be through the store of purchase. I know that Fry’s would just swap out the return and I could wave goodbye to 5 years of data on my drive (the joke is they want you to use this drive as a backup). I went to Fry’s to confirm the bad news. And it was exactly as I feared. They suggested I contact Buffalo.

I called Buffalo who referred me to DriveSavers. Now this didn’t sound good. DriveSavers is a data recovery company. You know, you dropped your laptop in a lake and after fishing it out a week later, they can pull the data off your destroyed drive. My problem was simple, the controller on the enclosure was defective. My data was sitting right there all warm and cozy. There was no need to restore the data. DriveSavers wanted to charge me $700 to $2700 to “restore” my data.

I called Buffalo once more. I tried to ask if they would just repair the enclosure. I was told that they do not repair enclosures. That they would be happy to swap my product.

Now, I may be cynical, but it seemslike that if their product fails after 21 days and they have a “rule” that states they do not repair their product (in this case it would be easy to remove the drive from the bad enclosure and place it in a brand new working enclosure) then this happens a lot and it’s a money loser. Let me rephrase that so the slow witted (i.e. Buffalo Americas, Incorporated) can understand. I have a business to make money. I have a product that has a tendency to fail. If I have to repair a large number of my products, I don’t make money. So I make a rule, let’s call it Caveat Emptor, to ensure I make money by not fixing bad products.
What the companies don’t realize is that eventually there is a tipping point. You eventually have enough customers who have bought their products and realize that customer service does not exist. So what happens is they do not buy your product again. And eventually, your company, like Blockbuster Videos, CompUSA, Best Buy…just becomes irrelevant.

Installation was streightforward, and the print server worked great - for a week or two. Then it started acting up. It would print a few pages, then time out. Or it would not print at all. Cycling power would make it print the next few pages, and than it stalls again.

Sniffing IP packets through Ethereal showed that that connection attempt SYN was immediately RESetted. We used this WPS54GU2 on two printers, a Brother and a Xerox WorkCentre via USB. On the other end of the connection is a Linksys access point.

I wish this device did not work from start, so I would not have wasted so much time.

This laptop is possibly the worst purchase I have ever made online. Especially for the money that I paid for the product. I bought this laptop back in November, 2014, in preparation for the spring semester at school.

My first complaint is the Samsung bloat-ware that came pre-installed on it. It wants me to upgrade their Samsung Smart Advisor software and hassles me almost every time I start up my machine to either pay to upgrade it or to buy some other product to "upgrade for free". Next, I purchased an antivirus product when I bought the machine. Samsung continuously complains that I should buy "their" recommended antivirus even though I already have a product loaded. When I try to uninstall Smart Advisor, it automatically reinstalls itself. In addition, for a while, it complained that I had 2 antivirus products installed. Total pain in the a$$... well, neck.

My next complaint is that the default screen resolution sucks. 3200 X 1800 might be fine if you have amazing vision and a magnifying glass handy. It may very well be a good size for watching videos if that is all you want to do with your laptop. Most things either don't fit well on the screen at all or they are so small as to be unreadable. If you try to adjust the resolution to any other available setting, it tells you that things will not fit properly on the display. So, why even give us the option to change it? Stupid. I bought mine for school and I wish I had just bought a 17 or 19 inch of another brand. If I could return this 'machine' right now, I would probably buy a Toshiba or a Sony.

Another complaint I have is that one reason I bought this was because they said it had an amazing battery life. Up to 11 hours of actual use. I think if you cut that figure in half, it might be more accurate. If I take it anywhere, I carry along the power cord because I don't really trust it to work as long as I would like it to work on battery.

Finally, I sit inside at a computer desk all week for my job. Part of the reason that I bought a laptop was with the idea that when possible I would use it while not stuck at a desk. If I wanted to sit at my desk to work, I would have bought another desktop PC. So, aside from the battery life, I am just going to say that the glare that comes off the screen when trying to work outside or even in a well lit room if absolutely horrible. I have been trying to shop for anti-glare filters. 3M does not make anything this small. I have yet to find a vendor that has an anti-glare filter that I can buy at this time. So, no sitting on the porch outside in the fresh air to work or at the park or really anywhere outside.

If you are thinking about spending this much money, you might want to do some more research if this is a laptop you are considering buying.

Update 8/31  A cheap capacitive stylus actually helps out a lot. I can't say whether it's Windows 7 being clunky or whether screen typing just doesn't work out for me, but holding the Iconia in one arm and pecking at it with a $3 capacitive stylus feels a lot more comfortable. But use a regular-length stylus, not one of the short stubby ones.    Updates:   First, I have found that the SD card slot supports SDXC, allowing 64gb and 128gb upgrades.    Second, I tried out a Galaxy Tab 10.1 in a store, and it was slow too! Flash video took a while to load and didn't reorient correctly between portrait and landscape--just like in Windows.    My criticism and low rating remains, though, perhaps now expanded to Android tabs as well.    ***  Forget about the \\"keydock\\" contraption. Consider the W500 as a Windows tablet, able to pair with any USB or Bluetooth keyboard, or just resort to the wonky on-screen keyboard. And what have you got?    The greatest of all Netbooks, the least of all tablets.    There needs to be context. There have always been Windows tablets--questionable Archos tabs, overpriced UMPCs, and convertible tablets with swiveling screens. Aside from a few hot-rod $1,000 models, the Netbook-based Windows tabs like the Dell Inspiron Duo and Lenovo s10-3t have suffered from glacial sluggishness and cheap LCD screens whose poor viewing angles make actual tablet use a pain. Hold it wrong and the image turns blue!    But that's where the Tab W500 delivers. As a multitouch-based Windows 7 Netbook-tablet, it just works. Touch response is quick if not buttery smooth, finger-swipe scrolling works in Firefox and IE but not Chrome, and pinch-to-zoom...works on pictures but lags for websites. Now this screen--it's beautiful! Off-axis viewing angles are nearly perfect. The image is almost as stable as my smartphone, or an iPad.     That screen quality is a huge deal, and it means that if you're thinking about a Windows Netbook at all, the Iconia W500 is the ONLY way to getan excellent screen!.     But, as a tablet? The processor bogs down easily--one Flash video at a time, max--and battery life is insufficient for e-reader duty--4 hours of surfing, 2-3 hours of Flash video. It's also too blasted heavy to hold comfortably--two pounds for the tablet only. Compared to the iPad and slew of Android Tablets in its price range, the Iconia W500 cannot compete.    So the point of this computer is really just Windows 7--full document and spreadsheet editing, PDF editing if you buy software, regular desktop programs, full Web support, both Flash and Silverlight, two USB ports, USB printing, and a full-sized HDMI port for mirroring and extended desktop. It elevates the experience of a premium Netbook by adding touch input and great viewing angles.    The problem is, after spending two weeks with my new W500 tablet and writing half this review on its wonky ON-SCREEN keyboard, I'm still jealous for an iPad or any Android tab that runs Flash. Even with their limitations, mainstream tablets are very functional--focused, you might say--and they all have excellent battery life. This little touchbook is such a different machine, a traditonal computer that dressed up in a tablet costume, a jack-of-all-trades that excels at nothing, except for that screen. The Android tablets and iPad have a gravity to them, because they're designed to do fewer things but do them very well.    The bottom line? The W500 is for those looking for a Netbook, not a tablet. As a Windows machine, it's a decent Netbook with a bonus touch screen. As a tablet, it's too heavy and the battery life is nearly inexcusible.

I asked Netgear for advice: I told them that I wanted a range extender that would accept a directional antenna.

They recommended this unit. While it does have removable antennas, apparently (as I discovered while asking them followup questions after purchase) putting on another antenna will void the warranty, so I'm not sure what they were thinking recommending this. Nor will the unit, as far as I can tell, figure out to use a 2.4GHz directional antenna for the 2.4GHz band and a dual-band or 5GHz antenna for the 5GHz signal.

However, the unit is effective if you don't need anything fancier than the antennas that it comes with, and the 3-colour light that tells you how good the signal is makes positioning the unit marginally easier (although you can--and you will want to--go into the device's webpage for more precise information).

Shame on Netgear for failing to stand behind their blatantly inappropriate product recommendations, but for what it is, it's pretty decent.

Within 2 weeks of receiving this marvelous top-of-the-line computer, problems started happening:

1. The the lower right corner of the screen popped out from the lid (i.e., no longer sitting flush to the lid. I only noticed it because I happened to be working in a dark room at the time and light was leaking from the corner.
2. The W and CTRL keys started to become unresponsive.

I notified Eliktronics, but they told me to call HP. If you buy from Eluktronics, you better notice and notify them of any problems within 7 days or they absolve themselves of responsibility. Fine. HP sent out a box for me to send the laptop back to them in.

The day before it arrived, Windows mysteriously crashed and failed to boot \\"No OS Found\\" -- no boot media, so no way to repair. I spoke with HP again to update the trouble-ticket. We clearly agreed that the issues were the mfg-defective screen, the keyboard, and now the SSD/HDD/OS.

The brand-new computer was sent to HP; dead as a brick. They were supposed to fix the three problems above. What I received back, was a computer that was wiped clean, the OS installed on the 5400RPM HDD rather than on the SSD, a screen that was still leaking light because they never replaced or adhered the screen, and a keyboard was neither replaced nor fixed.

Frustrated and tired of the irritation, I decided that this \\"premier model\\" was a lot less than, and that I will just bend over and deal with this POS for the next year or so and buy a different one -- that works.

So, that being said, I had manually installed the SSD drivers, moved the OS from the HDD to the SSD and decide to just deal with having to make sure that W and CTRL key-presses take. And I am ignoring the popped screen.

It was a nice effort. Until last night. Now the USB 2.0 port stops working unless I reboot which seems to fix it for several hours.

This is a total lemon. I am in IT and have been computing since the old 8088 days. I've never had issues like this before.

When I received the tablet, I found that the power adapter was missing. So, I went to plug in another adapter and found out that the AC/DC port was missing from inside the tablet. So, there was no way to charge the tablet. Next, a micro-USB fell out of the package that should have been inside the tablet. So I opened the tablet to attach the USB port,and found some other loose unidentifiable parts. The most shocking was the motherboard secured with duct tape. It started looking like an explosive device you see in the movies b/c of the shoddy design underneath the cover...wires everywhere and duct table holding things together. My wife became suspicious so she said to throw it away in case it was does blow up or something else.Then I found a return postcard inside the box, someone had previously returned the product b/c it was defective. I contacted the seller for  a return. They live in China and I had to pay for shipping. Take a guess how much it costs to ship an item to China. Hint, it's more than the cost of the tablet. Beware of TOBOY (the seller) and shame on Amazon for allowing defective products to be resold to unsuspecting customers.

Amazon replaced it but this one still makes a buzz or hum noise that is continuous in all recordings. I thought it was my computers at first. I was using an Asus EEE 1005 and it was suggested that the 2-prong power pack for this netbook be replaced with 3-prong (grounded) power pack. So I purchased a 3-prong power pack for my netbook and the microphone still buzzed / hummed non-stop while recording with it. It was then suggested that all other USB attached deviced be removed from the computer. That did not solve the problem. It was also suggested to try another PC. I tried a new HP Pavilion All-In-One PC (connected to an APC UPS) and it still made a buzz. It was suggested to connect to the microphone to a powered-USB hub, tried it and still made the humming noises. It was suggested to ground myself, tried it and still didn't work! Lastly it was suggested to connect the microphone to the netbook, disconnect the power cable to the netbook and run it off the netbook's battery... finally this worked but I don't want to be forced to keep using up my netbook battery and recharging it to make a poorly engineered microphone work. Also this headset hurts my ears after wearing it for longer than about an hour.

Setup of the unit I bought did not go seamlessly.  I contacted LinkSys support via their online chat system which hung up on me 3 times.  I was so frustrated that I gave up and bought an Apple AirPort Extreme and Apple Care support package (where I got to talk to a real live person who talked me through the setup in a logical step-by-step manner.    I would avoid Linksys for this reason.   THe support system is terrible.  However, if you enjoy 4 to 6 hours of frustration, by all means buy a LinkSys product and use their product support.

Bought this notebook around Christmas 2012. I needed a decent budget PC for college, and this seemed to fit the bill.

Right out of the box, the laptop had issues (small at first). Occasionally, the screen would freeze up, or it would inexplicably crash and shut down without warning. For the most part, I suffered through these issues without contacting support because they did not affect the basic performance.

Today, however, the laptop completely crashed on me, and refused to reboot properly. It froze for over half an hour at the startup screen, at which point I force-restarted it to wait another hour on the "automatic repair" initialization screen. After this, I proceeded to have to attempt all the different fix options. None of the options that would have let me keep my files worked, and when I finally went to try a full system wipe, I was notified that a required drive partition was missing. All I know at this point is that my hard drive is locked (there is no way to 'unlock' it) and that I cannot fix it.

I have a kindle fire that would no longer take a charge,so I called customer service. After speaking to 3 representatives I'm frustrated, annoyed and have a splitting headache but have no idea what they are sending me as a replacement... The first representative told me that they would send a new kindle right out to me, they just needed a credit card number to charge, if I did not return the broken fire and the the charge would be $199. I did not have my card with me so they said to call back and they would mark my account. Number 2 said that this problem was common in this model but it would be replaced with a new one not refurbished, I would be charged $199 if I didn't return my broken Fire and I could upgrade at an additional cost but first I needed to try the newer charger, so they sent it to me. It did not work. They did not call back as per their confirming email, so I called again.  Number 3 said I could upgrade, my warranty had expired but there was an extension because of the battery issue but now I only have one day left, to make my decision. I was then told I would probably receive a refurbished one with a 90 day warranty, but if I wanted to upgrade I could buy a refurbished upgrade with a 1yr. warranty or a new one at the regular price with my Fire as a trade in for $50-$100 and again I would be charged $199 if my fire was not returned!!! I asked for a Supervisor. Number 4 was a supervisor who said there was a misunderstanding with her people and she would speak with them, but couldn't offer me an explanation as what I would get for my  trade in so I asked the Supervisor how much I would be charged if the Fire was not returned so I could insure it and she told me that they would send me an insured mailing label for the return but I would still charged $199 if I don't return it (like I really wanted a broken Fire). Is Amazon going to charge the Post Office $199 if it's lost???? I have no idea what I'm receiving new or refurbished or what model Fire I'm getting so I took the replacement one in complete frustration and going out to look at the other Tablets with a better Customer Support.  I have never written this kind of review before but I had heard of the great customer service and support for the Fire from Amazon and can't believe that this is what I had to go through when all I wanted was a repair.

UPDATE as of April 29th, after 4 months of use:

This tablet sucks, the so called \\"faulty mini USB port\\" is no longer working... I finally got used to the fact that the tablet should be standing still while charging, but in the past weeks, it's even harder to get the right contact, having to use any kind of things to support the tablet in an angle that the usb port makes contact within the tablet.

Now it has come to a point where no matter if I get the right contact, the tablet just doesn't charge or do so very slowly, like 3 or 4% of charge in a 24 hour period... This has render the device totally useless, and as I am not in the USA right now, I cannot do anything about the warranty... I must wait to go back...

I won't ever buy anything cheap from ASUS again!

--------------------------------------------

It's an amazing tablet, good screen resolution, powerful, awesome for gaming.

The only thing that has concerned me so far is the faulty mini USB port that comes in the Tablet. After a month of normal use, when the tablet is plugged in to either the computer or wall, the slightest move makes the cable move withing the socket and lose the connection, going on and off if you keep moving it.

I thought this was a problem of the mini USB- USB cable that comes with the tablet, but I have tried many cables from Nexus and from Blackberry and I figured out it's only a problem of the faulty socket that is not built well enough to hold strongly the mini USB end of the cable inside it.

Well, you just have to let it stay still while charging/transferring data, however if you are an avid gamer who plays lots of HD-battery draining games and have to do so with the tablet plugged in, then it's a big deal... other than that, it's an awesome tablet.

PD: I bought 2 tablets, one for me and one for my gf, and both have the same issue

This is a bit of a mixed message, but here we go. The Cherry MX Brown key-stroke action is 5-star, no question. The Rosewill RK-9200 met these expectations superbly. I love typing on it.

The back light feature is very disappointing. I made this purchase for only two reasons, the Cherry MX Brown keys and the backlight, both of which are very important to me. I sent a message to the seller, AramediA, regarding what I assumed were non-functioning lights on the keyboard I received. They are very responsive and are contacting the manufacturer for clarification. However, after researching this issue in several places online, I find that only lower case characters are designed to be lighted on the keys with dual functions! Examples: top row: numeral 1 but not exclamation mark, etc.; second row: brace but not bracket, etc.; third row: semi-colon but not colon, etc.; bottom row: comma but not smaller-than symbol, etc.; and secondary functions on the number keypad. This does not work for me at all. My keyboard usage is primarily words, so I need to glance down for the lesser used characters - that Rosewill does not light up!

In addition, to light the keyboard at all, one must complete a number of key combinations, and the same is true to change colors. As others herein have remarked, if you turn off your computer or the keyboard lights only, you have to go through all those annoying steps all over again. This doesn't work for me at all and the keyboard is virtually unusable to me! As a matter of fact, I unplugged and reboxed it after an hour's usage. Having been out of town when the keyboard was delivered, the 30-day return period for Amazon Prime had already been passed when I returned and opened the package. Now I have to figure out a way to sell it in order to recoup some of the $150.00 plus I spent on this product. Very disappointed. Rosewill missed the boat big time as far as I'm concerned.

I am 25 years old and this product was the worst consumer decision I have ever made in my life. When I first received it, the laptop would not switch on or it would switch on for a few hours, or it would switch on, work perfectly normally for a few minutes or hours and then randomly shut down again. After looking various forums and failing at attempts of self-repair, I sent it in to Asus, and then after that it could switch on but the wireless was completely disabled.    So I called their service line. Their customer service is ATROCIOUS. You call and they put you on hold (which is fine, I can wait even an hour), but after 15 minutes, they hang up on you and you have to call in again. The line is also very bad (and my connection has worked fine with Skype, etc, so I believe the problem is on their side). I was put on hold for at least an hour today and spoke to 3 different reps, having to explain my problem again each time.     Their representative advised me to reboot windows (removing all my programs installed previously, and also making my version of MS office unable to work) which would be acceptable if the wireless started working, but it still does not. And so I have to send it in to Asus again.    I heard a lot of good things about Asus, but I really, really regret buying this laptop and really wish I could get a refund. It was a complete waste of time, money and effort. I bought it in Februrary this year but because I have been travelling in and out of the US, I still have not been able to use this laptop for even a few days, and had to buy another one to tide me over while I waited for Asus to get their act together (which is taking 7 months and counting). I am completely and utterly disappointed with the company and with my laptop.

Although a great idea the stylus simply does not work as advertised.  My stylus worked great for a few days but now just skips when writing.  Read the Adonit support forums before buying, you'll see numerous complaints about these devices going back to 2009.  Adonit support was fast and friendly but never resolved my issue.

My second M570 just failed. The issue is the spring in the right button only lasts around 6 months when the M570 is used ~9 hours a day, 5 days a week. The issue is the spring gets bent slightly and you end up double clicking when you single click.

There are several pages that explain how to fix this, but getting the tiny spring back in place is a PIA. Also this fix voids your warenty.

Anyway, I can't recommend this as I have a Logitech trackball purchased in 1995 that still works fine, and many of their mice without this micro switch issue.

Final while it was working, I had to clean the ball constantly because with any dirt you can feel the ball dragging. Older trackball were much more tolerant of a little grime around the 3 ball joints that grip the main blue ball.

Bought this product based on the previous reviews. However, heres my thoughts.

-Disassembling the battery from the (mid-2009 MBA) is pretty easy, 10-15 minute job.
-The BTI battery is slightly bigger than the OEM battery (which requires a few manipulation of the hard bottom plate to get into the correct position).
-The wires of the battery connector that connects to the power (of the MBA) is slightly longer/larger which makes it hard for the battery to stay connected into the board.
-Installation was straightforward

Post batt install
-Assembly, having that it was a slightly bigger battery, i had a hard time flushing the cover back into place.
-Comp wouldn't turn on, plugged it in and it was a 0%. Let it charge overnight and it was still 0% but now it says "battery not recognized". Googled this issue and it said to reset the SMC, followed the steps and they worked....sorta. After 10+ times of restarting the computer, 5x taking the battery in and out, it finally was getting a "percentage reading". Plugged in it was say it was 100% then when you disconnect the power, it shows 56%. Symptoms = slow, lags freezing computer. Frustrated, i contacted Amazon and requested a RMA. Reinstalled the old battery and everything worked flawlessly.

Would you recommend? No. (but maybe my battery was faulty). Even though Apple charges double, i think paying for OEM is worth it.

I bought this RAM for my Early 2011 15\\" Macbook Pro. I have used this monitor for 2 weeks now. The joystick toggle on the back of the monitor used for menu control does not work in the down position at all, which means you always have to scroll up and can't turn the monitor off. You absolutely must color calibrate this monitor when you get it because it is totally washed out. The response timing is good but there is an unacceptable amount of back bleed for a VA panel. I do like the level of curve as it is more pronounced than its competitors, Dell and LG. I bought this monitor for gaming and would not use it for any type of work as the fonts are very difficult to read. The gaming aspect would have been ok as the speed is good but the contrast levels expected out of a VA panel just aren't there. I have asked for a return from the seller. So far the seller has been very responsive as there has been a few other issues, like I had to complete the import paperwork through Federal Express to get the shipment out of customs. I did a read/write test on it, and it wasn't fast enough to do HD despite it's claims,even using the FW800 port.   - It uses Hitachi hard drives - in this case the drives outlasted the enclosure which surprised me. But that's a substandard HDD if you ask me.  - the AC power adapter is clunky and unmanageable.     The company didn't offer any help either. They said they don't support that product anymore. And weren't very helpful in general. I get that - they can't support stuff forever. But I've been on the phone with other video companies (like Varizoom) and they bend over backwards to help you. These folks don't seem to care.    The only saving grace is that I was able to pull out the hard drives (two 250 g drives) and reformat them. That's about $100 worth back.

Getting a 2D 1080p picture working was reasonably easy and quick. Follow the instruction manual and you'll have it working in minutes.

Getting 3D to work was *much* more challenging (it's the most demanding since it needs to send double the data down the wire): I've run 3 new Cat 6 cables through my walls for my home theater - each wire length is around 45 feet, so well within the working range of these devices. Yet, while I was able to get a clean 3D picture out of a random 10 year old cheap 150ft cat 5 cable run across the floor that I had lying around, I could barely get any 3D picture through my installed wall wires. Most of the time the picture blacked out entirely or had severe noise. The wall wires terminate in Cat6 rated punch-down sockets and the HDMI cables on both ends are Amazon Basics High-Speed HDMI Cable 3 Feet (trying to keep the HDMIs as short as possible). 3D 1080p didn't reliably work on 2 of the 3 cable runs (even though they test fine with a basic continuity network cable tester) - and it just about hung on with the 3rd cable.

You can get some idea of how much margin you have by how sensitive the setting is on receiving unit (it has an adjustable dial for "EQing" the signal - seems like a gain knob in actuality). With the old 150ft direct cable, about 5 of the EQ receiver settings gave a picture with no defects. Using the wall run wires, only 1 setting was mostly clean, and the settings on either side had bad break up. I tracked the problem down to the punch-down wall sockets. Stripping the wires of insulation and re-punched them again made no improvement. Then I tried soldering the punch downs with a lot of flux and solder. This improved the 3D pic stability noticeably, but next day it wouldn't work again... I broke out my scope and sent test signals down - it seemed to perform fine. Out of exasperation and options, I decided to pull the excess cable out of the wall and terminate it in a plug so I could plug the wall cable directly into both the send and receive units. Then everything worked absolutely perfectly. All 7 "EQ" settings on the receiver unit delivered a flawless picture.

So, beware of using punch-down wall sockets with 3D - it really seems unable to handle the extra bandwidth required. Using a keystone coupler instead of a punch-down socket did not improve things sufficiently well to work. 3D just about worked with a coupler on one end, but not the other. Even then it wasn't solid, so you do need to have 1 continuous wire running end-to-end and nothing more.

If you're running wires yourself, I'd obviously recommend leaving plenty of slack in the walls to give the option of continuing the same cable out to wherever you need it to plug into. You may find it completely necessary.

Equipment: Sony HW40ES projector, Pioneer SC-1523-K receiver (Atlona between the Sony and Pioneer), Samsung Bluray, Verizon Fios Motorola Cable box/DVR.

2016 Update - one of the boxes in the pair died and no longer functions. So I got a replacement set that's HDBaseT, and they are far superior. It remains to be seen if it will last more than 2 years, but the usability is much better and HDBaseT seems far more robust.

Here's the set I have now: Atlona AT-UHD-EX-70-2PS 4K/UHD HDMI Over HDBaseT Tx/Rx Kitscope and sent test signals down - it seemed to perform fine. Out of exasperation and options, I decided to pull the excess cable out of the wall and terminate it in a plug so I could plug the wall cable directly into both the send and receive units. Then everything worked absolutely perfectly. All 7 "EQ" settings on the receiver unit delivered a flawless picture.

So, beware of using punch-down wall sockets with 3D - it really seems unable to handle the extra bandwidth required. Using a keystone coupler instead of a punch-down socket did not improve things sufficiently well to work. 3D just about worked with a coupler on one end, but not the other. Even then it wasn't solid, so you do need to have 1 continuous wire running end-to-end and nothing more.

If you're running wires yourself, I'd obviously recommend leaving plenty of slack in the walls to give the option of continuing the same cable out to wherever you need it to plug into. You may find it completely necessary.

Equipment: Sony HW40ES projector, Pioneer SC-1523-K receiver (Atlona between the Sony and Pioneer), Samsung Bluray, Verizon Fios Motorola Cable box/DVR.

2016 Update - one of the boxes in the pair died and no longer functions. So I got a replacement set that's HDBaseT, and they are far superior. It remains to be seen if it will last more than 2 years, but the usability is much better and HDBaseT seems far more robust.

Here's the set I have now: Atlona AT-UHD-EX-70-2PS 4K/UHD HDMI Over HDBaseT Tx/Rx Kit

I've had these about a week now and was considering keeping them despite the negative reviews, but now that I find myself in the middle of packing them back in their box for a quick return to Best Buy I think the people should know why.  Having a small child around the house I had not had the chance to crank these pups up 'til this morning, but when I finally did, lets just say I was not too happy.  I've owned the Klipsch ProMedia 2.1 and also a Logitech 5.1 PC speaker system that was about half the price of this Bose setup, and both of those can attain higher volume levels with much less distortion.  The reason I had been considering keeping these until this morning was because as I stated earlier I had only been listening to them at a low to moderate volume.  At those volumes I had heard the \\"tinnyness\\" people mention in their reviews but only on a few songs and I was actually impressed at how a few songs sounded.  I tried watching a movie and could not discern any sort of surround sound, this is because I'm using them in a pretty open area and I'm figuring the surround requires walls to bounce the sound off but I didn't buy them for their gimmickey \\"5.1\\" claim so that didn't really bother me.  Anyway, back to the music, the reason I bought these speakers.  When I finally got around to cranking them up, all the tin in those satellites started attacking my ears with a vengance, this coupled with the voices now coming out of the bass module was quite enough to send these suckers right back to their packaging.  Perhaps if all you do is play games and watch movies (without music) these speaks will be acceptable, of course if thats all you're doing I think you would have just bought the ProMedias and not the Bose, thats what I would have done.  I cannot recommend these speakers to those who listen to or create music.

ChatEnd Chat

I am sorry for this hassle James.
In this case we will need to replace the device.

Amazon:Device is out of warranty.

Amazon:In this case we can replace it with another model at discounted price.

Certified Refurbished Kindle Touch, Wi-Fi, 6\\" E Ink Display - includes Special Offers & Sponsored Screensavers for $74.

What I can do from my end is give you $15 promotional credit to your account which you can use on next purchase.

Bought this tablet for my husband for his birthday. He was happy with it at first and then 5 months later the camera stopped working and the screen orientation failed too. I contacted Hannspree about returning the tablet and their customer service was appalling. After many emails, I didnt get any replies from them and many phone calls, I was still waiting over a week later for a return number and address. By the end of the week I was getting lied to and given the run around. I contacted Amazon hoping they could speed the process. Full credit to Amazon, they answered my email within 15 minutes. I had an email with the return label and details and a full refund organised that same day. I will not be reordering a Hannspree tablet, I wont buy from that company again because of the dreadful customer service. I woudnt recommend this tablet, because even though it was pretty good for the price, if something goes wrong then Hannspree customer service suck.

The mouse doesn't work well with windows 7, 8 or 8.1. The third mouse click switch buttons has tons of lag unless you open the Logitech Gaming Software and keep it minimized in you task bar. So  have it start up with my computer. However randomly the mouse buttons will stop working while I'm playing causing me to lose a game and then having to reset the software. It happens so often that its extremely annoying and I can't do anything about the issue since Logitech refuses to create new drivers for this unit. People have been complaining about this issue for years and no one has done anything about it and I purchased the mouse without any knowledge of this issue. If it wasn't for the mouse lag and spotty software this mouse would have a 100 stars since its build quality is excellent and when it works its amazing. I would not recommend this mouse to anyone because of these issues that are not going to be fixed.  If you want to learn more about it go to google  and type G600 input lag and you will see how far back the issue goes and how little Logitech cares about their customers.
