I was having issues with the old power supply failing, and constant restarts with kernal power error41 (63).
So I bought one of these from Fry's Yesterday, got it all hooked up, double and triple checked EVERYTHING...
Plugged it in, took a deep breath, Flipped the switch and pushed the power button on my case....
Then, a quiet-ish fizzly pop noise and a burnt electronics smell, pc will no longer boot, have tried 2 power supplies...No luck, all that happens is on fan starts to spin for just a second and then nothing....I'm pretty sure my Mobo is toast...old psu will run its own fan using paper clip jump test method, yet doesn't attempt to start up at all when i push the power button on the case....my pc was operational before this (upgrade)..aside from restarting issues...now its just a really expensive custom built paperweight. Best Birthday ever!

Originally I posted: I had a little bit of trouble at first with this range extender, but I found out that it was due to issues with the Time Warner Cable modem/router that I was using. Once we changed out the unit, the extender connected quickly and easily, helping our son to be able to use the Internet upstairs in his bedroom to watch movies, do school work, play video games, etc. Contacted customer service via email and they responded in less than 24-hours with great tips/ideas to help get us connected.

Updated Information: However, a few days later we moved the unit over a few inches and it would not re-connect to the Internet. I went through all of the same steps I went through the first time we got it to work and it still would not connect. I tried over a dozen times and in several different locations including the one we moved it from originally. We plan on returning this now. I have spent way too much time on it and it is just not worth the effort. Customer service was friendly and helpful, but the unit just isn't working for us as a range extender.

Having read the reviews before purchasing the Targus Lap chill Mat a little under a year ago, I thought it would be great.  Nope.  First of all, to adequately cool my laptop, I had to set it awkwardly off center on the pad.  It also collected cat hair and would clog up easily and it was extremely hard to clean out.  I would have to use a lot of canned air, a toothpick, and extremely long tweezers to remove the cat hair balls and this was a weekly event.  But my main complaint is that it did not last even a full year.  It didn't last 10 months.  While it did last, it did the job it was designed to do.

At the moment the current nvidia drivers out for this card make it impossible to play a few games. Constant frame drops to the point where I was getting better fps with my old hd 4850 with source games, and even NBA 2k15. BioShock infinite seems to be okay. I'm debating just returning the card and getting an amd card if this isn't resolved soon
Waste of time and money. Didn't come with instructions and could never get it to open. It didn't come with any thing to install into the computer or nothing....sucks .
Strap came undone my first time using it on a trip out of town.
I love the design along with the speed however recently (less then 1 month use) the memory volume got corrupt while transferring 800MB file into the volt, no format option

battery is compatible with my late 2008 unibody macbook pro, however after 2 month of using the battery, it simply just stopped charging...  price may be half of apple product but now i am regretting purchasing non-apple product.  I just sent a RMA form to seller, hopefully their service is good enough to supplement the mediocre product.

Final Update 6: I have dropped the rating to a 1 star, while the specs may be nice, you can get better spec'ed laptops for about the same price. They will probably last you a lot longer. I've had 2 warranty repairs in the first year of ownership and now the reliability has taken another hit, where the graphics card likes to crash on occasion, even after installing different drivers and such. I finally attempted a Windows 7 re-install and things seem to be running ok, though with 1 crash since the redo it makes me question it,but I haven't really used it too much as I NEED reliability. So I ended up getting a new Laptop. Better spec'ed and better built by far. Plus it was a little cheaper. Samsung also seems to have abandoned the Gamer series as there has been no Haswell refresh of the Gamer Series, where Asus, Alienware, even Toshiba has done refreshes and everything. When I bought this laptop, I expected it to last me at least 2 years, if not longer as the specs where higher than I needed at the time. (I expect this out of all laptops I buy. Since I tend to buy while thinking ahead.) Instead, it's been about a year and 3 months. It's now out of warranty, and I will not spend ANYMORE money on this laptop. It's just not worth it since the reliability is the most important thing to me and it's the one thing in question.

With all these updates I CANNOT recommend this laptop with the reliability issues I have had. To be fair I probably got a lemon, but also with everything else newer that has come out I can't recommend it. With this being said I will not be doing any more updates until it actually dies. (Even then it may be awhile before I update it as it's not at the top of my todo list.) I am still a student, and almost done with classes, but still use the computer for so much more. I can't have reliability issues. I have owned Asus before this and while I've had small issues here and there. They were ALWAYS fixable, but when primary parts fail like in this one. (Cpu first time, gpu second time and now maybe a third time and it's no longer under warranty.)

Will this marks the end of this part, read on for the whole shebang, but this is the most up to date one.

Update 5: I received my laptop back on June 14th (2013) after about 2 weeks of waiting. (This includes shipping it to them, which cost me another $50) It is running like new again. I added a star since the repair went pretty quick and seems good. I may add 1 more star if this lasts longer than that last repair (which was in November, so it was like 7 months.) I won't be giving 5 stars no matter what as this issue has soured my thoughts on Samsung now. (And I think I may be generous with the 4 stars, but I am also keeping in mind I may have gotten duds.) Again, 2 repairs in less than a year? It makes me question the lifespan of the laptop. Performance wise it's great, but it may go bad again, only time will tell and if it happens I will be completely re-writing my review from scratch. I really, really want to love this laptop, but it's becoming harder to do so.

Update 4: This is a minor update to Update 3 (Below): They have pushed my Estimated repair date twice now. Originally it was going to be done on June 4th, then it got pushed to June 10th. Now it's been pushed to June 11th. (They are probably waiting on a replacement part.) But this is just not good. I have docked another star due to the issues. It is making it harder and harder to suggest buying this laptop. I really WANT to love it, and for the specs you can't go wrong. But the issues I am having is just a big issue when it comes to making me wonder about longevity. I bought this laptop to last me for a long time, and now as stated later, I have had to send it in 2x in less than a year for repairs. Almost $100 more for shipping it. The brand Samsung, has always been the name of a great, wonderful and quality product to me. Now I am really starting to wonder if they have left me like other brands have. I am just glad I picked up an Asus G46 for under $700 at Best Buy so that I could still do my schoolwork and play games. I anxiously await getting my Samsung back, if only to have the horsepower again, and will just hope that all the delays allow them to really make sure that it is in full working order. If that happens and I don't need to send it in again, ever, I will restore this to a 5-star despite the issues, I'll know that Samsung still takes care of their customers. (I'm really hoping things will be great so I can do so. :)

UPDATE 3: I had to send my laptop in again for repair! This is starting to get ridiculous! I paid almost $2000 for a laptop that was suppose to last me a long time. (I bought it for gaming and so that even if the games started getting a little more advanced I figured that for the power it would last me awhile. But now after having ownership for about 10 months and needing to send it in twice now it's just mounting up to be even more expensive! It cost almost $50 to ship it both so add another almost $100 to the price I paid! I am now docking 2 stars from the perfect 5 stars I gave it. I understand things can go wrong, but twice in 1 year, scratch that less than a year? I'm sorry but this is drawing the line. I'm just hoping they will give me a whole new laptop instead. I don't know what else to say, I really want to love the laptop, it's great for the price and specs. But I'm questioning the purchase now. It's not about warranty service or the laptop itself, it's lifetime of the product, and I expected more than a year. I will update once I get my laptop back.

UPDATE 2: I recently had to send my laptop in for a repair. The cpu fan seemed to not be working properly and it would overheat when running almost all my games. Fortunately it is still in warranty. I sent it about 3 days before Thanksgiving and due to The holiday it didn't get there until Monday following Thanksgiving. They repaired it. (Seems the replaced the motherboard, gpu and the keyboard. (I now have a Windows 8 style keyboard where the Start key isn't the older orb shape but is the newer windows logo) All in all, it took about 2 weeks due to holiday to get my laptop back. Which isn't really bad considering I live in Ohio and had to ship it all the way to Texas. I shipped via UPS ground with insurance (I am paranoid about that stuff.) Samsung shipped it back with 2 day Air. I was able to track both ways and knew when it would be coming so I was ready for it. The fix is good! Now I no longer overheat. Now I think that my issue was just a fluke as I don't see many with the issue, so I'm not taking any stars away and would in fact add a star for good customer support if I could. I still recommend this laptop. As you still get a good bang for your buck.

UPDATE: Other have written that you can't turn down the brightness if you run the screen at 120Hz. This HAS been fixed! Download the latest video drivers from nvidia Geforce 310.33 beta or later and you CAN adjust the brightness level while on 120Hz. I already tried it with 310.33 beta and can confirm it works. Nvidia has also released another beta (310.54)today (November 12th, 2012) that I have yet to try, but can for sure say that the beta 310.33 works fine. So anyone who wants to adjust their brightness while on 120Hz, you can do so!

On to the review now.

I've owned quite a few gaming laptops, The Asus G73JH (I still have that one as a backup), Asus G53SW (I sold to get this one) are the closest in comparison. Though they are still decent gamer laptops. This one blows those out of the water. I have owned mine for close to 2 months now and don't have much to gripe about.

Comparisons (These are comparing the differences of the Asus's and this Samsung one):

* Asus used crappy Atheros Wifi cards in their laptops (I had to upgrade to in Intel card for better wifi. This one had an Intel init already, I expected to have to change the wifi.
* Both My Asus's cost a max of $1,200 but after upgrading the ram and adding a second hard drive as will as upgrading the wifi + any labor expenses they each cost as much as this Samsung.
* All the laptops have a big rear. That's good for the cooling. 2 exhausts 1 is for the cpu and 1 is for the gpu. All laptops win in this category.
* The Asus's felt a little cheaper built than this Samsung.
* The Asus's Keyboards are of the chiclet style, this Samsung one offers something a little more traditional and feels great! A note on the G53SW and from what I have been reading all the
latest Asus Gamers seems to be a keyboard lag at times. When you type sometimes it would skip letters. This drove me crazy on the G53SW. To the point I ended up only using it's keyboard for
when I was in class. Not the case on the Samsung gamer. Typing is a dream.
* I can't really compare specs since I'd be comparing 1-3 year old tech to now. But I'm a gamer, music maker, photo editor and video editor (student in the last 2) and this laptop has yet to
disappoint in any of the categories. What I thought was an awesome gaming experience on my other laptops was nothing!

Negatives:
I don't have much to gripe about and have been very happy with this laptop but if I would have to nitpick:

* The glossy screen lid and screen are finger print magnates. Though a lot of manufactures use that stuff. It would have been nice to have a anti glare screen at least. But I'm used to it.
Considering I do a weekly cleaning and dusting of my laptops it doesn't bother me too much. I knew it would be this way by other reviews so I really can't gripe since I still bought it
knowing.
* If you go to turn off Wifi with the shortcut button it turns off both wifi and bluetooth. It would have been nice to cycle or something like that. But I hardly use this function so it isn't a
big deal to me.
* The power brick is large, so get a large bag for it. I'm used to large power bricks as the Asus gamers had large ones, so I can't complain on this. Ideally I would love a small power brick
but think about how much power this laptop needs. The power brick is a 200W one. My Asus's were 150W.

On to any other thoughts:

This laptop does get warm when under heavy use. But it's never been so hot that I can't touch it. It's to be expected. Look what's in it. The I73610 ivy bridge is comparable to one of the most powerful mobile i7 sandybridge's (last generation) The gpu is comparable to a Desktop GTX 560 (I believe but don't quote me on that). frankly I'm astounded at how well this laptop stays cool. Warm laptops aren't new to me as I've had gamer laptops before. But honestly this one actually is a little cooler. I use coretemp and msi afterburner to monitor the temps of the cpu and gpu respectively and they have been cooler than my older machines.

I love the backlighting and how it changes colors for gaming mode. You can disable the screensavers that start up when you switch to gamer mode. It's under Mode Shift, then click Visual Effects.

I like the design and coloring, it doesn't really scream \\"I'm a gaming laptop!\\" Unless you put stickers or stuff all over the lid. I wanted something I could potentially use for taking to a job someday that still had a lot of power and this works fine for that. The samsung label on the lid lights up like the Apple logo lights up on macbooks. Just as a side note.
The 8GB Express Cache seems to work. I really can't tell other than things seem to run a little faster and boot up isn't bad. Better than my other laptops.

The screen is a vibrant one. I've always liked Samsung TV's for their screens and the screen on this laptop doesn't disappoint.

Battery runs for about 2 hours on normal use. Not much to write about. The battery is powering alot of powerful components.

Conclusion:

One heck of a laptop, you get what you pay for, and that is a lot of bang! You could pay more for an Alienware or such and not get as good of specs (I know because I priced them at the time I bought this machine some were as high as $1000 more!) This is one heck of a machine and you can't go wrong with it. I've been happy and surprised at how will it performs, yeah I'm still getting surprised 2 months after I bought it.

Notes:
I wish to put the specs of my old laptops up for comparison to this one.

Asus G73JH
17.3\\" 1600x900 display
Core i7 740QM 1.73GHZ turbo to 2.93GHZ
8GB DDR3 Ram
500GB 7200rpm and 640GB 5400rpm drives
Intel Wifi and bluetooth
Ati Radeon HD 5870m 1GB GDDR5

Battery gets 1.5 hours if I'm lucky on normal use.

Asus G53SW (Sold to buy the Samsung)
15.4\\" 1920x1080
Core i7 2630QM 2GHZ turbo to 2.9GHZ
14GB DDR3 Ram (upgraded by me)
2x 500GB 7200rpm drives (2nd drive added by me)
Intel 6230 Wifi and bluetooth (upgraded by me)
Nvidia GTX 460M 1.5GB GDDR5

Games I played on ALL machines: Torchlight, Command and Conquer Kane's Wraith, Sims 3, and Minecraft. They all played great and improved on each subsequent machine. Though Kane's Wraith couldn't do high detail on the G53SW when the nuke was fired. The Samsung has no problems. I didn't even buy Starcraft 2 until I bought the Samsung as I read people had issues with the 460M and SC:2. SC:2 plays at over 60Fps on the Samsung no problems. Minecraft would choke on some 256x and any 512x texture packs I tried on the G53SW though it was playable there were enough framerate drops for me to use only 128x or lower texture packs. Not so on the Samsung. I sued 512x packs and still got 60fps. (Contrary to belief you DO need a beefy gaming rig to play minecraft, ESPECIALLY with HD textures.

Hope this helps and feel free to ask me any questions if you have them and I will help you to the best of my knowledge. This review will be updated as the time comes so please check back every so often. Cheers!it already, I expected to have to change the wifi.

After months of frustration with both CenturyLink and this modem I feel it's important to weigh-in a warn people away.

This modem is an absolute piece of crap. It hasn't worked since day one. My mother was told to buy it by CenturyLink customer service when we started having internet problems back in march--since buying it and setting it up our problems have only escalated. The modem disconnects from the internet every 5-15 minutes every hour, all hours of the day, every single day. We've put in new ethernet cables, new filters, upgraded firmware, had the telephone company come out and inspect the wiring to and in our house. I've tried manually selecting the channel, like a few other people suggested--nothing works!

On the few occasions it stays connected for longer than 15 minutes don't expect good speeds. Just trying to watch a youtube video on two connected devices causes latency to spike ~2400 ms (I'm seriously have flashbacks to my dial-up internet but that would at least stay reliably connected even if it was slow).

Don't buy this modem, ESPECIALLY from CenturyLink because they will charge you about 3x as much for it.

Waste of money, waste of time, nothing but frustration.

Just while I was typing this (rather short) review my internet kicked off and I had to wait to get it back so I could even post this.

#TerribleLink

I'm new to mining so I had my buddy help me get set up. Initially when he told me to get connectors for my rig he wanted to sell me some his for $75 which was cool for me because like I said I'm new and had no idea what they went for. For all I know they could be a thousand bucks. Anyway I decided to look on the web just in case and came across the "RIF6 powered 16x to 1x PCIe riser with Molex connector and clip" and it was significantly less than that  at like $15. So what the hell I bought a few. I had him come help me set them up and he told me right away there was a problem. He said one of them had faulty wiring  and to not use it because it could destroy my motherboard. I thought he was b.s'ing me because i didn't buy them from him but he connected them to a rig with an extra drive he had lying around and sure enough it crashed his drive and motherboard! The system won't even boot now. luckily he adjusted them and told me to try it. It worked!  they seem to be working for my rig now but that was hella close there. All in all they work but I'm not sure I will trust buying them again unless I could get some sort of warranty.

Pros:
All of the reviews I read talked about the increased wireless range and superb routing ability. Well, I'm here to say that yes, is a tiny bit better than my older Linksys router in those two areas, but not really by much.

Cons:
This router has been dropping my wireless connections constantly on both the 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz bands. My wife is just fed up with it. I've owned and used a half dozen wireless routers for more than 10 years and have never had one with so many connection issues. Also, there have been a few times when the DHCP client in the router is not getting a reservation from the cable modem after a reboot. It can sometimes take a few more re-boots of the router for it to work on the internet interface again due to this.

This router is going back till Netgear can get this fixed.

I wanted to upgrade the cludgy on board video on my Dell530 Inspiration w/ Vista 64 bit. I added a new power 500W supply. According to Dell the onboard video does not need to be disabled. I insterted the new card, reconnected the video cable to the new adapter. Windows loaded a plain VGA driver. I then used the CD to to do the driver update. Windows took almost 20 minutes to reboot. When it did I got a black screen. I rebooted again and checked the BIOS. The bios fonts were almost unreadable. I checked to see if the PCI Express card was recognized. It was. I finished rebooting, and still a black screen. Then I got the - failure to start- Vista repair screen. The NVIDIA instructions suggest that the screen is caused when the onboard controller is not disabled either in the BIOS or in Windows. At this point I skipped further tinkering to find out if I could get the system running at all. I did. So then I started all over again, but this time disabled the onboard video adapter in Windows (this was a mistake). I got another black screen when I put the new card back in. Frustrated I pulled the card out, reset the cables, rebooted the computer and found that Windows would not load at all. I had to shut off the power supply to shut the compter down. This prompted windows to start it's system repair tool for which I was eventually asked if I wanted to use a previous restore point. Finally back to normal  The next day, I tried again. This time I let Windows updated the NVIDIA driver via the web. But no luck.   One moral is make a system restore point before you tackle this.    When I booted up with the NVIDIA card inserted properly etc, I noticed a pinhole pattern spread across the inital Windows Logo. The fonts in the bios are almost unreadable. I suspected a bent pin or pin adapter - none found. So I don't know why it wont' work, but it won't at all.  I dont't even know if I should try to return.
Bad product, do not buy

The spectophotometer is nice, self-calibrating, accurate (repeatable measurements), and samples over 380nm to 730nm at 10nm intervals.

The RGB-Easy print profiler is worse than useless unless your printer happens to already be perfectly linearized and already on target. The 45 samples points are grossly inadequate. Also, after creating a profile, there is no way to edit or correct it. You either have to live with what comes out, reprofile (timing consuming when you allow adequate ink drying time), or abandon your purchase in favor of the original printer manufacturer's profile. This tool is so bad that it guarantees that you will need to spend an additional $400 each to upgrade to Gretag-Macbeth's standard CYMK and RGB profiling modules.

Even after spending another $400 each, do not expect profiling to go easily. The blacks can block-up, your black and whites will not stay neutral throughout the gray scale, and the gamut can suffer. Most of these are correctable, but they require time, patience, and some ability to edit profiles (not included with the package). The provided instructions are minimal -- be prepared to spend hours with tech support and/or reading a book on the subject (such as Bruce Fraser's color management book).

The advertising falsely promises an upgrade path; however, if you price it out, the upgrades from Eye1-Design to Eye1-Photo are more expensive than buying Eye1-Photo outright. The least expensive upgrade path is to throw-away your original purchase and spend anew on the next largest package.

GMB has offered a free profile editor for every package except this one. You'll have it on your menu but won't be able to access it. This is a critical limitation -- you're denied the ability to view or edit your profiles. Viewing is essential so you can compare your weekly profile updates and detect when an anomalous profile has been generated (this WILL happen from time to time). Without profile viewing, you're left to detect the profile variance by eye. Without profile editing, there is no way to correct systematic errors (perhaps your monitor's red phosphors fall near the dividing line between two sample intervals).

GMB's tech support team is knowledgeable and helpful. However, they've advised me that all of the packages under $2,000 are considered entry level products -- the company stays focused on it printshop and graphic design clients who spend $5,000 or more on GMB products. Purchaser's of Eye1-Design are the bottom of the barrel and regarded with distain by the company.

I contacted a GMB sales exec, Dwight Davis, regarding the upgrade conundrum. His scornful response indicated that the company has published its pricing and upgrade policies for all to see, so buyers get what they deserve. Essentially his advice is to not buy a package and expect to purchase reasonably prices upgrades; instead, you need to anticipate all future needs (including an understanding that the RGB-Easy and CYMK-Easy modules are useless) and buy a more expensive, all-inclusive package.

If all you need is a monitor profiler, you can do much better with other companies and should consider a colorimeter instead of a spectrophotometer. If you buy the spectophotometer, consider buying better software at a lower price (ColorEyes for example). If you need more than monitor profiling, be sure to get a more complete package than this (for example Eye1-Photo includes a much better print profiler, an editor, and a number of other tools).rofile viewing, you're left to detect the profile variance by eye. Without profile editing, there is no way to correct systematic errors (perhaps your monitor's red phosphors fall near the dividing line between two sample intervals).

However, they've advised me that all of the packages under $2,000 are considered entry level products -- the company stays focused on it printshop and graphic design clients who spend $5,000 or more on GMB products. Purchaser's of Eye1-Design are the bottom of the barrel and regarded with distain by the company.

If you need more than monitor profiling, be sure to get a more complete package than this (for example Eye1-Photo includes a much better print profiler, an editor, and a number of other tools).

It's $50 camera, so I guess I have to take that into consideration.

First off, the power adapter doesn't fit snugly into the jack on back of the camera. When connected it feels as though it will come unplugged easily. Poor fit and finish.

Next, I have it setup and am trying to record for the first time. I am managing the camera in my Web browser and click the Record button. I am prompted to specify the location and name of the file. I accept the defaults (the Documents folder, with a defaulted name). I let it record for a few minutes and then click the Record button again (presumably to stop the recording process). When I look for the file, it's just not there. So I click Record again and it shows me the *previous* file name in the Documents folder -- like that file is there. I try to right-click and copy that file, then paste it somewhere else, but when I do I get a Windows error saying that the file no longer exists. Somehow the dialog box things it does. So I try the recording process again with the same result. No dice. Over and over again, in different locations from different computers, no dice. I have no resolution at the moment.

I then tried to update the firmware and cannot find a firmware update file for this camera. At one point I am redirected to the Foscam support site, and the model numbers and firmware update numbers sent to me in an e-mail (after registering on that site) don't match my camera. I am still unsure how to obtain a firmware update file, or if that will fix the recording problem.

The tech support Chat feature is offline. It's 2:00 PM ET on a Friday.

The documentation is skimpy and has not been any help yet. There isn't even any instruction on how to perform video recording.

It only cost $50, but I am considering returning it and trying something else. You get what you pay for, I suppose.

All in all, I think I would give another brand a try. Ihave used a D-Link camera in the past, and at least its stated features worked. I can't say that for this EasyN model 136.

Everything about this router is great except for one thing that should be standard in any router. If you just want it for wifi then it's fine but I'd advise you to get a different router if you need it for a bigger network.

Here's my application and why it doesn't deserve a high rating:

I connected this router to a switch and a computer and printer to the router. The computer could not find the printer. I had purchase a nighthawk before where the switch is already built in.

I tried connecting the router to the modem and the switch to the modem but still couldn't find it.

I then bought another switch to connect it to the existing switch. Then everything, router, computer and printer to the new switch. Now it can find the printer. For over $200, this router can't even allow a computer to find a printer that both are connected to it.

Get the nighthawk instead.

While I knew the flash drive I bought was a used one, it arrived containing the former owners data, some personal, and also had a missing part of its slide essential for inserting it into the computer UBS slot.

I bought everyone in my family one for christmas at the end of 2010 (6 in total), of those 6 only 3 are still working.  There is a serious problem with the firmware which has caused 2 of them to freeze during the boot-up process, and a 3rd to stop the computer from accepting a charge all together.  The is no US number that you can call for customer service because they are based out of China, only an email address.  I looked online and the only poeple that know how to fix it are very computer savy people that recommend reinstalling the firmware!    Yes it is a very good price, but in this case you get what you pay for.  The ones that do work are slow, have lots of inputs but few actually work, a very short battery life, and make a better paper weight than a computer.  Learn from my mistake, TAKE YOUR MONEY ELSEWHERE!!!!!

I bought this from Amazon on Nov. 27 and to my disappointment, one day later the order was canceled by circuit city siting that it was not in stock.. I go to my local CC and they have plenty of them in stock. Caution: Do not buy anything from Circuit city from Amazon.

I have four of these drives, designed to replace a bunch of older external drives; the first three work great, but the fourth, an newest ( less than a month old) just crashed, along with a 100 meg of files...Amazon says they will replace the drive if Iomega does not solve the problem, but the telephone numbers they list are no good.
If one out of four is good enough for your, then go ahead...But that is not a good record for me.

A month later, another drive is going South, no customer support, and too late to return it to Amazon.

I have had the Cisco wi-fi adapter for 6 months and it was beautiful how it enabled such amazing wi-fi connection. But sometimes the long attenna would precariously knock against objects or objects would accidentally knock into its long erect extension.

I left it inside my laptop under my bed and grabbed my laptop today to find no wi-fi adapter attached on it. I looked down to see the black wifi adapter on the ground... Which is strange since I did not remove it...So I pick it up, and I cannot see the usb section..... after half a second I find the usb sectoion still attached to my freaking laptop! Like a bee stung my usb port, died, and left behind it's stinger. My cisco wi-fi adapter has died in a suicidal way.

I could not give this one star due to my love for its powerful connections, but the durability under 1 year and expensiveness ($40 at best buy) makes the ordeal not worth it.

Best of luck, and I recommend instead purchasing a SHORT wi-fi adapter since this is too long. Size matters!

Candidly,
John

In summary, this unit has some design problems that seem to have been solved in newer models. Move on, but consider a Netgear.
This is a great product, when it works. I purchased this unit in Septerber 2002. Very easy to set up, great browser-based interface. I have past experience with the Netgear MR314 and the FM114P is more user friendly and less flaky. No problems getting the print server to work. Great wireless signal strength with the stock antenna. Ran it continually for a year.
Then BANG, one day it died.
Called tech support, got right on (no holding!), very friendly but a bit hard to understand (from India). They did some trouble shooting. Nothing worked. I got the old "My manager will have to call you back." I thought "Great, how long will that take." Got a call back in 3 minutes. Got my Return Material Authorization (RMA) without any argument, and I hope to have a new unit in a couple days. They also have a nice feature where for a couple extra bucks, they will express mail you a new unit, with a postage paid box, and then you mail back in the dead one after you get the new one.
Unfortunately, they will be sending me another FM114P. It seems like these things are good for about 6 to 12 months then they die. Netgrear should really discontinue this model and offer an upgrade or replacement with a model that does not have the same design problems. But great tech support, great capabilities, and high marks from a user-interface and capabilities standpoint.

I bought 14 of these for our laptops that are in use in our sales department.

I like the unit and how well the keyboard connects to the unit. There are two things I dislike when using the unit. The first is no fault of the unit but when using an external keyboard you get no word suggestions on the tablet. What is the fault of the unit is that the magnet holding the keyboard is very week so very often the keyboard falls out and crashes to the floor. So far it has continued to work after each plunge.    A 6 month update: I have dropped my review to 2 stars and plan to look for a different unit. I still dislike that the keyboard falls out but now there is a big delay when turning on the keyboard. It takes several seconds to link with the tablet and begin to type.

[...]    As a regular user, I tried all possible solutions such as moving closer, tried three different brands of wireless adaptors, choose all kinds of different configurations, so on and so forth.     As an experienced computer engineer, I tried different firmware, tried to use network strumbler,tried linux, and more.     Nothing can prevent this router from crash. You can literally tell the router automatically reboot by just looking at the light leds on the front panel. It blinks for 40-50 seconds, and whennever the traffic through the router goes a little bit higher, all leds lighted up staticly and then all shutdown. There you go, re-----booooot!    Someone may say, you get what you paid for. Yes it is CHEAP. but for this product, I would rather pay NOTHING. I won't bother to call the customer service, they could not be more proficient than me. I would not waste more time on this product, otherwise, I would ask D-link paying me for all the time I spent to disgnose this crap.    So, DO NOT BUY! And if you happened read this, and you do agree, please try to click the LINK stating that you think this comment is useful. So that no more victims would suffer as I did in the past few days.
Not very easy to use and the signatures are awful, not discernible at all.  Not at all what I expected or wanted.

I bought this Amazon 6 feet USB cable 3 times and each time they stopped working after 2 weeks to a few months for no reason. I just used them normally, not yanking or straining them or anything but after a while the cheap connectors become loose on their own and I had to push them manually into the phone's connector for them to work--when I release, they stopped working. I keep re-buying them because of all the great reviews, thinking that I was just unlucky to get the bad ones. But after the third one failed, that's it, never again!!!    But I do love the long 6 feet length, it's really convenient to be able to lie in bed using my phone while having it plugged into a wall charger 6 ft away. So I bought this Mediabridge 6 feet USB cable instead: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004GF8TIK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1    I own a few Mediabridge HDMI cables that have been working great for years now. So far the Mediabridge USB cable is working great! The connection is noticeably sturdier and fits tighter. I think this one will last. Will update if this isn't the case.

This product is worthless. Every fingerprint, every speck of dirt and dust show up, I am constantly wiping off my screen.  Just purchased an anti glare, anti fingerprint screen protector like the one I have for my Kindle Fire.  I purchased this one because I just got the HD and I didn't want my screen protector to affect the clarity, but this p.o.s. is driving me nuts.

I've owned each Kindle e-reader, currently my favorite is and it remains the 2nd gen Paperwhite.

About the only thing I like about this new voyage is the slight increase in screen resolution.

There is a slight change in cast from top to bottom in the lighting, it's not as bad as the blotchy first generation Paperwhite, but not as nice as the Papwerwhite V2.

I welcomed the return of buttons as an option for page turn, unfortunately I can't quite get comfortable with these new ones. They just don't feel right to me.

Why after all these years is there still an "Experimental Browser" what? remove it please.

I'm confused why the auto-brightness seems to work backwards. In a dark room, it turns the lighting down, making the Kindle harder to read for me, and then in brightly lit rooms, it gets brighter? huh? why wouldn't the built in lighting basically turn-off in a bright room and become brighter (to a point) in a dark room?

I suppose if the Voyage were $100 cheaper I'd probably keep it, unfortunately I just can't seem to justify spending over $200 for this device.

Got this about 6 months ago, and it never worked continuously for more than a month without a reboot. Called customer service several times, they made me make some configuration changes but the problem repeated. It started having a new problem lately and I couldn't use it anymore. The wifi connection suddenly went bad, speeds were down to 1 Mbps compared to 30 Mbps I normally get. Tried rebooting several times but it didn't help. Out of warranty (it only comes with 3 months warranty), I wasn't sure what to do with it. Replaced it with Mediabridge router for less than 1/3 rd of the price and my wifi is now back alive. I'm even getting slightly better speeds (35 Mbps). WNDR3800 is just garbage. Never buy Netgear again.

I purchased this product less than 90 days ago from Amazon.  It is imported by BrainyDeal in Brooklyn NY, sold by PowerDirect and fulfilled via AmazonDirect.    The product was manufactured in China.  Unfortunately, it is of the same very poor quality if have experienced from other products manufactured in China and sold by Amazon.  It overheated and would not charge.    Amazon will not accept a full warranty return of the product since it was 2 days outside the 30 day return window.  Amazon told me it would charge me a 50% restocking fee to return it and may, based on their findings, refund what would amount to only $3.  I told them to stick it.    My solution, never buy from any of the above mentioned companies, and avoid the following label \\"Made in China\\"

I had to return this item. I am very disappointed this didn't work because it is so hard to find this keyboard as a wireless device. This item came with a wireless keyboard and a wired mouse, as shown in the picture. When trying to connect the keyboard I found that there was no USB receiver in the box to link the keyboard to the computer. The only other item was the wired mouse, which I never intended to use due to it being wired.

I submitted a return request and was answered promptly with an RMA number and the following statement - "It does not ship with batteries or a mouse, the other device in the picture is the receiver". Not sure what that means because the only other item in the box is a wired mouse (as shown in the picture on amazon). Does that mean that the wired mouse is the receiver and not a mouse? So the wired mouse would have to be connected to the computer in order for the wireless keyboard to work? Kinda defeats the purpose of trying to go wireless doesn't it?

I'm also not very happy with the fact that I have to pay return shipping for a product that was not correctly represented in the ad. I would never have ordered this item if it had stated in the ad that you had to connect a wired mouse in order to use the wireless keyboard.

Bought this in February, its now August of the same year and it no longer charges. I've tried multiple cables, and plugged my phone as a double check. All cables charge my phone, not a single one charges the keyboard.

Not sure if others are having similar problems, or if its just me. Seems unusual that a keyboard charge slot would be broken in only 6 months. I have also noticed that if the keyboard gets bumped or jiggles when its plugged in, the entire thing will vibrate and blink rapidly. If you jiggle the cord a bit you can get it to stop & continue charging.

Keys are pretty sensitive, which is nice. F1-12 are not raised keys, just touch activated. Hitting the FN key turns the row from white light to blue, making it a little harder to see what the icons are. Not sure if there's a way to change this, but kind of annoying that its the default. Keyboard is nice & compact though, and works fine in your lap.

I wish I could give this product a flowering review however I cannot. I had purchased this product to replace another snap shield whose corner had cracked and broken again. Of any of the snap shields we're used to date, this is the most disappointing. I had it installed less than 24 hours before all 4 corners developed stress cracks due to poor manufacturing tolerances and fitment. As a result I ultimately returned it.

All in all I cannot recommend the Belkin Snapshield product. Between the two iPads we have in our house we've gone through 6 Snapshields in the last two years with only one needing to be replaced as a result of accidental damage.

In my opinion Belkin is using too brittle of a plastic compound for the Snapshield allowing it crack far too easily from just normal usage.

Pros:  -The form factor of this device is great, perfect size and weight.  Cons:  -It is impossible to click and drag with this.  You click and hold the button and start to drag your item, but the remote will just drop it.  This is my biggest complaint because you cannot drag and drop files, move windows around on screen, or use scroll bars.  It is not an issue of RF interference, as the remote never misses a keystroke or mouse click, it just can't drag on screen items properly.  -The thing tears through batteries.  In three months of extremely light HTPC use I have already had to replace the batteries twice.  Tried Duracells and Energizers with the same results.  Only going a month and a half with almost no use is pretty poor, considering my main keyboard (which handles millions of keystrokes each year) only needs its batteries changed about annually.  -The dark blue ink used to label the alternate functions of the keys is very hard to read.  Being that the main market for this device is a HTPC remote, where it would be used in a darkened environment, this is just a very poor design choice.  -The right mouse button on the side of the device was broken on the unit I received.  Conclusion:  I do not recommend it to anyone, at any price, for any use it simply does not work well.  I would not purchase it again.

Beware! I bought this item and they sent me the wrong model twice! Instead of a M471B5273DH0-CK0 they sent me a M471B5173QH0-YK0 it's the PC3L one.. After checking with a friend he said that it should be fine. But before settling in with this one be sure to do a memory test for the ram as the first one they sent me was causing my laptop to not boot! Be smart and test out your ram with memtest86

Virtually impossible to apply without collecting dirt or bubbles.  Gave up and trashed it since a small piece of dirt got underneath and was impossible to remove from the film.  At a lower price, I'd be less annoyed.

I chose it mainly for Intel Small Business Advantage. According to Gigabyte, this model is suppose to have Intel SBA but I find it is completely absent on the packaging, and in manual. Even though there's still software on their website--it did not work, that means there is no longer Intel SBA. My board looks different than pictured on Amazon, even though the model name is still the same. This seems common practice for them. They also reduced the size of their Ultra Durable heatsink and now it looks cheap. If you're looking for Intel SBA, go with another manufacturer.

I got this cable for my husband. Was very happy with the size and the tangle free cable. You definitely had plenty of room to move around while charging your phone. Had no issues plugging it into iphone 5 with a lifeproof case on it. Then it happened, it wouldn't charge his phone. I believe the cable has a short in it because you can move the cable and the charge symbol kicks on and off. Only used the cable for approximately two weeks. I find the same problem happening with a lot of the plastic cables.

This product, (the M003) is without a doubt a lazy effort to throw some low-end components together to try and rip off people.    The world needs a good, light weight, Android 1.6 (it works just fine for most of what most people need this sort of thing for:  email, web browsing, social media. movies, ebooks, etc.--my 2 year old HTC G1 works quite well for this with a too-small screen to read comfortably.  This product tries to pretend to fill that niche.    THIS IS NOT USEFUL!    The product does not work, and it is a total waste of time and money.  The touch screen is worthless, the response time is horrible, the Android market does NOT work and the 9 applications in the vendor's \\"market\\" are worthless.  With a lot of effort you CAN download apps onto a SD card and load them that way, but since they perform so poorly on the platform, it is a sad waste of time.  WiFi barely works within a few feet of the router.  System locks, crashes after a few minutes use.    Worst of all, the US importer only offers a five (5) day warranty!  Hmmm...didn't quite see that on Amazon's site.  Funny how that happens.    The price seems to move down a lot now that people have purchased these and word is out.     Do not buy this.  You will be disappointed, and it will give Android and Amazon a bad name.
The device came broken and I was never given a refund. Tried working with slingbox and even they admitted it was a faulty unit but was never issued a RMA. Very UnSatisfied with this item.

I bought the white version less than a year ago, after my original Sanctuary quit working.  This model is slow to charge and the plug is incredibly cheap.  The adapter no longer works, you can't buy a new one and customer service hasn't responded to my emails.  I will be switching to a simpler--and cheaper--multi-USB charger and storing it in a box.

I'm super disappointed with the burner. It claimed to be a Lightscribe burner and that it would work on a Mac. Unfortunately it does not come with any drivers for it. I downloaded a program from the app store hoping that it would solve the problem but it didn't recognize the burner for Lightscribe. LG support was unhelpful and just said it wouldn't work. I think I'm going to send it back and start over.

I had to send back the first idea tab because there was an issue with the wireless adapter. The replacement IdeaTab that was sent to me had other issues. There was some problem with the battery because it would not hold a charge for more than one hour. It would also randomly update Windows and turn itself off almost every day. It seems like the power would be lost midway through the update as it would do this over and over again. It also seems like the micro USB port port was faulty as it would not always charge when plugged in. All in all not a great experience.
did not work for its intended need.

I wish I had paid just a little more and gotten a supported, mainstream USB Wireless Adapter! The adage \\"Stingy pays twice!\\" was certainly true. I tried installing this on one of my XP machines - I \\"kind of\\" had it working. [Incidentially, the documentation was minimal - and unhelpful]. However, then I started to have all kinds of problems on that XP computer - looking a lot like something had infected it. I got \\"missing INI files\\", \\"illegal instruction at ...\\". So - I assumed that it was just a sick PC - and then tried it on another XP machine - with similar miserable results. After 3 days of failed attempts to \\"Restore a windows backup\\", \\"Repair Windows XP\\", \\"Reinstall XP\\", and finally Install XP from scratch on the 1st computer. That failed as well. The other XP box - I had to reformat the harddrive and install from scratch. Finally I am back working on 1 of the computers - but WITHOUT the suspect wireless adapter. No way... I have owned 2 LED TV's and loved them both. So, I had no understanding that there is apparently some issue with LED monitors wherein the backlight causes the screen to be unevenly lit, causing portions of the screen to be way too dark and/or way too light. It was obvious to me right away, and the owner's manual describes this problem as a common issue with LED monitors. It sounds like malarkey to me; I have a hard time believing that if people knew that only part of the screen was usable, that they would buy these LED monitors, but that's apparently how it is. The top of my screen is too dark, and the bottom is too faded. Only the middle third of the screen is good for viewing. I have tried adjusting the brightness and contrast, however all that does is change which third of the screen is viewable. If I adjust the brightness to where the top isn't too dark, then the bottom 2/3 of the screen is faded out. If I adjust the bottom part to where it's not faded, then the top 2/3 is way too dark.

I miss my old LCD monitor. I wish it hadn't died!

Although this monitor does have a very crisp picture, and great size -- there is a noticable \\"bowing\\" effect towards the top of the screen, right out of the box after I hooked it up properly and installed the drivers. Although the horizontal curvature is slight, and only appears to be on the upper 1/3 of the screen, it *is* noticeable, and can get annoying after a while when you discover that it cannot be fixed with the controls. (No amount of tweaking could fix it, so I had to return it.)
If you like STRAIGHT horizontal lines on your webpages, word docs, etc/, trust me -- don't get this monitor. It's easy to tweak the vertical lines, but the horizontals cannot be altered. No monitor has a \\"perfect\\" display, but with this one I'd say there's a pretty good chance you'll get some horizontal \\"bowing\\" that you can't correct with the adjustments. If not, consider yourself lucky -- or maybe not -- because it'll probably crap out in 6 months regardless.
That being said, I used to have a Viewsonic A70 and never had one problem with it. However, if you're looking for a reliable 19\\" monitor with nice, correctly drawn graphics and text, I'd look elsewhere than this one. This is definitely not a \\"flat screen\\" monitor (literally and figuratively) -- something Viewsonic convieniently fails to mention.

It was also not possible to just go to a service center in my area to have the battery replaced because the policy is that all the computers of this type are sent to Toshiba depot for repair. I was looking for a large HDD to store media files and bought this one because it was on sale.  I hadn't used a Seagate HDD before so thought I'd take a chance.  Unfortunately, this will probably be my last Seagate purchase as well.    The HDD installed fine but wasn't formatted so wasn't recognized by my computer.  Inconvenient, but not a problem.  Rather than using the native Windows 7 HDD tool, I installed the packed in Discwizard software.  The software detected and formatted the HDD without a hitch, or so it seemed.  When I tried to reboot my computer later on, it wouldn't boot.  I'll skip the details, but after a lot of troubleshooting it turns out that the software messed up the master boot record of my computer.  This problem was easily fixed once identified, but this kind of problem should not exist with an HDD installation.    During my research, I discovered that the firmware my HDD shipped with (0034) has known issues (such as the loud operation and clicking some people complain about).  Upgrading the firmware turned out to be an ordeal.  Again, this kind of problem shouldn't exist with an HDD installation.  I don't know why they ship HDDs with firmware that is known to be bad.    I ultimately returned the HDD because of all these problems, although I did get it working for a while and it was fine during that period.  But I can't trust an HDD that gave me so many problems during installation with my media files.  I've installed dozens of HDDs in several computers and have never had half the problems I had with this one.    This gets two stars instead of one because I did get it working eventually, and once working it was apparently fine.  Plus it came with a SATA cable which was convenient.  If you manage to install this without problems then it's a good value.

This was a below average PC for me when I first started playing on computer, but now that I have been playing for a while, I realize there are necessary upgrades.

1: The RAM NEEDS to be upgraded from 4gb(x2) to 8gb(x2).

2: The Graphics/Video card NEEDS to be upgraded from the NVIDIA GT 720 to something like the GTX 960 or greater.

3: The CPU SHOULD be upgraded from an AMD FX-4300 to an AMD FX-8150 or an Intel i5-3570k quad-core, which would require a new motherboard.

All in all this computer is FAR below average, even lagging behind laptops. I highly-suggest building your own computer rather than buying this PC.

This computer is okay for games that aren't graphically intense, but for games like Battlefield, Far Cry, and Metro: Last Light, you will NEED to upgrade.

(edited every year after purchase to improve accuracy of review)

It worked well for about three months and then it started having the same problem as the prior three routers.  It starts dropping you and at first, you reboot your PC and it works again (for a while).  Start a spreadsheet of the date, time, what YOU did to correct it, whether you called Linksys, Name or ID of whom you spoke to at Linksys - add a column for what THEY had you do to resolve it.  Once you realize you are doing this on a every other or daily basis you call Linksys.  First they tell you it must be your ISP - Internet Services Provider (Cox, Verizon, AT&T, etc.), so you hang up and call your cable or other provider and if they don't tell you - ask them how many days your internet has been connected in a row.  You call Linksys back and they tell you that you need to have a computer directly connected to it with a RJ-45 or Ethernet cord. (so much for owning a laptop to use wirelessly).  You connect your PC to the router so now you should be able to get onto the internet.  They immediately tell you that your software must need an update.  They get you signed into their Smart WiFi site and they run an update for the software even if you don't need it.  You will Never see them run the  "is my software up to date"  button because then they might have to look further and do more than an update.  After they run the software they always changed the channels your router is using and tell you that will fix it.  And it does, for about a week. When it starts again, you think about having to bring your PC to where your router is located and sitting there while they try to correct the problem. So - you Google the problem - and you discover that Windows 8 has a new piece of software that resets your router adapter for you which corrects the problem.  You start using this nifty tool andyou think, this isn't so bad, at least I have a network connection.  After a while you realize the problem is persisting and your little fix isn't working all the time.  That is when you start going to the router and unplugging it and plugging it back in again.  Add every little thing you do to your spreadsheet.  For some reason resetting your router and at times your modem seems to work well and you think, its fixed - I solved it.  You get into a project and you are spending a lot of time on your computer and it starts again.  Now it happens when you use your computer for more than checking your email and calendar. You call Linksys and they update the software and change the channel a few more times.  Then out of frustration you go to the library to do work or anywhere they have a free network.  The seasons have changed and getting out isn't so bad.. then one day - you say I've had it and you call Linksys and tell them you can't stand the problems with this router.  The are very polite and tell you that you have only called 7 times in the entire year so it doesn't qualify as a recurrent problem and oh by the way  - your warranty expired.  But they are happy to sell you a new router, a better one - SAY _ NO Thank you and Run to the nearest real store to buy a different brand.  I wish I had... j

Windows 8 sucks. It adds multiple extra steps do anything, such as shutting down. Setting are not intuitive and are difficult to navigate. All in all a pain in the butt. If this is the future of Windows, I might finally be buying a Mac.

This review will be based on my experience with the unit. It's not intended to
refute the \\"successes\\" of the others that have reviewed this box. I do not
intend to assert that after \\"Detailed Study\\", it's the boxes fault. That
said, on with the review.

This box is AN ORNAMENT. It is entirely well suited to placing in ones
office with lights flashing so others think, \\"WOW, is that cool or what?\\".
It is only a NAS in that it does attach to a network. And, it does have
storage. I guess that's enough. But, as a flexible, functional, RAID
server, it is NOT!

I bought this NAS/RAID Server to replace my Promise NS4300N RAID file
servers which were getting long in the tooth. Hell, I bought an extra
one as a warm backup/standby. Well, go figure, both my NS4300N boxes
died almost simultaneously. I was able to transfer all their data
just in time to the TS412.

It was just in time because the 3TB file transfer on a GBit ethernet
to the TS412 took DAYS! Shortly after that, the last NS4300N finally
gave it up.

I am now backing up the primary TS412 on my secondary TS412.
According to the NAS, the remaining time is...... 13 DAYS! That's
13 days for a 5TB transfer on GBit Ethernet. The 412s are right
next to each other connected by a 3 foot Cat6 cable. I utilized the
fact that they have 2 network interfaces. I set them up to do
backup so as not to busy the primary network. The bandwidth
usage graph for that interface shows less than 7MB/s! Remember,
point to point over 3 ft Cat6 with no intervening hardware....
7MB/s! Must be the processor? Nope... less than 50% utilization.
Must be the Memory? Nope... 60% physical/12% virtual utilization.
Must be my imagination? If you don't hear from me in the next
13 days, you'll know the answer.

This box is pretty. The software/web interface is pretty as well.
It's stuffed with cool functions. Too bad the software is buggy
and quirky. You think the guys writing the software would
have checked out what the box does when creating multiple volumes?
Apparently not. Having 2 volumes with the same share folder
names causes the box to hide one folder. I found that out
when I created a second volume and all my files appeared to
disappear on the first volume. I couldn't get to them from
the web interface. But, storage was being used. I telnet
into the box and voila, the files are on the first volume,
a new share folder name is on the second and it is empty.
The web file manager shows.... empty. You figure it out.
I've had a USB external drive simply drop off line when backing
files from the 412 to the external drive. TS412 fault? I dunno.
I've tried to create a 3TB mirror from essentially blank
drives. I was surprised to see the format part of the program
go quickly and then I had to wait hours for \\"Synchronizing\\".
I'm sorry, did you just format 1 blank drive and build the
mirror on the other? You couldn't just mirror the blank
drives without synchronization and then format the mirror?
Please try to save me hours of my life next time. I tried
taking a 3TB mirror and migrating to RAID5 with another 3TB
drive. That took the better part of a WEEK! I was using
it as a USB printer server. It was working fine before
messing with the RAID volumes. Now, it's not working at all.
Is it a 412 problem? I dunno. Yet another thing to waste
life cycles on.

If you research this stuff on the web, you'll find the
QNAP support forum. The nice people here are more
than happy to give you one of a few \\"canned\\" answers....
1) RTFM.
2) Remove the volume and recreate it.
3) Buy a more expensive box next time. (ie \\"What do you expect?\\")

My previous life was as a software engineer. And to RTFM, Isay,
if you're getting the same damn questions over and over again,
maybe you need to wonder if your software is \\"USER FRIENDLY\\". Save
yourself and the customers some time, consider building it so
it's intuitive to OTHERS and not yourself. To \\"Remove the volume
and recreate it\\", I say, is that what RAID, high availability, and
fault tolerance is about? If my RAID is down the majority of
the time because I need to destroy the existing volume, the machine is
slow, and I'm rebuilding, who cares how robust it is when a drive fails....
the box is DOWN! And, if I have to spend the better part of days
rebuilding because of a real drive failure, how am I protected against
another fault? During that lengthy period another fault takes me
out entirely. And, to the final response \\"What do you expect?\\", I say,
I expect that an advertised feature should WORK... not work on an
upscale box, not be a tease. I expect that 2 boxes transferring
files, connected directly by a cat6 cable, should melt the cable.
At 6MB/s, you DONT NEED A GBit LINK! I expect that, should I have
a drive failure, the box can reconstruct the RAID in a \\"reasonable\\"
time so as to minimize the possibility of a second fault wiping
all my data. And, I expect, professional software and hardware
engineers know what I'm saying. I shouldn't have to buy a
more expensive box.

I would not buy this box again. I will probably not buy another
QNAP box even though the ratings always seem good and the
higher end boxes seem to have quantum leap performance
improvements. I have a Drobo5N. I will be getting a Synology.
I'm repairing my Promise NS4300N servers. And, I'm thinking
of simply building my own RAID NAS. Fool me once.......

Bought this shortly after I got my MBP a while ago. Since I like to keep things new and fresh I get a new decal at least once a year. This will not come off as cleanly as I'd hoped.

The screen protector is shipped in a cardboard container with just a pre-printed label. It comes with a squeegee card, which is pretty handy actually.

The instructions start by telling the buyer how difficult installing a screen protector can be. They even offer you a toll-free number to call them if you need help--but they don't provide any illustrations to aid you with this difficult task.

They give you two screens, a cleaning cloth, and something called pre-installation film.

Right off the bat, the instructions and the labels do not match. It says to peel the tab labeled \\"Step 1\\". The tabs on both screen protectors do not have Step 1 printed on them.

In Step 3, they say when you are happy with the alignment, they say to pull back the mask attached to the tab labeled \\"Step 2.\\" Regrettably, there is no tab labeled \\"Step 2.\\"

Based upon sparse and confusing instructions, and the apparent requirement to call a toll-free number for installation, I cannot recommend this product.

Rebecca McFarland Kyle, June 2013

Avoid the Toshiba brand. The fan exhaust is on the right-hand side. I use a mouse instead of the touchpad for faster response and ease of use. My wrist is thus positioned just inches from the heat exhaust and it literally burns my wrist. I have a Satellite P875-S7200 17.3 inch model, likely the exact same layout with a slight difference in model number based on retail branding.

The AC plug is also on the right-hand side which cuts down on space and makes it awkward and impossible to comfortably use the mouse or desk space, plus the cable dangles in front of me. We have an older Acer laptop and the engineers at Acer are much more intelligent. The only thing Acer put on the right side was the DVD--very, very smart!!! The AC, the heat exhaust, two USB ports, the VGA, card reader, et al. are all in the back! These engineers got straight A's in college in the ergo courses! I looked at a Dell that, although not laid out as smart as the Acer, at least has the exhaust on the left side.

Unless you live in the Arctic and need some heat or unless you love pain and discomfort, or unless you are left-handed, or unless you want to scald your wrist so you can sue the deep pockets of Toshiba, avoid this Toshiba as well as avoid any laptop that does not put most of the ports in the back, especially the heat exhaust and AC plug. Please note .... most laptops crowd the USB ports right next to each other. Some devices are so wide that plugging in one USB makes the other USB unusable. I have that problem with a card reader. Look for ports on both sides or on the back and one side. The designers are too dumb to put the USB ports at least 2-3 inches from each other. If anybody is debating going with a desktop or laptop, go with the desktop since laptops always will run hotter, thus shortening the life. Desktops have three cooling fans (one game machine has six) and desktops have plenty of internal space for air circulation. Using this Toshiba has convinced me that laptops can be a very bad deal, and a real \\"pain\\"--literally! I have to leave now to go put an icepack on my right wrist.

I bought the dual band WRT610N wireless and the WUSB600N dual band USB adapter abt two weeks back and have been greatly disapponited by the very POOR performance of this particular Linksys product.    Signal strength between the adapter and the wireless router is always poor (previously good to excellent on my WRT54G router) on both the 5Mhz ans 2.4Mhz band. This is only a distance of abt 10-12meters with a concrete wall in between.    Calls to online chat support and phone support did not help.... Updating the router to the latest firmware (B18) and adapter to the latest driver which did not significantly improve the poor performance. All other measures suggested by tech support (including turning off the 5MHz radio-antennae?!?) did not help either.     Online search revealed multiple posts on many blogs and forums complaining abt the poor performance (and heating problem) of this particular product...    Moving the wireless access point and adapter nearer to each other to abt a distance of 5-6meters between them did significantly improve the performance but it totally defeats the purpose of spending so much money to buy something which did not work as advertised....    For the time being, my trusty old WRT54GS is back again to serve me until Linksys figures out hot to fix this mess with the WRT610N...

Keep in mind that today marks the first day I will use this device exclusively, as it only arrived Friday afternoon.
I am using this device at my place of work, as the standard MS-mouse and other typical mice leave my ring and little fingers feeling cramped and tender at the end of the day. My hope is that using a vertical mouse with a place for all five fingers will take away two stress factors with one.
So far, it is awkward to get used to, and fine, precise control is hard to achieve. This will likely be the case for any vertical mouse, however, and I am only considering that worth half a star. The most obvious issue for me right now, is that it feels like I have to squeeze the device to keep my hand where it needs to be. My hand is \\"hanging on for life\\" as it were. This causes a different strain, that I hope I find a way to eliminate. There are other reviewers that mention that a wrist support will be necessary with this type of mouse. I agree, however, I have a wrist support, and I would add that you need a wrist support at least twice as thick/tall as mine. The one I have is about .75 inches tall. In order for my arm to relax and keep my wrist in a neutral position, I think I will need one from 1.5 inches to 2.25 inches.

I plan to add and to this review as the week goes by, and I make my decision to keep or return it.

Day 2:
The strain of gripping this mouse is getting to me. As I stated before, You have to squeeze the device to keep you hand in the right spot to use the buttons and wheel. Strain is less obvious, so far, compared to a typical mouse, but not absent.

Also, When I step away from my desk for 15 or 30 minutes, the mouse has powered-down, and will not power back on with movement. Turning the main power switch on the bottom of the device *sometimes* corrects this issue, but I have already had to remove and re-insert the USB receiver four times in 24 hours.
EDIT: Clicking a mouse-button wakes the device.

Day 3:
The hand strain I was experiencing with \\"normally\\" shaped mice has just changed a bit with the new hand-position. Since you *have* to grip the device (read: squeeze), you end up with a different type of strain on top of the one you are purchasing this device to relieve.

*Final thoughts*
Overall:
This device is imprecise and a little bit difficult to get used to. The ANKER idea of up-down is a little out of alignment with my idea of up-down. By that, I mean that when I think I am moving the device in a way that will make the mouse pointer travel only vertically, I am actually moving the pointer in a diagonal. A calibration utility where a user can choose orientation would be valuable here. I don't even feel that the orientation is quite right.
Precision:
Were have had +/-30 years to get used to the fine-motor control needed to move the mouse a single pixel at a time in any direction. This ability is rooted in the fingers (for me, the ring and thumb) and wrist and their ability to move very precisely. With a vertical orientation, ANY device with be less precise -- at least at first. I find that the same reason that these devices are supposed to be useful and ergonomic -- that they translate fine motor functions to the entire arm and specifically the shoulder muscles -- is what makes them less useful as input devices for full-time.

Take my comments with salt. They are only my opinions.

I am running a fully loaded (4GB ram, 1.8 GHz, 251GB flash) latest gen (2011) MBA.  If you are running the same configuration I do not recommend this product.  I purchased one of these cases tonight at the local Apple store and installed it immediately. I wanted to be able to go \\"sleeveless\\" in my briefcase to take advantage of the thinness of the MBA when traveling. I had researched several tech blogs on these cases as well as the feedback on Amazon as I was concerned that there may be issues with heat build up if the aluminum housing wasn't able to radiate/dissipate heat appropriately. When I saw the cases were sold in the Apple store I assumed this would not be an issue... I was wrong.  I have just removed the bottom cover after 3 hours of work for fear that too much heat was building up in my MBA. The aluminum shell on the bottom was noticeably warmer than it has ever been; it was hot to the touch. Tellingly, the aluminum cooled down almost immediately upon removing the cover... this was the nail in the coffin for my new \\"protective\\" cover.   During the three hours of use I had four programs open including outlook (a processor hog... its a work thing), was using the lighted keyboard and was charging the battery. Still, I continued working this way with the cover off and the difference in temperature was highly noticeable. For this reason, I will not be re-installing the bottom cover on my MBA. I do, however, intend to keep the top cover in place, as it fits nicely and will protect the more visible portion of my MBA over time. At full Apple store price (Amazon is $20 cheaper) this is an expensive consolation prize.

I bought this because I needed just a little more range than my router was providing. This product definitely increased the range of the wifi but dropped the speed of downloads drastically. I live in an apartment and was wanting to extend it to my neighbor who lived directly next to me. Not in a separate complex, right on the other side of my dining room wall was their dining room. The downloads speed dropped significantly from about 30mbs to 5mbs and uploads dropped from 5mbs to 1.5mbs. I had a better connection from my medialink N300 router (Great router by the way) in my neighbors apartment.

I followed all the trouble shooting tips from their website and other forums. I changed the channel, security, placement, antenna adjustments, etc but I couldn't get a better result. I ended up returning it and instead got an Asus RT-N66u router which had a surprisingly stronger range and didn't affect my download speed.

Overall, it increases range but drastically affects internet speeds. A better option would be to get a router or WAP, I'm having great results from the Asus Rt-N66u.

This was a great keyboard for the 5 months that it worked.

The pros: Good design and offers solid protection for an ipad air. The keyboard had an OK but slightly cheap feel, yet was functional and enhanced the ipad user experience. The look is great - the case creates a high-end look and the color selection is solid. I ordered the brown and the color and look is an exact match to the pictures

The cons: Low quality materials - the keyboard base is a dense cardboard and unless used on a solid surface, can make for a flimsy typing experience, the synthetic leather started to come apart a little at the seems after about 3 months of light use, the plastic of the keys have a cheap feel and the keys don't satisfy like other more expensive keyboards when typing.

The unacceptable: I really wanted to like this keyboard, but cannot recommend due to the B and N keys no longer working after 6 months of fairly light use. This would have been a great keyboard for the price, the good design and styling overcome the negatives even considering the lesser materials - but a build quality that only stands up to 6 months is unacceptable. I can't find any product warranty information so am assuming a total loss. Replacing items in such a short amount of time is a waste of time - I recommend spending $10-$20 more and buying a product that will last at least 1 year.

I bought one of these from Best Buy and was wary of the hard snap in design damaging the iPad.  It didn't at first but I noticed significant wear on the corner just from normal use.  I took the iPad out of the case just to noticed it was very damaged where the case was biting into it.  I took the case back to Best Buy and they gave me another.  A month later the second case had the same problem.  This case is good at housing the iPad but not protecting it, even from itself.

CONS:
My keyboard did not come with any documentation, I have no idea how to program the G keys or what the other extra keys do. I guess I will have to go search their website to find out how to use them.

During intense game play I have to hit keys twice sometimes \\"reload\\" because it just doesn't read that I hit the key. It is a bit frustrating when that extra half second gets me killed. The whole point of me paying so much money for this keyboard was because I thought it might give me an edge in battles like that, instead it's done just the opposite.

I hate the fonts on the keys, they just seem odd to me being squared.. the $ symbol looks like a squared 5 the @ symbol is a square, it just looks weird. It took me a couple seconds to even recognize some symbols at first.

It is a bit loud when typing, louder than other keyboards I've used.

It uses up 2 USB ports.

PROS:
I like the look and feel, the back-lit keys are very nice. It seems to be made really durable and has some weight to it like it's solid.

CONCLUSION:
It's an OK keyboard but not for gaming apparently. Certainly not worth the price.

I've had my Kindle 3 and this cover for several months. Within the past two weeks, I started having problems with my Kindle freezing up and rebooting without input by me. I thought I had a defective Kindle, so I contacted Kindle Support. First, be aware that if your Kindle freezes, if you push and hold the on/off switch for about 20 seconds, it will unfreeze (thaw?) and reboot. However, a continuous problem does not mean a Kindle defect. I waited several days for Support to get back to me, and when they did, they told me to remove THIS COVER. They issued me a refund, and gave me $25 towards a cover WITH THE LIGHT. Out of curiosity, I went to the product page for the cover today and was surprised to see it still being offered, and I noticed several recent negative reviews. Those people writing positive reviews might still encounter problems; it took several months for my Kindle to start acting up.  I have nothing but GOOD things to say about Kindle Support; they are always extremely helpful and polite. However, I am very surprised that this cover is still being offered for sale.

The laptop is ok for the price. I bought this machine in 2011 from Amazon.

PRO's
* Good battery life: While it doesn't last 6+ hours on a single charge, it has a good battery life.
* Light: Not bad for the hardware package, which includes a DVD/CD drive.
* Acceptable build quality. Again, not bad for the price.

CON's
THESE ARE SEVERE ENOUGH FOR YOU TO CONSIDER NOT BUYING THIS MACHINE
* An irritating touchpad design: The mouse buttons are integrated into the touch sensitive area of the touchpad. The simple act of clicking the mouse moves the cursor when not necessary. All. The. Time. This will be a daily aggravation.
* Function key row that can only be used by pressing a \\"Fn\\" key simultaneously. If you are keyboard short cut user, you will find this irritating.

So, if your use case involves: (i) keeping this laptop on a desk (ii) with a separate mouse and keyboard, then it's fine. Otherwise, think twice.
