After trying 2 of these modems with the same problem on each, and researching the issue for several weeks, I have concluded that this modem has a severe design issue which causes it to be overly sensitive to power fluctuations and line quality. This modem issue causes the modem to be utterly uselss unless you happen to have near-perfect line quality. It will reboot several times a day, sometimes as many as 4 times per minute. The logs will show the same 3 messages at reboot: (1) 6-Notice N/A Cable Modem Reboot due to power reset, (2) 3-Critical R02.0 No Ranging Response received - T3 time-out (3) 5-Warning Z00.0 MIMO Event MIMO: Stored MIMO=-1 post cfg file MIMO=-1; CM-QOS=1.1;CM-VER=3.0. EVERY SINGLE TIME. Basically, the modem is too sensitive to power fluctuations. It sees a power fluctuation and goes into power-reset mode.

I called Motorola customer service and they denied any issues with the modem. They said that things like this don't indicate a bad modem, or bad design, and that everything needs handled on a case-by-case basis. No amount of reasoning and logic would help. They said that nearly every modem returned to them as not working works just fine in their test labs. Unfortunately, the real world isn't a test lab and this unit contains a flawed design that makes it too sensitive for real-world applications. When it worked, it worked fast and great - but it rebooted CONSTANTLY, making it's abilities hard to appreciate.

Like I said, I tried 2 of these modems and each did the same thing. The comcast-supplied Arris modem worked fine. Finally I returned this modem and bought a Zoom 5341J (which is $20 cheaper and just as fast and awesome as the motorola should have been). The Zoom has not rebooted in 2 months and the logs look great.

BEWARE...this Motorola modem has known issues (just search on the internet, post after post with the same issue) and motorla refuses to accept or help. They ignored my findings andconcerns (I am a 6-sigma black belt statistical problem solver / Shainin Red X journeyman - I get paid to problem solve extraordinarily complex problems). They treated my findings as if they were insignificant even though I had 100% confidence in the problems being caused by the modem. They flat out denied that this common issue, which is widely reported all over the internet, is a design problem or due to faulty hardware. That's not customer service.

Get the Zoom 5341J and you'll not have any problems at all. It's as blazingly fast as the motorola and far superior in technical design.

When buying computer systems from iBUYPOWER do not look at buying higher end hardware based on the factory warranty. Due to the fact that the "new" computer systems that you pay so much for are actually built using factory refurbished parts, and the only warranty you will get is a refurbished warranty from the manufacturer or the company that refurbished the item or IBUYPOWER themselves. I paid premium prices for my build thinking I was getting the Lifetime warranty on my $400+ motherboard (main reason for purchasing that motherboard), but when it went out 3 years later I found out it was only covered for a year because it had an R at the end of the serial number, meaning it was a refurbished board and the warranty had expired two years prior. I would expect that when I spend over $3K on a gaming system it should be built with new items. Ask questions about your build and the warranties on individual parts and try not to get stuck with used parts. Motherboard was only used part on my build. Good luck.

I do like the backlit keys, though I'm not a night owl and won't use them often. And I like the function keys separate from the number keys.

I'll trade it in and give it another whirl — if that one works, I'll gratefully provide a review with a better ranking.

Used this to replace a Corsair CX430 in order to upgrade the graphics card. Corsair has a good reputation, and I have had good luck with their PSUs in the past. This one, however, seems to have a non standard 24pin ATX connector. It will not snap onto the motherboard even with quite a bit of pressure. The CX430 snapped on perfectly. Due to the loose ATX connector the plug will occasionally vibrate loose requiring me to open the case and reseat the connector. Surely there is a fix for this other than me cutting off the connector and soldering on a  new one.  Would give it five stars otherwise. It's reasonably quiet and powers the system nicely (when it stays plugged in).  Edited to add: Corsair does stand behind their products. They replaced the unit under warranty although I have not tested the replacement since I ordered a  n Antec HCG620 to replace it before sending it back to Corsair. The new Corsair unit is just sitting here to be used as a backup in case I need it.

The flow does keep the HD semi-cool (because I place it practically on-top of it) but it seems to be completely ineffective in blowing the hot air away from the top of the Xbox one.

Take the palm of your hand and exhale normally and feel that force. That is about the flow these fans create. Then again they are basically silent.

I'll be returning mine. I'd say these suck but they don't do that either - suck or blow. DO NOT BUY.

First, let me say that I have two Kindle Keyboard 3G and, as a whole, I love them.

This review is specifically aimed at the Kindle/Audible.com relationship.

I received an Audible.com offer from Amazon through my Kindle Keyboard 3G account. I accepted the offer, but couldn't get the audio book to download. After a great deal of trouble-shooting, I contacted Audible.com and was told that the problem was my Wi-Fi connection, and to call Amazon. I called Amazon, who promptly told me to call Audible. After a few sessions of "Tag- you're it,” Amazon finally informed me that you can't download books over the 3G Whispernet.

My question is why are they pushing Audible.com content to Kindle 3G owners, if the device isn't capable of receiving it unaided? I'm really disappointed that Amazon never stated anywhere that you had to have an additional Wi-Fi to receive the content. I understand Amazon owns Audible.com, and so they would want to push their audio books, but I find this extremely misleading.

He tried the one he brought along and it worked fine, so it was an issues with this modem. I am returning it, and bought a Motorola SurfBoard instead. I called to activate it, and it works perfectly. I got this thing last week to replace a Radeon 9600.  The only reason the old card was replaced was because the cooling fan on it got noisy.  ATI makes its cards so that even something as small as a fan problem means replace the whole card.    I got the x1550 and loaded the drivers.  Everything looked normal until I tried to play mpeg2 videos.  The video froze on the first frame, but the sound kept playing normally.  I spent a week updating drivers, codecs settings, etc. and it still wouldn't play mpeg2s.    I got frustrated enough to open a ticket with ATI on their web site.  The only response I got from them was an automated email that suggested all the same repair procedures I had spent a week doing. I never heard from an actual human tech support rep.    I gave up and dropped some WD40 into the fan of the old one and put it back in.  The new one goes back to the store, and ATI products are now persona non grata on my machine.  I don't know if oiling the fan will be a permanent fix, but somehow I doubt it.

It made me feel like I was getting nickled and dimed to death.  Made me wonder what other apps I was expecting to be built in would not be as full featured as I would expect.  That plus a lot of the android apps my roommate uses on his android phone would not run on the tablet.  I finally gave up, returned this tablet and bought an iPad 1 for $400 and have been MUCH happier.  The main problem is that I'm an iPhone user and am apparently very picky about app quality and quantity.  It seemed like most of the free apps in the android tablet app store were either junk (lets just call the user interface \\"quirky\\") and 50% of the apps were just porn apps (no wonder android malware is up 600% from 6 months ago).  Played around with a Samsung galaxy tablet on black Friday and it looked like it fixed many of my concerns, though at a higher price point.  The Samsung seemed to perform slightly better, and its email app seemed to be generic and allowed all email accounts not just Google accounts.  I think to slake my app development desires, I'll just have to try out Mono-touch and see how it goes on the iPad.

Let's start with the fact that the plug was so tight, I couldn't actually fit a device into the female end. So I took an old expendable USB extension cable, had to ram it in, then wrench it back and forth to create even a workable amount of space. Unfortunately the Male end does not have the same problem, and pops out of the USB port without too much effort or resistance. Then, to top it off, it's not even USB 3.0! Sure it's a pretty blue color, but when plugging in a USB 3.0 stick (Kensington), into this adapter, which is plugged into a 3.0 port, Windows tells me that I would get better performance if I plug the stick into a 3.0 port - which I have as soon as I remove this crappy adapter. USB 3.0 Stick performance on 2.0 port = 23.9Mb/s, on a 3.0 port = 33.6Mb/s, using this adapter (on the 3.0 port, of course) = 24.2Mb/s. Draw your own conclusions.

At least it didn't cost much - but still completely misleading. Maybe I'll shove it into a port at the back of the case, and forget it ever existed.

I used this Ricoh MP9120A DVD/CDRW drive in a secondary Dell PC exclusively for playing CDs (20 per month on average) and burning CD-Rs (5 per month on average). I'm sad to report that this drive is now a costly paperweight after just 18 months of moderate use (6 months after the warranty expired; it figures). I expected to play more than approximately 400 CDs on the unit before it died.
Now every CD I put in spins up to speed and within a few seconds the drive is making an *AWFUL* racket. I have to shut down the PC and put a paperclip end into the emergency eject hole to retrieve the CD.
Inspection of the CD usually reveals plastic dust on the rim of the hole of the CD, evidence that the Ricoh drive has started to shred it through violent vibrations and shaking inside the drive. (My best guess is that the spindle of the drive is off-balance. Even turning the four restraining tabs over the CD does not help, as the tabs do not extend out far enough to cover the edges of a standard CD. That's a frustrating Ricoh design flaw!)
Every time the awful noise happens and the shredding of the CD in the Ricoh drive begins, I take the CD out and blow the plastic dust off of it, then put it in the *5 year old* Sony CDRW drive on my primary Dell PC (that has flawlessly played at least 1,000 CDs and burned hundreds of CD-Rs over 5 years). It always plays just fine in that Sony drive.
I'm now shopping for a non-Ricoh drive to replace this one. I will never buy a Ricoh drive again based on this bad experience, and I can't recommend this Ricoh drive to anyone who expects it to outlast the one-year warranty period.

I am on my 9th Kindle Fire and I've had enough with replacements of replacements of replacements.....you get the idea. When the Fire works properly, it absolutely ROCKS. No other machine comes close IMO. The problem has always been defective the battery charging port; it becomes loose (even when handled with kid gloves) after a short time of use and won't charge properly. With Fire replacement #9, the battery itself died after only days of use and will not charge. I'm done. No more replacements of this junk. CAVEAT BEWARE!

The good thing is Amazon's (usually) excellent customer service. The phone reps were always courteous and tried to be helpful; THIS ISN'T THEIR FAULT. So here's the deal I was offered: I can get replacement #10, or I can upgrade to the new Fire HD with 80% credit. Since I'm not a complete idiot, I took the HD deal. It's supposedly a different machine in construction. I love the Fire --- when it works ---so I'll give this a try. If I have problems with it, I'm headed to the iPad; more expensive, less bull@!&* so I figure I'll break even.

I have a Kindle DX that has always worked perfectly and I'd kill and eat anyone who tried to steal it. But the first generation Fire has problems; I can see that it isn't getting very good reviews. I really hope the HD is better.

BOTTOM LINE: Skip the \\"plain\\" Fire and go directly to the HD. After nine of them, I'd trust me if I were you!

I respect product reviews on Amazon and most of my purchases are based on these reviews. I bought this drive also after reading all the good reviews. It did indeed serve me well for it's warranty period, i.e. just an year. Soon after it (copying files) slowed to a level that it practically became unusable, followed by CRC error. Tried CHKDSK /F and /R several times leaving it complete repair process overnight etc. but to no avail. Then I formatted it couple of times using WD software, that did not help either. Finally I did run Western Digital Data LifeGuard Diagnostic which reported too many bad sectors. When checked with WD, it says my warranty had already expired a whole month back, so it won't be replaced. What a coincidence !
So did a little google on this issue and realized I am not lone victim. WD products seem to have a lifespan only of it's warranty period as if by design. I have decided to stay away from WD products as long as there's an alternative available to me.

I pulled it back and tried to get the lint off off with one of the enclosed cloths. What a mistake. Then I had lint all over the screen protector leaving the first screen protector ruined.

Then I used the 2nd protector and it went on crooked. I pulled it back to try to straighten it, and after doing that twice, I got it on straight but there is lint under the outside edges and part of the camera is covered. There are also several tiny bubbles that I can't remove and trying to remove them just scratches the screen protector. But there are probably microscopic pieces of dust under the screen protector causing the bubbles...

And it fingerprints worse than the bare Nexus screen!!!

I bought this GPU with the hope of keeping my computer alive longer, and as a cheaper alternative then buying a new processor and motherboard. Unfortunately when I tried putting it into the slot, and hooked it up to my screen nothing came up. Zip, Nada, NOTHING. I plugged in my old GPU, and it was recognized. Upon suggestion, I uninstalled my old drivers, and attempted to install the ones off the CD...it BOSDed halfway through installation. my motherboard was more then able to handle this GPU, and despite checking multiple times if it was plugged in, and plugged to the PSU, it would still never register to the board.

While not relevant, but still significant to my review, I gave up and tried to re-install my old GPU, which despite being detected before having the drivers installed, was no longer picked up both the old GPU, or the onboard connections upon installing the drivers.

For the headache in putting in, and the headache even upon removal for what is likely a GPU that was dead on arrival, I cannot recommend ASUS, ever, again, and must suffer the "I told you so" from one of my tech-friends, and another who told me to go with a newer GTX 600 model since I was working fine with a GTX 440 before. Thanks Asus.

I tried the full product for the one week trial offered by Cisco. (Sept 2009 - from Linksys site \\"Network Magic Pro\\")    Network Reporting:  This product reports network activity over a 24 hour period for specific PCs you specify then e-mails the report once a day (I got an e-mail after midnight most of the time.) So the reporting function IS NOT local, but depends on using a Cisco web URL to work. It reports the PC's sites visited (but not times), overall online usage time and a funky over simplified graph. The reporting would be much better without having to wait for a report, and depending on a website \\"service\\".    Software Installation:  In a peer-to-peer network, not using a server, you have to install and setup the software on each computer - a big waste of time. This includes setting up a username and password for each PC.    Network File sharing:  What a joke - you can set this up in windows, why on earth would you want to have more software using resources ?    Network Printer Sharing:  See Network File sharing ,(above), same thing - you can do it easily with windows.    Oh - the only thing that was nice was the network diagram. It showed devices on the network with their names, for instance iPhone, PDA, Desktop, laptop, etc. and indicated if they were on line or not.     A lot of what this software gives you can be accomplished with windows GUI, Graphical User Interface, or DOS command line commands.    Now if you have a Linksys (Cisco) router after the week trial you get limited functionality of the program - you can't get reporting anymore for instance.    In my humble opinion I think if you buy a Linksys router they should give you this software instead of having to pay $50.00 for it (on their site Sept 2009).  I have subsequently gone around and un-installed this software on all my computers. It is not worth anything - well maybe $5. for the network diagram, that was nice.    One more thing - you cannot do file/printer sharing with a Palm device. (I have a Palm TX, but it did show up on the cute network diagram !!!    Please don't waste your money or time. Thanks.

3 weeks after receiving this item I got a follow-up email from the seller asking how it was performing and suggesting if I had any issues I could reply to the email to alert customer services. This was strangely ironic timing since less than 48 hours later the adapter would charge only intermittently, and as other reviewers have mentioned, this was due to a faulty power cord. It got to such a point that the unit failed completely.
The email exchange with customer services was both prompt and polite and they sent a replacement unit, at no charge to me, which arrived only days later. Upon unpacking and plugging in the new adapter I was dismayed to find that it was DOA. No light and no amount of cable wiggling would change that.
In a last ditch effort I tried the new cord with the old adapter and the old cord with the new adapter and found that the first combination actually worked (for now).
I will continue to monitor the performance of the adapter over the coming months to see if it will last longer than the previous one.

I understand that products sometimes fail, and the initial email from customer service admitted that they expect 1 in 1000 units to fail, but to have 1 die after 3 weeks and the replacement not even work on arrival reflects poorly on the manufacturing and/or quality control department.

As far as the adapter's performance while working - I was very pleased. It does the job it is built for and in comparison, the cable is just marginally shorter than the original HP one. Also, this adapter does not get as hot as the HP one used to. For the money, so long as you aren't the unfortunate 1 in 1000 (twice) this would be a reasonable replacement should your original HP give up on you.

Personally, even though the customer service was impeccable, I doubt I will make a future purchase from this company, nor will I recommend them to anyone.

In summary
Adapter performance (for 3 weeks) 5 stars
Manufacturing/Quality Control 1 star
Customer Service 5 stars

Overall 2 stars, considering I actually \\"Frankensteined\\" a (currently) working adapter from 2 dead ones.

Edit:
Since writing this review, the adapter has failed once again. Totally frustrated with this company and unwilling to waste anymore time with them, I decided to open the unit in order to figure out the issue. Having a degree in Electronic Engineering, I figured that I could spot a loose wire or something in the transformer pack.

I was horrified to see that the inside of the casing was scorched and discolored. The reason for this was a dry joint on the plug where the power cable plugs into the transformer pack. I tested the device with the case open and found that the dry joint was causing sparks which discolored the interior.

I also opened the other power supply and found the exact same condition, a dry joint causing sparks as the electricity arcs across the gap.

In my experience, these adaptors are potential fire hazards. I recommend heartily that you do not buy from this company.

I have since dropped the rating from 2 stars to only one, since Amazon.com does not allow zero star ratings.ars Overall 2 stars, considering I actually \\"Frankensteined\\" a (currently) working adapter from 2 dead ones. I'm a professional photographer and have a few of these.  The last one I bought (in March 2015) was found melting and smoldering where the power supply plugs into it.  I feel lucky to have found it before it caught fire entirely and burned my house down.  Having young children makes that even more traumatizing as a possibility.  Worst, Seagate said they can't help me.  I later tracked down an internal "Ethics department" at Seagate.  They were far more concerned, and said they would take care of it and even get me my data back - the current massive problem since I need my thousands of images that were just put on there.  Seagate said I had to pay for that service, despite the error being on their side and their supposed guarantee.  Now, after pressing, they said they'll waive the fee for data recovery if I sign a document.  Crazy still, they won't even send the document until I agree to sign it.  Well, I guess I can count on Amazon to take care of the matter and press Seagate and to consider not selling drives that can catch fire and kill the buyers.  Nope.  Amazon said they can not do anything.  They did replace my drive. yay.  But, can not help with my data recovery, talking to Seagate, nor are there any concerns. I'm in shock, screwed out of my data by a drive that could have killed me and these large companies can not put a dime or effort towards my data recovery.  That's ok, I have insurance.  Nope.  My insurance says it's  manufacturers default and they don't cover that because its' the responsibility of the manufacturer.  They are right.  It is.  But this manufacturer figures it's just not worth it.  Buyer BEWARE!!!!!!!  This drive could be your last. Literally.

Maybe it's just the kind of laptop I have (Toshiba Satellite, which mine gets really hot because of its bad design), but this does not work for me. I have SpeedFan on my laptop (tells you the temperature inside your laptop), and without letting my laptop get so hot that it automatically shuts off...it's the only way I could think to see if this product actually worked. The temperature on SpeedFan actually goes up approximately 3-5 Celsius every time I turn this pad on. If I arrange the pad so that none of its fans are directly under my laptop's fan, then the temperature remains roughly the same as if the pad is off (i.e. less than when the pad is on). The only real utility I get from this pad is, since I use my laptop on cushion-y surfaces all the time like the bed and blankets, having a hard pad (turned off) underneath my laptop keeps the air flow from getting smothered by those soft cushions--those cushions raise the temperature inside my laptop and eventually result in my laptop shutting off. But as far as my laptop going up to 60 or even 70 Celsius while just trying to watch videos online sometimes...this does not totally help with that, no matter what I try. I would have liked to be able to watch videos with my laptop's power settings on \\"high performance,\\" (not to mention keep my AC adapters from frying to death--I've had two die with this laptop since getting it a year and a half ago) but the temperature still gets way too hot to be able to do that. The only way it won't go into the 60s or 70s is if I keep it on \\"power saver,\\" which oftentimes will make the videos run slower/choppily.     Guess I will be looking for a better cooling pad.

I bought a pair of these sticks in 2010 and they are still working perfectly.

But somewhere in 2011 the price plummeted so i decided to buy another pair. However when I got them I was surprised to see that these ones were single-sided, unlike the older ones which were double-sided. This fact is conveniently not mentioned in the product description.

Manufacturers always try to downplay the difference between single-sided sticks and double-sided ones, but in many hardware reviews and benchmarks it is clear that the double-sided ones are more stable and can usually be used at higher frequencies/lower timings.

In addition to this the pair I received was DoA. So I got a replacement from Amazon. It was also a pair of single-sided sticks, though I specifically requested the double-sided ones. They seemed to work ok at first, but after 4 months I started to get occasional BSODs and now I get one every day.

The original double-sided sticks were great and are the ones featured on the hardware review sites, but the ones shipped currently are of substantially lesser quality, so don't waste your money.

I liked the idea of this drive.  I have a small home network (two computers, a desktop and a laptop), and this seemed a better solution for file-sharing than the USB thumb drive I had been using.        Alas, I don't think this product is quite ready for prime time.  I installed it as directed in the Quick Start guide...and nothing happened.  The drive was not detected.  It just gave me a \\"failed mount\\" error message.  I tried uninstalling and reinstalling.  I tried installing it on my other computer.  I went to Western Digital's web site, searched their knowledge base, and tried every solution suggested.  No dice.      So I e-mailed tech support.  They said they'd get back to me in one business day.  They didn't.  So I called them.      They do have a toll-free tech support number.  And you get 30 days of free tech support, starting from the first time you call them.  After that, it's fifteen bucks a call.      Navigating the Western Digital phone menu is a bit of challenge.  Which number you should press for help with this product isn't obvious, and if you don't press a number, they hang up on you.  I was expecting to be routed to a human operator if I didn't pick a number, but no.  They hang up on you, and you have to listen to the spiel and go through everything all over again.  So here's a tip: choose \\"firewire or USB external drive.\\"  Even though this isn't a firewire or USB drive.    Once I got that far, they put me on hold.  Which I was expecting, but it was particularly obnoxious, because they play classical music - at truly ear-splitting levels.  It was so loud I had to hold the phone several inches from my ear or it was downright painful.  I was really starting to think they were trying to get you to hang up and go away.    The call center, judging from the accents, is somewhere in India.  Everyone was very friendly and polite, but it was often hard to understand what they were saying (especially if you're half-deaf from listening to that darned music).They made me spell out my name, address, etc., in military speak (alpha-bravo-charlie-delta).      They talked me through pinging the new drive and mapping it.  That seemed to fix the problem.  The drive was detected, both via Windows and via Mionet.  I hung up.  And the computer promptly gave me the \\"failed mount\\" error message again.  Arrghhh.      So I called back the next day.  Again the ear-splitting music, and a different (but equally polite) guy with a thick Indian accent.  I had my case number, but they had no record of it.  Yay.  I got to spell out my name and address again.  After all that, he was not able to resolve my problem, and put me on hold again.  After several long minutes with the music from hell, he told me that his supervisor would be calling me back in 15 or 20 minutes.      He lied.  They never called me back.  However, the problem fixed itself when I created a new Mionet account.  The new Mionet account didn't work, but when I went back to the old one, it started working.  I have no idea how long this fix will last, but at the moment, it's working as it should.    Mionet is now owned by Western Digital.  It's kind of like GoToMyPC.  The version you get with this drive is a limited edition.  It gives you 30 days of regular Mionet access, then you have to pay or many features go away.  They don't really make this clear in the product description.      You don't need to use Mionet, though (except for remote access).  If you just want to use this drive on your home network, you can do that with Windows' built-in networking capability.      And here's a tip for ZoneAlarm users: turn it off while you install this drive.  Letting Mionet through isn't enough.  I had to turn it off to map the drive, then I had to add the IP address of the drive to ZoneAlarm's \\"trusted zones\\" list manually.  For some reason, it didn't add itself, or ask me if I wanted to allow it.      PROS:  Looks very nice.  Small footprint.  Cool idea.    CONS:  Installation was aheadache.  (Search on \\"failed mount\\" and \\"mionet,\\" and you'll see it's a common problem.)  It's slower than a USB or Firewire drive, at least on the average home network.  Tech support could be better.  Documentation (a PDF on the installation disk) is pretty poor.          I've been an Amazon customer for years, and have bought a ton of stuff from them.  This was the first item I seriously considered returning.  Now that it's working, I will probably keep it.  However, if I could do it all over again, I might buy the [[ASIN:B000UF3DNG 2.0TB My Book Premium USB/fw]] instead, and just use a USB switch or something to share it between my desktop and laptop.    UPDATE: Five months later, I am happier with this than I was originally.  I would probably give it one more star.    The first month or two, it was very buggy.  It kept dropping off my network, and I would have to try various things to get it back.  (Turning it off and on, rebooting my computer, logging in and out of Mionet, pinging the drive, etc.)  I was about ready to name the drive \\"Brigadoon,\\" because you never knew when you see it.  Especially annoying is when it would go offline while you were trying to copy files over to it.  (The slow connection means it takes a long time to transfer data.)    However, lately it's been pretty reliable, and I'm happy with it.  I must admit, it's convenient to have one drive that all the computers in the house can share.      I'm not sure why it's working so well now, when it didn't before. I suspect it's Mionet.  If the Mionet site is down, you can't access your drive.  Well, you can if you're computer literate enough, but really, this drive isn't being marketed to that kind of person. Mionet seems to have improved their reliability lately, and so this drive is performing a lot better.    IMO, Mionet remains the biggest drawback to this product.  I don't think they made it clear enough that it's a subscription service (though you can use a crippled version for free), andthat if Mionet is down, you can't access the drive (unless you're a pretty advanced computer user).    Update, 9/29/2009: I just got notification that Mionet will be down for THREE DAYS while they upgrade to Mionet 4.0.  That it just unacceptable.  Three days is a lifetime when you're talking about accessing your computer files.  What are they thinking??!!!

I have a RangeMax 240 Router in our house that has performed well for a year. So I thought of buying a compatible adapter card (WPNT511) to maximize the performance. I followed the instructions, which is to load the software first, to install the card. When the installation prompted for card insertion, I followed and it froze the laptop. If I manually unplug the card, the computer would unfreeze (and even perform keystrokes I have had entered during the freeze). I thought the card was not compatible with my computer's particular setup. But when I tried it with a second laptop (completely different brand/setup) it freezes in the same way.

So instead, I tried avoiding the software, and just use Windows to install the driver and manage the wireless. I got that to work maybe 5% of the time, the rest would result in the same freeze until I remove the card. After searching online, I found that I am not the only case experiencing this or similar problem with the product.

I looked on NETGEAR's website and found that there are no firmware updates available since the initial release in 2005. Apparently, the card has been phased out in favor of the newer RangeMax NeXT series (including WN511B & WN511T).

I would avoid this card and look at the newer, and probably better supported, RangeMax NeXT cards. If you could wait (and has it been a long wait) I'd suggest waiting till they ratify the 802.11n spec so that companies can start making inter-compatible adapters/accesspoints.

I got this keypad for use with my MacBook Air at home connected to a large monitor and Apple's wireless keyboard and Magic TrackPad. I do a lot of spreadsheet work for my business and wanted a keypad that would fit in and complement my MBA system. Well, after over six months of use, I've decided to ditch this and went to the local Apple Store to pick up Apple's extended keyboard with the USB cable. Wireless is nice but the problems that this unit was causing made me decide that it's just not worth the annoyances.

First off, as other reviewers have mentioned, this LMP keypad looks and feels cheap. But I was willing to accept that since all I really needed this for was crunching numbers. What I couldn't deal with anymore was how fast it consumed the rechargeable batteries and how it wouldn't sync up every time I replaced the batteries. It also caused some sort of a conflict with Apple's wireless keyboard every time I rebooted the computer. The Apple keyboard wouldn't work until I signed on using the built-in keyboard on the MBA. When I would turn off this keypad, then this problem would go away.

Replacing the batteries on this unit and getting it working again with the MBA became an exercise in frustration. When you go through something like that, all the other little details that you find lacking on the product start becoming more and more bothersome. The poorly designed battery compartment cover makes it more comparable to a cheap toy you'd buy for little kids at Toys R' Us. I started feeling bad about placing such a device in between Apple's keyboard and trackpad. When you start typing on it, you immediately notice it just doesn't feel as good as Apple's keyboard. Still, I was willing to live with it and I did for many months.

Again, the main problem was having to start over and set up this device like it was a brand new one every time I changed the batteries. Another thing that's not quite right about this keypad is that the layoutisn't like a normal extended keyboard. Combine these annoyances and you have a unit that just isn't worth your time and money. I just replaced the Apple wireless keyboard (although there was absolutely nothing wrong with that fine piece of gear) and this keypad with the Apple extended keyboard and I wonder why I put up with it for as long as I did. This is simply not a good product. It worked well enough but just doesn't deserve to be hooked up with Apple devices.

I thought wireless meant \\"without wires\\"! Not the case with this device; you will have plenty of wires to choose from! This player is going back to the store...you get what you pay for.

Wireless
The description claims that you can \\"Carry the Music System around the house and have access to your entire music collection\\". Well the only problem is that you will need a VERY long extension cord to do this, because this unit does not run on batteries...only an attached DC power converter.

Setup
I have 5 computers in my house sucessfully connected to my wireless network. However, I was unsucessful in creating a robust wireless connection to this device. I could get it working, but then the device seemed to reconfigure itself on occasion. It also often grabbed bogus IP Addresses when using DHCP.

Features
In concept, this device is nice. It includes a lot of useful features such as: Internet Radio, self-populating Playlists. However, I often could not get many of the features to work. Many of the songs would not play (media error) even though I can get them to play on my other 3 MP3 streaming devices.

Ergonomics
Wires Everywhere! The back of the device is a web of wires...one to power the device; one to power the speakers; one to connect the right speaker to the device; one to connect the left speaker to the right speaker. And...they are all jammed closely together, which makes it nearly impossible to coonnect them all.
The other problem is that you must use the remote control in order to access most of the features of the Jukebox. I think its reasonable to expect to be able to control/configure a device from the main unit.

MUSICMATCH Jukebox:
What was Cisco/Linksys thinking? This device requires MUSICMATCH Jukebox running on your media server in order to access your songs. Now, I realize that this area is still not standardized in the industry...each manufacturer seems to have their own server-side software package that is responsible for streaming your music. However, most manufacturers are using either Windows Media Player, or their own proprietary software. Linksys chose to use a shareware program that constantly bombardes you with advertisements, and ofers to \\"upgrade\\" to their not-free \\"professional\\" version.

I will return this today and continue to search/wait for a more robust stand-alone media streaming device.

Approximately one month after purchasing this computer it stopped working.  Up until that point it had been fine and I had been happy with how it was working for the money I had spent on it.  It had a technical issue where the battery would not charge and the computer could not get power from the adapter.  I could not turn it on at all.  Since it was covered by the warranty, I decided to contact Gateway.    First of all, you can only contact customer service online.  You can't call, only chat.  This presents an issue if your computer is not working and you don't have another backup computer handy.  That said, if you buy a Gateway computer, it's probably wise to have a backup ready.    I understand that broken English is par for the course when it comes to tech support, so that didn't bother me much.  However, the people I was forced to chat with were so slow to respond that gateway's own chat client kept shutting down due to inactivity!  I had to log on three times and each time explain everything the person before had told me.  This took a total of 5.5 hours just to get the address to send the computer to for service.    The first tech support person told me that I should go out and buy another adapter to see if the one I had was the issue.  He said that if it was, they would send me another one.  Since i didn't have a 19Volt adapter with the specific gateway end on it I went out and got one, only to find that it wasn't the problem.  So now, I own two adapters for my broken computer.  The second person I \\"spoke\\" with again timed out while asking me questions about what the first person had asked me to do.  The third person told me that the warranty would NOT cover the situation and that I should send them $199.00.  I told the person that the previous 2 tech support people had both said that it was covered and after a 10 minute pause (during which I had to keep tying to stop the chat client from timing out) he informed me that he was wrong and that I did not in facthave to send money.    However, I did have to pay to send my computer to Texas.  It has to be wrapped very specifically (3-5\\" of protective wrap, no packing peanuts, etc etc), and they tell you that it should be insured and not sent by the USPS. It cost me $61.00 to send it including the money for the special protective box.  Honestly a total nightmare.    When a Dell I purchased had a broken speaker I called tech support and the next day a special packing container arrived from UPS.  I just put the laptop inside it and handed it back to the courier.  They fixed it and got it back to me with no money spent on my part and almost not fuss at all.    I suppose the point I'm trying to make with all this is that if you buy one of these laptops you had better hope (against the odds) that it doesn't break.  I definitely got the sense that my experience was not at all unusual for people dealing with this company.

I guess I am in the minority on this one. I bought it because it could be propped up if you were unable to hold the Amazon Paperwhite, as crazy as that sounds to me now, that was my line of thinking at the time, but in reading a book which is what you do with a Paperwhite, you still have to press to turn pages. I am the Queen of Cases. I have several for each of my electronics iPad, iPhone, Paperwhite, Kindle Fire HD 7 inch and 8.9 inch.

I like cases like this that actually snap into the back cover, which is like a tray. From experience, the cases where you slide them in from the top, have been problems with sliding our of case if you pick it up wrong. I have been using the Nouske Origami Case for the Kindle Paperwhite for a couple of weeks now and I feel that it is one of the least protective cases I have ever purchased and with the amount of cases I own that is saying a lot. The back of the case is fine, it has the tray like design that the Paperwhite snaps in to. It is the front of the case that I have a problem with and let's face it.....the damage to a screen can pretty much guarantee that you will have an expensive repair or have to get a new Paperwhite. Where you see the lines are very thin rubber or maybe silicone and the puzzle piece larger parts are like similar material over cardboard (at least it feels like cardboard). The binding that attaches the back tray to the front cover is very thin and very pliable and I think this is the biggest problem. If you just close the cover it could close a bit off position where the one end is slightly off the front. I think this is caused by the very thin binding material, which also due to the thinness does not provide protection to the binding side because the hard plastic tray is cut out almost the entire length of the binding side except at the two corners. Finally like most of the covers with the snap in tray bottom, there is a magnet in the top edge. On most of my other cases, this magnet is strong and almost draws the top over to the correct position to put the cover in perfect alignment. As I am writing this I am double checking and there is probably some sort of magnet but I cannot feel it at all. Most times between the weak magnet and the very flimsy binding the cover closes out of alignment. If you want to protect the length of your battery you want you Paperwhite to go to sleep, but if the top of the cover has the alignment off it does not always do that. I think this is one of the few covers I have bought that really leaves the screen open to accidental breakage. I am taking the cover off and I don't think I have the covering that came with it so I am out the purchase price.

I have tried to give a complete and not exaggerated review of this cover. If you are like me and you put your Paperwhite into your bag when you go somewhere like the doctor's office, you might want to look a one of the other covers with a full stable front cover and a full snap in back tray with four FULL sides instead of three.almost draws the top over to the correct position to put the cover in perfect alignment. Most times between the weak magnet and the very flimsy binding the cover closes out of alignment. If you want to protect the length of your battery you want you Paperwhite to go to sleep, but if the top of the cover has the alignment off it does not always do that. There are many commendable features in this router but it finaly had to be returned after Netgear support was unable to resolve two serious problems. The Netgear WNDR4500 replaced a still-working Cisco/Linksys WRT320N and I was able to swap the routers back and forth to insure these were router issues. Netgear support was helpful in reviewing the problems and router configuration but ultimately felt there was a design issue with the WNDR4500 and that replacing it wth an identical unit would not help. I was having these problems on a wired connection to the router, so this is not a review of its wireless capabilities.

Problem 1: Web browsing to many sites would stall after entering the site name and pressing Enter. Clicking on Refresh almost always immediately got me to the site, but it was annoying to have to do this. This behavior was not seen on the old router.

Problem 2: The Remote Assistance feature of Windows Live messenger was unusable. Attempting to establish a Remote Assistance session would cause the users to be logged off Live Messenger for about 30 seconds. This was true not only trying to use this over the internet but also locally on our LAN. This problem was also not present using the WRT320N.

Netgear suggested replacing the WNDR4500 with another model, but I will first be trying the Linksys/Cisco EA4500 since I was happy overall with the WRT320N.

Hi,
I purchased my Logitech z-560 in June of 2002. They were AWESOME. About 2 weeks after they arrived in July, I had to send them back due to failure. Tweeters worked, but subwoofer didn't. I just had to cut power wire off of sub, and volume controls, and send it back. 4 weeks later, another new system came. It was great up until December, when the left speaker output jacks went out. I plugged both into right, soon after that failed also. So eventually, I ended up plugging tweeters into another stereo, and running a different line to sub, just so I could have some bass. 3/23, subwoofer stopped working. I'm going to take it apart, and try and salvage the subwoofer itself, but it is not easy to repair these things if they break, they make sure of that. Anyway, If you want a system thats going to last longer, I reccomend you go custom. Buy a reciever with some sattelite tweeter speakers, and run another line to a amplifier powering a sub, thats how I'm doing it now. BECAREFUL, only 90 day warranty.

I have a love/hate relationship with my Logitech G930. It is wonderfully comfortable and has great range, in case I want to get up and grab food or even do a chore around the house. When the software is cooperating, the surround sound is rich and well worth the cost of the headset. The problem is Logitech's software. The headset will pair with the computer and you're able to get sound from it and use the microphone like you would any other USB headset. Logitech's software just doesn't recognize that the headset is plugged in and that eliminates the surround sound and G-Buttons (which I rarely use).

Logitech has released at least two versions of software for this headset and both have the same issue. The headset is completely useable without the software, it's just a shame that the rich bass and surround sound won't work without the software. I've tried multiple times to uninstall and reinstall the software, to no avail.

If the software was functional, this headset would ABSOLUTELY be five stars.

As others have said, this cable will not transmit enough power to run a USB hard drive.  Not a bus-powered hard drive, not a powered hard drive, not a hub connected to a powered hard drive.  If you like the sickening beep that hard drives make when they're attached to an intermittent power source (and the sickening clicking they'll soon make after that), then go ahead and plug your drive into this cable.  It's your honeymoon photos on there, not mine.      But if you value your hard drive, heed my advice (which is identical to the advice others have posted here) and spend a few extra cents on a better cable.  I thought the unit I got was defective, but the replacement cable (which cmple very responsively shipped) was exactly the same.  Cmple has since very courteously refunded the purchase price of the product, and I think they deserve a lot of credit for that.  But unfortunately it doesn't change the fact that, with hard drives, not working is just a feature this product has.

I'll be on my third one of these soon, none have been drive failures. Drive failures I generally don't attribute to the manufacturer (Buffalo in this case) since any drive can die and they're usually made by the big boys like Seagate, Western Digital, Hitachi, etc. The first of these Buffalo devices failed within a week of ownership so Amazon replaced it freely and easily. Failures can happen to any device like this no matter how well engineered, so I was ready to dismiss it as a fluke. I don't like the clunky raid mode selection or the cheap plastic, but this is a fairly inexpensive device for the storage it provides so I was willing to overlook it and not give any rating.

Now that the warranty is almost up the drive is constantly falling offline where all other devices are fine. Given all the other variables of my situation this is a clear sign the electronics inside the enclosure are failing. The first problem I had also indicated the electronics inside the enclosure and not the drives.

I do not recommend this drive.

I bought this bag to hold my Lenovo S12 when traveling. Knowing that it's not a TSA compliant bag, I also bought the STM 13\\" neoprene sleeve. My intent was to put the computer in the sleeve, and the sleeve into the bag. I thought that I had researched this well, but there's nothing like having the actual items in hand to see what's going on.    Once I put the computer in the sleeve (it fit fine), and the sleeve into the bag, I realized it just wasn't going to work. Part of the problem was the 6 cell battery, which caused the computer/sleeve to stick up beyond the plane of where the top flap would close properly. I was able to pull the top flap over and it reached to the velcro to attach - not all, but some.     Then I starting putting in the rest of the stuff. I stuck the mouse into the little phone bag attached to the sleeve, and put the power brick & cord into the front compartment, along with my 2 electrical adapters. I could immediately see that it just wasn't a good fit, and that it wasn't going to work.    I did experiment to see how the computer fit into the bag without the sleeve - it did fit, but just barely at the top. Again, once you start loading up the bag with the power brick & cord, etc., there just isn't any room at all. I didn't even see how you could fit a magazine or a newspaper in once it was loaded up.    Lastly, in looking over the bag, I didn't think that it was really well made. I did like the look of the bag, though.     If you have a netbook smaller than my S12 (mine measures 11.5\\" x 9.1\\" x 1.1\\"), it will probably fit OK. Just don't expect to be taking a lot of other stuff along with it.    I write this waiting for the replacement bag - a Mobile Edge MEUEMB, also ordered from Amazon (great price) - to arrive this week. Hopefully, it will work out better than the STM bag, especially since it doesn't need the sleeve.

I was SO EXCITED to find out that Logitech had come up with something approaching a replacement for the MX Revolution - which came out in 2006 and was, quite simply, the best mouse ever made, and which was retired in 2009 for reasons that are still beyond me. Some Logitech exec must have had stock in eBay, because for six years that was the only place you could go to get a mouse of the Revolution's quality. Since my last Revolution died, I'd been considering buying a "new" one on eBay, so just imagine how thrilled I was to discover the Master. The price point was absurdly high, of course, but then even a six year old used Revolution isn't much lower. For the right kind of user - I do CAD drafting, for example - it's worth it.  From a hardware standpoint, the MX Master is ALMOST there. It's beautifully designed, fits nicely in the hand, and has many of the features that made the Revolution so perfect, like the software-controlled ratchet/freewheel scroll and the thumb controls. It does lack the side-tilting center scroll wheel, which was wonderful for things like tab-switching in a browser, but the thumb scroll wheel seems better than the Revolution's. And there are some ways in which it's clearly an improvement over the Revolution, like the seamless Bluetooth pairing, a better laser, and improved battery life. (That short list of improvements may seem like faint praise, given that the Revolution came out almost a decade ago, but that's because the Revolution was amazing, not because this isn't.) It also has a gesture button under the thumb, which is a little awkward to use - you have to press the button downward while moving the mouse up, down, left, or right, but pushing the button down with the thumb tends to brake the mouse's movement - but which I suspect I might come to like with time. (EDIT: I have indeed come to like this, and it didn't take very much time at all.)  But then everything went wrong on the software side. While the Revolution used SetPoint, Logitech's longtime beast of a software controller, the Master uses a new program, Logitech Options, and is apparently incompatible with SetPoint. That would be a good thing if Options could do what SetPoint did, but it... doesn't. There is no way in Options to set application-specific button assignments. When you click the "More" button on the Options homescreen, expecting to see the application-specific settings, you get... your mouse's firmware version number.  Let me be clear: it is completely impossible to assign a given button to do one thing in one program and another thing in a different one. If you want the thumb scroll wheel to change tabs in Firefox, but you want it to scroll horizontally in AutoCAD... that's too bad. It can't do that. You just spent a hundred dollars for a mouse that can't do that - not because of any limitation of the mouse, but because they removed that capability from the hardware. The word "nerfing" comes to mind. Not to get too Freudian, but the word "castrating" comes to mind too. This mouse has a custom "gesture" button... but you can't assign different gestures in different programs. Just... what?  Why on Earth did they do that? According to a Logitech rep on their forums, "The new software interface emphasizes more on the simplicity of navigation and accessibility to all types of users." This is incomprehensible even as an excuse; why on earth is "simplicity" the primary design criterion on the software for a mouse with five buttons and two scroll wheels? Besides, as I said, there is already a "more" button that opens a tabbed dialog with exactly two options (notifications on low battery and automatic updates for Logitech Options). An additional tab in that dialog would hardly count as bloat.  Logitech is, apparently, considering (or at least considering considering) adding application-specific settings at some ill-defined point in the future. Once they do that, then I might be more willing to recommend this. But without application-specific settings, how can I possibly recommend this mouse to a power user? And with a three-digit price point, how can I possibly recommend this mouse to anyone else?

The problem is that the products electrical output can not support all 10-ports being utilized simultaneously. Below is a copy of the email dialogue that I had with HooToo Customer Support. They were polite, so no complaints there, however what is the point in making a 10-port hub when a maximum 5 ports can actually be utilized?

"I sincerely apologize for the inconvenience caused to you. Normally we do not advise customers to connect so many hard drives at the same time, because it will caused power shortage. 5 drives is too many enough. The electric current is divided to the 10 ports if you connect 10 hard drives at once, which will caused the power shortage. So
it only recognizes 5. I am so sorry about the inconvenience. If you are not satisfied with the function, we will offer you the shipping label to return and refund. Is it all right?
Best regards,
​Amily​
HooToo® Customer Service Representative"

A friend of mine bought the g500 and then the new one came out right afterward, he wanted a big mmo gaming mouse so he bought that one and gave me this one having used it only a bit, he had all the junk for it and just gave it to me with its nice little weight bag etc.

I happily recieved my new logitech mouse after my g35 one had finally started having issues after years, with its left click not responding and cutting out. (Something I later learned was a new, accelerated process with logitech mice)

Within a couple weeks of using this mouse, the left click died, it either doesnt click, clicks partially and releases mid hold, or hilariously, douoble clicks when you click once. IT has done some amazing things due to this, from dropping items in the wrong places on a desktop to making my machine guns in FPS simply stop shooting because full auto doesnt work if your mouse click stops sending a signal even though your finger is pressed down on it. Computer programming with this thing attached to your pc is a pretty big nightmare because you cant reliably select even simple things like blocks of text, half the time when you click to close a tabbed window you will close two etc. The list goes on, its pretty annoying and the only reason I still have it around is because I am debating tearing it open to see if I can fix it.

Despite the pros of this mouse, I would say get a Razer brand one instead. The same friend who bought me this thing had his brand new logitech mmo mouse (an $80 dollar logitech mouse at time of purchase) die after less than a month of use. All other logitech mice I have seen recently have all been developing this issue as well.

Logitech's response is that your usb ports must be bad etc.

Logitech has lost a loyal customer of many years with their cheap quality sub-par hardware. I started buying logitech with my first joystick years ago and a keyboard from them is probably the last purchase I will ever make from them (I bought it before the mouse started dying or ID have just bought a different brand of keyboard as well) The price is all the name now, but you are getting something cheap with the logitech brand name stamped on it. Avoid Logitech Lemon mice. The keyboard seems good though

Just Google \\"Mac Goflex problems\\" and do some reading. This drive is marketed as PC/MAC compatible but that is false advertising. The drive simply doesn't work with MACs. Period. Seagate tech support will tell you to install the Mac drivers that \\"will solve the sleep issue\\". This is incorrect. The Seagate drivers made the issue worse for me. Based on some reading I deleted the drivers and reformatted to Mac and it worked slightly better. By doing this at least now I can copy large files without hanging up on me (the only resolution is a hard restart of the Mac). But now when the Mac goes to sleep it periodically will either a0 put the drive to sleep from which it will not wake up, or b) cause the drive to spin at a high speed without sleeping! I have two of these drives (3tb and 4tb) and it happens to both.

Seagate's reply has been to update the drivers with theirs (again, makes matters worse), or to let you know that they have a Mac compatible version of the drive that doesn't need the drivers - thanks for letting me know this after my return period on these crap drives has expired! Your marketing of PC/Mac compatible lead me to believe this WAS MAC COMPATABLE!

[10/29/13 edited to add the following information:]

There are times when I'm on-line browsing and want to type some text (say, a comment in a user forum) and the keyboard will go haywire.

One example: I press a single key (alphanumeric character) and the browser will fly to another browser tab, or open the java console. Then when I navigate back to the original tab and try to continue typing, either the keyboard will hijack the same keystroke and throw me off again, or I simply will not be able to continue typing. I will be able to type in OTHER tabs but not that one. After about three tries, and refreshing the tab, I will be able to continue typing. I have had many computers (laptops, desktops, etc) and have never had this issue with any of them.

Another problem is that the start menu sometimes pops up when I have not pressed the Windows key. And I have also had issues with the computer backing up the browser tab to the page whence I came - something that should only happen with the backspace key, and even then not when I'm typing text.

I'm sure there's a fix for it. But frankly I wanted to take the @)#(*$)@ thing out of the box and USE it, not have to research why this is happening.

I built a NUC using components purchased from Amazon: i3 with 8Gb RAM, SSD and this card. I have a ASUS RT-N66U blazingly-fast router. I love the NUC but I hate the wifi adapter on this card. The bluetooth adapter on this card is excellent, see way below. That's the only reason I gave it two stars.

My desktop registers 20 - 30Mbps using OOKLA speed test (comcast). So does my Android phone. This thing registered about 1Mbps. File transfers moseyed along at about 500KBytes/s (yes K not M). I returned it for a second one. That one goes 3Mbps. I bought a USB wifi adapter and plugged it into the same NUC, viola' - full connectivity. I can transfer files at about 10.5MBytes/s, the limit of my wired network.

The bluetooth is fantastic: no dropouts, easy connection, Windows 7 had all the drivers. Bluetooth can be such a pain the the neck to set up and then be very unreliable. I wanted one that was bulletproof for my HTPC because I have no wired keyboard or mouse, and this one delivers.

My primary problem with this device, and ultimately the reason that I returned it for a refund, is that it is unacceptably slow. And when I say slow, I mean 10 times slower than a USB drive. I measured the throughput by copying a 1GB file over gigabit ethernet, and it clocked at 2.5MB/s, whereas copying the same file over USB measured 25MB/s. Copying across a wireless network to another computer was also faster. I got these results *after* updating to the latest firmware -- performance was even worse with the shipped firmware.    Other complaints: no explicit support for Mac or Linux, although both can be made to work given enough Google searches. Pathetic documentation even for supported Windows platforms.    Strongly NOT recommended. Still searching for an alternative.

This is my forth Gyration product, so I am a definite fan of the concept, if only they would finally get it right. The first was the Ultra GT. It was great, but it used a proprietary rechargeable battery that quit taking a charge and have not been able to find a replacement. (Message to self, \\"NEVER buy a rechargeable mouse again.\\" A stupid design decision IMO.) The others were the Media Center Remote, which is great and I still use daily, and a Gyrotransport which had potential except for an idiotic battery compartment design. That brings me to this one, which I was hoping would be a suitable replacement for the Ultra GT, but no way.    Pros:  Standard disposable batteries.  Nice carrying pouch.  Convenient storage slot in the mouse for the receiver when not in use.  Gyration's customer service.    Fatal flaws:  Ergonomics - Unlike all the other Gyration products I've used, this one is very awkward to use.  Battery Cover - Like the Gyrotransport, this one also has an idiotic battery compartment design. The battery compartment cover broke while putting in my first set of batteries.    Gyration's customer support has been perfect, if only their design team was as good.  They have replaced the broken battery compartment doors for both the Gyrotransport and this mouse with no hassle. Unfortunately, I will probably need a large supply of these battery compartment covers, since they are at risk every time I have to replace batteries. It's a fight getting them open and they are very very fragile.

I will review this laptop from the perspective of the owner who is used to the more expensive notebooks in the past. I have purchased ASUS on the request of the friend as for the price it had some very good specs and seemed to be a real bargain. Large screen, Intel i3 Dual core CPU and 4GB of DDR3 RAM plus plethora of connectivity options.  Laptop came very quickly thanks to the Prime and, besides from Amazon providing virtually zero padding to the package, everything else was in order. After testing it for the past couple of days here are some notes:  - First thing that jumps at you once you start it up is that keyboard is as bad as everyone else is reporting here. With every key stroke, the whole keyboard (not just the key you press) presses down and then springs back up. It has a good 1/4'' vertical movement. Once working on it for half an hour, I was able to readjust my strokes but the feeling of the cheapness does not go away and I have to seriously question long term durability of this keyboard. I have seen some cheap keyboards in the past but ASUS was able to create a whole new category of low and take a leading position. Besides, the keyboard does not have a back light and I find it mystifying of why such a low cost but highly usable feature is continuously being left out on the cheap models.  - Screen is big and this is seriously the only only complement I can give. The brightness, contrast and view angles are bad and don't compare to the screens you would find in other brands. This screen is practically unusable in bright light conditions (outdoors) and whatever contrast it has when you look straight at it is quickly lost once you shift around.  - Battery life is mediocre. Laptop comes with 4 power modes that can be further customized: from power mode to the battery save mode. In power mode with full screen brightness and streaming video from Wi-Fi connection, it lasts less then 2 hours. This is not what I would call ideal. In light browsing with screen half-dimmed I was able to work for 3.5 hours which is still inadequate. The battery is quit simply weak, so don't plan on going too far away from the power source.      The rest of the news are not as bad. Laptop seems very responsive and can handle quite a few tasks, including playing every video I could throw at it while simultaneously processing large archive of data and downloading latest patches from the Internet. Intel Core i3 is a definite upgrade over the budget chips and if your budget allows it, I would even spring for i5 CPU as it handles power more efficiently and should give a good jump in battery life. 4GB of RAM is more then enough for anything you might throw at it as ultimately, the CPU (and GPU) speed would become a bottleneck. There are three USB 2 connectors which should be plenty for most situations.   Unfortunately, there are no high speed connectors like USB 3 or eSATA but I found it to be less critical in notebooks compared to, let's say, desktops. HDMI out is a great feature as you can connect this laptop to any digital monitor or TV (some monitors would require HDMI-DVI cable for the connection) without any loss of resolution and clarity. There is a nifty Memory Card reader to quickly upload pictures from the digicam.    The built-in DVD reader can also burn DVDs and notebook includes software to assist you with these tasks. You can't play Blu-Ray movies on this laptop though, as this configuration is usually not included in the low cost models.  There is not much bloatware that comes with a laptop. There are few ASUS programs that help with management and face recognition and few trial versions of software from other vendors that you can quickly ditch in preference of the free source alternatives.   The included Webcam is sufficient for video-conferencing and can handle a variety of light situations with not much difficulty. The laptop is not light but also is not too heavy and for the size of the screen it is what you would expect.   I found speakers to be adequate. Some reviewers commented on poor sound quality but I guess it comes with expectations. Good sound comes with air volume. It is difficult and expensive to create quality speakers in small package. In sample music and video that I played on the laptop sound came clear and loud enough for close listening and this is as much as I would expect from any general purpose notebook.   You should not plan on installing and playing video games on this laptop. It can handle simple flash-based games without a problem and can still run some older (3-5 years old) games quite all right, but without a dedicated GPU anything more would be more that this laptop can handle.    Overall, I can not recommend this laptop. One can live with poor screen and weak battery, knowing that this is the price you have to pay to get laptop under $500. But cheap keyboard outweigh any advantages of getting good Intel CPU inside. You simply can not rely on it to last you long in heavy use scenario and any positive impression anyone would have seeing the laptop for the first time would quickly dissipate once they try to type on it.    P.S. I had a chance to test this laptop against identically configured Toshiba Satellite L655-S5158 (available on this site for the same price as of now). I can tell you right away that keyboard on Toshiba is better by a large margin. Great tactile response, built-in light indicators, physically separated directional keys, etc. Also, Toshiba, while having the same 48Wt battery lasted 1hr 15min more in the video test (2 hours in Asus vs 3hr 15min for Toshiba for identical video with same brightness, Wi-Fi turned-off, CPU throttling set to the same percentage and all background processes shut down.) Asus was continually drawing more current which I attribute to a more efficient LCD on Toshiba (TruBrite LED-Backlit display). I could see this difference in battery in other tests too. Toshiba lasted me the whole day in light usage while Asus quickly drained battery even with screen fully dimmed.

There are two problems with this keyboard:

1. It is just too small to touch type on with normal to small hands. The keys are small, measuring 7/16ths of an inch in height/width and only a tiny, maybe 1/32th of an inch space between keys. It is very tight. I tried to make it work, however, I can only type marginally well if I slow down considerably and actually look at the keys. They are just too tiny and I find even with my rather slender fingers I often hit two keys at the same time.

2. The portion of the case that allows it to "clip" onto the tablet is directly in front of the space bar, making the space bar difficult to get to.

Otherwise, I found the unit to be well constructed. The keys had good action, felt solid. It doesn't feel cheap, it feels like a quality keyboard. I've typed on worse. It is just too small folks. I can't recommend this even for people with small hands, the virtual keyboard is faster and more accurate, especially if you learn to use the swype action on the virtual keyboard.

I think the key for a small keyboard like this is to make better use of the space, like the Zagg Folio for the Note 8.0, it uses much more of the available space for keys and actually has space between keys.

I like this case but the durability definitely is not what I expected. After 6 months of very light use (i.e., it sits on a shelf for weeks at a time), the rubber holding the device in the case is deteriorating. The thin piece by the on button and USB port has already broken off; it clearly wasn't designed to last. This didn't bother me much, but now the rubber around the lower-right corner is falling apart as well. A strip of rubber from just below the next page button on the right all the way down and around to the power button is now falling off. Considering the press-fit nature of this case, having the rubber fall apart should be unacceptable; the rubber is what's holding the device.

I called Amazon but they said their cases have no warranty beyond the original return period. So as always, caveat emptor.

Otherwise this is a nice case. But considering the price, it should be. It should also be considerably more durable.

The WNDR-3800 router is nice. It has lots of features and the Netgear Genie dashboard is pretty easy to use and will suffice for most people. The range is not the best, but it was adequate for my 1300 sq/ft 2 story home (basement and ground level). Out side, it left alot to be desired. I couldn't connect on my phone or tablet in the driveway or back yard. The router was wall mounted in a closet, central to the house, upstairs.

Stability with the WiFi seems to be an issue that Netgear just can't get under control. Do a search for this router and you will come across page after page of owners who can't keep a wifi connection for more than a day. Mine would usually drop once a day and I would have to disconnect and reconnect the devices in the house to resume use. This was especially troublesome with my Nest thermostat. Trying to turn the ac or heat on and off was a crap shoot at best. Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't.

This issue has been going on since I bought the router 12/2011. I have tried every version of the firmware that Netgear released and not one has been able to fix it. Just to make sure it wasnt my cable modem (SB6120) I connected an old WRT54G. Service was rock solid and NEVER dropped. Put the WNDR-3800 back into service and all the problems came back.

The wired side of this router has been rock solid from day 1.I have never had a problem with the 2 TV's I have hard wired, or the 2TB drive I have connected to the router via USB. It streamed HD video to my Samsung TV's without a hiccup. I have never had a problem accessing the drive via the ReadyShare Cloud app on my Galaxy S3 phone while away from home.

All the problems are with the wireless stability. Netgear has released firmware updates to no avail. They have recently EOL'ed (End Of Life) this router too, which means no more firmware, no more updates, and they are done trying to fix the problem with this router.

It should be noted that even the replacement for this router (WNDR-4300) and the top tier 4500 are having similar issues and nobody seems to be able to fix it, even Netgear. As they have EOL'ed this router, it likely will never get fixed.

This week, the router finally died (a blessing in disguise). I was surfing the web, before bed, everything was good. I woke up and found I had no WiFi conncetion. Standing next to the router the best signal I could get was -93dbm. A connection that was so low, it was unuseable. Tried a bunch of things, firmware, DDWRT, Tomato and nothing helped. It seems to be a hardware failure. Which I'm ok with cause now I got an asus RT-N66U and its clearly the router I should have got the first time.

After the failure, I started looking into other routers and found that Netgear has a long lineof issues when it comes to wireless stability. I don't consider myself a \\"power user\\", I only have 4 devices connected to WiFi at any given time (2 laptops win7 and win8 and two Galaxy S3's). This router should be able to handle the light load I place on it. Instead, it failed with 0 support from netgear. Never again Netgear. Never. Again.

If your looking for a router with the same features (including the remote access to a USB drive), longer range, faster speeds, and a STABIL connection, get the Asus RT-N66U. The range is amazing, and the WiFI is rock solid. No matter what, DO NOT consider this Netgear product if you need reliable service.the replacement for this router (WNDR-4300) and the top tier 4500 are having similar issues and nobody seems to be able to fix it, even Netgear. As they have EOL'ed this router, it likely will never get fixed.

First, i have been a buyer of Razer products for the last six of seven years and have loved almost every product i have ever gotten from them.. I currently use a Blackwidow Ultimate (gen1), Mamba mouse, and a Goliathus extended.

Build: (1/5)
They are built fairly well, a lot of plastic running everywhere which never really is a good thing, but its not cheep plastic.
The over head band was clunky and the bonded leather "pleather" seemed to be cracking from just opening the box. The Microphone stays far out of the way when you want it hidden and the split adapter that comes with it is nice. The "folding" they advertise doesn't really do anything, the headphone drivers just end up sitting on each other in the center, not a lot of regained room by folding them.

Sound: (2/5)
Compared to Sony MDR-V7506 @$99.99
These headphones were a total joke. The lows are so over saturated it made the mids and highs sound so far out of place. I found that people with normally high voices (Pentatonix) had voices several octaves lower. Overall it changed the way the music was experienced and not in a good way. I'm sure if you were listening to nothing but trance music you wouldn't mind, but voices are so bad on these.

Comfort: (1/5)
I wore these for around four hours and found the left side going out frequently. The pads on the side (again pleather) seemed to stick to my head more. I would have liked to have seen a softer pad to relieve this.

Test Music:
Lindsey Sterling - Shatter Me
Pentatonix - Daft Punk mix

Overall: (2/5)
In the end i wouldn't recommend these, for the price they have overly low lows and terrible mids and highs.
Your better off getting a headset made from a company that's dedicated to music, not making things flashy and green (no offense Razer, i still love you)

Bought this for my son and it is an attractive box. However, when we built our computer we immediately noticed many issues. The drive bays are very difficult to get to, and nearly a third became unavailable when the graphics card was installed. It is difficult to insert or remove a drive once the wires have been connected, in fact, we had to disconnect most of the wires to get the second drive in.

To top it off, when we finally got the system built and turned on, the front fan was incredibly noisy. There is no way to remove it without removing all drives (and power cords), and removing the drive bay construction itself, so we ended up disconnecting it and installing an extra fan elsewhere in the casing.

This is a low-cost, mid-size box, and I didn't expect much, but it has failed to meet even those low expectations. For the record this is our third Cooler Master case and I am very happy with the other two. I'd recommend paying a little extra to get a better box, unless you never plan on cracking the thing open again after it's built.
