You learn something every day. Today, as a result of buying this cable, I learned about EDID. From Wikipedia: "Extended display identification data (EDID) is a data structure provided by a digital display to describe its capabilities to a video source (e.g. graphics card or set-top box)"

I installed this cable on a new computer. The display resolution was wretched, far worse than I expected. I looked in the computer system logs and found lines like: "Unable to get display device CRT-0's EDID; cannot compute DPI....using default." Using those words in a Google search yielded: "...sometimes...vga cables can't send the EDID correctly." I swapped in a different cable (same length), and hey-presto the display worked.

Bottom line: I do not believe this cable is usable with newer displays and computers that expect to pull the EDID from the display. It might work okay in older systems where the display information is stored in a static file on the host computer.

Using Bluetooth in Windows turns out to be a nightmare. I bought this for two uses, listening to movies on my computer without disturbing anyone, and using it to connect to a wireless headset for a college class. After three hours of trying to sync with every smartphone in the building over and over and over and over and over and over, Windows finally let me connect to the headphones.

But Windows would not *enable* the headphones after finally connecting. Two hours of searches and forums and I found that this is a problem that Microsoft knows about and will not fix. Microsoft support's advice was to buy a smartphone, connect my Bluetooth headphones to it, and sync the smartphone to my Windows PC. I'm not kidding.

I was going to try it on my Windows 7 laptop, since it doesn't work with my PC. But installing the downloaded Broadcom driver failed. By then I was another two hours in, the time was three A.M., and I went to sleep.

I got this case to go with the kindle at xmas time.  The case is nice, it does have a funny smell when it's new, it isn't the greatest at illuminating the entire kindle page but it does an ok job.    So, my kindle seemed to be losing battery life really quickly and would be drained completely after I was sure I'd turned it off. I thought maybe the light was draining the battery when it was turned off.  So, then my Kindle started acting funny and I would have to restart it, turn it on/off several times to get it to work properly, this caused all my books to get erased (normal but a pain!) and folders I had attempted to organize my books into.   So, I figure out the Kindle acts fine if the case was not attached.      I called amazon and they sent me out a free replacement case even though this just happened and I had purchased the kindle at xmas (amazing!!!).  So, last week I got the new case and I attached the case and set my kindle down on my bed to charge.  I came back later and went to get on my kindle and the screen was broken.      So, another call to amazon and they sent out a free replacement kindle with instructions to send the other back...  So, the new kindle arrives.  I register it, then attach the case and read on it for about 20 minutes.  I then adjusted my hand grip and I hear a \\"pop.\\"  The screen cracked again!!!!  2nd Kindle bites the dust!!!  Very frustrated. This doesn't definitively prove the case is bad but I am not going to risk it again and it's the only common denominator. I hope amazon is as amazing this time around when I call in for the 2nd replacement kindle in less than a week.  I wish the kindle tech support would have warned me or something when I called for the replacement kindle...  \\"Oh, the case you have might be faulty...\\"  Even though it was a replacement case...

I've tried multiple applications and methods using this but I was never able to get lower temperatures than with using an Antec Nano Diamond Formula 6 thermal paste. I'm also using a Corsair H75 liquid cooler.

Although I very much wanted to like the kindle--in part because I was running out of space for books in my small NYC apartment--it has a critical flaw that should give many pause before purchasing this version.  When reading a kindle-book, it is impossible to know which page of the physical/printed version of that text you are on.  In short, you could never cite the page number of a kindle-book.  You could exchange the \\"kindle location\\" with other users of the device, but that's not going to get you very far in a footnote.  It is really rather remarkable that Amazon designed a reading device that is functionally worthless for what would seem to be a potential core market: editors, academics, and others who read for a living.   Indeed, this flaw suggests that too many techies and not enough readers/writers designed the kindle.  And while it rapidly became a cliche to refer to the kindle as a 1.0 device, the phrase is as apt as it is overused.  It's such an easy software fix that I'm almost tempted to hold onto mine until the proper patch emerges -- almost but not quite.

This laptop has all the hardware specs in line, but fails at real world use.

I purchased this laptop in May of 2012. I was really impressed with the performance campared to the price.
Everything looked good, but I get more disapointed everyday. I'd just like to go through a list of some of the issues I've had so far.

The screen resolution is a little too low for my taste. This is mostly my fault for picking out a notebook that is very portable. It is/was comparable to everything else on the market, but hopefully the market will dictate better screens in the future.

The Battery life is noticebly shorter than what they claim, even more so after installing an SSD. I guess that is expected though, and it isn't really a deal breaker for me.

The wireless on this machine is mediocre. I don't have much trouble with the speed, but the range is not so great compared to other similarly specced machines I have used in the same building.

I have yet to successfully burn a CD or DVD. I have tried a dozen different formats and brands with different burning software, but it always fails. It also has trouble reading discs burned on other systems, often times stalling out and refusing to spin.
I sent the machine into HP after going through troubleshooting over the phone, and it was with them for just over three weeks. About mid way through, HP called to tell me they were waiting on parts, I assured them I could wait. When the laptop was returned to me, no parts had been replaced, but the BIOS had been updated to a version not available via the drivers download page. The burner still does not work.
They did happen to send me Factory Recover Media. These DVDs do not work either becuase the drive will not read them properly, or the software used to customize the DVDs is terrible. Either way, I currently could not reinstall the copy of Windows 7 that was provided.

UEFI and BIOS are very restricted, only allowing code signed by HP to run. As far as I can tell, all of thier business line notebooks allow the use of unsigned code, but this feature has been stripped out of this notebook. I would like to boot windows 8 using UEFI to take full advantage of the features, but that is seemingly unatainable. I was going to update the firmware on my SSD while reinstalling windows, but that is also not possible because HP has disallowed running the disk in IDE mode while disabling almost all options in the BIOS.

The HP Quickweb feature wasn't a selling point to me, but I would like to mention that it is slow to load, almost defeating the purpose it is supposed to serve. I seem to remember that in older versions(on other models), you could boot into windows right from Quickweb without shutting down, but this model/software requires a cold reboot.

I would like to add that I haven't had any issues with the keyboard and the ports are spaced conveniently around the case. Nothing gets blocked by using a mouse, printer, ethernet, or output display. Hinges are nice, feel solid.

If you happen to make it through this giant rant/review, consider yourself warned against purchasing HP notebooks.

We received Adaptec 31605 RAID controllers in two SuperMicro servers, ordered in early Dec 2007.  Our primary server had 10 1TB Seagate hard drives - new drives with 32mb caches (1.2 msec. read seek time, 1.0 write seek time - NICE).  After about a month of testing we deployed the server in production.  A week later we discovered CATASTROPHIC data loss on the controller's RAID6 array.  With our server vendor's assistance, we isolated the problem to the controller's lack of support for hard drives with 32mb cache.    We tried to work with Adaptec to resolve the problem with a BIOS firmware update, but their front-line support was very rude and condescending.  They refused to acknowledge the problem, even though our server vendor told us that they'd gotten a CONFIRMATION from Adaptec that the problem was known and that a firmware update was pending that would resolve the problem.  AND Adaptec charged us $75 just for the front-line support call!    We switched to an LSI Logic 84016E RAID controller, and so far we're much happier.  The documentation is more detailed & easier to read, their customer support has been more friendly & MUCH more helpful, AND on top of all that the card's less expensive.  We haven't deployed this card into production yet, but I have high hopes that it'll perform more reliably!    Bottom line:  the Adaptec 31605 RAID controller card appeared to have very high performance, and the setup utility is easy to use.  But if you're using it with recently-manufactured hard drives (32mb cache), BE AWARE that this card may not be reliable!  It probably works fine when the RAID array's made of hard drives with 16mb caches (i.e, old drives), but we've lost too much time recovering from our data loss to care.

This is the third generation wireless trackball from Logitech that I've used. I've been using trackball pointers for over a decade. I love the cordless optical trackman (2nd generation to me). When I first bought my first trackball, I wanted to return it...it took over 3 days to get use to it and love it. I waited over 2 weeks of use of the M570 trackball before writing this review. I don't like it for 1 major reason that is very frustrating. I didn't think much of it at first, but moving the trackball from using the index and middle finger to using the thumb is a very bad idea. The reason is that with 2 fingers, the user has precise control and stability: with the thumb, the user only has control. If the user of the M570 uses this trackball for precise pointer control such as CAD work, solidworks, schematic capture, or photo editing I highly doubt anyone would like this product. When I use my thumb to move the pointer in combination to using left mouse click, the pointer moves 1 or 2 pixels. It's very frustrating when the user needs precise pointer movement. Many times I want to left click (index finger) and use my thumb to click and drag and I often off by 1 so my connection is off...never had a problem with my optical trackman.

The positive points about the M570 is use of the new tiny usb receiver. Just like my other logitech products it connects and seamlessly works.

So any gamer, CAD, or photo editing, I suggest waiting or using the optical trackman. For casual web browsing and such it will suffice. For reference, I keep the M570 at work and the optical trackman still at home. I am still forcing myself to muscle train my thumb...but really the ability to use fingers 2 to 3 of them to control a pointer is far better than 1 thumb.

It also beeps annoyingly loud every time you turn it on or bring it back from standby that I can't turn off or down.  Performance is terrible mainly due to the cheap and slow hard drive it comes with.  I had to replace it with a solid state drive for it to be fast enough to be useful.  Only main attraction on this is the tablet screen, but there is some kind of problem with Lenovo's driver; I cannot get pressure sensitive pen to work on any of my graphics apps even after searching various forums to find many others with same problems.  It appears Lenovo's just not up to updating their own drivers with fixes.  Build quality is flimsy overall; it's nothing like what you see on these photoshoped pictures you see on the web.

The old IBM legacy of top end notebook computers is over now that Lenovo has taken the product line. This machine is not up to IBM standards, and do not expect IBM quality.
It is quiet, and has a nice display. However, the most used input device on a notebook PC is the mouse, which in this case is a touch pad. This is the worst touch pad I have ever used! You will try all the settings and never get it to work correctly. Just try doing a right click on the background to set display resolution and the background picture. On my Sony Windows 7 notebook this is trivial. On the Lenovo touchpad it is nearly impossible- this thing will not recognize right click! Try to create a short cut on the desk top to your favorite programs- sorry- not possible on this machine!
This touch pad does not have true buttons. Instead, it relies on pressing a certain area of the touch pad. I still can not locate where that area is, so good luck with your experiments in trying to get this to work. It will go back in the box and I will now consider other brands of PC, such as Toshiba. Lenovo has now killed what used to be the BEST notebook brand in the world.
I did note that battery life seems to be OK, and the weight is acceptable. My machine came with a 256 GB solid state hard drive, and this is a nice touch for faster system operation. It should also help the battery last longer, as spinning a hard drive takes a fair amount of energy.
The ultimate solution to making this machine useable is to forget about the touch pad interface, and purchase a nice USB / wireless mouse or external touch pad. Now you can use this machine and make some serious progress on all your computer work. It just means when you travel with this PC you must carry along another piece of hardware- a working mouse.

DroboShare connects to one or two Drobo drives via USB, shares the power supply of one of them, and serves the drives using SMB over Ethernet. Like the Drobo drives, DroboShare requires no setup.    SMB might be a suitable protocol for a Windows environment, but it is a very questionable choice of protocol for a Mac. DroboShare advertising states that you can switch a drive at any time to USB/Firewire and back to DroboShare. Physically that is true; however, when you create files over SMB, the Mac's data and resource forks are placed in separate files, but when you create files over USB, there is only one file. If you create a file over SMB the archive bit will be set -- once you see the file over USB, you will find that it has turned into a Unix executable file, i.e., double-clicking the file in the Mac finder might have unexpected results...    Bottom line: if you don't move your drive around (e.g., for faster transfer) and if you just store simple files (e.g., music or pictures) the DroboShare might be ok for a Mac; if you plan to put your home directory on a network drive the DroboShare might not be what you really want.

Folks,    I have tried two of this model card and found the analog performance was consistently poor on both. The bottom line is that there is a low level whine on the mic and line inputs. Running with very high gain helps to alleviate this condition, but it never fully goes away. If you are using the card only to play music from files or CD/DVD then you will probably be happy with the purchase. If you are looking to reproduce and record audio from the analog inputs then you will be disappointed.    There are very few low profile cards out there. There are two that I know of. One is the Soundwave 5.1 from SIIG, and the other is the Soundblaster Audigy SE SB0570 from Creative. Either of these is vastly superior for analog reproduction and are very low noise. I have tried both of these cards in the same system as the Startech card and there was no whine or noise noted.

Let me start of by saying that I have been a IT professional for 14 years and deal with networking on a daily basis.  This Access point is by far the worst networking product I have ever had the displeasure of using.  I purchased it for a client because it was the only Access Point I could find locally.  When I went to set it up it requires that you use the included CD.  There is no default IP address to configure it manually.  I popped the CD in and started the configuration process, between each step is a long wait while it churns away.  After I was done with the setup I tried to connect and verify it worked.  It would not pass DHCP packets no matter what I did, I was eventually able to set an IP address and do some manual configuration and still no IP address on the wireless. I could switch to my other wireless access point with no problems at all.  I finally downloaded the latest firmware and installed it,  Finally I was able to get an IP address and access the internet.  Confident that the firmware update had fixed the problem I box it back up and send it to my client.  The next day the client goes to install it on the network (ie... plug it in) No IP address, No response to Pings from the wired side and now No SSID broadcast.  Despite resetting the device 3 or 4 times and verifying that everything was installed correctly it still refuses to work.  It is going back to the store and in the future I will NEVER AGAIN buy anything with the name Linksys on it!

I was very enthusiastic about this heat sink after I have read many good reviews on Amazon. However, it failed after five months.  The computer started giving warning signals at start-up that the fan speed was too low. I also heard a low pitch humming noise going up and down. Because I could not afford to send the fan for repair and wait weeks until I get another one, I opened it and fixed it myself. Apparently they used some crappy grease for the shaft of the fan and because of that there was lots of friction and the fan rotated very slowly. I cleaned it properly with Isopropyl alcohol and used some quality white grease used in RC models. Now it works like new without any noise and I do not get the warning message at start-up. So, finally the problem was fixed because I knew what to do but what if it was a non-technical person? I do not recommend this product because it is not reliable.

Amazon has the power to delete books from your Kindle--books you paid money for and that you thought you owned. On July 17, 2009, Amazon used this power to delete unauthorized copies of George Orwell's \\"Animal Farm\\" and \\"1984.\\"    There is an excellent article in Slate magazine today by Farhad Manjoo about how this technology could be used for censorship. If Amazon can delete a book it believes to be infringing copyright law, then the government can order Amazon to delete a book for other reasons.    Don't give the government this kind of control over your bookshelf. Don't order the Kindle or any other device that allows a bookseller or a technology company to control what's on your digital bookshelf.

I bought my Kindle Touch at a local OfficeMax store earlier this week. I've been using it a lot in the last few days and overall I'm not happy with this model at all. Biggest problem for me is, the \\"whispersync\\" technology is very buggy, it does not sync the last read position at all across my Kindle Touch and the Kindle app on my Windows Phone or my PC. It also had some trouble downloading the Kindle books in my Kindle library at first but I probably solved that by restarting, deregistering, and then re-registering! What's also annoying is, I borrowed a Kindle book from the Kindle Owners' Lending Library (KOLL) and when I returned it, it stays on the Home screen with the word \\"Returned.\\" Just unsightly! My second problem is the screen really flashes too much, to the point of being distracting as well as equally annoying. I turned on the option to refresh less between pages of a book but it still flashes more frequently than I'd have liked, and it flashes each time elsewhere in the interface. Speaking of the UI, the touch is not very responsive, and there's little feedback after you press a button or book title, so I'm never sure if I pressed the screen hard enough. Many a time I end up pressing the same spot twice or more which ends up doing unexpected things after the first press/tap actually registered. Finally, the screen is really too small to be comfortable. I have excellent vision but this strains my eyes, and the text font options are too few. One last thing, the \\"email-to address\\" feature is buggy, as it shows an address that is NOT mine! I purchased the OCZ SSD upgade kit (from Amazon) as well as an ocz ssd (from a local retailer) and a windows 8 pro upgrade (from Amazon) thinking that the acronus true image 2012 software in the upgrade kit would make upgrading to windows 8 and a solid state drive a snap.  The hardware in the upgrade kit was satisfactory, the software was not.  In over 25 years of working with computer hardware and software, rarely have I seen so many problems in a single software package.  First I tried to clone my primary system disk with windows 7 to the new solid state drive, then upgraded to windows 8 which appeared successful, until the next morning when the system wouldn't boot.  A review of the acronis knowledge base online revealed that this is a commonly documented and discussed, but unresolved, problem with the cloning feature of the Acronis software dating as far back as 2009.  Review of the Acronis website pushed for an upgrade to the True Image 2013 version with additional features available.  This was offered online for 29 dollars, i found an online coupon and purchased the upgrade for $19.00.  I then attempted to clone the drive again, without success.  I then made a backup of my original hard drive and tried to do a system restore to the SSD.  The result is that the restore files successfully copied to the ssd but the system and system image files did not leaving the drive not bootable.  The bootmgr files were not copied, for which a knowledge base search reveals that this too is a long time shortcoming of the Acronis software. I am presently on my 7th or 8th effort to remedy the problem without success.  What makes my frustration level even higher, is that upon going to the Acronis website for support I was prompted to make an account and register my product and upgrade.  At account registration I was emailed an assigned password, which I used to access my account and then changed my password to something that fits in my password system.  Now when I attempt to logonto the Acronis site it does not accept the new password or the old password, and when I request a new one through the password recovery system it fails to respond to me. I'm generally an easy to please sort of guy, but honestly,I've nothing good to say about the Acronis Software Brand as it appears to me that the company is knowingly selling a defective product, then baiting the consumer to upgrade to a product that also doesn't work all while making it exremely difficult to contact the company for assistance.  In some jurisdictions that is a crime.

Unfortunately, my mom forgot if she had dropped or spilt something on them, but when I got there, there was no visual evidence of anything having happend to them. I am miffed as to why these stopped working, but they were good while they lasted.

First of all like other's experienced the 2.5\\" enclosure will not house the Vertex 4 256GB - The case is literally too small for this SSD. As a matter of fact the circuit board came out and was attached to the Vertex 4 256GB Drive, when I stopped trying to insert the drive into the case. Since the circuit board was attached to the Vertex when I removed it from the case, I made sure it was seated properly and cloned the HD to it using the Acronis software. Note: I did not encounter any specific instructions as to what steps to take in cloning the SSD using the software. The data showed on the Vertex 4, but when I installed it into my system the system in place of my existing HD it started to boot up and then stopped. It appears that the clone wasn't installed properly. So, I emailed OCZ and they said I should use a dual powered USB enclosure for the transfer - the one in the kit doesn't have enough power to provide a proper transfer. Another note is the SATA III cable they provide in the kit IS WAY TOO SHORT FOR MY DESKTOP - definitely another piece of useless junk.

I'm now at the following stage of this worthless SSD upgrade to my system, I reinstalled the original HD and then installed the Vertex 4 in a second Hard Drive bay in my computer. My system boots up with no problem using the original HD, The Vertex is sitting in the second HD bay waiting for me to install a SATA III cable that would fit from the SSD to the slot in my mother board. When this occurs, I guess I'll try another transfer to the SSD to see if that works (OCZ thinks it stands a good chance). I'll update this if I get it to function properly.

The kit is a total waste, of time and money - The housing won't provide enough clearance for the Vertex 4 SSD and you should be using one with dual power especially for larger size SSD's (according to OCZ), the cable provided is far to small for use in a desk top and finally the software is not user friendly IMHO.

I spent several days copying data that was on many USB drives and then backed up all my computers to the Buffalo LinkStation Quad 6TB NAS. I knew from the reviews that it would be slow, so that was OK.  After getting all the data on it I started to play with the software.  I though the software was very complete and worked great.  After I was able to get the e-mail notifications to work, I kept getting messages that there were HDD errors on unknown disk and data was lost.  Immediate replacement of the disk was recommended.  I forwarded one of these messages to their tech support and was told to back up all my data and re-setup the RAID array to see if the problem goes away.  If it doesn't they would replace the hardware.  As you can imagine, it took me several days to back up the data (the backup software always failed to do a backup to the USB drive attached).  The speed of this drive became a huge factor when I had to do all the copying.  I decided to just return the drive as I didn't want to go through this whole process again.

They tried to do everything on the cheap end. The first hard drive was DOA, took over a week to get a replacement. I bought a second hard drive to use while waiting for the other. They use some cheap off brand power supply. It killed the replacement hard drive, and the second replacement hard drive after that. They go for the maximum profit and try to short you on the quality.

I bought this keyboard to replace my old MS Natural which was 7 years old. I loved that keyboard. The keys had just the right feel, and the quality was excellent.  Understanding that it would be impossible to buy another keyboard built with that quality, I went searching.  I decided on the Microsoft Natural Elite because of the reviews I read here.    Updated Review 8/22/2010.  Since I have now owned the Microsoft Natural Keyboard Elite for 5 months, I think I have a better understanding of why some of the reviews for this product were negative.  Since my purchase on March 31, I have started coding Java, and doing a lot more writing.    The spacebar has always been a problem. It sticks badly if it is hit on or near the edges.  I am also having trouble with the shift keys. Like the spacebar, it sticks badly if you don't hit it just right. This applies to both the shift keys, so it's not a defect per-se, it's a design flaw.    I have had enough of this keyboard. I am going to look for a different one at a local retailer where I can try the keyboard before I buy it. Right now, I'm thinking a Logitech. Anything but another Microsoft product!    After 5 months, I rate this keyboard unacceptable, unless you don't use it much, or have a very heavy hand. Definitely not the keyboard for writers or coders.

We have a WRT150N.    We had no problems with it, but I decided to \\"upgrade.\\"    Installation was a bit of a problem, and I called Linksys.    That was our second mistake.  The tech support people told us that we would not have problems if we'd purchased directly from them.  \\"Our firmware is better than Amazon's firmware.\\"  They guaranteed next day delivery and 12 months of tech support and warranty.    Cisco (Linksys's owner) has truly disappointed me.    They did offer to let me send them the device I'd bought from Amazon.  Then, I'd have to wait \\"a few business days\\" for them to send me a \\"better unit.\\"  I offered to let them charge my credit card as much as they wished, so that I'd have something to use until the replacement arrived.  (Then, I would return the unit and let them credit me back when they had the replacement device in hand.)  They refused.    This is just unacceptable.  Buy any other router from any other company.  This has cost me three days of my time, and it's not worth it to me.      OKAY!  This is an edit I'm making on April 24th at nearly 10 PM Eastern.    I cannot believe that I'm going to say this, but I've spent more than 15 hours with their technical support, and they only get worse with each call.  We now get 2 MBPs of signal when we are 70 feet away.    What does Linksys say about this?  \\"Well, do not worry about this.  Wait 48 hours and the software modifications will improve the signal.  We have gone in there and modified the software some more, and it will be a very good signal in two days.\\"    ARE THEY INSANE?    Has Cisco/Linksys come up with some heuristic program that will learn how to bounce signals off my walls?    I am even more frustrated because my son, who builds systems and software for a living, had gotten the broadcast up to 20 MBPs before I called Linksys.  They told me that he was incorrect in using the Range Expander (which they'd told me to buy), and that everything will be fine when the software has a chance to do its magic.    Now, I will come back with a huge apology if this thing somehow generates a better signal in 48 hours.  But I'll bet you a ticket to Bangalore that it ain't getting any better.    These guys must get paid by the minute.........  ==================================================================================================================  I waited 48 hours.  There was no \\"magical fix.\\"    This time, I chose CHAT for tech support.  The CSR laughed about the experiences I've had and told me that the WRE54g was not compatible to extend the range of this device.  He told me to go buy a WAP54g.    Are they serious? I purchased a D-LINK G520 card for my PC running Windows XP Pro on an AMD processor. I am using is in conjunction with a D-LINK DI-624 wireless access point. I have downloaded and installed the latest drivers from the D-LINK website. I followed the installation instructions to the letter. The connection works fine, for anywhere from five minutes to an hour.
After that, my computer freezes completely, every time. If I remove the D-LINK card and enable and plug in my regular LAN card, I have no problems. This is the only time XP has ever frozen for me, after over one year of use.
I am in the process of testing the card under Linux, but as far as I know the only available drivers are in pre-production form.
I am not certain what makes my PC different from that of the other reviewers, but if you search through you will note that several other reviewers have had the same problem. If the issue is solved, I will write another review explaining the fix. Until then, I recommend that you do not purchase this Wireless card.

Status update in July, 2015:  After 8 months, I am having start up errors due to disk errors!  I went to their support site and searched support for, well, support.  I went to their software downloads page for firmware or diagnostic downloads...  The page had categories listed with "filler text" of nonsense words!  There were no links to ANY drivers, firmware updates, diagnostic tools, etc...  NONE!  Do yourself a favor and avoid this unit, if not for today's computing needs but for your needs 8 months later.  My original review is below, written in December of 2014.     - Haven't had it long enough to complain about a short life BUT I can say that I was disappointed upon opening the package...  I have bought two 40GB SSDs before at much lower-per-gig prices than this and BOTH of them had adapter trays (so that it could be installed in a 3.5" bay).  Also, both of them came with screws and connector cables for power (4-pin to SATAs) and data!!!  Case sounds and looks like it is plastic, I didn't dare do anything to confirm or deny that but (as with my other two being in aluminum shells) I do believe that heat dissipation is a concern.  Can't say that Patriot seems to be concerned about heat as there is no real mass to the casing even if it were metal.  So, if you're installing it in a desktop, expect to spend another $10-$20 for a tray, screws and connectors (depending on where you get it).  If you're putting it in a laptop, you wouldn't be buying such a small drive anyway...  More like a 240GB or 120GB Patriot Blaze would be like it.  The only reason I am keeping it is that I needed more space on my OS drive as I've installed some programs that require residency on the OS drive (I now run 4 drives, three SSDs and one "analog" as I call it).

After an agonizing and awful year of adjusting and tweaking I’m sad to say I’m switching back to NVidia. NVidia may have flaws, but from my experience the cards work reliably and as advertised. AMD failed to perform. Right out of the box the card worked amazingly, but less than a month later I started having multiple issues. My computer would BSOD while playing half of my games. I know the card is designed to run hot but I suspected that this might be part of the problem. Opening up the driver control panel I increased max fan speed to 100%, dropped the max temperature by 10 degrees, and underclocked the GPU by 10%; I paid a ridiculous amount to over, not underclock my card. This completely eliminated the rage-fueling-random BSOD problem; unfortunately a new problem quickly popped-up. Without even running a game or stressing the GPU the driver would crash constantly. This crash would result with the screen turning black and staying so for roughly five minutes (usually enough time for me to force a shutdown out of frustration) until eventually the poorly written driver had time to restart. I’ve spent hours researching the problems I have experienced and nothing seems to make this card even slightly more reliable or consistent. I’ve had great experiences with both companies in the past but for now I’ll be running a 780 while waiting for AMD’s next big move.

Right out of the box, this laptop is beautiful. Great screen, audio quality, and most of all, amazing keyboards. However, I am very disgusted at Samsung's build quality of this laptop. I have had to return this product for a new one two times.

First, I had display driver fault; frequent blue screen of death, shutting down on its own, SW update software did not help, it is really not user friendly in terms of updating the drivers.

Second, the mouse cursor kept on disappearing and two oscillating orbs appeared on top corners of the screen. I wasn't even touching the screen, but it registered as using the secondary click option and displayed square.

Third, I am currently on my third ATIV 2014 edition not being able to use my touchpad. On my second ATIV 2014, I could at least bring back the mouse cursor, but on this one it is completely gone. Restarting the computer did not help.

Again, I thoroughly enjoyed Samsung laptop experiences until recently these unbelievable things happened. I am very tired of returning this laptop, restoring it to factory settings, and setting it back up as I had to do this countlessly. I don't know if I should try one more time to return and get another version of this laptop or get samsung ATIV book 9 plus or switch to Macbook altogether.

If it works well (i.e. Windows XP pro), then get rid of it _______________ Edited Update:  Returned HP Envy; I give credit to HP for the smooth return process & timely refund.  As an example of just how slow this machine was-->  I have a Dell VOSTRO Desktop (8years old) with Pentium 4 and 4 GB RAM running Windows 7 Home Premium and when I did the Malwarebytes "threat scan", about 320K files, on each computer...the Envy and the Dell Desktop running Pentium (8 years old); the Dell took 3min 30 seconds to complete the Malwarebyte scan, while the HP ENVY took 29:54 minutes; both scanned approximately 320K files.  I either got a lemon or HP has an issue with configuration.  Just one example of many.

I purchased this hub from Target last month in an attempt to stop my small children from removing devices plugged into the tower.  What a waste of money ($30), and it's totally useless!  Here are the issues we experienced:    1. The power cable connection isn't tight enough, and it repeatedly falls out.  3.  There are no LED's to show you that your devices are successfully connected.  4.  Half the ports didn't work out of the box!  5.  The other ports are crooked, or you have to pull the device out half-way and wiggle it until you get some kind of connectivity.  6.  Forget plugging even two things into this hub at once.  Since the connections wiggle, one device is disconnected in the attempt to connect another.    RESULT:  I'm tossing this product into the trash.  Belkin won't get any more money from me until they step up quality control.

Yes, there are a lot of good reviews on Kindles DX. If you want to know some bad things, please read here.

ESPECIALLY, if you expect to read a lot from PDFs (For example, you are students or IT guys who have a lot of papers/books in PDFs)

- It cannot make notes or highlights on PDF. DX can only make notes
and highlights on Amazon's format.
- It cannot use the 5-ways-navigator button in PDF. Then it is not easy to use dictionary in PDF.
- !!! Ironic, the format that can do all above must be Amazon's format BUT most of the books in Amazon's format has very bad comments about it layout , incorrect display and etc. Then you cannot have good well-formated document to be able to do important features (notes/highlights) in DX
- (minor) It cannot use 'go to next chapter' in PDF
- (minor) It cannot click link in PDF
- (minor) It cannot \\"text-to-speech\\" for PDF.
- All above comments leads to the conclusion that, Kindle DX is for free-time reader (such as novels) not serious readers.

It should have written clearly in the comparison table between Kindle Wi-Fi, Kindle 3G, and Kindle DX that DX cannot hightlights on PDF but Kindle 3G can do that !!! surprised?!! DX more expensive (ok i know it bigger) but cannot do as the cheaper models !!

Other bad things, you should be aware:

- No WiFi, you have to aware to be charged for fee if you use DX's wireless (3G).

All of these missing functionalities, you can find it in Chinese e-readers (I never have one but I found some blogs talking about that)

- Oh, one more thing, I never see any reviews mention about this. Although e-ink looks exactly the same as paper, it has 'too good' surface. What does it mean? it means the screen is a bit shinny (yea, it is 'Pearl', then it is shinny, isn't it?), then sometime it reflex more light than paper to your eyes. For me, sometime I feel pain in my eyes. I recommend you to try your friend'sKindle before buy one.

I originally purchased this unit because of its Print Server capabilities.  The 1st one I bought, must have been returned by someone because the password was not what the default should have been.  The reset button on the unit would not reset the factory settings as documented either.  I called Tech Support and was on hold for ONE AND A HALF HOURS!!! Finally, the tech showed me how to reset the password (holding the reset button in, while unplugging the unit, waiting 20 seconds, plugging it back in, ALL THE WHILE holding the reset button in with a pencil, then releasing it).  After that ordeal, I was able to get the PrintServer portion working, but it would not connect to my ISP (Bellsouth FastAccess).  After several attempts, I finally exchanged that unit for an identical one, which did connect to my ISP on the 1st try.  THIS time though, the PrintServer portion would only work 1 out of 5 times and that was after rebooting the unit and my PCs!!!  I re-installed the D-Link DI-704 model which doesn't have the PrintServer and this one works like a charm (I've had it for a year now).  It also has an on/off switch which is handy for when you need to restart it, you don't have to unplug anything, just flick the switch.  As for the printing, it is MUCH more reliable to just hook the printer straight into your server which is always running, and share it.  From the client machine, just select network printer and point to the server and it works 100% of the time.  But the D-Link 704P was just not reliable enough for me.

I would STRONGLY recommend not buying this unit (or any other Netgear product). In late July, my Netgear Range Extender became very hot to the touch, creating a fire hazard. After posting this note of caution here on Amazon, a Netgear customer support rep named Mary Ann left me voice mail giving me a case number and asking me to return it for a replacement. I hadn't had a chance to call them until now but have spent the morning trying to get this resolved. The first indication I had that this is a very poorly run company (Patrick Cs Lo - take note. Your Board may be interested in how you're running this company) was that the Support number Mary Ann left is completely wrong and bogus. The company it actually reaches says that they get Netgear calls all the time. So, back to the drawing boards. I finally found a tech support number and, after an agonizing discussion with someone from India, I was told that my unit is no longer under warranty and so they can't do anything for me, despite me having a voicemail stating that "they didn't want a defective unit in the field and wanted me to call in for a replacement." So, I give up. It's not that much money and so I'll be buying a new unit and, forever, staying away from all Netgear products. I would use extreme caution if you're considering anything they make.

If you follow the manual carefully the accounts and finger prints are fairy easy to setup but this where the true problems start to show.    Now here is where it really SUX... the software crashed, i.e. failed to save the password and freezes, 2 of 10 times.  Yes, that is 20% failure. And each time the computer (XP SP2) must be rebooted for the software to work again despite the documentation citing only needing to logout and logging back in.  MAJOR FAILURE.      It's Dec 2008 and still no Firefox support?  Hello APC, Firefox is *open source*! We love the Freetime feature! Coming from an IPad, it took sometime getting used to the Kindle swiping and not having a home button to go to. Since this is more of a parent controlled tablet, there is initial set-up to be done. I love that the apps they can see is geared towards their age. My kids were so excited to get a couple of app choices without having to \\"pay\\" for them. I've set up two profiles for my daughter (3) and son (6), they have since ignored the ipad and fought over the kindle.    Pros:  - Different profiles for everyone.  - ability to control apps that the kids can see. We can really download any app from the Kindle store and decide if we want our kids to have access.  - The limited time feature. I've set it to first read 30 minutes of books before playing any games or videos. I've noticed that my son is loving books more and is very excited to read new books every night.  - 2 year warranty    Cons:  - Coming from Ipad it does take a little getting used to but my son loves the swiping of books and apps. He said it's easier to find vs the ipad.  - It took me a while to figure out how to make the home screen appear but tapping in the middle of the screen did the trick (while reading books, have not tested videos and apps)    Switching profiles is easy, just press the power button, tap the profile icon and it should let you select the available profile.    My daughter has been begging me to buy her one too but she has to make do with our old Ipad, I'm not spending anymore $$$.    *** Update 11/4/2014    Okay we have the tablet for more than 2 weeks now, everything has been going well until we run out of storage. It was frustrating to us as we have a lot of apps to install. Not only that, there are times that I would approve an app and it would not finish downloading at all in the child's profile. It will forever have that orange/yellow status. It works fine on my profile but not on my child's profile! I added a new profile for 2nd child and whatever app I try to approve it just doesn't come up in her profile.    I wanted to love this, I do but the 4 gb usable storage is just not cutting it for us plus there are still a lot of bugs to be fixed for this tablet. I am downgrading this to 2 stars. I instead bought a refurbished kindle fire 3rd gen with 32g, will install freetime and buy a kid proof case. That should do it for the space issue.

Seemed like a nice concept, but upon receiving it I found it's a terrible execution. Trays are cheaply designed with a support you have to remove to install the drive. Once that support comes out, the tray is flimsy and difficult to work with until the drive is secured in it. On well-designed trays, the support doesn't need to come out; it just stays out of the way.

I was concerned it would ventilate effectively. There is a fan, however there's 2 small holes in the backplane to allow airflow; the fan grossly dwarfs these vent holes. I don't see how it would cool the drives at all and I didn't get to find out...

...and here's why: I installed the cage in my media server, hooked power up to it and mounted 3 drives in their trays. I slid the trays in and powered up. I heard the SNAP. My case fans twitched. Then nothing happened. The machine wouldn't even power up. Trouble shooting revealed the three drives just over a year old were no longer working. They were fried by (my best guess) a voltage overage or a short in the cage.

I just shipped this back to the seller with an RMA. I'm thankful for that. However, what about the $300 in drives I'm out? I contact Icy Dock who put it as nicely as they could: sounds like your problem. They maintain they stand by their product, however they won't go as far as to replace the drives. That makes me a little angry. I can only urge you stay away from these guys and everything they sell. I bought a product in good faith it would work, but it caused damage to my property and I'm left paying for it.

If you want a great analogy as to what can happen to you with this device, watch Tommy Boy. You know, where he explains what happens if his client buys inferior brakes: a fiery car crash with kid screaming and the manufacturer of those brakes just shrugs.

Anyway, I'm off looking for a different product and 3 new hard disks. Hope Icy Dock goes under and they find work at an iPhone sweatshop.at an iPhone sweatshop.

The first enclosure that I received was dead-on-arrival. Kudos to Lexivon for promptly sending a replacement at no extra charge.

Functionality: About 1.5 times as fast as my USB 2.0 enclosure. Received error message on a freshly reformatted Windows 7 computer with all updates. Works even with error message (\\"hardware has malfunctioned, etc.\\"). No power cable included even though there is a port for it on the enclosure. Doesn't worry me though as USB 3.0 provides plenty of power. Screwing mechanism for the enclosure is cheap. 2 out of 4 holes in the internal chip of the enclosure do not align with those of the hard drive (even though all four holes aligned perfectly on the defective enclosure). Additionally, screwing the chip portion of the enclosure to the case portion requires some dexterity since the holes for the screws are not whole circles. Rather they are part of a circle, so you have to carefully align the final screws to the holes without seeing them.

Aesthetics: Looks better in the stock picture. Not a fan of the glossy highlights. Fingerprints do show on casing. Included male-to-male USB 3.0 cable is combined with a useless USB 2.0 end (sort of like a Y-shaped cable).

It came quickly and in decent shape, but it's too big for my RT. I haven't contacted the seller yet as I may get a pro soon and this might fit it. I'll have to take it check first.

Overall - o.k. case, it's not stiff at all, but provides some padding if you were to drop a book or something on top of the tablet. Would prefer it to be less \\"floppy\\" and of course, fit.

Pros  Great looks and one of a kind packaging.  Feels good in the hand and similar to the fantastic Death Adder.  That being said, 2 additional buttons are pretty easy to assign a macro to and were big selling point for me.  I wanted a mouse with more buttons than the Death Adder (which I love) and the Razer Mamba was a dream come true before I received it.  When working properly, there is no noticeable lag in the wireless part of it.  Overall build quality is top notch.  This mouse does not feel flimsy at all and the materials are of good quality.  Probably the most impressive build quality I have come across in a mouse.        Cons  Battery issue is true and annoying.  Had full charge did not get much use before the battery was showing that it was dying.  The mouse is pretty heavy in my opinion and made my hand tired the first night.  I have rather big hands and I was surprised with the heft of this mouse.    The first night with the mouse began with trouble right off the bat.  My software kept crashing when I tried to open it.  I, uninstalled, re-downloaded, and then I was able to open it in wireless mode only.  The software was glitchy and synapse memory saving painfully slow.  It seemed as if everything needed to write to the synapse memory even if just closing a menu with no changes.  However, in the middle of gaming, my Mamba software crashed and was nice enough to put me to the desktop to tell me.  At this point, I decided to try the wired mode after a reboot and could not open the software as it would say that it could not detect the mouse, but the mouse saved much of the settings and in wired mode, felt okay to use.  Going wireless solved this problem of getting back into the software, but I was left me scratching my head.    One odd item is that I could not find an option in the software to use 5600 dpi and lower the mouse pointer speed.  Other mice put the windows slider in there to make it easy to adjust.  I personally like to use full DPI available andadjust the speed of the pointer to suit my taste.  I feel this enhances precision in games and the DPI is sort of what I am paying for.  This software uses DPI as the speed and I thought this was silly.  When my software crashed, the mouse would be extremely slow and a pain to use.           Second day, bad problems began.  I had charged the mouse overnight to make sure the battery was fully charged.  I could almost live with the software issues with the hope that they could be ironed out.  The real issues began when getting the freezing of the mouse reminiscent of my G7 years back.  My hope was that this mouse with its \\"advanced\\" channel scanning feature would be different that the G7 experience I had (note: G7 worked for months before the freezing.  I thought it was broken at the time and not environment related).  I, uninstalled, re-downloaded, and installed multiple times.  I tried nearly every USB port in the back of the computer and it would work for a second and freeze for 5 seconds.  I tried syncing it and everything I could think of.  There was nothing online to help to give me any direction.  Razer's site is not helpful and a bit too self promoting.  I uninstalled the Mamba and reinstalled the Death Adder and had no issues at all with that mouse.  My conclusion was that there were some defects with either the mouse or software or both.  The only thing I did not seem to have problem with was packing it up and sending it back to Amazon.      Summary  Overall, I had a bad experience with this mouse.  Will it happen to you? Who knows.   Since most reviews online I have read seem to be slam dunks (makes me question the source honestly), I think the odds could be in your favor.  I might just have issues with the 2.4ghz frequency where I live since the G7 gave me the same type of problem after 6 months.  One other thing noted often about other products is that Razer support is weak.  They responded to my detailed account of what happened, but the response was \\"try a different USB port on the mainboard directly\\".  I asked if others had the same problem and whether it could be fixed with update etc.  No responses to those questions only the try other USB ports, which I already did.  I did not have the patience to \\"hope\\" it would be fixed later on.    The packaging is nice and I had people from all around me at work marvel at it.  You really need to see this in person to appreciate it.  However, I would rather have simple clamshell packaging and save a few bucks in the process.      The mouse has great potential and I wanted to love it.  I rate it 2 stars for the apparent build quality and the packaging.  I am not trying to bash Razer. Just finished rebooting a third time and -at last!- I'm free of the program with which this deceptively harmless-looking Airlink dongle infected my machine. This review refers to AirLink 101 N 150 Ultra.

Let me backup, please. I am not a computer person accept by necessity. I hate working on them, but I spend a lot of time doing it, even with new PC machines, recent software and redundant antivirus programs. Every once in a while, some sneak slips under my guard and fouls the computer. I believe this airlink is such a sneak and if I am right, what it did on my machine, it will do to yours [or may have already].

Perhaps no one else has found this to be a problem? If it is a problem to others, please confirm this review so that others may know. Here's what happened:

Bought the Airlink 101 mini N dongle, put it in a free USB port and... XP \\"found new hardware,\\" but had no luck in its search for drivers on the web. So I loaded the CD that came with the dongle and used it to download drivers- innocently letting the \\"install\\" run. I am directed by the software to restart.

After the restart, I connect to web, OK so far, although suddenly the net seemed running much slower than before. On inspection, I see in my system tray a bold new icon. What's that? I click on it. \\"Intel Rapid Resource Technology\\" had been installed on my machine. What the..?

I have my computer connected to an older Alpha antenna that is not enabled for N protocal [these antennas are an excellent way to boost receptivity and speed of access, available through Amazon]. Foolishly I thought the N dongle would in some way act to augment reception from the Alpha. Instead, it took over from the Alpha, set up a \\"Network Connection\\" of its own- ok, I understand the need for that now, BUT- in establishing itself on my machine, this dongle also added this \\"Rapid Resource\\" software: this program had also ingratiated itself in my startup programs;it was hogging resource.

I decide to get rid it, there goes another 15$ wasted; but that's when the trouble started.

Many of the best programs come with \\"uninstall\\" as part of their set-up menus. Not this thing. Before going to \\"Add/Remove Programs,\\" just in case, I went to the net to google \\"how to remove Intel Raped Resource Technology.\\"

I downloaded the instructions on how to remove, the instructions being from Intel itself- a full 7 pages of them. Intel's instructions for its removal begin with this ominous warning: \\"...Removing the Rapid Resource Technology driver may require reinstallation of the operating system.\\"

Gulp.

I did a full backup before doing anything more. Then, I followed Intel's instructions for removal- and also performed an Uninstall from XP's Add/Remove software page- then I restarted and, still following Intel's instructions, I entered the machine's bios, not without trepidation.

Suffice to say, I did as directed to the bios; then, restarted again...

Lo! It's all there, my o/s, programs, data, configuration in tact, and this usurper is gone. Just in case, I ran a registry cleaner [which found several objects the uninstall had left behind], and then completed a full virus sweep.

As I say, please, I am obviously not a technology person. My moral in terms of a computer: \\"If it ain't broke...\\" Veer from that dictum at your peril. In this case, the N dongle cost me a little money and a lot of time.

You can save yourself both:
keep your start-up menu clean, your system tray uncluttered and your registry unsullied-plus, get faster internet speeds: take a look at the Alpha antenna. One model of the Alpha sets up N capability, so you get N speeds along with much enhanced receptivity, but be sure to buy the right Alpha for your situation- as I say, the antenna will, almost certainly, greatly enhance both your range and your speed [read the reviews posted on Amazon for the antenna]. [Disclosure: I am NOT associated with Alpha or any computer-ware; but I am elated when I find a computer gizmo that actually works, and works well]

The Alpha will install itself without taking over your computer's bios and without cluttering your system tray and, there is no time drag from the added start-up program when next you start your machine.

The Alpha is small, light and portable- though certainly much bigger than this mini dongle. This mini is small all right, but doesn't matter if it's invisible, I don't want it in charge of my computer.

As with all computer lessons, I learned the hard way to upgrade my antenna rather than install over it. The Alphalink Mini is in the trash.

EDIT:
I just read the review posted here June 17, 2012, by Thad.
Perhaps following Thad's advice [searching for drivers on the net rather than off the CD] will spare you from having your bios manipulated by the software on the CD. I have not changed my one star rating, since I can only review from my own experience and I doubt I am alone in considering it safe to access program and drivers from the Mini's accompanying CD.

UPDATE 02 April 15: NETGEAR BAIT AND SWITCH BEWARE SHAME ON YOU NETGEAR
This is directly from the web page at Amazon:
“Warranty Information: This product comes with a 1 year warranty”
BEWARE: THIS IS NOT TRUE
It actually comes with a 90 day warranty for software and 1 year warranty for hardware. The problem I had was everything seems to be a software issue and they won’t tell you even when you ask a very specific question as I did if this type of issues is hardware or software. Several times during our conversation I was asked to purchase their addition service plan for them to answer my questions and resolve my issues. Towards the end they did state that if the issue did turn out to be a hardware issue I could request a refund of the money I paid for the service. Again I told them I wasn’t interested because I already had an extra warranty with a third party vendor so if my issue wasn’t covered I would use them.
In fairness to Netgear, it seems they farm out their customer service to people who are reading from a book and do not have the expertise to verify from the script. A lot of companies now do this. From my view the main drive for the two CS people who were helping me was to upsell me to their extra cost service plan
Eventually I did resolve my issue. In my case I tried to reset unit per page 166 which is hold reset in for 7 seconds. I did this on three separate occasions and you do see the led’s change and it appears the unit resets but the unit did not work. After doing a lot of reading and discussing the issue with a knowable friend, I decided to hold the reset button in for 30 seconds. It shut down, rebooted and all is well and working now. Only Netgear can tell us if there is a difference between a 7 second and 30 second reset. I also have to be aware that maybe my 7 seconds and their 7 seconds are not the same. I did not use a timer. I am trying to be fair. I do want to thank Netgear for offering to help after I posted my complaint on line. I used Square Trade for my service warranty and I highly recommend you buy an extra service plan.
This is the best router I have ever used and highly recommend it with an extra warranty plan.
I can only hope at some point someone starts a class action suit due to the false advertising or Netgear starts honoring what the write on line. Good luck to all, jimrty vendor so if my issue wasn’t covered I would use them.

The Cisco RV110W router has a modest physical size and includes a VPN end point - pretty much the two major selling points in a nutshell. The RV110W also has native IPv6 support and can support up to 4 segmented virtual networks - handy for WiFi or larger rollouts. However, once you actually install this product the failures make themselves all too apparent:

1) 4 10/100BaseT Ethernet ports - NOT gigabit. If you have a multi-computer SoHo install you can't / shouldn't use this as your network backbone with anything resembling modern computers as this will be the bottleneck of an internal LAN system. A modern router with fast, rather than giga, ethernet is a no-no.

2) painfully slow administration front end. I haven't hit a router's configuration system this slow in YEARS. Odd when off the shelf consumer routers put the RV110W's web config page speed to shame.

3) *no x.x.x.255 broadcast address support*. This is a big one - it means that anything that uses broadcast addresses, such as WoL functionality, is blocked by Cisco's firmware. You can WoL a computer by port forwarding directly to the internal IP but it means you can't easily WoL multiple computers via a single broadcast port. Very bad. There is no way to bypass the x.x.x.255 broadcast block - reports that writing to the ARP table directly will only last for a while then get wiped automatically.

4) 2x2 802.11n. Again, sad that a number of consumer routers offer 3x3 performance.

The QoS system does perform reasonably well, so give a plus to that, I simply put HTTP& HTTPS manual priority entries into the tables and got good throughput response. I could wish, on a "SoHo" router, that WiFi WAN throughput could be set so that internal WiFi LAN speeds would not need to be throttled simply to restrict WiFI WAN usage, but maybe that is asking for a lot.

The VLAN features are very handy if you are looking for increase security or multi-partitioned LAN configurations, and the built-in VPN endpoint might work for you (I haven't tested it yet but, again, several consumer-level routers offer the service now as well). However, the RV110W's 10/100-only ports and broadcast blocking are a bit turn-off on a SoHo-oriented router, as they can limit overall functionality and accessibility to both remote users and internal LAN performance.

It has the "Cisco" name on it but I've gotten better overall packages of cost vs. features vs performance from other products. Not a "stay away', it does work as intended, but I feel (and have experienced) better.

The first thing I have to say, is I will NEVER buy ANYTHING from Iomega again.  I purchased this drive 2 months ago, saving it for when I bought a mac. I then erased them all on the pc, (the pc was dying, and I knew it would not restart) and plugged the drive into my mac.  No problem there either, (and yes, I know the filesystem type was correct).  I then went to get a cup of coffee, came back, and the drive was clicking.  ON THE VERY FIRST USE!!!  I didn't even have a chance to back it up.  Stay away from Iomega.  At least, if you want to keep your data.

Packing on this product was terrible. The card and adapter come in a plastic protective case but then the reader is jammed into a too-small plastic bag with the card and adapter. The reader chassis is not terribly strong and when jammed into the small plastic bag there is soo much tension that the force of a heavy box on top of the shipping envelop will easily crack the reader, as happened on the first one shipped to me. A slightly bigger plastic bag and a little more padding would fix this.

The second one arrived unbroken but neither one of the readers was able to consistently copy files without crapping out and throwing errors. I had decided to pay more for this package because I wanted the convenience of a compact USB reader but these readers are total trash (my Transcend reader works just fine with the cards).

We did that (after having loaded our own software and changing our preference) and it seemed to fix the problem.  We reloaded our software, changed our preferences again and put it away for a week.  We took it out and booted it up, and once again the 2 USB ports didn't work.  Again we called Acer support (who were very helpful).  After trying a number of fixes, we were told the only thing left to do was to do another \\"restore\\".  We were not happy campers.  Not knowing if this would continue to occur, we decided to return the unit to the vendor.         As to the features, I liked the keyboard size.  The screen, though reflective, was crisp and clear. The AmazonBasic stand is by far the superior product in all aspects and you can use it for the whole range of current tablet sizes.

I have been running ZyWall products for years and love them because they LAST for years. I agree with many of the other reviews here these are not your friendly \\"easy to set up\\" products - they carry the ISCA labs certification because they are rock solid and through that comes complexity of configuration. Still - you can find the information you need on the web or in their support docs.

This review is because of some unacceptable stability issues I have experienced on 2 pieces of hardware with this model and the latest firmware.

At random intervals the wireless network will just stop. It's there, you can see it, but it will fail to pass traffic. There is never anything in the logs, nothing in a capture, it's like it never stopped - except there's clearly no traffic. The hard wired network continues to function fine without issue.

Here's the licker - any change vi the UI to the wireless configuration - no matter how small results in the wireless network becoming available again. Change the channel - works. Change a DHCP time-out setting - it works. The change shows in the logs and immediately all the activity shows in the logs. It's nuts.

Given there's no artifact of the event there's nothing support can offer yet the event happens 1-2 times in a 24 hour period. Second piece of hardware does the exact same thing when configured the same.

Worst part about this is - it's a very basic configuration with the WLAN bridged to the LAN and a cable modem on the outside. Add insult to injury - a less than fifty dollar Medialink Wireless N Router works just fine 24/7.

Sorry ZyWall - you were my goto hardware for years... this experience has left me with a nearly 200 dollar paperweight.tting - it works. The change shows in the logs and immediately all the activity shows in the logs. It's nuts.

I bought this adapter from Other World Computing (OWC) to connect the eSATA on my RAID drive (a Drobo S) to my computer's USB 3.0 port.

When I received it, and connected it, the utility software that came with my RAID drive would no longer recognize the drive or run on it.

I contacted OWC support and told them about my hardware and the problem I encountered. In emails and on the phone for a few weeks they kept telling me that there was no problem with the adapter, but that it was a software problem.

Eventually, after doing some research online, I found out that RAID drives with eSATA (or any multiple drive enclosure with a single eSATA connector) uses a port multiplier, and that ONLY adapters that support Port Multiplier enclosures will work properly. I also learned that this NewerTech eSATA to USB 3.0 adapter DOES NOT support Port Multipliers.

When I contacted OWC support again to let them know this information I was told that they knew that this adapter does not support Port Multipliers.

I asked why they had been telling me it was a "software problem" instead of a problem with the adapter not being compatible with eSATA RAID drives, especially since when I ordered the adapter there was no mention of this important fact on the Web page. I was told that OWC felt it was "not important" enough information to include.

I recommended that they do include this information so that others with eSATA RAID drives do not order the adapter and then find out that it DOES NOT WORK PROPERLY with eSATA Port Multipliers.

Since then,the people at OWC have fortunately added this text to the bottom of the Web page: "This product does NOT support port multiplication."

I returned the adapter to OWC, and have found another adapter (DAT Optic U3eSATA) that DOES support eSATA Port Multipliers.

If I turn the sensitivity down, the pad does not work when I want it to without me mashing my finger onto the pad.

Stick with the buttons, Acer.

I bought a larger SSD drive for my Mac. The 256GB that came with it (the largest available apple would/will install) was getting a bit tight on the Mac side, so bought a larger one. The software said it would work with both Mac and PC, so I mistakingly assumed it would clone both the Mac and Windows partitions at some point.

The first thing I realized is that the \\"Mac\\" software is nothing but a text file telling you how to accomplish what you need using utilities built into your mac. Then of course I learned that even that won't work, and had to buy Carbon Copy Cloner to transfer the Mac OS to the new SSD.

So, now I was assuming that the software WOULD work with the windows side of this project. Nope, not in this situation. It will clone an entire drive, but not a partition ON a drive. Now it MIGHT have actually cloned the drive, created the partitions required, formatted them appropriately for the battling OS's, but at that point I was pretty skeptical that this was the case.

I ended up buying WinClone to transfer the BootCamp partition to the new drive.

So...if there was a zero star I might have checked that. BUT it does come with a very useful SATA/USB 3.0 cable that was most helpful. And I know apple would have sold me one of those for twice what Apricorn did so all things considered I'm not getting my money back.

IF this is the scenario you're working within, you might just look for a cable and plan to buy all the other cloning software.

Tech support says that they can most likely fix the speed problem over the phone by adjusting some router settings, but it will cost $79.00 to buy an extended warranty to find out. When I explained that I was not willing to spend one penny to solve an obvious setting defect that they are aware of and post negative feedback, I was told that my comments, nor buying a different brand, would hurt a big company like Netgear. This was the worst customer service imaginable. As a consumer, I don't like the strong arm tactics that I received today and I will never buy another product from Netgear. I gave this product one star because there is no zero. DO NOT BUY FROM NETGEAR! BUYER BEWARE!

Upon receiving the Kindle as a gift, I thought how wonderful!     I travel to third world countries or past third world countries for about four months a year. What a great idea to be able to carry a bunch of books in one little  device. No more carrying a books in my day-pack and carry-on. Maybe I could carry a few more shirts instead.  But,after spending a little time with the kindle, I realized I could not risk taking it with me. It seems cheap. The tabs seem flimsy. A litle thumb touch here or there and your forward a page or two or back a page or two. There are so many seams for dust and mist to foul it up that I'm afraid it wouldn't last two weeks.     In this day and age one would have thought that any company producing something like this would have thought of the beach, camping, travel etc. Something other than lying on the couch and reading.    A thirty inch drop test is silly to explain how tough it's suppose to be.    The side tab with the reflective pica isn't very easy to read at certain angles.    In all, the screen seems fine and the interface w/ kindle Store seems good.It just too bad the device wasn't constructed as a more solid unit w/o seams similar to the Ipod, with smaller tabs that need a little more pressure, and with a cleaner design.    And what's with the poorly made cover and terrible locking clip. Really!
